name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 8 October 2015 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which On behalf of the European Parliament, I strongly condemn the bombings in Ankara and express our deepest condolences to the families of the victims. Our thoughts are with the nearly 100 people who have been killed and more than 500 injured, whom we wish a speedy and complete recovery. In these difficult days, we stand by the victims and their families. This brutal terrorist attack on peaceful demonstrators was an attack on democracy. It is quite clear that these criminals want to stir up discord and spread fear in the run-up to the elections. The perpetrators must not win! At present, the EU and Turkey are in close contact to find a common solution to the refugee situation. The dramatic events and developments also, of course, influence the current debate on Turkey's status as a safe third country. In my recent talks with Turkish opposition politicians and with the Turkish President, I have also expressed our concern at the escalating violence and polarisation in Turkey over the last few months. That is why free and pluralistic media must be defended by the state as an indispensable pillar of democracy. I have also made a strong appeal for a return to a ceasefire and a political process with the Kurds. The European Parliament has made it clear more than once that reconciliation is the only way to lead Turkey into a secure and prosperous future. We trust that the democratic forces in Turkey will now stand together, break the spiral of violence and advocate peaceful coexistence in order to allow for a free and fair parliamentary election on 1 November.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! The European Citizens' Prize recognises the extraordinary commitment of citizens, groups and organisations in our Union to better mutual understanding and cooperation across borders. It also commends activities that give concrete expression to the values enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The winners are involved in very different areas, in intercultural dialogue, in the field of direct solidarity, in the field of integration or the maintenance of historical memory. Today at 5 p.m., the European Parliament is honouring this year's winners at a ceremony here in the House. All of you, ladies and gentlemen, are cordially invited to do so. A number of these prizewinners are here today, and I would like to warmly welcome you, ladies and gentlemen, to the Winners of the European Citizens' Prize, in the gallery in this Chamber! (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as laid down in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on 1 October in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested that a resolution be concluded with a resolution on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the impact of the ECJ ruling on the USA/Safe Harbour. This resolution will be put to the vote during the October III part-session.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the People's Parliamentary Group is calling for the debate we are going to have this afternoon on the judgment on the Safe Harbor Decision to give rise to a Parliament's resolution in the next plenary session.  We have found that the data of our citizens and our businesses are less secure than we assumed and believe that Parliament should urge the Commission to enter immediately as soon as possible.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Gonzalez Pons, I would like to thank Mr Gonzalez Pons for his work We already have a debate. There is a statement from the Council and the Commission. It is about the resolution. It is therefore only requested that a resolution should also be voted on at the next plenary session in Strasbourg.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I believe we agree that the decision of the European Court of Justice to annul the Save Harbour Agreement is a very important judgment. The Commission has acknowledged the inadequacy of Save Harbour because of the pressure exerted by the European Parliament, which the PPE-DE, including other political groups, has also opened up on the Commission in view of the fact that the data under the Save Harbour Agreement are not adequately protected. For this reason, however, it is also important that Parliament should remain on the ball and that we adopt a resolution together in order, firstly, to express our view and, secondly, to work with the Commission to find a quick way forward for us to achieve sensible cooperation and legal certainty in Europe in the future with regard to the flow of data towards America and vice versa.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I can confirm that the safe harbour verdict was an important judgment. I am also pleased to hear that the PPE-DE has always said this; I have also heard other statements in the meantime. As far as the resolution is concerned, this Parliament has had a clear position on Safe Harbour for years, namely to say that the data is not safe with this agreement. Nor do we need to confirm this position again. The ball is now clearly on the Commission's side. The Commission must now say how it is dealing with it, and it cannot be circumvented: continue to do so. It must now present a new proposal, and we can then respond to it.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I put the motion to the vote. (Parliament rejected the motion) The Group of the United European Left/Nordic Green Left requests that a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Turkey be put on the agenda entitled 'Mass killing of a significant number of innocent people during a peace rally'.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), on behalf of the group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it would be a great mistake for this House to see this as another suicide attack. The hundredth of the dead obliges us to see where this country is heading, after the blood of so many dead, but also with so many other dead in recent months between Turkish forces and the Kurds. The European Parliament must discuss this issue in depth, on an exceptional basis today. I am not taking the floor as someone who wants to wrong Turkey. On the contrary, we will all benefit from a timely and in-depth discussion of the issue. The discord that lies in the country can push it into chaos and we must oppose this course. Expressing solidarity with Turkish citizens and a minute's silence that we have not made should not be an alibi to avoid a comprehensive debate. Our aim must be to avoid, after the Arab winter, the possible Turkish winter. No one knows what that might mean.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I put the motion to the vote. (Parliament rejected the motion) (The order of business has therefore been adopted.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements in preparation for the European Council (15-16 October 2015) (2015/2768(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Council which will meet tomorrow and Friday will once again be marked by the refugee crisis. This crisis is a challenge for all of us and for the Union as a whole, and we must provide the common answers that are needed. No Member State can manage migration flows on its own. We have become aware of this, perhaps sometimes painfully, hence the need for true European solidarity fully assumed. I think that in the last few weeks, things have changed in a positive way. The European Council has been dealing with this issue since the beginning of the crisis. President Tusk told you about it last week. The European Council must decide not only on emergency measures, but must also develop policy guidelines on the whole of migration and asylum policy. Tomorrow, he will discuss three fundamental issues. Firstly: to cooperate with third countries to prevent migration flows. Secondly: to strengthen the protection of the Union's external borders. Thirdly: responding to refugee flows in Europe and ensuring a return policy. Let me go into these three areas: first, cooperation with third countries. Mr President, I would like above all to join, on behalf of the Presidency and the Council, in the words you made earlier. The murderous and criminal attack in Ankara shocked and shocked us all. We are of course with the Turkish people, we share their sadness and we express our sympathy, our solidarity and our deepest condolences. But beyond that, we also share what you have said about the importance of dialogue, about all the efforts that must be made to organize the elections, to give Turkish democracy the strength it absolutely needs in these difficult times.  I return to the part of cooperation with third countries, particularly with countries of origin and transit, which is a top priority for good management of migration flows. Until conditions in these countries improve, too many refugees will risk their lives to leave and nothing will stop them.  On 8 October, the high-level conference on the Eastern Mediterranean and Western Balkans route was held. It marks the beginning of a process that will allow us to strengthen cooperation with all our partners, for the benefit of all, for a more efficient management of migration flows. Solidarity with the Balkan countries seems to me to be of great importance in this regard. These countries also face challenges, including economic difficulties: we must help, support and support them. The Valletta summit with African countries, scheduled for mid-November, will need to forge a stronger partnership and lead to concrete measures. A few weeks ago, we had a discussion here in Brussels on development, on all facets of development and also about migration, particularly from Africa. We must realize that development and migration are often two sides of the same coin, the medal of underdevelopment and poverty. These two major meetings are tangible proof of the Union's determined willingness to engage in constructive dialogues with the countries most concerned. Strengthening relations with Turkey will also be on the agenda of the European Council, with a view to adopting the joint action plan that I believe we already discussed last week in Strasbourg. The second part is the strengthening of the protection of the Union's external borders. The treaty is very clear: we need to gradually put in place an integrated system for managing external borders. The European Council will work to provide concrete guidelines in this direction, for the Member States, which are responsible for protecting their national borders, but also for European agencies, in particular Frontex, whose tasks in this area should be reviewed and strengthened. Thirdly, the response to refugee flows in Europe and the return policy. It is our duty to help refugees, but among those who cross our borders illegally, we know that not all need international protection under the Geneva Convention. A coherent, credible and effective policy on the return of irregular third-country nationals, which fully respects the human rights and dignity of the persons concerned, and the principle of non-refoulement, is an essential part of a comprehensive European Union on migration. This starts with identification and registration. In this context, the first "hot spot" was set up in Italy. Of course, we must continue to do so. Much remains to be done, particularly with the active support of the Member States. Decisions taken at the Council on relocation are being implemented and must be implemented to the end. Another part of our migration and asylum policy will be discussed tomorrow: the external component. As many have said, the causes of these human tragedies that produce these migratory phenomena must be eradicated. We need to actively look at our role on the international stage and what is happening in Syria and Libya. These topics will also be on the agenda of the European Council. Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, the Presidency has ensured that the Council works tirelessly on the responses to one of the great crises we are going through. We have achieved significant and significant results in extremely short time frames, including in September the adoption of decisions, on the basis of the Commission's proposal, to relocate 160,000 refugees. More recently, on 8 October, the Council adopted conclusions on the future of the return policy, which provide an accurate overview of the work to be undertaken. The Council also had an in-depth discussion on the management of the Union's external borders; it has adopted financial measures to enable policy monitoring through rapid action on the ground. The interior ministers were also briefed on the latest developments on the implementation of relocation decisions and welcomed the first relocation operation that took place on 9 October. On this occasion, my colleague, the Minister of Immigration, Mr Asselborn, visited Italy and Greece. Finally, I would like to express once again our gratitude for the responsibility that the European Parliament has taken on the issue of migration, particularly for relocation decisions. You have been extremely fast, engaged and effective, and this cooperation has been very valuable. As you will have understood, the meeting will be dominated by this major challenge. But I would like to add, as President Tusk's invitation letter indicates, that the European Council will also take stock of the next steps in the process leading up to the British referendum. He will listen to President Hollande on the preparations for COP 21 in Paris, which you will talk about here later. Finally, work on the report of the five presidents continued in the Council, particularly under the Luxembourg Presidency. The European Council will now take stock of the work being done, based on a report prepared by the Presidency and to be presented by Prime Minister Bettel, knowing that deepening economic and monetary union is a priority for the Presidency. Thank you for your attention.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I was in Passau last week – Bavaria, Germany – talking to refugees and, above all, talking to those who care for refugees. The most beautiful pictures are when you talk to refugees; the most interesting conversations are with those who care – very often on our behalf – about refugees and their fate. I would like to say once again – and I have said this repeatedly – that I am full of admiration for the life achievements of the people who care for refugees, who do not ask how much clock it is, and who can hardly make a difference between day and night. This applies to the volunteers, and in particular to the police forces deployed. The police are not often praised. However, I would like to say here at this hour and after this visit, which I did not complete, but did, together with the chairman of the group, Manfred Weber, and other colleagues, but went through: you can sometimes thank the police for the most difficult tasks they have to carry out, and that is what I wanted to do with this. (Applause) Now the refugee drama will once again dominate the agenda of the European Council almost integrally. It would be good for all of us if we were to tell the people of our countries that this refugee crisis will not be over for Christmas. It will last for years, perhaps decreasing in density, but will remain as a phenomenon. Ergo is not only important, but above all, short-term action, but it is also important that we talk about the fight against the refugee crisis for years – not with composure, but detached from understandable but ultimately stupid passions. That is why the Commission has proposed a permanent relocation mechanism. I believe that the Member States would be well advised to follow this approach quickly by the European Commission. We need to define short-term answers, but because the phenomenon and the problem will continue, we also need to know that we also need to have a permanent mechanism for dealing with this challenging refugee issue. That is what we, as the Commission, will do. Moreover, the Commission does not abandon the intention I expressed when presenting the European Commission's priorities to present a legislative proposal on legal immigration. I agree with others that the short-term problem cannot be alleviated by such a proposal and decisions in this regard. But we need to know that Europe is an immigration continent, and we must face up to this challenge and this opportunity responsibly, and I hope we will. I would like to say the following about the situation, and I try to be brief because I have an appointment with the President of Latvia at five o'clock: the hotspots – a terrible word, we should try to describe these places more tenderly – are making good progress. Italy has identified the location of four hotspots, Greece five. I had sent the Director-General responsible for structural reforms in Greece to Athens. He spent a week there talking to everyone. He reported on this at the Commission meeting today. He is directly subordinate to me, because I do think that the migration problem is a problem that concerns the President of the Commission in the first place. He tells me that greece has had very impressive success esstify in terms of installing the hotspots and dealing with the refugee issue in general, which I am of course pleased about. What I am less pleased about is the fact that the European Council took decisions on the refugee issue on 23 September this year, including budgetary decisions. Now the European Union is being criticised without interruption. I don't really like to turn on German television anymore, because every television programme – but not only in Germany – criticises the European Union as such. Europe must do this, Europe must deliver, Europe must deliver, Europe must not deliver. Europe, the institutions of Europe, Parliament and the Commission have delivered! We took decisions in the European Council on 23 September, and the budgetary implications that have arisen from this were immediately taken into our own hands and budget proposals were made for 2015, for 2016. I am extremely grateful to the European Parliament and also to you, Mr President, for the speed and brevity of you, with the necessary speed and brevity. have responded to these proposals. European Council on 23 September, we arrived today on 14 October. What was expected of the Commission and the European Parliament has been done. We must stop criticising the European Union and its institutions. It should be noted that the institutions have delivered. Member States have not done so in the same way as the European Union has done. We were promised that the European Agency for Asylum would recruit 774 additional officials, eASO demands. So far, the Member States have delivered 81 men. Frontex has requested 775 additional posts, to great applause from the European Council. So far, the Member States have committed 48 posts. We are in the process of redistributing the 160 000 refugees, although I did not like every staging in this regard. Nineteen refugees being brought to Sweden and 160,000 refugees to look after say it all. However, the beginning has been made. I would like to praise the Luxembourg Presidency in general, but I would also like to commend the decisions taken by the Luxembourg Presidency, in particular Foreign Minister Asselborn. This was a very impressive achievement by the Luxembourg Presidency. Nevertheless, we must now continue with the development of the national contact points, which are necessary for registered refugees to find an address from where they can move to other countries. All but three Member States have designated such contact addresses. I would like to express my astonishment at the fact that it seems difficult to get enough refugees in Greece to seek their happiness in Luxembourg. Luxembourg is one of the richest countries in the European Union and it seems extraordinarily difficult to find enough candidates, if I may put it that way, to move to Luxembourg. Now I can understand that many people think that Juncker is no longer in Luxembourg, so Luxembourg is no longer the same country. Nevertheless, please, it is not an imposition to ask people who are on the run to move to Luxembourg. That is why, although they are not listening to me, I would like to campaign very much for the fact that there are enough candidates to take this journey, which seems to be confident in the end result. I have drawn attention to the fact that the Commission and Parliament have taken the budgetary implications of the Council's decisions of 23 September at an unprecedented rate of speed, first Parliament and the Commission. We have provided EUR 1.7 billion in additional funds via the 2015 supplementary budget and also in anticipation of the 2016 budget as the Commission, in such a way that a total of EUR 9.2 billion is available to allow us to deal with this refugee crisis in a reasonably adequate manner.  As far as humanitarian aid is concerned, I would like to commend the work of The High Commissioner for Refugees, Mr Guterres, here, and the Commission has made an additional EUR 500 million available from its budget for world hunger aid. All the Member States agreed to a declaration on 23 September which stated that the Member States should make precisely this contribution from their own budgets. So far, however, only 275 million have been announced. That is of no value, because of this EUR 275 million, the United Kingdom alone accounts for EUR 225 million. I would like to express my praise for the commitment of the British Government and the British Parliament: this is lived solidarity.  Not only are the British talking about this, they are also acting. I think that deserves the utmost recognition. (Applause) Of these 500 million humanitarian aid, 225 million are therefore missing. I would like to see the European Council bring in this 225 million tomorrow! (Applause) It is not enough to make promises. You also have to deliver by proving the deed. That is what I expect from the European Council, which will meet tomorrow. For the Syrian Trust Fund, the Commission, together with Parliament, has put together an additional EUR 500 million from its own budget – hardly anything to the Member States. In this respect, 492 million are missing in direct comparison with the Decision of the European Council of 23 September. I would like these 492 million to be made available tomorrow by the Heads of State or Government. (Applause) For the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, the Commission has made EUR 1.8 billion available from its own budget, that is to say from the budget allocated by the citizens of Europe – it is not ours. money- come. At the European Council on 23 September, it was agreed that the Member States would also set up EUR 1.8 billion. To date, nine million euros have been pledged: Luxembourg three, Spain three and Germany three million. I really wanted to see that explicitly confirmed here. There are 1 791 000 000 missing in direct comparison with the decision of the European Council of 23 September! I would like what was promised on 23 September to be delivered by the Member States tomorrow at the European Council. It is not enough to make promises. Deeds count! (Applause) En ce qui concerne la Turquie, Monsieur le Président, je voudrais tout d'abord m'associer vos paroles de condoléances et de compassion, tant il est vrai que condoléances et compassion doivent aller de pair. Nous avons re u, avec vous-méme, Monsieur le Président, avec le président Tusk et d'autres coll gues, notamment Mme Mogherini, le président Erdogan il y a peu pr s une semaine. Nous avons eu des entrevues séparées avec lui, puis nous avons eu une réunion de travail avec lui et les trois présidents des institutions. vrai dire, ce fut une réunion fructueuse. Je n'ignore rien des probl mes qui caractérisent la situation actuelle en Turquie et je voudrais m'associer vos appels en ce qui concerne le processus de réformes démocratiques, la liberté de la presse et les autres grands principes que vous n'avez pas manqué de mentionner. Toujours est-il que je me suis senti obligé, apr s en avoir référé votre Président, Mesdames et Messieurs, de présenter un programme de coopération entre la Turquie et l'Union européenne sur la question migratoire, qui fut tout de m me bien re u par le président de lapub Rélique. Chacun d'entre nous a ses idées propres sur les processus en cours en Turquie, mais nous avons besoin de ce pays, comme ce pays, sur d'autres points, a besoin de l'Union européenne. La Turquie abrite 2,2 million de réfugiés, et fournit ce titre un effort semblable celui du Liban et de la Jordanie. comparer nos chiffres, notamment ceux qui concernent l'obligation ardente de relocalisation, avec les réalités turque, libanaise et jordanne, je suis, pour le moins, un peu géné. Les pays non européens font plus que les Européens. Faut-il en étre fier? Non, mais nous devons en étre conscients et placer ce constat sur notre radar d'analyse du probl me migratoire. Je suis fermement résolu, en dépit des doutes, en dépit des hésitations, en dépit des interrogations que nous pouvons avoir et que j'ai, mettre la Turquie sur la liste des pays s érrs. Sans cela, la Turquie serait le seul pays candidat ne pas figurer sur cette liste. De deux choses l'une: si on estime que la Turquie n'a pas sa place parmi les pays s érrs, il faut arr ter les négociations d'adhésion. On ne peut pas faire les deux choses en m me temps et en parallle. Par conséquent, je plaide pour que nous mettions la Turquie sur la liste des pays sérs. Je plaide aussi pour que nous accélérions le processus de libéralisation des visas. J'ai envoyé, avec leur accord, bien s ér, le vice-président Timmermans et le commissaire Hahn en Turquie aujourd'hui. Il était prévu que le vice-président Timmermans se rende en Turquie dimanche. Cela n'a pas été possible puisque la Turquie, pour des raisons bien compréhensibles, avait décrété un deuil national. Frans Timmermans et Johannes Hahn se rendent donc en Turquie aujourd'hui et négocieront les détails du programme d'action qu'au nom de la Commission, et avec l'accord de votre Président, j'avais soumis la réflexion du président Erdogan, notamment sur la libéralisation ce régime.  Je pense tr sinc rement qu'il faudrait au moins commencer par libéraliser ce régime pour ce qui concerne le monde économique et puis voir, suivant les r gles qui doivent étre appliquées, comment on peut progresser plus rapidement sur ce dossier que ce  Nous devrons déclarer notre accord de principe pour ouvrir d'autres chapitres dans le processus d'adhésion. La Turquie est un partenaire utile mais difficile, mais nous devons pouvoir alle de l'avant avec elle parce qu'elle est devenue la porte d'entrée vers l'Europe pour des centaines de milliers de réfugiés.  J'avais proposé au président Erdogan, en présence de votre Président, de mettre en place des équipes communes gréco-turques pour surveiller la mer entre la Turquie et la Grace. La Turquie était d'accord. Je viens de lire aujourd'hui que la Grace ne l'est pas. Il s'agit de l'Europe, ici, pas des relations gréco-turques! Je voudrais donc demander au gouvernement grec de revoir cette position, parce qu'il serait tr s utile que, sous commandement européen, les forces navales des deux pays coop rent pour faire en sorte que cette porte d'entrée soit raisonnablement fermée. Avec la Turquie, nous avons donc essayé de progresser.  Le Conseil européen de demain aura conna tre d'autres problémes: le rapport des cinq Présidents ... je ne vais pas m'attarder cela. Lorsque nous ferons rapport des travaux du Conseil européen nous pourrons évidemment évoquer ce prob me. Tomorrow I will have a visit (that means a working lunch) from the British Prime Minister in order to discuss relations, as our British friends say, between Britain and the European Union. I repeat here what I have been saying since March 2014: I want – we want, the Commission wants – a fair deal with Britain and we are working in that direction. I cannot give details, but our negotiating teams have been in close contact for weeks now. I cannot say that huge progress has been achieved; I cannot say that nothing has been achieved – but it takes two to tango. As some here know, I am not a splendid dancer, but I do at least know the rules that have to be observed by others, and it needs two to tango. And so we have to dance and our British friends have to dance, but for sure, I am 150 per cent in favor of having Britain as a constructive Member State of the European Union. We need Britain. Personally, I do think that Britain needs the European Union, but that is a matter of conviction. Others may have a different feeling about that; They would have the same feeling if ever Britain were to leave the European Union. But that is not the assumption under which I am working. So, Mr President, these were the brief words. They weren't that short, but it still took 23 minutes. I have to apologise for this, and also for the fact that I have to dilute myself here at some point, because I would not like to let the Latvian President wait. I would like to thank you very much for your attention. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. First of all, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats very much welcome the fact that the Five Presidents' Report is being carried on, that we are committed to deepening monetary union, and we also welcome the statements made by the President of the Commission towards the United Kingdom. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats also wants to play its part in getting the fair deal, and so we wish you a lot of fun dancing, Mr President of the Commission! Ladies and gentlemen, the most important issue today, of course, is the issue of migration, which has been moving us for weeks now. And when citizens perceive us, our European politicians, the focus is on: does politics in Europe have orientation on how to respond to the challenge? I believe that we must keep giving this orientation. The first principle is solidarity. If Jordan can do something, if Lebanon can do something, then Europe must also make a difference.  We must help and we must show solidarity in burden-sharing within Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, this also includes – as the President of the Commission has said – that the refugees do not have the right to choose the country, but that they must help in the partnership work of solidarity. The second principle is that external borders must be protected. This is an important point for my group. All models depend on the question of whether the state gets back to action, and we even believe that the European Council should have the strength to take great steps and, for example, to really tackle the establishment of a European coastal protection agency or a European border management agency that really deserves the name, with its own staff, Minister Schmit. Not only small and small – we need big steps! The third principle is repatriation, and this is important to my group. It is an unpleasant subject, but it is one of them! Last year, two-thirds of all applicants were rejected under a constitutional procedure. And then we must also ensure that these rejected refugees leave the European Union and are repatriated. These are the points of reference in the answer. Tomorrow at the European Council, i.e. much will surely revolve around the question of the countries of origin, the real reasons for the problems that are on the table. And here I would like to ask explicitly that, hopefully, tomorrow we succeed in bringing about a common wording of the Member States of the European Union on the Syria issue.  It is not acceptable for one to say: we must talk to Assad, and the other says: I am not prepared to talk to Assad. This only leads to confusion. Europe is not able to speak and we will not contribute to resolving this conflict on our doorstep. We need a diplomatic initiative!  And the second is Libya, which is not talked about enough. We talk a lot about Syria, but we also need to talk about Libya. And here we need a package to send a signal to the disputed parties there: if you agree – and there are also positive signals, not just negative ones – then we are also ready to help you with a package. These are the two points that surround the countries of origin there, and the transit country of Turkey is, of course, important. We support the initiative of our President of the Commission to extend Turkey's hand and to consider together how we can meet the challenges. The visa issues, the issues of mobilising more money, are on the table, and I would also like to signal support for the Group of the European People's Party on these points. In spite of all this, I believe that we are all driven by the fact that Europe must not forget the principles behind it. We must continue to speak plainly on the Kurdish issue, we must continue to speak plainly about human rights in Turkey, because we are only a good friend of Turkey if we treat each other honestly.  Ladies and gentlemen, last but not least, as we prepare the Council, I would like to go further in what the President of the Commission has clearly expressed today, namely the anger and frustration that we have here in Brussels at European level towards the behaviour of the Member States. The examples were mentioned: providing staff – big announcements, nothing delivered; Provide money - big announcements, nothing delivered. The question of simplifying and improving procedures, the slogan 'safe country of origin Turkey', proposed by the Commission, supported by the European Parliament. The Interior Ministers can rely on nothing to agree on. And that is why we ask you to stop deporting all the black Peter to Brussels! It is not Brussels that fails here, it is not the European institutions, the Commission and Parliament that are failing. What is failing here is national selfishness, and this must clearly be answered by the Member States. Finally, and this is again emotionally important to me, ladies and gentlemen, we had a debate last week in the European Parliament, where the leaders of our Member States were present – the Spanish King, Francois Hollande, Angela Merkel. And I would like to address myself to the right side; there are only a few of the right-wing populists of EFDD and ENF present today. But it became clear in this debate that they do not actually have points that are important to them, because the right-wing populists – who always hold the nation so high – even with the Spanish king were not even able to stand up and applaud, were not even able to treat heads of state with respect. And that is why it was said last week that many of these right-wing populists have absolutely nothing to believe in – neither in Europe nor in the nation states. You only believe in yourself, and that is shameful, ladies and gentlemen! Today, someone is standing at the microphone wearing a traditional dress era because the Oktoberfest is opening in Brussels this evening, and I would therefore like to say for myself: I am a proud Bavarian, I love my homeland. I am a German Member of Parliament and I am a convinced European. Because we want us to do it together, to get it together to answer the question of migration. We do not want to divide further, like the right-wing populists.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Weber. (Interjections and unrest in the hall) Have you calmed down? No? If you haven't calmed down, you can go out to calm down and then come back in. After all, you are not Parliament's timepiece. And if you don't stop screaming around here, I'll take action.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European Socialists, we Socialists share the President's words on Turkey: solidarity, strong and clear.  Mr Smith, tomorrow's Council should give two answers. The first is to implement emergency measures on refugees, the relocation triangle, hot spots – we do not like the word either, which seems to be the title of a hard magazine, but they must be made – and repatriations. Italy made the first "hot spot", it also gave the money together with Germany to the Fund, everyone does it. The famous greed of governments should give way in the face of an emergency as serious as that of refugees. The second answer that tomorrow's Council should give is to go to the roots, to the causes, because, as Juncker said, this is a structural phenomenon and not a cyclical one. It is not resolved in three months, but it takes years and therefore we need a broad strategy.  What are the pieces of this strategy? One is Syria, which is one of the main causes of the flow. The European Commission, Juncker and Mogherini, are working towards a common European position on Syria and I support this position. This is not a time for military action, we must support the efforts of the UN and promote a political transition and the defeat of ISIS, daesh. Iran is an essential component of a strategy to stabilise the Mediterranean. Iran can and must also help us on the Syria case.  As far as Turkey is concerned, the more demanding and rigorous we are in demanding respect for human rights, the more demanding and rigorous we will be in calling for the fight against terrorism, the more intransigent and rigorous we will be in demanding that the elections be held in a transparent and correct manner, the more we will have the strength to tell the truth, namely that Turkey is an essential partner of the European Union. , a candidate for accession, a partner to whom we must send not only a financial message, but also a political message. Turkey is a political interlocutor and we must say to the Turkish people that we are opening the door to visa liberalisation.  Finally, as far as Africa is concerned, there will be the Valletta Summit. We need to strengthen dialogue with African states, we need to work on the return of migrants, we also need to open the file of regular migration – thank you, Mr Juncker, for the proposal you announced today on legal immigration – and I believe that Africa must be the European Union's political priority.  If we do these things, which are concrete, non-rhetorical and demagogic things, we may not care so much about the caricature of some media towards Europe, nor about the anti-European offensive that will deflate as a blood pressure meter deflates.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" question. Mr Pittella, you were talking about Iran – world champion of state terrorism – which we so need in Syria. How were you going to do that? In Syria, the flames are already spreading more by the Islamic Republic of Iran. Would you like to explain how that is possible? I think that is a totally wrong geopolitical choice and also an immoral choice.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: answer "blue card". A few months ago, also thanks to the important role of our Federica Mogherini, there was an important agreement that prevents a significant risk to humanity. If we can discuss this with Iran, I do not see why we cannot discuss the geopolitical strategy of the Mediterranean, knowing that Iran has an important weight, consistency and influence in that region.  Syria is an emergency for us, we must address it. I believe that we must not tackle it with the use of weapons, but we must tackle it by supporting the action of the UN, we must tackle it knowing that there is a fundamental enemy that is ISIS, the so-called ISIS, and that there is a current situation that goes, with a useful process, completed and to an end.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, these are serious times with serious challenges, for which we need serious solutions: solutions that move away from the old mantra that, whatever the problem, more money, more regulation, more Europe is the solution; solutions that stop just talking about solidarity, but actually take account of the needs and the strengths of different EU countries; solutions that force us to be honest about the problems. So when the five Presidents ask what caused the crisis we face in the euro: was it because we did not have enough centralisation of the euro area? Was it because we did not have enough responsibility? Was it because we did not have the right rules in place? No, it is because the rules in place were flagrantly ignored. For economic and monetary union to work, we all need to be honest that richer euro-area countries will most likely need to make fiscal transfers to poorer euro-area countries for the foreseeable future – and probably for ever. So, instead of highly complex rules for monetary union that powerful countries flout when politically expedient, how about a few rules that we actually follow? Because yet again, political capital is being spent talking about ever closer union instead of delivering ever-growing economies and an ever more competitive Europe. Renegotiation and reform is not something that growing numbers of people in only one EU Member State want. In my last five years here in Parliament, my political group has grown to be the third-largest group – representing not people from one country, but from 16 different Member States – because people realise that the EU cannot go on as it is. The EU has to change. The EU has to reform. So of course, ahead of the EU referendum, David Cameron wants a better deal for the UK. But all of us here should want a better deal for the EU. To all my friends here in this House, if you really want the UK to remain a member of the EU, help the British Government to achieve these reforms. Dance, tango with us. But if you want the UK to leave so you can continue to construct a United States of Europe, tell the UK to stop wasting its time and close your mind to reforms. On the refugee crisis, let us get away from polarising the debate: telling people that you are either pro-immigration or you are anti-immigration; saying ‘let them all in’ or ‘let no one in’; or ‘we should do something’ or ‘we should do nothing’. It actually achieves very little. Therefore, in preparation for the summit, I hope leaders look to ensure that the basic foundations of a functioning and cooperative asylum system are in place: humane and fast processing; immediate returns for failed asylum-seekers; establishing hotspots – I am not quite sure what magazines Mr Pittella reads – or crisis points to quell the current crisis; and combining all of our expertise, willingness and resources available to achieve it – not opening a door and then closing it again; not causing confusion by acting unilaterally. What we need is to put the foundations of that cooperative system in place so we are better able to offer help to the most vulnerable people escaping this conflict, taking them directly from the camps and bypassing the traffickers. It may not sound as poetic as saying that the EU has a solution to every problem, but it is a responsible way of delivering a solution intended to help people who want to fulfil their dreams and a better future in their own homes. Tackling this issue at source in Syria and Libya needs concerted action, not only at European level but at international level, to get the various militias and their proxies around a table to seek a political solution. Otherwise the only alternative is a military solution in a powder keg, and the alternative is starting something that nobody knows how it will end. So these are tough and challenging times. But it is time to agree on what we can all do, not order others – or command others – what to do. Time for people to lead with their heads and not their hearts. Time to drop the fanciful wish list and to deliver serious solutions. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – Commiserations to Mr Kamal on losing out on the Conservative nomination for London’s Mayor, but I would like to ask him: now that the ‘remain’ and ‘leave’ sides have launched their campaigns, which side is he on?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Well, what a surprise that question is. As Mr Juncker said, we have to tango, we have to negotiate, and I will make up my mind when I see the deal that has been secured not only for reform of the EU-UK relationship but for the whole EU. Yes, you have made up your mind; you made up your mind before you even came here. What we need is a serious debate that understands the UK point of view but understands that reform is not only wanted by people in Britain, it is wanted by people right across the EU.  You can talk about what you want, but we know what you want. We know that you want to leave. We want reform not just for Britain, but for the whole EU. Any more questions? I can take more.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I understand that the future of the European Union will be decided in a dance contest and I cannot wait to see Mr Juncker taking Mr Cameron in his arms, but I would just like to underline that the future of Europe is decided in an open, transparent and public debate in a democratic process and not in backroom deals. The Council draft conclusions open with a very encouraging sentence saying that tackling the migration and refugee crisis is a common obligation which requires a comprehensive strategy and a determined effort over time in a spirit of solidarity and responsibility. And I thought, yes, this is a radical change of strategy in the Council: ‘Wir schaffen das’. Unfortunately, the determination of the Council ends after the first sentence. The decision on the 160 000 was already inadequate and everybody knew it, and many more people will come our way. But the Member States have not even properly delivered on their previous pledges, never mind for additional refugees, and the only response of the Council seems to be: let’s keep our eyes closed and maybe the problem will go away. But citizens are concerned, not just Members of Parliament.  I see the ‘remain’ or ‘leave’ campaign has already started in this room. But citizens – I can see that the Presidency of the Council is on the phone to a citizen right now – are concerned. They see the images of large numbers of refugees coming this way. They also see refugee centres being established in their neighbourhoods, and they are anxious. But the majority of European citizens, I am convinced, want to welcome refugees and they want Europe to show solidarity. But they also want to know that Europe is able to cope with the situation. They want to see leadership, but instead the government leaders are dithering and hesitating and ducking the issue and coming up with half-hearted and inadequate solutions. How can you expect citizens to be confident that Europe can handle the situation if government leaders themselves do not show that they are up to the job? The Commission and Parliament have put forward proposals repeatedly for a comprehensive strategy, but the Council is silent. But we urgently need a comprehensive policy here that includes legal avenues for migration, a real EU asylum policy with a permanent distribution key and a real EU border control system. On the talks with Turkey, I think that is very welcome and it is essential. But I wonder: the Commission, and in particular the Council, are making promises about financial support without actually specifying where the money will come from. Earlier promises of funds, as Mr Juncker just set out, have not been delivered upon, so how can you promise more money to a country if you have not even delivered on your earlier promises? It is very clear that the current financial framework does not allow for these kinds of exercises. And besides, I would like to echo the words of other speakers who ask themselves: how can we be sure that the human rights of refugees will be guaranteed in Turkey? The Council draft conclusions also mention the aim of developing safe and sustainable reception capacities in the affected regions and providing lasting prospects for refugees. I was a little mystified by that, because I wonder exactly what ‘lasting prospects’ means when you are in a refugee camp. I hope for your sake that refugees have the same notion of ‘lasting prospects’. Reception in the region and cooperation with third countries mainly means outsourcing our problems, and I think it is a bit bitter that we applaud the Nobel Peace Prize Laureate, Tunisia, and at the same time expect them to solve our problems and receive the people we turn away. Finally, the draft conclusions do not remotely constitute an answer to the current situation, so the ALDE Group expects you to go back, do your homework and come up with a realistic and comprehensive strategy, so that we can truly say to European citizens: ‘Wir schaffen das’. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear Colleague, it has emerged from your speech that the governments of the countries should do more. I've seen the same from other colleagues. I ask you: do you not think that governments and, by implication, the citizens of our countries should know very clearly what is the full programme devised by the European Union, from stopping the cause to ensuring the security of European borders?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – I am not really sure I understand the question correctly, but I think there are comprehensive plans on the table. Parliament has expressed itself repeatedly; the Commission has expressed itself repeatedly. So I think we do have an answer. Now everything depends on delivery, and for that we rely on the Council and on the Member States. It cannot be done only by the Commission and Parliament. That is why we make this appeal to the Council and the Member States.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Europe, as Minister Schmit has said, must show solidarity, but it cannot have a short-term view on migration and asylum issues. This is likely to be a lasting phenomenon that must be tackled more boldly, considering that our planet is common and that refugees are human beings forced to leave their land because of misery, repression, wars and the wound of terrorism. Yes, the humanitarian emergency must first be addressed. You are right, Mr Juncker, to deplore the lack of budget today, but at the same time you cannot advocate budget cuts, as you do. I believe, on the other hand, that we should support the project of an international conference on refugees. The solution is not to make our neighbours border guards, even if we have to help countries that have taken in millions of refugees.  As for Turkey, I say yes to compassion and solidarity with the Turkish people, but I will instead urge caution with Mr Erdogan. We have already had terrible experiences and terrible setbacks with Tunisia and Libya, which played a bit of this role as border guards.  The causes of migration must be tackled: poverty, repression, wars and terrorism. This would require greater coordination for large-scale diplomatic initiatives and for an international un-sponsored coalition against the Islamic State group. It would also require an end to the plundering and exploitation of Africa, an end to free trade agreements that destroy African agriculture and services, and the fight against fraud and tax evasion, which reach $50 billion a year for Africa! This is exactly the amount that would enable Africans to meet their needs for infrastructure and services. That, I think, is what could be discussed at the Valletta summit. I would still like to say two words about economic and monetary union, which you have not had time to talk about. The reason should, I believe, lead you to put an end to the current leak in companionship with the financial markets. Now we are reviving this dangerous idea of financial securitization. We are being told to further strengthen control of national budgets and to put pressure on wages with what you have called the 'competitiveness authorities'. Instead, listen to the Nobel Prizes in economics who repeat, every day, that we must make social recovery, thus raise wages and social minimums and be bold on investments for the coming century, i.e. ecological conversion, digital, and above all social and human development in education, health and social protection! Listen to the International Monetary Fund, which says greek debt needs to be restructured!  Let's discuss these topics! Let's make new decisions! We propose to create a social and ecological development fund dedicated to these new projects of the future. What we are advocating is a re-foundation of the European project, a humanist and solidarity project. I think that is the only way for Europe to exist tomorrow.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is very good, as Mr Juncker said, that we are talking about a problem that we will be dealing with for a long time. We have already mentioned this with Mr Hollande and Mrs Merkel last week. I just believe that this view of the long-term nature and the dimension of the problem must not lead to the fact that we are taking as much time as we have been allowed to deal with these pressing problems in certain measures that must now simply take place in the European Union.  And I think it is very right, Mr Juncker, that you said that it is a disgrace that the Member States cannot even implement the emergency aid programmes for Africa, Syria and support for the United Nations World Food Programme – not even these commitments – from one summit to the next. If this continues, Then I wonder how we are going to build confidence in the European Union's ability to act.  In order to combat the causes, i am able to say for my group that we are never really opposed to holding talks if that serves to achieve peace, a ceasefire, whatever. I only have the impression that we have to talk to Assad, or that you have to talk to Putin, that this is now becoming a banality if we do not know what and with what purpose these talks are supposed to be. And unity against ISIS – that is one thing – but that unity, which is not enough, is not enough to have a long-term plan for how this region, where we have so many major problems, should develop further. In order for the European Union to deal with the refugee challenge, the focus is on recognising that Dublin, as we have done, has failed. The first to express this was the Chancellor. In my view, this means that we need to do exactly what you said very quickly. We must ensure not only better management at the hotspots, but the connection of a lasting, solidarity-based distribution of the people who are fleeing to us and arriving there, that is what we must ensure. And for me, this is not a step that can take place next year, but that is something that needs to be decided quickly.  We have often argued about safe third countries. For the Balkans, I must say that I think it is right to set priorities in this current situation. But I also think that you have to work on what you said in the State of the Nation speech and come up with something. What does this mean in these countries to guarantee the individual right to asylum? The Europeans must then be clear about this.  Recognising Turkey now as a safe third country would, in my opinion, be a recognition of President Erdogan's policy – and that is not possible! Erdogan has led his country away from democracy, Erdogan has trampled on the rule of law. And I think there was just a moment to talk to him. The chancellor will go there and talk to Erdogan; I hope that this is not just about refugees, but also about how Turkey should develop. And I would like to see, even if Europeans are going there now, that we not only talk to President Erdogan, who has a great responsibility for the whole, for all this bad development, but also to talk at least to the families and those who had to mourn this insanely large number of victims at the weekend. Thank you for your attention! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: question with "blue card". Mr President, because the debate is constantly focused on self-criticism of the Member States of the European Union with regard to refugees, you do not feel in this Chamber that only the European Union, the European Commission, the European Parliament and the European Council are fighting night and day on the refugee issue while other countries, be they America, Russia or the Arab countries , in fact, to date they have not given a cent, have they not been sensitized, mobilised or supported this effort?  And, at the same time, I would like to ask to what extent, given this and with history as it stands, can Turkey now be seen as a reliable partner to cooperate even on these issues?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. If you look at the UN figures, this year there are 60 million people who are on the run, who have had to leave their homeland for various reasons. And I agree with you: there are many countries in the world that can take more responsibility for it. However, the European Union has not yet assumed sufficient responsibility in accordance with its economic strength, including in accordance with its own values. In the next few years, we will have to bring many more refugees to Europe, to the European Union, than we have done so far.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since Mr Weber does not like right-wing populism, I will try to confuse it, more than it already seems to be, with a fine left-wing populist speech. After the days of façade emotion, of the now clumsy and now angry management of the emergency, Europe is revealing its strategy, which consists of welcoming a handful of people and showing themselves with the most inflexible, to the point of the use of force, simply because they have no right to exist for this model of Europe if not at home. The fact is that they will come anyway, also because of a Europe that is always lagging behind in understanding the great dynamics of the world. So now the imperative is no longer to accept them, but rather to reject and expel them, and few know exactly what the rules of engagement of the police forces engaged on this new front are. This Europe is paying Turkey to keep 2 million refugees in its belly who, as we are told, will have access to health, education and work thanks to Europe's money. Pay the states from which people arriving in Europe flee to force them to take them back home, while knowing that they are encouraging an increase in the ranks of jihadist fighters. In the chaos of the Syrian conflict, this Europe does not exist, or acts by proxy – usa – or suffers action – Russia. It could, but does not, confiscate Assad's capital and use that wealth to assist the fleeing Syrian people. It could, but does not, regulate the trade in arms components. It could, but does not, create a credible European army as an instrument of deterrence from war. And I come to the summit that will take place tomorrow. The stakes are high and it is not just about immigration. Those who, with economic supremacy, aim to impose narrow leadership and governance schemes with differentiated integration, are taking on the very serious responsibility of creating a rift in Europe. If the 'better first than all' principle is affirmed, the end of the European specific is decreed. We believe in a Europe that measures people's needs and the awareness that those who are blind to the signs of their time cannot be the guide for the future.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: On which rule of the Rules of Procedure is your speech based, Mr Buonanno?

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Articles 166 and 167 concern me because before I entered this Chamber I was blocked, they got their hands on me, because I received a notification from President Schulz, who wrote me things about a ten-day penalty. It is a pity that the President, who has left, had to consult me first and then adjust the sanction and quote why he sanctioned me. He wrote a whole series of things, including some that aren't true, that I read and then returned the letter.  Furthermore, under Rule 167, the Member concerned, i.e. myself, may lodge an appeal with the Bureau within two weeks. The problem is, they handed me the letter and I returned it, but they still didn't want me in. I am not in agreement with the clerks, because they only carry out orders, but I, as a Member of Parliament, could not enter the Chamber, according to President Schulz. This is a disgrace because we are talking here about democracy, Turkey, etc., etc., but that is where democracy is not being made! Just because I took the leave to criticise Merkel and Germany, just because I took the leave to criticise Volkswagen!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Buonanno, you have made a point under the Rules of Procedure. Political comments are not the substance of your speech. A measure has been taken against him, which I believe will come into force from Monday next week. You are now in the Chamber and you have spoken.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: ent group. – To Mr Weber, who has just been ranting against populists, I would like to say: vox populi, vox deorum. I am proud to speak with the voice of the people. The next Council of Ministers will discuss the migration crisis in detail. The proposal before us is a cave in to the blackmail of Turkey. Turkey should never become a member of the EU and should never be exempt from visa requirements. The dictator Erdoğan was hailed as a hero by thousands of Turks in Strasbourg last week. It is clear that the loyalty of the Turks in Europe lies not with their host country but with the Sultan of Ankara, who is bombing Kurdish Turks, supporting IS and counting Jews and Christians among its great enemies. This country can't be trusted. If the EU gives in to blackmail and gives Turkey money for refugees, but at the same time opens the door to the EU, we will still be overwhelmed by millions of migrants from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Syria in a few years' time. Nationalised to Turk, they still enter the European Union. The Commission – and I give an immediate answer to Mr Juncker – must stop negotiations with Turkey on accession and on the abolition of the visa requirement once and for all. Let the Council speak out clearly against Islamic violence, both from Turkey and from Islamic organisations, and stop funding it. Finally, I would like to draw attention to hamas' ruthless terror against the Jewish people and to sly attacks by Palestinians against innocent Jewish citizens. Let the Council also make a clear statement against this.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it would not be an exaggeration to claim that immigration is one of the serious problems that the European Union has so far not taken seriously. But it is never too late to make the right decisions, but above all to take the right steps to tackle the problem. Europe's external borders should be protected with the care and responsibility of the states that are in them. As far as Greece is concerned, I would like to assure you that the country's armed forces can safeguard its borders if they are assigned this task. There is no need for joint patrols with Turkish naval forces. The only cooperation between Greece and Turkey could be Turkey's obligations not to send thousands of illegal immigrants to Greece to cause it trouble. Migrant registration and identification centres must also be located in the countries not of entry, but in the countries from which they are being forwarded to Europe. Finally, there must be a proper distribution of refugees in all countries. It is not understood that Greece, with eleven million inhabitants, has more than three million illegal immigrants.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, the European Council will meet for the fourth time since the spring to discuss the refugee crisis. There will still be two dozen more Council meetings on the subject, because the experience of the euro crisis has shown that some 20 last-chance summits are needed when the Union is threatened at its bases, and this is the case now. Tomorrow's European Council will be devoted to pressing issues, of course, but now is the time to also assess the medium- and long-term consequences. The exodus of refugees we are witnessing today is unprecedented, but it is only the first of a phenomenon that will characterize this century and it will force us to review in depth at least three of our major policies. Firstly, the budget: in 2013, the European Council wanted to reduce the European budget for a period of seven years. He'll find out tomorrow Thursday that the shackle he's set has exploded. We cannot finance both cohesion policy, agricultural policy, Horizon 2020, the Juncker plan, the strengthening of border control, the retention of refugees in Turkey and the 100 billion aid promised to developing countries for COP 21. It's a prank! Secondly, foreign policy: the migration issue must be placed at the very top of our foreign policy priorities. President Juncker rightly cited the case of Turkey. Finally, the policy of development cooperation. The Euro-African summit in Valletta should mark the beginning of a new kind of partnership between Europe and the African continent: the control of migration and the common interest of our old continent and the one that embodies the youth of the world. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8 of the regulation)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Etheridge, you have the floor, but the blue card is only for a question. Your blue card is before the start of Mr Lamassoure. Please, what is your question?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question. It is the seventh time of trying but I am eager to hear your answer. Do you share with Mr Juncker the absolute horror when he turns on the television and sees people disagreeing with him? He is emotional, he feels upset and he has to turn it off because these awful people – these electors, these right—wing populists, whatever names he wants to call them – do not agree with what he is doing. Do you share that pain? Or do you think, perhaps, if you aspire to a position of leadership, maybe you should listen to the outside world and listen to what people have got to say?

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer to Bill Etheridge. "Sir, like President Juncker and like a majority of Members here, I am struck by the fact that our constituents want this very serious problem to be dealt with both humanely and realistically.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, yes, of course the refugee crisis is – and should remain – our central and top priority. Nevertheless, I believe that completing economic and monetary union must remain a central priority. We need to address these increasing external pressures, but we also need to cope with very high tensions inside the euro area. We need to restore convergence in the euro area. That is why we need to have a new European Semester with proper coordination of economic policies, not only to rebalance the budget but to foster growth and jobs. We do of course need reforms, but we need investment on a large scale, counting on fiscal capacity, and we need to avoid what is now happening on the ground, namely that Member States are just competing by downgrading their social standards. So our expectation is that you need to have this roadmap to complete economic and monetary union with a proper social dimension. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – The lady mentioned completing economic and monetary union, and last week the President of France said the choice for the British people was full integration or leave. Is it her view that if Britain stays in the European Union there will be adoption of the euro, there will be integration with Schengen and there will be full union into the forthcoming European superstate?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card answer. – Many thanks for your question. I must tell you that you have perhaps misunderstood President Hollande. Let me tell you that I belong to his club when he says that he fully supports Britain’s membership of the European Union. We need to have Britain in the European Union, but we also need to make sure that the euro area will be able to deal with these specific problems. Frankly, I think it is possible to find solutions to both issues.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, President Juncker, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for his work. They paid tribute to the efforts of the volunteers who receive the refugees and provide first aid. You have paid tribute to the police, and I fully agree with those words. These are the European values that are so often upheld in this House. But European values also include the validity of the law, and if you turn off the television because you no longer want to hear the criticism of the EU, then of course the criticism of the EU will not be out of the art. The law is being violated in Europe: it is violated if the non-assistance clause is violated in the context of the euro crisis, and it is violated if the Dublin Treaty is trampled underfoot. It is up to you, Mr Juncker, to ensure that this does not happen. You must respect the law and you must enforce the law. The citizens of Europe feel that this is not happening, and that is where the criticism of the EU comes from. It is up to you to refute this criticism.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to echo President Schulz’s words of condolence to Turkey and also his appreciation of the enormous efforts that Turkey is making on the migration crisis. I will leave this aside from the issue of accession negotiations because I think that these are two somewhat partly interlinked, but still separate, issues. Let me say that I am quite happy that it seems that we have left the point when the EU was polarising itself over the migration crisis. I leave aside who has contributed more or less to it, but I think that, in the words of Nicolas Schmit, the word ‘common’ is important, and ‘common’ is what we should remain. It should be a common effort and with a common effort we can succeed. The European Council’s agenda is, I think, the right agenda. Let me just emphasise a couple of points. I am sure that we will comply with the principles and values of humanity, but the Valletta summit will also have to address, in an efficient way, the return and readmission policy of the European Union. That is why I welcome those words: ‘this is the expectation of the citizens’. Breaking up the criminal networks has, of course, to be sufficiently addressed as well, as does the prevention of illegal migration. Finally, I will make two very brief remarks. Regarding Frontex, I understand that we want to enhance the mandate. I would just underline that this is not sufficient. We really need to significantly transform the Agency, Frontex, into something that will have competences, people, a unified command, so to speak, and will be able to address the task. My final remark, addressing President Juncker, is on the packages that we are to get – one on the protection of borders, one on economic migration, and a third one. Let us make it one package at the same time so that we can really deliver in a very complex and comprehensive way. My apologies to the Chair. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. – While the EU institutions are struggling to solve the refugee crisis, I often wonder, for example as a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, what background powers can move? It was a major scandal recently that the Czech Defence Minister told a Czech newspaper that he knew from the Hungarian Defence Minister that Putin's Russia was financing the buses in the Balkans that were supposed to carry refugees in bulk. Have you heard of this scandal in the Czech Republic? Because if that's the case, then we're going to have to think about it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: blue-card answer. – I shall be very brief and also I apologise as I will have to leave immediately afterwards for a meeting with the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic. Very briefly, I can assess the scandal and whether I have heard of it.  Yes, I have heard the Czech Minister of Defence Martin Stropnický basically quoting the Hungarian Minister of Defence, his counterpart. I do not know whether one should speak of a scandal, but I know Martin Stropnický and he is usually very much on the cautious side, so I have no reason to disbelieve his statement. But I have not spoken to him in the last few days.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, you rightly pointed out that the refugee crisis will last for years. And a few weeks ago you quite rightly praised the baker from Kos in Greece who distributes free bread. But, unfortunately, the activation of civil society cannot hide the fact that the European Union is doing too little and too late. Gentlemen of the Council, you are currently out of the Chamber. How long will the Council delay and postpone the implementation of the decisions it took on 23 February? How long will the Council tolerate racist behaviour by governments, such as Mr Orban's in Hungary, that dispel all notions of European values? When will Dublin policy change? When will there be a single European asylum policy? When will we have a single one, not 28 policies on immigration and refugees? And because Chancellor Merkel will also go to Turkey in a few days, the debate with Turkey should not only be about refugees but also about democracy, normality, peace in the region. Talk not only with Erdogan but also with the other political forces. Cooperation with Turkey, yes, Mr Juncker, but respecting the limits and rules arising from the national sovereignty of my country of Greece in the Aegean and, of course, under the auspices of the European Union.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Mr President, colleagues, it is both unacceptable and strange for me that, in recent frequent speeches, there has been an indirect call for states to renounce their sovereignty and build a federal United States of Europe. Supposedly independent states are, due to different legal regulations and various political considerations, unable to cope with the crises of migrants and other crises that are devastating Europe, and the federal compound would be a salvation ostensibly from all the troubles that have hit the old continent today. Colleagues, so it is naïve, moreover, today no one has revoked the right of peoples to be free and independent. It is strange to hear today that the european Council has an item on the agenda of the referendum on membership of the European Union that Britain is about to hold. What plans could the President of the European Council set out for a further process that is legitimate and highly democratic? To ban the alphabet of democracy? Gentlemen, let us not forget that the Treaty on the European Union sounds like a Treaty on a Europe of sovereign states and peoples, and so far no one has given us or the European Council a mandate to review that Treaty.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have to devote a few moments of my time to Mr Weber of the European People's Party, who is not in the Chamber at the moment. In my view, it is intolerable how he is drawn to What he calls European right-wing populists. These are precisely the political forces that represent the opinion of their people, and with increasing support – whether that is the Dutch Vrijheidspartij, number one in the polls, whether that is the National Front, number one in France, whether it is the Lega Nord in Italy, on the way to becoming a significant force in Italy, whether that is my party in Austria. , which has now reached over 30% in the elections in the capital. But not only in my group, but also in other groups – whether that is UKIP in The United Kingdom, whether that is the AfD in Germany – these are all parties that increasingly represent their populations. You should write in your register that a successful policy will take place if you represent the opinion of your people, and not impose things here from the European ivory tower that fewer and fewer people want. Today, however, we are talking about the Council, and one sentence only: from Council to Council, from parliamentary debate to parliamentary debate, the situation is getting worse: unemployment is getting higher, debts are getting higher, social programmes are being reduced, and since 2013 the Council has been trying to reduce what it calls irregular migration from Africa. The truth is that the floodgates are more open than ever and this misguided policy urgently needs to... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, at this point in the debate I think it is important to note that the vast majority of Members support the Commission's policy and that the vast majority of Members support Council policy, because anyone who is seeing us from the outside may end up thinking otherwise. We speak less in number, but we represent many more Members, and we certainly represent many more voters.  I would also like to stress on the eve of the Council meeting that the Council has been meeting for three weeks and adopted measures, and that these measures have unfortunately not yet been implemented.
