And that there are many citizens wondering what Europe is doing, but what they should actually ask themselves is what the Member States are doing. Europe, through the Commission, has taken action and is implementing them. We are waiting for the Member States to be at the same level of action as the European Union because we are already beginning to repeat ourselves with the speeches. I repeat myself with the speeches. I'm going to say again that external borders need to be protected. I will say again that a legal immigration mechanism is needed in Europe. I will say again that all refugees must be protected, that these are not the first to arrive and that these will not be the last, that we are facing a problem for the next twenty years.  I will say again - as President Mariano Rajoy said today - that Europe needs a common immigration policy and a common policy of political refugees. We can repeat one another, but if you do not act, the worst thing that will happen to us will not be to repeat our speeches, but to run out of words. Soon winter will be effective and soon there will be no refugees. Don't be fooled, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, that refugees don't arrive in the winter, it doesn't mean that the crisis is over. He'll be back in the spring and he has to catch us ready to be human, decent and Democratic.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (...) they can come to Europe – statements by representatives of the European Union authorities, from the incentives of organised crime groups that encourage illegal immigration. Even if this immigration crisis is structural, even if it is a geopolitical process, it is the task of the Union authorities to relax the process, not to intensify it. Saying "come, come" does not lead nowhere. This is not only to the detriment of our countries, but to the detriment of those people who are encouraged in this way.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – I suppose the honourable Member has seen as I have the images of children drowned on the beach, of families giving their lives for trying to reach Europe, of the dead on our beaches. Refugees coming to Europe are not criminals. They're running away from criminals.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, indeed, the arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees and, with the repetition of dramatic images of these refugees taking steps in the fields of Europe, also diminishes media attention to this problem. But, this drama, which affects public opinion, which also lowers its arms in moments of supposed and false calm, is a drama with which we will actually live for a long time.  The Commission has submitted its proposals. The Council and Parliament have approved EUR 400 million which we will vote on in a couple of hours in this Parliament. But Member States still have a need to contribute EUR 225 million; and I want to point out that they must fulfill their obligations. And I would ask the Council, in the face of the 2016 budget, to be realistic and ambitious enough to provide financially what we need to do next year. Let us not repeat this image of the Council by haggling around millions of euros to meet the dignity of millions of people.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker has told us about his meetings with refugees. Of course, if in his previous experience he had avoided giving billions of euros to tax evasion and multinationals, all this money could have been used to address social weaknesses, help third world countries, etc. But it could still be done if it were decided to return this stolen money to the European tax authorities and to give it to these peoples. We would be in perfect agreement. It comes to us to ask whether non-European countries are no longer doing more than we do. I wonder which non-European countries do more than we do. For example, do the rich countries of the Arab world do more than we do in reception? I do not think that is the case.  And then again take advantage and seize this moment, I say this moment, to proclaim Turkey as a safe country! But you are obviously under the blackmail of Turkey, which tells you that there are as many as 7 million poor people in its neighbourhood, of refugees who could invade Europe. So let us give this erdogan satrap billions of euros, which we do not know what they are going to be used for, but certainly not to help the poor in that territory.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: "We are living in serious times, we are waiting for difficult problems to be solved, it is testing the European Union over and over again. Firstly, I would like to join those who thank those who still do today for protecting the borders, as well as for the volunteers who help to care for the migrants. At the same time, I also see that, although we are living in difficult times, we can even exacerbate this with uncoordished actions and ambily ambicum statements. I can see that terrible images are going around the world wide web, but I also see that the purpose of these images should not be to shock us and to talk about this in each and every one of our manifestations, but to encourage us to act precisely to find solutions that work in practice. I cannot turn off the television if I am criticised, I cannot not hear the request of the electorate, I can also say his will when it comes to tres71 when it comes to trading the migrant crisis. You have to learn from these mistakes. Our job is to find a solution that works. Talk less and do more.  The protection of the external borders must be firmly ensured, including the protection of the Schengen borders. The Schengen acquis cannot be forgotten. We cannot endanger them by not complying with legislation that does not make it any better. We may be able to talk about Dublin not working, but at the moment this is what needs to be done with the right resources, with a budget that will ensure that. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. "It is rare in this House to praise a fellow Fidesz member in support of his words. I would like to thank Madam Vice-President for everything she said about hungarian volunteers, because in fact tens of thousands of people in Hungary have done their job and are doing their job. However, my question, Madam Vice-President, is whether you agree with the words of your own group leader, which we heard a few minutes ago from Mr Weber, in which he says that it is not the EU institution and Brussels that have failed, but the national governments that are tearing apart, dismantling the European Union, and it is the often selfish national ego that makes it difficult for us to solve the crisis. That's what your leader was talking about. Do you agree with that, Congresswoman?

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Blue card answer. "I think that with all praise be careful. I am like the Trojan Horse with the praise of the Socialists, so I will be careful about this too. The Hungarian Government considers it important to support and provide resources to NGOs, and these organisations can help to care for migrants here, so thank you for your work, and also for the government. What the government is doing is complying with the law, registering migrants, protecting the green border and keeping border crossings open so that migrants can arrive and register in compliance with EU law. We're talking about 350,000 people. It's a huge number. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Ms Gáll-Pelcz, you have done a tremendous amount of hand-wringing – which is very commendable; what is going on is very upsetting – but I have been suggesting in this Parliament that instead of letting people be dragged halfway across the world to find refuge, why do we not build camps next to the Syrian-Turkish border? You asked for solutions, Madam, and I cannot think of a more perfect solution. Would you agree with me that that is the best idea? We build camps next to the Syrian border and we make sure that we get funding not only from Europe – apparently Britain is the largest contributor to this. Let us see some more action from the rest of Europe and from the Gulf States. Do you agree with me?

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Blue card answer. "I don't think I've broken my hand, I've held my earbuds, if that's a padding, I've been padding. However, as far as your question is concerned, that is a perfectly appropriate question. The problem must be solved where it arises, notably one origin in Syria, the other in Turkey, and all the refugee camps that these countries cannot provide. It is our job and our responsibility to help these countries and help solve the problem, but it is not a problem-solving if we irresponsibly make statements that drag on the flow of migrants, and then we talk about the women and children who have come a long way to Germany, that we will send them back through some kind of resettlement system. It's soulless. We have to act responsibly.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Sirs, Europeans are worried, refugees are in fear and despair, winter is coming and the cold and dreams are becoming nightmares. We expect concrete action from European leaders. There is very little talk of humanitarian protection, much more leaders focusing on securing the external borders, on strengthening, on return policy. What about integration policy? The relocation of refugees must be normal, fair distribution as soon as possible, and humane treatment of people must become the norm. I agree that solidarity with the western Balkan countries is extremely important, but also to prevent criminal activity and profiteering at the expense of the people. I expect a humane and solidarity-based response tomorrow. Europe can only lead and participate in the international community's efforts to end the war in Syria.  Colleagues, fleeing to Europe is not an option, and a safe and decent life in their homeland deserves everyone.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would essentially like to point here, first of all, to the question of the United Kingdom, which is going to be debated in this Council and where I think we have to make a consistent effort to ensure that the United Kingdom remains in the European Union. This does not mean, however, that there are no red lines and, therefore, it is important that the information that is given can provide states with a set of principles and ideas, of proposals, so that we can understand whether or not the United Kingdom really wants to remain in the European Union, because it also depends on the areas and concrete proposals that we will give. That would be a first point. Secondly, on the issue of refugees and, in particular, the situation in Turkey. I think we have to act with great urgency at the moment and therefore we already have to make some emergency intervention and then it makes perfect sense to use the Platform of Turkey and the agreement we have with Turkey to ensure the situation of these refugees, to ensure that they are welcomed and, in particular, that there is no invasion , let's say anarchic-chaotic, of the European Union. But that - and this was the point I wanted to underline here - should not make us forget that we must have a European response to our borders.  It is therefore important that we start preparing, in the medium term and even in the short term, a European response, particularly with regard to our borders, whether maritime, in the Mediterranean or land on the east side.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. –  Mr President, this is the second one I have asked, the same as other colleagues. Mr Rangel, you mentioned during your speech that you would like the UK to stay within the EU. That is a very commendable thing to say. The biggest single issue for the British people is control of the borders. Do you think that you could use as a silver bullet in the negotiations – to stop people like me who would like us to leave – giving us back 100% control of our borders? If you could give that back to the UK, as a sovereign nation, I am sure it would be very hard for people like me who want us to leave. Do you think that border control should be allowed to be discussed with the UK? Thank you for accepting my second question of the session.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – I appreciate your question, but it has an obvious answer: the UK already controls its borders, and controls them within the rules it has accepted, which are the rules of freedom of movement. Of course, if the UK wants to be in the European Union without freedom of movement, it cannot be in the European Union - then there is no alternative. Freedom of movement of persons is an essential freedom of the European Union and this cannot be called into question. Therefore, the United Kingdom controls its borders. If you want to be in the European Union, you have to guarantee freedom of movement for European citizens, not for others.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Guerrero asks for the floor to speak on a point of order.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, I did not wish to speak before on the point of order so as not to prevent Mr Etheridge's intervention. But I want to raise a general issue. It is already the second or third blue card that Mr Etheridge presents in this debate. And, if we take care of all the blue cards presented by the different Members, those who are harmed are the ones who are here since the beginning of the debate and have asked to intervene in the catch the eye. Therefore, as it is obvious that the Presidency has changed, what I would ask services to do is to have a list of blue cards so as not to continually give blue cards every time the presidency changes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Guerrero, indeed, you have said this: since I have sat here it is the first request you make. It is the first in order that has occurred of the three that have been requested and it will not be necessary to remember, among many other reasons because it would mean on the other hand a certain arrogance, that this is an issue decided by the presidency. Be that as it may, I take a very good note, and, I repeat, you yourself have said why Mr Etheridge was given the floor.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The sometimes chaotic conditions in some regions of our continent have a cause! The Member States have not done their homework for too long. There is no common strategy for refugee policy and no appropriate structures have been developed to take in refugees. Is this being made up now? The only visible common position I can see is foreclosure.  Mr Schmit, you are well aware that there are no legal routes for refugees! And yet you are insulting refugees as illegals and demanding that borders be protected. And what border protection looks like in Europe, we can see in Ceuta and Melilla, in Calais and in Hungary! Such action is pathetic, and it is also pathetic that we are now giving money to African states, specifically with the aim of controlling their borders. And it is also pathetic that suddenly Turkey is a great partner, which should please keep more refugees off our necks. And we should take note of the fact that refugees in Turkey cannot apply for asylum and are not allowed to work, and that, furthermore, Turkey is... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Regarding the wave of refugees, we need to be open to all those who flee from atrocities and criminality and who need to come to safety and security here. We need to combine that with firmness regarding our borders because that is a precondition for the handling of asylum. We need to reform in order to ensure that we can receive people and find them jobs so that they can be a part of society and also live where they arrive because otherwise we will have huge problems. But we also need to stabilise the situation in Syria and Iraq and in Ukraine. We need to deal with both these challenges. I would like to underline that there is one common denominator and that is the power play and aggression of Russia: in Syria, siding with the terror of Assad; in Ukraine, warmongering over another country’s borders and still proceeding to destabilise another country. We need to meet both of these challenges. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: question ("blue card"). Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Gunnar, you know what's happening in Sweden right now. We have a disaster. We have an influx of 2 000 migrants a day.  You're talking here about integration. We have had problems with integration for the last ten years. It's never worked. The situation is chaotic right now. You see how we've emptied all the homes. We've even had to build tent camps. In Sweden! And in Sweden it's cold in winter. So I do not understand how you can talk about how to integrate all that comes when it is more or less free, open doors to Sweden.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: answer ("blue card"). Thank you for the question. It reveals more than would be said, because my colleague from Sweden seriously believes that those fleeing the brutality, torture and executions of war should not be protected. That is what the refugee issue is ultimately about. We have shown in Sweden and Europe that we have been able to deal with this. I can address the House and say that in Sweden we took in a great many refugees from Bosnia. We made sure people got into work. They are today an important part of our society. That doesn't mean you should be out of control. But one should be open and, let me add, humane.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Mr President, the UK referendum was initially due to be the key item on the Council agenda. Now it only merits one sentence in the Draft Declaration. I realise that is due to the pressing refugee crisis, but there is also frustration at the lack of detail from the UK Government. To use Mr Juncker’s analogy, David Cameron seems like a dad at the school disco reluctantly trying to dance but an embarrassment to everyone – and that embarrassment is shared by many Brits.  Cameron has taken many months to provide any inkling of his demands. Some of what he suggests is sensible and in line with what the Labour Party has been arguing for for many years, but he has been ambiguous in other areas, not least when it comes to workers’ rights. That is despite the fact that guaranteed holiday and controlled working hours are one of the key reasons why many British people support staying in the EU.  So I want to ask the representatives of both the Council and the Commission: please, if David Cameron threatens working rights, make clear to him the damage this would cause to support for the EU. We need EU reform, but reform that works for the British people, not just the interests of David Cameron in managing his own political party.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian delegation also joins in the condolences for the families of the victims of the serious terrorist attack in Turkey. Moreover, Mr Juncker has just said that Turkey is a useful but difficult ally and partner. We agree with this position, because while Turkey welcomes refugees, who are mainly and almost exclusively Syrians, on the other hand we will be very cautious about possible visa liberalisation, because it could lead – and this is certainly a more than real risk – to a greater flow of migrants into Europe. We have also touched on the issue of increased resources with regard to migratory flows. The Council must be activated, but above all the Member States, which, like Italy, are making enormous efforts to manage migrants. I would like to remind you that in Italy, as the President of Frontex Leggeri said, 60% of immigrants are illegal immigrants.  The issue of detention for irregular migrants is of fundamental importance to us in order to guarantee, before removal, the physical presence of migrants. This is often not the case and real cooperation with the countries of origin is needed to identify irregular migrants and issue travel documents.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the next Council must put a final point, a firm point in immigration policy, both for emergency measures and for stable mechanisms, consolidating a new vision, but one that must be definitive, permanently focused on the common management of asylum and migration. Common management means costs that must be borne together, shared responsibilities between the countries of first arrival and the others. This also means the end of Dublin, which has now become an absolutely obsolete cage. It is not an act of generosity that some countries are asked – I would like to say this to my colleague who spoke earlier, to my Swedish colleague or to others – but it is simply the consequence of the fact that together we are Europe, and any new and serious events that happen in the East as well as in the South are a fact that must see a common responsibility to deal with it. My country, Italy, has been calling for these positions first and for some time. We have made miraculous efforts, as you know, but it is often pretended not to know in the European context, as Greece and other countries are doing.  We have called for this change and we are pleased that it has become a shared position today. But we must also have a long look, we must shift the prevailing focus of democracy and our diplomacy towards the Mediterranean and the Middle East, including with Turkey and Africa, because Europe's interests , and I would like to say Europe's peace and stability, are at stake in those countries and regions.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – It is good that the EU and Turkey are continuing to discuss a joint approach to the refugee issue this week. However, Brussels must not be held hostage by President Erdoğan's demand to relax membership terms in exchange for Turkish cooperation. That would be an unjustified reward for the democratic backlash in the country. The EU must be able to remain critical when it comes to human rights and freedom of the press. But if we are to reach a good agreement with Ankara, the EU must also have something to offer that actually eases Turkey's burden. Ankara is right to demand more financial support. However, it is not enough just to offer funds that had already been allocated to the country in the context of the accession negotiations. What about the financial support? Regulate the influx by setting up registration centres on Turkish territory. In this way, we help Turkey to share the burden fairly, but we also sideline people smugglers, prevent even more dramatic situations at sea and save a lot of money by already making a sifting of refugees and economic migrants outside the EU. Finally, I would like to warn President Juncker: please be careful not to link up with membership negotiations and a dialogue on migration. These are really two stand-alone processes.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Mr President, I address Mr Schmidt on the eve of the Council meeting, which must clearly decide to change the Dublin Agreement. In its current form, it is completely at odds with the temporary and permanent mechanism for the redistribution of refugees. It makes no sense, for example, for countries like Bulgaria for the next two years to redistribute 800 refugees, provided that 1,000 people enter the country per week, which under Dublin must remain in the country.  There is confusion and misunderstanding in society about the nature and functioning of the "hotspots". Citizens in Member States along the European Union's external border fear that their countries will become a kind of slum for migrants who will be detained in them, even if they do not want to stay. Europeans need an information and awareness campaign.  I would also like to address the Commission, although Mr Juncker is no longer with us. We must have a proposal for common border controls at the external borders of the European Union, not just the Schengen area. The additional budget and human resources for the European agencies FRONTEX, EUROPOL and EASSO are the first but insufficient step. We all have to deal with the migration crisis together, and European citizens will be our allies if they feel safe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I listened very carefully to the debate and particularly to what President Juncker had to say. I think that, while we might have been slow in responding initially, we were caught unawares. The European Union is making every effort to deal with this humanitarian crisis and I am quite sure the Member States are doing likewise. I know my own country, hopefully, is living up to its responsibilities. But we have to ask the question: why do the migrants want to come here? It is because of the pull factors: the quality of life, fundamental rights, etc. And why are they not going to countries like Russia, China or North Korea? I think this is something that should be borne in mind when people are criticising the European Union for its failings, rather than directing our gaze at those countries where the migrants would not want to go at all. And there are also, of course, as has been pointed out, the push factors. I am very pleased that we are now beginning to look at those and put measures in place to first of all bring peace to these countries and then help them to prosper.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, in this Parliament we have listened, sadly, to the testimony of Commission President Jean Claude Juncker, lamenting the deplorable image of the European Union in front of the television of his home, who does not even dare to see it. But it happens that the European Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and this Parliament is here to debate and even to vote, but also to require the Commission to enforce the Treaties and the conditions they impose on our external border: Turkey, the Balkans — but also the non-compliance Member States; and to be able to mobilisation the resources adopted in the Council and to enforce Council resolutions and conclusions.  European citizenship is dismayed by the drama of refugees, in the face of its humanitarian dimension, and it will not forgive the Commission for limiting itself, in the face of this drama, to waiting for one of its interlocutors or Member States to bring him out to tango.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the forthcoming European Council must lead to an intensification of efforts to ensure a sufficient and adequate response to the current crisis in the field of immigration and refugees. I hope that this meeting will actually represent that step forward, which Mr Juncker also called for today, which is important in defining a credible and effective European migration policy.  More support is needed for the Member States most affected by the arrival of refugees. In addition to the establishment of crisis points, the so-called 'hot spots', it is important that we succeed in ensuring that refugees are relocated quickly. Assistance must also be provided to the most urgent needs of refugees on the ground – in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey – and support must be given to the countries of the Western Balkans.  It goes without saying that an EU migration policy must respond to the causes of illegal migratory flows. We need a wide-ranging and long-term approach involving a shared effort by the European Union, together with the international community and the UN, to achieve a political transition in Syria and to defeat ISIS, two elements which, if overcome, would greatly reduce the flow of migrants to Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, tomorrow's European Council must take important initiatives on the refugee issue. Restoring peace in the Middle East and North Africa must be the Union's top priority. Turkey, instead of being part of the solution in Syria, is ultimately part of the problem, since it supports the DAES and facilitates the slave trade to transport thousands of refugees and illegal migrants to the Aegean islands. Turkey must therefore control its own borders and territory. But, as I said last week in Strasbourg, to the absent Mr Juncker at the moment, guarding the Greek border is Greece's sovereign right. We will not accept any co-management of our borders with Turkey, as Merkel demands, which must stop unacceptable interference on the top issue of control of Greek borders and now see the Merkel-Juncker duo that Greek sovereign rights are non-negotiable.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Mr. President, we must put our hand on our hearts and simply say to ourselves we were not prepared for this crisis, we were surprised by the refugee wave. Neither large countries nor small countries were ready for this crisis and unfortunately we have not shown this with solutions to this day.  And that's where I see the head problem. I can understand that the tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of people who have come to our borders have been a great surprise to us, but I can hardly understand that after so many months still the Council, the Commission does not have the answers to the end how to solve this problem in the long term, as this is a problem that will last for years. We just don't see a solution.  And that is why I want to take this opportunity to say that many countries that are not members of the European Union have done more than some members of the European Union. I mean the countries of the Western Balkans here, so please think carefully about how to help all of them in the future.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I thank you for your tolerance, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, this European Council will be another important meeting for the European Union at a time when it is struggling with its imperfections. Before the summer, you had to deal with the Greek affair, as the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished business. Today, you, as the European Council after the European Council, must deal with the refugee issue, since we have the Schengen area without having measured all the consequences.  I have the impression that this time, fortunately, you will focus in particular on the question of the relationship between the European Union and what is called our neighbourhood, that is, on our foreign policy. I invite you to be strong in this strategy, because it is the one that will allow the European Union to speak with one voice and to be present on the international stage at a time when so much unrest is erupting at our borders. There is good news, such as the Nobel Prize that Tunisia has just received, but there are also all these troubles on which Europe must express itself. We're counting on you!

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members, we all agree that the issue of refugees will accompany Europe for years to come. This is not a problem that has arisen and will disappear on its own. So let's be honest, some have just said this, and let's acknowledge that Europe has had a difficult start. We did not take the real, the right measure of the problem; hence the procrastination, hence the hesitations, hence the withdrawals. We can, we must regret it. However, I see that things have changed since then and that Europe has recovered. We have, in a short time, taken a number of important measures, which may still be insufficient, but it is a fact that Europe has reacted. One may, of course, ask why we did not foresee the problem or why we underestimated its magnitude. I think we all bear some responsibility, I say all, for not seeing the forces behind this phenomenon.  Today, it is clear that the time for action has arrived. As I said in my first speech, we need to act on two levels. First, the urgency. We cannot leave the refugees to their own devices, especially since winter is upon us, as some have said. Nor can we abandon the Member States or the countries, such as those in the Balkans, which are also hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees. We need to act urgently, and above all we need to plan for the future, to act in the medium and long term. I believe that this is precisely where Europe is struggling to move forward. It is like Greece, as you said. But the Greek crisis has made us grow a little bit. The refugee crisis poses the same challenge to us. We have to respond to it, we have to build what we have failed to build for years, because we thought that such a crisis could not happen.  On budgetary issues, I would like to rectify somewhat what has been said. At the end of this debate, you will adopt budgetary acts on the basis of the Commission's proposals. I believe that, as a co-budgetary authority, the Council has done its duty and approved these budgetary acts. That is to be welcomed.  With regard to the commitments made by the Member States, I believe that the message must be reiterated in order for the promises to be kept, so that all the commitments that have been announced are also followed up. But we also know the difficulties that some Member States are struggling with, and we know that things do not always happen as quickly as we would like. This is the case with the provision of public servants. This issue is extremely important if we want better border control, if we want hot spots to work better. I have been minister of immigration, and I know those situations where, suddenly, the number of asylum seekers is increasing. Look at Germany, which is expected to welcome hundreds of thousands of new arrivals. Look at Sweden, which is facing the arrival of tens of thousands of refugees. What can I do? You need officials on site. It is not enough to send a few to manage the "hot spots". So there is a complex organisational problem, which puts real pressure on the Member States. Again, the commitments that have been made must be implemented without delay.  As for other subjects, I will not return to Turkey, which I believe is an essential and fundamental partner. Therefore, the dialogue that we must have with this country must continue actively, in particular, but not only because of refugees. There is another aspect that we should not underestimate the importance of. This is the report of the five presidents and the deepening of EMU. Let us not believe that because the crisis situations have calmed down a bit, all this can wait, that there is no more urgency. Are we going to wait for the next crisis? No. When we look around, we see that the situation in the global economy is not very encouraging, not very positive. It was heard in Lima at the last meeting of the International Monetary Fund. There is now an urgent need to work to deepen the governance of the Economic and Monetary Union and to improve the governance of this EMU, extending it to areas where citizens are waiting for us. And where are they waiting for us? They are waiting for us on employment, they are waiting for us on social protection, they are waiting for us on their living conditions. Of course, that's a lot of work for Europe, but we can't choose the news. This is imposed on us, and it is in these times of crisis that Europe must face and show its ability to act. I am sure that the next European Council will take stock of these problems and the challenges ahead, and that we will come away with solutions, or at least with solutions that will better prepare us for this difficult situation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the completion of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that Mr Cameron wants to negotiate for the continuity of the United Kingdom in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. There will be no carte blanche.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the completion of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that Mr Cameron wants to negotiate for the continuity of the United Kingdom in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. First of all, I would like to add my voice to the condolences expressed by President Schulz for the victims of the Ankara massacre and for the families affected by this act of terror to which I express my full solidarity. The next meeting of the European Council is the fourth meeting, in just six months, devoted to the issue of migration. It is now clear that the management of this crisis cannot be left to the individual responsibilities of the States that are under constant pressure from these flows. "Hot spots", the points of crisis, are already a part of the response and Italy was among the first countries to implement one, but this measure must be followed by a common effort in the reallocation of refugees. In order to manage such a delicate situation, it is necessary to dwell on what is happening beyond our borders and to look at the origins of these phenomena – I am referring to what is happening in Syria and also in Turkey.  As Mr Juncker said today, what Europe is facing is a structural crisis that certainly needs immediate responses, but above all a long-term perspective. I think it is a good thing that it has been understood that this perspective cannot be found in an isolated and individual approach, but must be the result of a common effort.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the completion of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that Mr Cameron wants to negotiate for the continuity of the United Kingdom in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – In the last month, ministers and heads of government have met a total of seven times. But not for that reason the Member States have been able to do what is necessary to respond to the humanitarian emergency, having taken few steps and doing so late. I am referring to the relocation mechanism, which still faces resistance and problems on the ground and which is clearly insufficient; I am referring to the allocation of the European agencies with the most human and operational means, which is so necessary for the operationalisation of hotspots; I am referring to financial support for reception centres, which are coming soon.  I therefore hope that tomorrow the Member States will be able to give a clear political impetus for the implementation of these measures and other measures, and that we will actually be able to cope with the humanitarian emergency. Of course, we must not ignore what is at the root of this emergency. The diagnosis has been made for a long time and solutions have been presented for a long time. Now it is totally illogical that tomorrow's political impulse is for the long term, when we have not yet been able to resolve the present. We don't need catadup a measurements or media piroudes to simulate movement. We need to act!

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Tomorrow’s European Summit is another step in the right direction for the European Union, which is this time giving a clear indication on the need for better, stronger cooperation with countries of origin and transit in the light of the global international crisis, paired with the adequate protection of Europe’s borders. The crisis Europe currently faces cannot be seen in a vacuum, and Europe must up its game in terms of assessing the root causes of migration and ensure that European policies do not add to the push factors forcing people to flee. The Valletta Summit, to be discussed in tomorrow’s talks, can act as an opportunity to not only enhance our dialogue with our African Partners but also better understand the challenges growing African economies face, such as their own fight against criminality and human trafficking, in order to address this global issue in a comprehensive and holistic manner. This Parliament has been calling for internal solidarity in this field for many years now, and we have finally made great strides in this respect. It is now time to show external solidarity with our sister continent and tackle this global crisis with a global approach.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the completion of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that Mr Cameron wants to negotiate for the continuity of the United Kingdom in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should supplement this figure by contributing EUR 225 million to fulfil their obligations, as scroded by the Heads of State and Government. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal, in an integral way, with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the realization of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that your Prime Minister David Cameron wants to negotiate for continuity in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am watching with concern the discussion on the refugee crisis. I believe that the mandatory quotas on this issue, which are imposed on the Member States, violate the principle of sovereignty and subsidiarity. I regret that the European Parliament supported the measures adopted by the Council as a matter of urgency. On an issue so sensitive and with financial implications for the Member States, an in-depth discussion is needed, not a rush. In the face of this crisis, it is necessary to combat its causes in these countries on the ground, so that their citizens do not have to leave their homelands. Hasty ad hoc action will not solve the problem in the long term. Europe, and in this country I Polish, cannot afford to accept all immigrants.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The arrival of bad weather slows the flow of refugees, but worsens their situation. On a proposal from the EC, the EP and the Council approved EUR 400 million for refugee aid, but it is not sufficient and Member States should contribute EUR 225 million more to fulfil their obligations. In view of the 2016 budget, we should be more realistic and thus avoid repeating the Council's image by haggling around a few million euros affecting the dignity of millions of refugees. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with the refugee crisis, with a common position in Syria. As regards the requests to the Council, we must not forget to demand the completion of EMU in the face of external pressures which seek to weaken the euro. To this end, we need to coordinate economic policies within the framework of the European Semester to include growth, employment, investment and the social dimension as pillars of EU development. Finally, as regards the UK referendum, we expect further indications of the conditions that Mr Cameron wants to negotiate for the continuity of the United Kingdom in the European Union. There will be no carte blanche.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – One of the points to be addressed tomorrow by the Council is the reform of Economic and Monetary Union. Unfortunately, the direction of the proposed changes deepens the shortcomings of the current euro area (and the EU itself): on the one hand, the liberalisation and integration of the banking and financial sector into the European economy, without an even development of regulation, nor a harmonisation of European rules that ensures its control; on the other hand, the primacy of neoliberal and regressive economic objectives, with no greater mention of social objectives than that of granting a varnish of democratic legitimacy to the ordoliberal project. The direction of EMU reform should be another: ensuring public funding for States wishing to develop, democratically, policies other than those imposed on them by markets, using ECB support in secondary markets where necessary; strengthen the separation between credit activity and speculative activity; and ensure that the costs of bailouts fall on shareholders and not on citizens. Otherwise, divergences and discontent with EMU will increase, thereby digging its own grave.

name: David McALLISTER
text: in writing. – In the first half of 2015, more than 82 000 migrants from the Western Balkans applied for asylum in Germany. These migrants come from EU candidate or potential candidate countries that have a clear European perspective. We need to ensure that the right to seek asylum is respected for those in need of protection, while especially swift and effective return, readmission and reintegration policies for those who do not qualify for protection are put in place. To resolve the migration crisis for now and the future, the EU needs to agree on a Joint Migration and Asylum Policy. This policy should set one European procedure for asylum seekers and refugees, ending the discrepancies between national asylum policies. It should include one permanent and binding mechanism that ensures the fair sharing of responsibility to host asylum seekers and refugees, according to each state’s economic and social capacities. An agreement on a joint European list of safe countries of origin will relieve asylum systems and discourage further economic migrants. We have to stop the inflow of asylum seekers from the Western Balkans. The European Union needs to focus its asylum and reception capacities on those who are truly in need of protection.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. "All the walls will fall: today, tomorrow or after a hundred years". "Orban's fence will collapse like the Berlin Wall." "Europe was born to knock down the walls, not to build them". No, these are not Hungarian opposition politicians, but Pope Francis, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said recently. Today, there is no responsible politician in Europe who manages the refugee situation by building walls or deploying the army. The European history of the 20th century has taught us that the Iron Curtain, encircing ourselves, is not the solution, it only creates further tension. There is no high fence that is desperate to stop people who are going to save their lives and their families. There is no army that can take action against a traverse of fleeing families. It is our job as Europeans and Hungarians to take in those fleeing war, because we were refugees once. If we turn our backs on the troubled, the persecuted, we lose our humanity, our Europeanity. Today, europe, the European way of life, is not threatened by refugees, but by whipped national selfishness, by the surrender of our Europeanism and principles, by the politics of closed doors. Europe cannot be a fortress, the walls are not durable, sooner or later they will collapse.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I agree that the European Council will put the management of the refugee and migrant crisis, which is a historic challenge for the EU, at the heart of its October meeting, with a aim of strengthening the measures envisaged at the previous informal meeting. The Commission has proposed an appropriate package of measures and funding to the Heads of State or Government. Strengthening this and starting implementation is now urgent. However, I recall that, informally, eu unity for effective joint action has not been achieved because some European leaders, in particular the Hungarian Prime Minister, continue to prioritise their own political interests, undermining the common EU solution. I consider it urgent that, this time, EiT members recognise the danger of this and stand firm against the asylum practices and communication of Member States that degrade, inhumane and discredit refugees. This also requires that, as in the EP, the political responsibilities of leaders who, in contrast to the principles and commonly decided policies of their party families, openly attack the decided reception quota system, threaten the EU's efforts at the level of heads of state or government. In particular, I expect from this important EiT meeting that, in the wake of political pressure from the Member States and joint action by the leaders of the European institutions, the Orban government will also assume its share of the common European responsibilities on refugees, while at the same time end the manipulation of its domestic public opinion.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. – Europe in the speeches by Schmit and Juncker is a Europe that is unable to propose reforms to put an end to the refugee tragedy and which only recognises, months later, the need to commit itself to dealing with the ongoing migration crisis. A Europe still unprepared and disorganized, leaving Italy and Greece alone in the task of managing migrants. I would like to express my enormous concern: the management of emergency situations has put the problem of controls in the background, and the funds are often a business for the managing bodies of the centres and, in some cases, for organised crime. Often the money is given without invitations to tender and there are no systems for monitoring how they are spent. The European Agenda on Migration has highlighted the need for a global approach, but too little has been done in this respect. The burden of this humanitarian crisis continues to fall on a few Member States, without the solidarity that undersoes the European construct. We need a Europe that reformes the Dublin Treaty and implements assiduous control against fraud, that proposes solutions that respect the human rights of refugees and that knows how to act, more than talking.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – EU leaders will meet on 15 October 2015 in the context of the migration and refugee crisis in Europe. This will be the fourth European Council in six months that has focused on responding to the so-called refugee crisis. Once again we hear a chorus of good intentions. But in the face of such passivity, we ask where are the values of democracy and human rights proclaimed to the four winds by this European Union that is always entitled to teach the world lessons. The EU is complicit in the crises in Libya, Syria and Iraq. Just days ago we heard the laments of the United States about the Russian bombing sprees against terrorist units that had given the ClA so much work to create and form. The EU therefore has a moral duty, not only in the face of its responsibilities in the influx of refugees, but also in the name of the values it has to proclaim, to welcome all refugees with dignity and to create humanitarian corridors that cease with all these perfectly avoidable deaths that hurt our consciences.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. – The European Council must take brave and ambitious decisions to tackle the refugee crisis. The increase of EUR 400 million in the first 1990s and 1990s was a significant increase European funding is necessary, given the situation at the EU's external borders. Certain Member States, such as Greece, have lifted the greatest burden of the crisis, even though the problem is European. In addition to the collective effort required at European level, the EU must at the same time press third countries to cooperate and stop facilitating slave trade to transport thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants to European soil. The case of Turkey is typical. Turkey must cooperate with Europe in this area. But this must in no way mean any retreat of the EU from its fundamental values. Extortionate dilemmas, proposals affecting areas of national sovereignty, such as the proposal for the Turkish army to be present at European borders, and other absurd considerations cannot and should not be accepted by the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Gilles Pargneaux, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, entitled 'Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris' (2015/2112(INI)) (A8-0275/2015).

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, we say this and we must repeat it: we are facing the fight of the century. Yes, the fight of the century, for several reasons.  The first, if nothing happens and we fail to limit the rise in global temperature to a maximum of two degrees by the end of the century, we will see more droughts and floods, melting glaciers, and a decrease in agricultural land. It should also be remembered that climate change will be an aggravating factor in the migration problem. Today, year after year, we count 24 million displaced people and refugees, because of wars, dictatorships, but also because of climate change and climate change. Again, if nothing is done, we will have a temperature increase of 4.5 to 6 degrees by the end of the century and we will have 200 million climate refugees in the world.  We must overcome the failure of the Copenhagen summit at the end of 2009. This failure has been a trauma for all of us. We must therefore make the Paris conference a success. I believe that the report I am proposing for your review this afternoon, on which we will be voting this evening, is a report that will enable this success, which will enable Europe to be a model and a driving force at COP 21 at the end of 2015.  In this report we propose a universal and binding agreement. We have known Kyoto, where some, like the United States and China, did not want to be signatories. We have included ambitious climate targets for the planet and for Europe in this report. Firstly, the total elimination of global greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, but also the reduction of at least 40% of these emissions in Europe by 2030. We also aim to increase the share of renewable energy in Europe to 30% by 2030, as well as increase our continent's energy efficiency by 40%, again by 2030.  Without such goals, we will not trigger the paradigm shift we so desperately need to address climate change. Colleagues, as Laurent Fabius, French Foreign Minister and President of COP 21, recently said, I believe that the financial issue is and will be the cornerstone of the Paris Agreement. This is therefore a major focus of my report. We call for a clear roadmap from the states to see how each government intends to fund the $100 billion annual Green Fund from 2020. Public and private commitments currently generate $62 billion a year. States must now be clear about how they plan to reap the remaining $38 billion that will be missing each year within five years. Another proposal is the awarding of a global "carbon price" to ensure that the least polluting technologies are the most attractive to investors. We are also making proposals on the use of ETS funds to finance the fight against climate change. The price of ETS credits has fallen dramatically in recent years in Europe, rendering it unable to finance effectively the fight against climate change. As part of the ongoing revision of the directive, Commissioner, we must ensure that the price of a tonne of CO2 is raised significantly. Let us be well aware that we must give pledges to developing countries, which are most affected by the consequences of climate change.  In my report, I also wanted to highlight other avenues of success in Paris, including the revision of the Memorandum of Understanding every five years.  I would like to welcome the commitment of the French Presidency, but also of all parties, and I would also like to recall how climate change is an opportunity to initiate new economic growth in the world but also in Europe, green growth, and to put in place a new energy policy in favour not only of jobs but also of the purchasing power of the 500 million Europeans.  Finally, I thank the shadow rapporteur for the excellent work we have done together.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Pargneaux, and all the Members involved in the draft resolution we are debating today. The Paris Conference is a historic milestone in the international community's efforts to combat climate change.  In his State of the Union address to the European Parliament, President Juncker stressed that the European Union will not accept any agreement. As responsible for the European Union negotiations in Paris, my job will be to ensure that the European Union leads the negotiations and is not a passive spectator. And with this new global agreement we must start a dynamic process that allows us to effectively combat the risks of climate change and accelerate our global transition to a low-emissions and climate-responsible society. Ladies and gentlemen, a key challenge this year has been to ensure that the Parties to the Conference submit their national contributions on mitigation and adaptation. Today, one hundred and fifty Parties have submitted their respective contributions covering almost 90% of global emissions. The European Union was one of the first to do so with an ambitious emission reduction target of 40%. We have set an example for our partners and others are following us, but we have also carried out extensive international awareness work throughout the year, encouraging third countries to engage in global climate action.  In this context, we are witnessing a fundamental transition from the action of a few to the action of a majority. Comparing the contributions to date presented with the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, which runs until 2020 and covers only about 12% of global emissions, progress towards the Paris summit is remarkable.  Today we find that there is an obvious global political will at the highest level. I have just returned from the Forum on Adaptation and Mitigation Commitments that we have organized with Morocco's collaboration in Rabat, involving more than forty countries. I was particularly pleased that Mr Pargneaux took part in this forum, which has shown participants the importance this Parliament attaches to the Paris Summit. While we have found in this forum that the contributions presented to date are not sufficient to achieve the goal of limiting global warming below two degrees Celsius, the good news is that these contributions are already a big step forward and put the goal at our fingertips.  These contributions are more than just the drafting of mere numbers, they are real strategies developed at the highest political level and, moreover, if we take into account that many countries design and implement these climate plans for the first time, we realize the progress we are experiencing globally in climate action.  But the main question is how we make sure we get an ambitious agreement in Paris and how we define its success. In my opinion, the answer to these questions comes down to three essential elements. First, set a long-term goal.  Secondly, ensuring that the Paris agreement includes the flexibility to strengthen its ambition over time. Therefore, the new agreement needs to include a review mechanism that allows us to assess progress and strengthen emission reduction targets on a regular basis in the light of the latest scientific data available to us. Third, the agreement has to include provisions to ensure transparency and accountability because these rules will be the foundations of a credible international regime. Marking the goals we have a hard work ahead of us. Next week begins the last technical negotiating session in Bonn. In this session we will discuss a draft agreement which the co-chairs of the negotiations presented on 5 October. The good news is that the new text is shorter and more understandable. The least positive news is that the text is un balanced, lacks ambition and specificity in many respects—including transparency and accountability—it lacks a mechanism to dynamically increase mitigation ambition over time, and some key political issues remain open. That's why it's going to be a crucial negotiating session. Ladies and gentlemen, in order to be effective in these negotiations, the European Union must stand together and act with one voice. That is why I am pleased to note that in the draft Resolution, and after discussions in committee, there is a common basis between the institutions and the Member States. In this sense I consider it extremely positive that the draft resolution recognises the need for an ambitious agreement, of universal validity and legally binding. I share with you the conviction that the Paris agreement should promote an objective assessment system based on common and transparent standards that include provisions for its monitoring, notification and verification. And I strongly support the sustainable and dynamic draft Paris agreement. Finally, Parliament attaches great importance to climate finance in the fight against climate change in order to achieve the $10 billion target by 2020. Climate finance will be a key issue where the European Union also has an excellent track record. Important resources of the Multiannual Financial Framework will be earmarked for climate change-related projects abroad. We expect financial contributions to increase by more than double, reaching the amount of two billion euros per year.  And with regard to progress towards the overall target of one hundred billion dollars, I am pleased to note that the most recent estimates show that climate finance reached $62 billion in 2014, as indicated in the recent OECD report.  Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by stressing how important the European Parliament's support for the European Union's negotiating position is. The legally binding agreement must be ratified by Parliament. The outcome of the negotiations will be presented to this House for consideration and it is therefore essential that Members are associated and aware of the progress of the negotiations. In Paris, I will report personally to the Delegation of the European Parliament every day and instruct the Commission's negotiating team to provide Parliament with all the necessary assistance. But beyond the negotiations, experience in recent months shows how important it is for the European Union to remain the global leader in the fight against climate change. And that's why we need credible and effective national and European climate policies. And Parliament's role in this regard has been very valuable. I would like to thank you, once again, for your support and enthusiasm in strengthening climate policy in the European Union and in our global leadership in this area.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the AFET Committee. Mr. Vice President, I want to first thank Mr. Pargneaux for his excellent report, but of course Mr. Commissioner Cañete. On behalf of the Foreign Affairs Committee, I was obliged to express an opinion on this, and I am also a member of the Environmental Protection Committee.  We have committed to Article 3. treaty on solidarity and sustainable development of the planet Earth, and also by Article 191 TSC. Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we are committed to promoting measures to combat climate change. This is the moment to fix what we did wrong in Copenhagen and I simply want to believe that all of what we heard from the report today and what we have heard from the Commissioner's presentation will succeed in being realised. So the objectives simply have to be binding. If we do that, we've accomplished a lot.  But what I'm saying on behalf of the Foreign Affairs Committee is that the role of climate diplomacy needs to be reinforced. So the External Action Service of the European Union, as well as climate diplomacy, need to be more involved. When I talk about it, I mean the unified position of the countries of the European Union.  And just one more sentence. It would be very important, and we wrote that in this opinion, that when negotiating TTIP, everything that is agreed at the Paris conference is included because I don't think we will be able to negotiate TTIP without it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, I would like to use this opportunity to stress the strong link between COP 21 and the new sustainable development goals adopted last September in New York, with Sustainable Development Goal 13 about taking urgent action to combat climate change. When discussing future actions aimed at keeping the rise in global average temperature below 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels, we cannot ignore the fact that the least developed countries are not able to cover the costs of necessary investments in cleaner technologies. This is why it is important to keep in mind that the international community will have to share those costs. The report is right in saying that without the contribution of developing countries, our global efforts will fail. So the fight against climate change must remain one of the top priorities, both in our environmental policy and overall development cooperation policy. Por último, señor Presidente, quisiera agradecerle al Comisario Arias la excelente cooperación con la Comisión de Desarrollo en todos los temas en los que tenemos que cooperar, desde el desarrollo sostenible hasta el cambio climático.

name: Seán KELLY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, as rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), I want to thank my colleagues who helped me to get what I think is a very balanced opinion. I would also like to thank Mr Pargneaux and my friend and colleague Karl-Heinz Florenz for taking our opinion on board and incorporating it in the overall draft. Hopefully we will now get a strong mandate, going forward to Paris, from the entire Parliament, because global warming is something I think we all recognise is happening. We have to deal with climate change and we are going there with form, in the sense that we have given leadership in the past and we intend to do so into the future. But it is absolutely essential that the big emitters in particular come on board. If they do not, then we are actually wasting our time. So it is very important that we go and say that we have commitments and we are going to honour our commitments, but the other major emitters – and indeed all the other states of the world – have to come on board if we are to save the planet for future generations. So that is the target.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Pargneaux for drafting this own-initiative report, which also pays good attention to the transport sector, which is also still one of the sectors emitting the most CO2 – not only NOx if we are discussing a Volkswagen, but that is another discussion. I also think that it is very important that in this own-initiative report we are addressing very clearly the aviation and maritime sector, and directly related to that I have a question for the Commissioner, because next week in Bonn there will be negotiations on the new text that has been published. In that text there is no mention at all of the international maritime and aviation sector, which is something that needs to be corrected and I am counting on you, Commissioner, to correct that in the negotiations in Bonn or later on in Paris. Another thing I like very much in this report is the linking of the revenues to the Green Climate Fund, and that brings another question for the Commissioner. We know that the mandate for climate financing will be determined by the Ecofin Council in November. How can we make sure that Ecofin will deliver predictable and additional financing, because that is key and is also expected by the developing countries? That is something I think this Parliament report gives good suggestions for, so I would recommend that you also let that be picked up by Ecofin in November. Another very important point is to stress the five-year commitment period, which is also in this Parliament report; but I have not heard the Commission very clearly endorsing that. It would be good to hear that for Europe, too, it is indeed important to move to five-year commitment periods for the longer term because we all know now that we will not achieve the 2 degrees in Paris. You have also said this in interviews. So then it becomes very important that there will be reviews very quickly so that the ambition level can be ratcheted up, and I think a five-year commitment period is important and that Europe, for example, does not restrict itself only to 2030. These are some of the issues; there are many more in the report and they are very welcome too. One final point on the long-term target for 2050 – phasing out carbon emissions – mainly to my PPE colleagues. This has been Parliament’s standpoint for two years now. It would be a bad signal if now we were suddenly to change our position just a couple of weeks before Paris.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Rapporteur, thank you very much for your cooperation. I believe that this is a good report, even if it goes a little too far for us at one point or another, but we will put them on the right path. I believe that we must remind you once again that Paris is not such a normal climate event, but that we now have the very last chance to get a successor treaty from Kyoto. If we do not succeed in this, then the world community will in fact fall apart on climate policy issues. And then Europe in particular will suffer greatly, because then we will perhaps come back to national regulations. I therefore believe that the responsibility, Mr Caete, as you have just said, is exceptionally great for us, and we must seize this real opportunity now, also in the sense of competition policy. After all, if we do not get proper and ambitious regulation in Paris, carbon leakage will continue to exist in the future. And that is what we want to dismantle. We want to harmonise the competition rules so that Europe remains a powerful location, combined with the desire to achieve the two-degree target. I am therefore glad that we have not been able to present a Wischiwaschi text here now – the danger still exists today, but if we move in the right corner, that will not happen and we will be able to present a goal-oriented text. Of course, we need binding targets. That would be even nicer if we were not to propose binding targets here in Europe, but let us tell the South Americans to agree to a binding treaty, which is really illogical. So what we have written in terms of binding targets here is correct. I do not believe that we will have to change that by 2050, and that one or the other wish from my group will also play a role in this. All in all, Commissioner, you need an ambitious paper so that we can have an ambitious treaty so that competitiveness and the climate in Europe have a fair chance.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Climate change is a global problem, which is why we need global solutions. And that is why we must take every opportunity in the run-up to COP21 that this Conference of the Parties will also be a success at the end of the day. In order to do this, however, we also need to take a close look at sectors that have not yet taken part. Karl-Heinz Florenz has just mentioned carbon leakage. The cement producers, the aluminium producers, are all on the mat and want to claim carbon leakage in these areas.  However, we have sectors in the European Union that are completely excluded. That is air transport, that is shipping, and it is precisely in these sectors that we have the greatest increases in CO2 emissions, namely up to 200-300% in the aviation sector. That is why I would like to make a heartfelt request, Mr Canéte: once again, give it all in the place that we find it in a text at the end of the day. Otherwise, here in Europe, too, it will be very, very difficult for us to tell the steel sector, to say to the other areas: you must save, but we have exclusive competences for some sectors of the economy that may be on the move globally, that is right – in the case of Christian shipping, but also in air transport – but here we need a clear wording in the text. Otherwise it will be very, very difficult for us, with subsequent legislation. We have the ETS report on our agenda next year, which we must bring here through Parliament and through the institutions. I would therefore like to ask you to ensure that these two areas are brought into one document.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, there is much in this report that will unite us, I believe. The Green Climate Fund is absolutely core and we support that. We recognise that the Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) are falling short of the two-degree target and that more climate diplomacy is required to scale them up. We recognise that the Emissions Trading Scheme must be part of a global endeavour, not solely an isolated continental movement. The report is both original and good. Unfortunately, the original parts are not good and the good parts are not original. I have too many problems with the report, as it presently stands, to give my consent to this particular report. That pains me, because I believe we should speak with one voice in Paris. I believe we are stronger when we can do so, but I cannot do that. Right now we see again commitments put into this report that need not be there, that seek to divide us when we could be united, that indeed seek to put forward an agenda that need not be shared by all of us, and yet there is much that we do share. So I cannot endorse the report as it was drafted, but nor will I vote against it. I will ask that my group abstain on this. That saddens me, because I think that in reality we could have been stronger and I think we could have done more. This has been an unedifying experience and I would suggest we do not do it again in this manner.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
