text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I think we all know the immense importance of the climate summit in Paris – even the ECR, Mr Duncan – and it is absolutely crucial that we reach a very ambitious, legally-binding, comprehensive agreement there, an agreement that goes beyond the INDCs that are being collected now – because we all know that, if we add them up, we will never stay below the 2 degrees centigrade, as the Commissioner has already said. One of the crucial elements, again, will be international climate finance, and it will maybe be the sole case that can make or break the agreement in Paris. Europe could be the broker of such a deal, but unfortunately, in the Council mandate for Paris, the climate commitments after 2020 are missing. Apparently there was no agreement yet, when the climate ministers came together in September, among the Ministers of Finance for this very crucial finance. In our own Parliament’s resolution, we do mention it. We set aside a number of allowances from the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) to create a fund, an EU international climate action reserve that will raise revenues in a fair way and will create a fund independent of national governments. I think that is a crucial element of our resolution. As mentioned before, in November the ECOFIN Council will come together, and I urge our Ministers of Finance to seriously look into the suggestion made in this Parliament’s resolution. Just like the others, I would like to urge the Commissioner to be present there and to make sure that ECOFIN copies that suggestion.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I would like to draw attention to the large and damaging role played by the lobby of the business community in the drafting of the climate agreement at the end of this year. The extent of this role became painfully clear to me when I heard that aviation and shipping had been removed from the latest draft of the climate agreement, whereas these sectors together account for as much as 8% of CO2 emissions. Moreover, that proportion is only growing. There are more such examples. The same draft shows that we no longer want to phase out fossil fuel subsidies. The fossil fuel industry is engaged in a large-scale greenwash action to divert attention from its major contribution to global warming. And then there are the official sponsors of the climate conference: Renault-Nissan, Coca Cola, GDF Suez, Avril, all big polluters. It seems as if a number of parties do not realize that it is all hands on deck. This kind of company is like the orchestra on the Titanic that keeps playing on to earn an extra pocket money before closing time. In fact, they're turning a few more strokes at the helm toward the iceberg because they think they'll earn more when the ship is right on the setting sun. It is absurd and totally irresponsible. The COP 21 conference is open to all. Unfortunately, it is not possible to keep all lobbyists out when legislation is being legislated, as the World Health Organisation does with the tobacco industry. Let us, however, insist very hard that full transparency is being worked on and that as much attention is given to civil society organisations and citizens as to the lobby of the business community. (The president interrupts the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I have had one blue-card request but, colleagues, I will have to refrain from admitting blue—card questions because we are already running late. I ask you to respect that.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, today we vote on our report concerning the climate agreement in Paris. At the moment, when the environmental credibility of the European institutions has been shaken by scandals within the car industry, I find it extremely important to send a very strong signal with this report.  The report itself is a strong signal, and I would like to thank Mr Pargneaux, our rapporteur, for that. Still, there are some important considerations to raise. Being ambitious is not merely a question of restoring Europe’s credibility; it is also a scientific necessity if we want to limit climate change to two degrees. Evidence shows us that we need to phase out carbon emissions by 2050 to limit climate change to two degrees, and it is possible, but without this phasing out it becomes an illusion to put us on a track which keeps us below the two-degree target. That is why I am deeply concerned about the amendment tabled by the PPE Group, because I believe that if we water down our commitment to decarbonisation till 2050, we will step on a track which takes us beyond or above the two-degree limit. Also it is important to mention that the INDCs which we already have are clearly not enough to reach our goal of keeping climate change below the two-degree target. This means that we need mechanisms to raise ambition within the European Union and at global level at the Paris talks. One last point: to phase out CO2 emissions, the first step for that is to phase out fossil subsidies, and that is something we have to do very soon.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been involved in the drafting of this report and I believe that it is a good report because it shows Parliament's willingness to move forward in the fight against climate change. These are words written in black and white, but they are still words. On the way to Paris we have heard many more and we will hear many more.  The European Union describes itself as a leader in the fight against climate change, but the policies of its Member States often contradict its commitments and declarations. We are afraid of the consequences of global warming – they are now a daily story – but at the same time we are financing its main cause. According to an International Monetary Fund report last May, global subsidies to oil companies are over $5 trillion, $5,300 billion to be exact, $5,300 billion in coal, oil and gas financing, mostly from advanced countries. Perhaps we are not mainly responsible for this huge gift to the oil lobbies, but the European Union is certainly also involved, which provides EUR 330 billion a year in subsidies, but also in financing infrastructure, gas pipelines and deposits through the European Investment Bank. The International Monetary Fund also tells us that if we cut these 5 trillion subsidies globally, we will achieve an immediate 20% reduction in global emissions and free up in a virtuous flywheel resources that would lead to 3.5% growth in world GDP. The real question, then, is whether we are prepared to go against the fossil fuel lobby. We are talking about COP 21, but in the meantime the race to the fossil continues, and indeed the interest seems to be renewed. Even laughable resources, such as those in the Adriatic Sea, attract and ingest the oil companies, which are trying to dig the bottom of an increasingly scarce barrel, to the complacency of national governments. After the failure of Kyoto and the inconclusive global climate policy of recent years, the Paris Conference must lead to a binding agreement on reducing emissions. Without the commitment to an energy revolution, however, it will not be enough.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the COP 21 Mass is likely to be a failure again. European countries are expected to bear the burden of the world on the environment. However, for years, Europe has effectively reduced its greenhouse gas emissions. Yes, we have invested, built and developed innovative, clean and sustainable structures. Everything to please, but some here seem to forget an important point, it is reality. Do not displease, the effort has cost European industries dearly. We could agree to a binding agreement on the condition that as many countries in the world as possible participate, because the heart of the problem is to make coordinated and shared efforts. However, for years, emerging economies have been polluting on a large scale and many of them have refused to join binding agreements on the pretext of preserving their economic development. Ladies and gentlemen, rather than incantations on reducing rising temperatures, let us seek a balanced and broad agreement, let us not break our industries and our competitiveness. Reality is not decreed, they are imposed.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – First of all, the European Union should clarify one question: in hindsight, looking back at the Paris climate conference, when will it classify it as effective? It is clear from this report that there is one main objective, to prove that the European Union should no longer be the engine and frontrunner in the fight against climate change, and we are now setting more ambitious targets.  It states that by 2030 the 40% reduction is only a lower limit and by 2050 the total elimination of CO2 emissions. These objectives are unrealistic and do not achieve the desired results. They are unrealistic because they do not take into account the economic impact, the costs, the impact on energy costs and they are not reaching the target because it is a global problem. The European Union is responsible for 9% of emissions, while the United States and China are responsible for 35%, so they should be persua subject to mandatory emission reductions, and this is not mentioned once in these 82 points.  The other aspect is that nuclear energy is not included as the energy that triggers fossil energy and is clean in terms of climate change. In these 82 points, this is also unacceptable.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Some of the contributions– perhaps many – here in the debate are a little pessimistic to me. Of course, we have to make an effort, of course it will be difficult, and the result in Paris will probably not be as perfect as we as the European Union would like. But we have a historic opportunity: we have 140 countries that have already announced targets and are already preparing for implementation, including China and the United States. We have a very promising decision from the G7. We have support, for example, through the Pope's encyclical. It is a historic opportunity to really make great progress. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports the Pargneaux report. We would like you to include three more amendments. Then I would also like to respond to the Greens. There is no point in making utopian demands here. Decarbonisation by 2050 is not realistic. What was decided at the G7, what the PPE-DE has submitted, was generally welcomed, including by environmental associations. Why do we not want to decide on this? I would like to emphasise very strongly the point made by some colleagues on aviation and maritime transport, and then make a precise argument: if we implement our climate policy, lime, cement and steel producers will have to reduce 40%, and in some cases even more. They will no longer be able to use CDMs – international loans – and at the same time, icaO is talking about a reduction in air traffic. That must change, and that is why I support all those who have called on the Commissioner to bring this into the process in Paris.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Madame la Présidente, je veux d'abord remercier Gilles Pargneaux pour son excellent travail. I would like to thank Gilles Pargneaux for his excellent work and hope that this report can count on a very broad majority. Perhaps the ECR will have to think carefully before the final vote. After all, it is very important that we act as united as possible if we are to maintain our leadership role. Normally, the arguments should be obvious. If the earth continues to warm, we will not only be faced with terrible environmental disasters, but we will also see a population movement that is fading today's refugee crisis. Studies say 200 million people will flee. If you look at how difficult we are today, I think there is a reason to all support a good report by Gilles Pargneaux and a climate agreement. Finally, I would like to make one more important argument. Above all, we must continue to play our leading role. It's not enough to lecture the rest of the world. We must try to reach an agreement, but also and above all we must deliver on our own initiatives and our own clear objectives on renewable energy and energy efficiency.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I do not support this proposal because, like most of the documents coming out of the ENVI Committee, it sides with a pragmatic approach to the subject, rather based on demonising coal and imposing a move away from the use of this raw material by the Member States. Such projects violate the principle of neutrality and undermine the competence of Member States to decide on the structure of their energy demand. The fact that emissions can be changed pragmatically without excluding any source of energy shows the example of Japan, China, India, which are spreading technologies of supercritical coal combustion, which leads to emission reductions of up to 30-40% and significantly improves the efficiency of the blocks. This can be of colossal importance for countries for which emission reductions pose a threat to energy security, as is the case with Polish. Unfortunately, the text of the ENVI report does not even allow this option. This data can be found in a report by the Centre for Clean Coal or the International Energy Agency. I therefore do not agree with the restriction of energy Polish, because energy security equals national security in Poland. One of the most frequently used words in Parliament is solidarity. Why is it not present in the Polish coal economy?

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Madam President, when in 1998 we recorded the warmest year in modern history, there was still an easy way out. At that time we could explain that this was just an outlier in statistics and we could go back to normality and not worry about the future. When we look at the statistics of global warming and the temperature in the world today, we see that during the last 10 years we have had a steadily rising tendency. There is no longer an easy way. But we have one problem, which has already been alluded to by other speakers, namely how to finance it. With an unstable tax base, we see a tendency for Member States to use income from emission rights to substitute a tax base which does not function. We have to fix it.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Madam President, twenty years of summits, ten years of emissions market and no real solution addressing the causes of climate change. The sale of emissions bonds is a speculative, poorly designed market that has generated a huge bubble. Sometimes, moreover, this mechanism has only benefited the most polluting industries. Ladies and gentlemen, we are playing with the health of the planet and the people. The consequences are already disastrous. The loss of biodiversity, the flooding of small island states and the lack of water and food for millions of people are a reality. That is why we demand the exclusion of false solutions for the Paris summit such as the price to CO2, the RED plus system, carbon capture and storage or fracking.  Ladies and gentlemen, curbing climate change will only be achieved by developing a new production model based on renewable energy. This is a historic occasion. Please take advantage of it for the good of the planet and for the good of mankind.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As gender coordinator in the Environment Committee ENVI, I welcome this report and the wordings that are now on gender equality and human rights. I would like to thank the rapporteur for including the amendments I have tabled with other Members who also want a fair and equal climate agreement. Respecting, protecting and promoting human rights and, in particular, gender equality, the full participation of women under COP 18 will be crucial if we are to meet the enormous challenges we face. Technological innovation will not be enough. The only way forward is social and economic innovation. If we are to fix the climate, we must have sustainable and fair development. We cannot have fair development without equality. That is why we must now fight to ensure the financing mechanisms of the agreement and to fairly allocate resources to women's adaptation needs in the countries most affected.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, good science is based on observation. One swallow may not a summer make, but the arrival of a Bewick’s swan 25 days earlier than expected at the excellent Slimbridge Wildfowl Trust in my constituency is always seen as a harbinger of a severe winter. The fact is that lots of people choose to believe theories which are, at best, not proven. After regular rising temperatures, which may also correlate with sunspots, the rise has stalled. It is not happening. Antarctic ice is growing again. Paris is based on crude modelling. The long-term evidence is of oscillations to patterns lasting thousands of years, and the pursuit of this chimera is costing jobs and investment – but only in the UK and the EU, as the climate change theories export them to China and other developing countries. The developing countries will laugh at us, refuse to sign our agreements and profit at our expense. I prefer to believe the Bewick’s swans. They are leaving Russia early because it is too cold.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – Soon thousands of people will be flying to Paris to talk about the climate while enjoying a glass of champagne. Mr Eickhout will of course be there again. At the end, we will have to see that this is going to be another fiasco, just like in Copenhagen. That is not so difficult to predict, because everything the EU deals with is going to be a fiasco. Whether we are talking about the Greek crisis or the refugee crisis, it will be a fiasco. But – and this is good news for Mr Eickhout – there is also something the EU can do well, namely the burning of tax euros at a huge rate. That's why I'm asking you to stop this pointless mission. Stop this climate summit and give the money back to its rightful owner: the people who pay taxes.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, once again we are discussing global warming today, as so many other times. Once again, we will be voting on a text with which, more or less, we all agree. However, in order to be able to improve the current situation we need something much more drastic than another agreement. Even if we manage to have an agreement in Paris, its implementation will run into insurmountable obstacles. The recent Volkswagen scandal shows that European companies do not respect the decisions and agreed in the European Union. I believe that the Union needs to change its strategy and behave much more aggressively. The candidate countries, as well as any other country wishing to have trade and other economic relations with the Union, must comply with European environmental protection rules. Countries with huge production, much of which is exported to Europe, such as China and India, are obliged to protect the environment and their refusal to mean the closure of our market in their products. In any case, the protection of the planet concerns us, but especially for future generations. We can no longer content ourselves with beautiful words, we demand actions and we demand them immediately.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – There is no doubt that, as a result of human activity, we are having a negative impact on the climate, that we are promoting global warming. I think it is very clear that we need to act. It also seems right for me that the European Union is taking the lead in the world by showing by its example how others should act. My concern is that if Europe takes the lead, it is important that we are also followed. Let us think about the title of this report, the international climate agreement in Paris. It is very important for us in Paris to ensure that the rest of the world, especially the US, China and India, is following us, because they are the main environmental, natural pollutants that contribute to these CO2 emissions and global warming. So, if we do not get to follow up to understand the consequences, it can come to this way that Europe, by imposing on its industry the need to reduce emissions, actually reduces their competitiveness. For us to remain competitive, others need to follow us.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, today I am hearing the words ‘idealistic’ and ‘realistic’ as though these are two opposing issues at the extreme ends of the same line. Why can we not act by being ambitious and realistic? They are complementary to one another and not contradictory to one another. Climate change is a global problem with grave implications, its worst impact being felt by the most vulnerable and poorer countries, and whilst technological advances will help, each and every one of us has the strength and power to change things. I am proud that back in 1989 Malta put climate change on the agenda of the UN General Assembly. That is why arguments that we can wait for another century or so to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are totally unacceptable to me. We cannot wait any longer. Time is of the essence. I am convinced that the Commission understands this and can continue to be the key player fighting for a really ambitious and legally-binding global agreement.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, the Paris meeting will be vital in establishing the way forward for the world’s climate. Yes, Mr Gerbrandy, even the ECR agrees with this. We want to be ambitious. We want to be united. But given that this motion calls on the President to forward it to the UNFCCC with the request that it be circulated in Paris to all non-EU parties, this causes confusion. This is unfortunate. It is one thing to communicate to the Commission whether Parliament takes a different view, but I believe Europe should approach Paris with one voice.  My Group cannot support calls for binding targets on energy efficiency and greenhouse gas reductions beyond those already agreed. I do not think it is helpful to have a position that prescribes the earmarking of ETS revenues, as this report requires, when this is not agreed. I believe we should go forward with one voice, and this report is not helpful in that regard.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I think there's some fateful atmosphere in here. Some people think we're heading for the end of the world at a fairly brisk pace. Others believe that nothing will happen. I can reassure both sides that you will be disappointed. What must be the objective of our aim with the Paris Agreement is to include as many countries as possible. So that it does not turn out as when we adopted the Kyoto Protocol once upon a time, which only covered the equivalent of 16% of the world's emissions, without covering as much as possible. The second and perhaps most important thing, which we also learned from the Kyoto Protocol, is that we beat the goals we set ourselves there by horse lengths. We have gone much further than the targets set. I believe that technology will prove that we are not politically mature to take decisions other than on things that we know about today. It is therefore important that we should also have the opportunity to come back, to upgrade the agreement every five years at the latest, which I believe is the only way to keep up to date. That's what's going to make us meet the 2°C target. Not the Paris meeting itself.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Many thanks also to the rapporteur. The situation is serious and it is therefore urgent that all CO2 polluters be included in the climate negotiations. But there is far too little talk about one of the biggest climate killers: CO2-equivalent emissions from global livestock farming. A few figures: there are about 1.5 billion cattle on Earth. A beef emits about 400 litres of methane gas per day; 1.5 billion cattle, yields 600 billion litres of methane gas per day. If I multiply the result by 25, because methane gas is just twenty-five times more harmful to the climate than CO2, I come to 15 trillion liters of CO2 per day.  So, to exclude mass animal husbandry in the climate negotiations is simply scandalous. That is why I appeal: mass animal husbandry must be on the agenda in order to achieve the climate targets. If that is not the case, then I can only say that steak is more important to us than the climate, and then we can say: meal!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, I would like to call on the EU to be very strict in endorsing a human-rights-based approach to climate policies. This is an important aspect of climate policy as we need to make sure that climate mitigation activities, including climate financing, do not cause environmental and social harm to people, including the impact on indigenous peoples and their environment and livelihoods. Many multilateral development banks do have such safeguards on environmental and social impact, but unfortunately the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) does not have any. In this respect, close to 100 organisations and several MEPs have written to the CDM Board to make sure that they will put in place such safeguards on human rights in their policies. The UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights and the Environment endorsed this letter just a couple of days ago.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, well here we go again. Paris. Another UN climate conference: as ever, high hopes disappointed, commitments below expectation, delivery below commitments. We should remember that there is still a great deal of uncertainty about climate theory. It is not clear that the rise in atmospheric CO2 is anthropogenic or that atmospheric CO2 has anything like the effects postulated by the IPCC. Nor is it clear that the climate policies we are pursuing will have any material effect on levels of atmospheric CO2, or indeed on the climate, but it is absolutely clear that we are utterly unable to predict future changes. All the predictions so far have been falsified by the data, and it is clear that our climate policies will do far more economic damage than anything that could be conceived as a result of climate change. It is time to question our hysterical obsession with the new religion of climate alarmism.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If we do not know what is going on, it is almost always about money, and in this case it is about the big money that is in the subtext of this debate. We need to be aware of this in order to understand the phenomenon we are talking about. It is the case that co2 emission limits have been set – carbon dioxide emitted by human activities is of little importance to nature and to the content of this carbon dioxide in nature, but is of great business importance. Well, countries that have developed before are benefiting from those limits that have already been reached and would now want to charge carbon pricing from countries that are just about to develop. So rich countries want to maintain their wealth at the expense of the wealth charged to those countries that just want to grow – and that is the essence of the problem, and that is what we need to understand.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, when we decided to draw up this own-initiative report in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we thought that this debate was necessary in order to also give a mandate to the European Parliament delegation to the Paris Conference. We have had an in-depth debate – and I thank Mr Pargneaux for the great work he has done – and we have found shared mediation with regard to a text that clearly needs to be ambitious. Commissioner, we are well aware of how Europe has guided the process in the fight against climate change, and in Paris we must continue to look at ambitious solutions. We must force the hand of those countries that have not yet believed, and the targets communicated for the reduction of emissions from 140 countries are certainly a first result achieved. We must continue along this path, aware that only if there are strong commitments from all major polluting actors can we continue along this path. On the other hand, to those who are concerned about reducing the competitive capacity of our system, I say that we will not have to see what we can do until after Paris. Then we can decide.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, December’s climate talks in Paris are an opportunity for us to make a positive impact on the future lives of millions of people in the EU and billions across the world. It is vital that we secure a comprehensive global and binding agreement, based on the IPCC’s two-degree target, providing a clear plan to tackle dangerous climate change. At the heart of that agreement, we need to ensure that social justice is there in the changes to come and that a just transition is guaranteed to a cleaner future. By creating decent jobs, inspiring people to innovate and transform their own workplaces and communities, whilst ensuring social security in times of change, we guarantee the public trust and support needed to tackle dangerous climate change. This opportunity must not be lost. I support the report and I ask people to support Green Amendment 12.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In 1997, I attended the environmental conference in Kyoto with the then Environment Minister Angela Merkel, and at that time we both campaigned for specific and not absolute CO2 targets. Meanwhile, Mrs Merkel wants to save the global climate. It is in the rescue at all: it wants to save the euro, it wants to save Greece – three times, it wants to save the banks through the European Banking Union at the expense of the German savings banks, and now it wants to save the world refugees. Ladies and gentlemen! More and more foreign colleagues in this body are also showing and telling me that Mrs Merkel and the Federal Government seem to be suffering from helper syndrome. This must be stopped! May I take this opportunity to say once again that Europe should not make any further progress in the German nature. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I would like to draw attention to the fact that the single euro europe must be divided and abolished.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, I have got a point of order, because we had a Labour MEP who was not being given the opportunity to be held to account for the legislation that her government implemented that cost the jobs in Redcar in one of their constituencies. Legislation created from this place... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Aker, this is definitely not a point of order. I will continue with the list of speakers.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, $100 billion will have to be mobilized by 2020 for developing countries just to combat climate change. In one go? No, every year. Developed countries have pledged $62 billion at this stage, plus $15 billion announced by the World Bank, the African Development Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. What these figures do not reveal is that, first, we may not be able to mobilize the remaining $23 billion. If that were to be the case, there would be only a month and a half left to do so. Second, if this can be done, it would be likely that substantial amounts would be taken from development funds. I would therefore like to call on both the Commission and the Member States to act in such a way that the European contribution is added to official development aid. Can the Commission make a solemn commitment to this?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, at the next UN Climate Conference we must reach an agreement that must be implemented by all. However, in order to achieve this, the commercialisation of the land must cease. Substantial targets must be set to tackle climate change and to meet the needs of society. Unfortunately, the Volkswagen scandal has proved what we all knew, that large multinational companies, with the complicity of certain governments, are promoting their self-interests at the expense of society and public health. It's not an isolated incident. It is why strict control measures must be taken immediately but also to put the interests of people and the environment above the interests of multinational companies. Then the European Union, and in particular the rich countries, must take the lead in finally implementing the commitment to create a green financing fund for developing countries, because that is the only way these countries can adapt to new climate change. That's the only way there's going to be a chance to save the planet.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have no doubt – global warming must be stopped, but this is the global problem. We will only solve it if the countries that emit the most greenhouse gases join our efforts. Only then will the European Union become a real leader. A leader is someone others follow, and now it looks like we're a lonely long-distance person. The lack of an effective, legally binding global climate pact, on the one hand, puts the EU economy at risk of declining competitiveness, job losses, especially in energy-intensive sectors, and, on the other hand, it also undermines the meaning of our climate efforts, for the climate in the European Union, which the Union has been undertaking for a long time.  COP 21 must therefore conclude with an agreement in which the rest of the world commits to efforts tailored to those of the EU. Otherwise, we will have to think seriously about our EU climate targets and our global partners, whom we want to convince the agreement, should know this; we should inform you that we do not want to combat climate threats alone.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the whole world looks forward to Paris. The excellent work done by Mr Pargneaux gives us a strong report, clear in its objectives, realistic because reality and facts tell us that we must change course. What still needs to happen to understand that decarbonizing the economy is not a fixation of cavemen who want to block development and progress. That is why we must insist on progressively reducing incentives for coal mining and shifting these resources to renewable sources, energy saving and energy efficiency. That is why I still believe that sustainable development does not rhyme with new drilling. Realism means not putting your head in the sand. Earth's resources are not unlimited. To maintain our Western standards of well-being we need to change. We cannot continue to use one and a half minutes' resources in a year. This is the challenge of the circular economy: to produce 30% using resources at its best.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, too. It is essential that we MEPs talk with a united voice on this crucial issue for the future of our planet. In Paris, I want us to get a binding international agreement for as many people as possible, and in particular for the most emitting countries. But this agreement will have to be realistic. Indeed, just because there will be an agreement in Paris does not mean that we have found the solution to climate change and its attendant disturbances (floods, hurricanes, droughts) that we are seeing more and more frequently. This summit can only be considered a success if we get concrete solutions and binding commitments. The best way to succeed in Paris is to be ambitious and pragmatic. The European Union must not be the only one to act. We account for less than 11% of global CO2 emissions. Without a concrete commitment from our partners, our efforts will be of no use. I would also like to mention the importance of credible funding, because, as we all know, money is the nerve of war. That is why I am calling for support for innovative financing and increased private sector participation. Finally, I would like to reiterate the importance of not stigmatizing certain sectors. I believe more in affirmative action than in punitive action. On the other hand, it will be necessary to make it clear that everyone must participate. In this regard, the association of non-state actors alongside governments is paramount in climate action.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Madam President, just two weeks ago in New York, world leaders signed up to 17 global goals for sustainable development to end poverty, combat inequality and tackle climate change. The goals are ambitious and set a strong foundation for a sustainable future. COP 21 in Paris is the first big test of whether governments are serious and will turn those words into action. Without a binding global agreement in Paris and concrete financial commitments, the Sustainable Development Goals have little chance of becoming a reality. The poorest are already paying the price of climate change in many developing countries and, as Charles Goerens has said, we must help them pay for adaptation. Therefore, I welcome the words in our resolution on climate finance. As President Hollande told us last week in Strasbourg, Paris is make-your-mind-up time. There is no second chance because we do not have a second planet.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union has demonstrated its commitment to protecting the planet and from climate change. We have led successive Conferences of the Parties and have adopted effective policies to reduce emissions in recent years. We are also committed to meeting emission reduction targets in the coming years.  But what we now need is an international agreement with commitments made by all parties. That is why it is important to come up with a balanced solution, so that all large countries contribute according to their responsibilities and capabilities. Objectives must be mandatory and ambitious, but they must also be realistic and achievable. We cannot allow our industry to be relocated or induced to resort to other strategies such as the so-called 'Volkswagen case' in order to comply with the regulations. In this sense, greater integration of European climate change and air quality policies is desirable.  This Resolution has broad consensus and is a clear support for the work of the Commission and a focus on reaching good agreement for the environment and also seeking a level playing field for the competitiveness of enterprises.  Finally, I would like to wish good luck to the fifteen Members who make up the delegation at the Paris summit and, of course, to you, Commissioner. I'm sure they'll make an important contribution to it on behalf of all of us.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Many people talk about climate change as if it were something that would happen in the future, but the fact is that they are hitting people today. I met the Marshall Islands Trade Minister in the spring and he was able to tell us how this small country, which is, however, a large maritime nation, was already hit by more storms in May than is normally the case throughout the storm season, i.e. in the autumn. People are affected today. We run the risk that many people will be forced to flee in the future if we do not act resolutely. I would therefore like to thank our rapporteur for this clear own-initiative report. It contains very clear and ambitious objectives. I am particularly pleased that we need binding energy efficiency and renewable energy. I would like to highlight, as a call to Commissioner Arias Cañete, who is here today, that we must also include shipping and the aviation industry, which is now excluded from the text. Work hard to ensure that these are not excluded. It sends negative signals to all those who have to work hard for a...

name: Ivo BELET
text: I would like to congratulate fellow rapporteur Gilles Pargneaux first and foremost. It is to his credit that we can go to Paris with a broad and strongly supported position. I think we agree that all sectors must make efforts: transport, construction, industry and power plants. But, of course, it will also be driving and looking at it, and above all, ensuring that the competitiveness of our European energy-intensive industry is not compromised. I am sure, Commissioner, that this is also one of your concerns. That is why we must, among other things, go all out to link our unique European emissions trading system to similar models on other continents. That must be one of our goals: a global emissions trading system. This is one of the best tools for achieving low-carbon production. We must, of course, be and remain a leader and also make it clear that this presents enormous opportunities for our industry. I wish the Commissioner every success in Paris and we are counting on him, of course.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Madame la Présidente, je tiens à remercier le rapporteur, M. Pargneaux, pour son travail ... I am glad that the Commissioner has not been consulting the same oracle birds – the swallows, the swans or whatever other mystical bird UKIP has been consulting – when it comes to climate change, and that he intends to follow an ambitious programme here, because that leadership role is absolutely crucial. I believe him when he says the EU must maintain a leadership role. But we do have a risk of undermining that role if we do not take into account the principles that were agreed just a few weeks ago in New York in discussing the Sustainable Development Goals. That means that the principles of a just transition, which apply of course to those sectors that will be affected most by a transition to a low-carbon economy, apply also to developing countries, and we have to put that principle right at the heart of things. Some good text was removed in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and I regret that, but there is a chance now to vote to put that text back in. I support the report and I support those amendments which will do just that. (Applause)

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: – Hopefully a climate agreement will be concluded in Paris, but we are far from that. Today we are talking here in Parliament about our ambitions in relation to this agreement. Sustainability is the new key word in politics, but also in business. It's hot. That is exactly what we should be doing if we really want to get a result in Paris. We need to keep everyone on board. As politicians, we must recognise that there is no contradiction between an ambitious climate agreement and a liveable environment for our businesses. It's not "or" but "and and" The Pope has also called for this. Now, as politicians, let us lead by example. Our own European business community is calling for an agreement. Our companies need to work on this and don't know where they are at. All sectors must be involved in achieving the goals we have set, otherwise we will not get there. We must not let today's jobs and the economy and those of our children disappear from Europe. Now a great opportunity is given to...  (The president interrupts the speaker)

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, I would like to commend the excellent work of the rapporteur, Gilles Pargneaux, which will send a strong and clear signal that the European Union will be at the forefront of the fight against climate change.  I myself was very pleased to be able to contribute to this text as the shadow rapporteur of the Group of Socialists and Democrats for the opinion given by the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Yes, transport, a sector that accounts for a quarter of the European Union's total CO2 emissions and is the only sector whose emissions will continue to grow, must and can play its part in the objective of keeping global warming below 2 degrees. Without a strong awareness of the role of transport in a context of increasing urbanization to reduce CO2 emissions, we will not be able to achieve the cop 21 targets.  We must call on the Commission and the Member States to raise awareness among all stakeholders about the issues linking transport and the fight against global warming. It is also a formidable economic and social challenge that we must face by developing public transport with exemplary engines, promoting the modal ratio of freight to rail and river, and intensifying research on alternative fuels and new engines.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the very good report by Gilles Pargneaux, we called for carbon to be priced. It is a disaster that the Earth's atmosphere is being used as a dump, that billions of tonnes of gases are being blown into the atmosphere at no consequential cost. It is high time that carbon got a price – either through a certificate system, as we have in the EU, or through a carbon tax or tax, as other countries do. I would therefore like to ask you, Commissioner Caete, how does the EU take initiatives to ensure that we have something in the Paris Protocol about carbon pricing and a global carbon market? If we had that, the problems of carbon leakage would also be less, because others – especially the main competitors – would then also tax carbon.

name: Pavel POC
text: – Madam President, let us sum up what we have on the table forty-seven days until the Paris climate conference: optimistic statements, an excellent report by Gill Pargneaux, commitments negotiated or offered so far, which are about half of what we would need, poor replacement of the coal stone revision clause, 100 billion climate finance, but the reflection of states, the reflection of those parties are very much , very self-conscious – so also inadequate. We have more global support for fossil fuels here than support for climate change mitigation measures, and many still say we are too ambitious. Thanks to Gill Pargneaux, we're going to be in a good position at the climate conference, and let's be clear, Paris is our last chance. If countries do not agree on a solution in Paris, the next conference will at best be all about adaptation or survival. If anyone needs a picture of climate change, let them multiply the current migration crisis by about 100 times.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to greet Dr Manuela Eanes who is in the galleries and who has been awarded the European Citizen Award today.  We are just weeks away from the Paris Conference on which an ambitious and binding agreement is to be reached at global level. As we approach this, pressure from some sectors to mitigate the level of ambition of a possible agreement is higher than ever.  We are concerned that we see the recent exclusion in the draft conclusions of the co2 emission reduction targets conference for the maritime transport and aviation sectors. If progress at ICAU and IMO has been manifestly insufficient so far, the absence in Paris of a benchmark in terms of objectives for these sectors would simply be irresponsible and would be a political endorsement for the absence of a shared and balanced effort to reduce CO2 emissions. Maritime transport and aviation account for around 8% of global and growing emissions combined. It is not fair to require additional effort from other sectors, such as energy or industrial, which are also fighting for their competitiveness and whose contribution to reducing emissions is already clear. We must ensure that ambition is maintained in the Paris Climate Agreement.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, with an estimated 200 million people in the world forced to leave their homes because of natural disasters in the last five years alone, it is highly likely that climate change could soon become the biggest source of population displacement and that it would have a disproportionately higher impact on less-developed states. The costs of inaction are enormous and the preventive measures of today are far less costly than the adaptation costs needed tomorrow. Succeeding in reaching an agreement at the Paris conference is not the end of the line, but rather the start of a long period of transformation and adaptation. Therefore, in order to ensure that this agreement will have the strongest possible impact in the long term, we have to make sure that the targets are ambitious and binding enough, and that the agreement is underpinned by strong rules on transparency in reporting, monitoring and verification.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I would also like to turn to a are that is an admonition to those who are representatives of the European Union in Paris. Mr Eck has already mentioned that there are other pollutions compared to the sources we know so far. We are constantly angry at cars, heating and this and that, but really let us not forget that agriculture is also one of the largest emitters of CO2, not only because of livestock production, but also, unfortunately, because of methane emissions from forests left unclaimed. So, if we are to build a future, I ask everyone to take into account not only the unos-boring conditions that have been said so far, but also the new phenomena that we have not yet taken into account.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Climate change, together with biodiversity loss and resource scarcity, is one of the most important global challenges. Inaction has irreversible consequences and is detrimental to the planet, man and the economy. Europe has been at the forefront for years but cannot solve the problem alone. Reaching a new international agreement is therefore fundamental. To succeed, Europe needs allies. Although there are positive signs, for example from the US and China, it remains to be seen whether other countries actually want to share the European level of ambition. Regularly looking over the shoulder to see if everyone is still following is the message. The resolution before us contains many positive elements which I welcome. However, I do think that more realism would strengthen Parliament's position as a credible and influential interlocutor in certain areas. Reconciling ambition with a sense of reality is essential to actually take concrete steps forward.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, two ideas for this report on climate change.  First, to emphasize the decisive role that local and regional institutions play in this cause. 80% of measures to promote energy savings, sustainable mobility, waste reduction and recycling, or citizen involvement in this endeavor, are taken at the local or regional level. Think global, yes. Support action from the next and involve local and regional powers in decision-making, too. Regional alliances such as Under 2, which involve California, Quebec, Baden-W'rttemberg or the Basque Country, whose Minister for the Environment, Ana Oregi, accompanies us in this debate, are an example of the way forward.  Second, let us promote global agreements to avoid production-based competitiveness differentials that ignore global climate change targets. European industry needs us to exercise surveillance and take action against the sale of products that by manufacture or characteristics do not abide by the measures that our companies do respect to combat climate change.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, the motion for a resolution we are debating points out to us that climate change poses a huge threat to human societies and that there is an urgent need for action to lead to a global legally binding agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is also right to highlight the report on the need to exploit clean energy technologies. However, the practice of the institutions of the European Union is a far cry from these fine declarations, as evidenced by the scandal of misleading emissions data provided by German car manufacturers. As early as 2013, according to a report by the European Commission's Joint Research Centre, the existence of data-distortion systems was known. But as punishing the weak, for example with austerity policies, and protecting the interests of the powerful tends to become standard practice, we are not surprised at the refusal to impose sanctions on time.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Madam President, dear Gilles Pargneaux, congratulations on your report. It is a clear and ambitious report. Yes to a binding and ambitious agreement in Paris. Yes to clear funding. Charles Goerens said what needed to be done, namely that The Member States should not again lure the third world countries. And yes especially to renewable energy and energy efficiency.  Now, when we vote, we see the right saying 'yes, maybe something can be done for climate change', but it does not want us to be specific about the instruments.  I am saying that we must move towards renewable energy and energy efficiency, not only for the climate, but also so that we are less dependent on Mr Putin and to create jobs in Europe. Therefore, in view of the vote, I say no to the amendments of the EPP Group and the ECR Group.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to reiterate my thanks to Mr Pargneaux and all those who have collaborated on the delivery of this important report. I just want to make four points. First of all, there is a lot of work ahead of us in the 50 days we have before Paris. We are not there yet. It is true that there are indices: at the moment, more than 150 countries have presented their indices. There is a high level of ambition but we are not within the two-degrees objective. Under a business-as-usual scenario, according to the IPCC assessment, the increase in world temperature would be in a range of 3.8 to 4.7 degrees. With all the 150 indices on the table, according to the Joint Research Centre estimates, we are at about three degrees. A lot of work has to be done in Paris, and that means that Paris must produce an ambitious agreement with a dynamic process of review, including transparency and accountability, and with a clear long-term goal allowing us to take stock from time to time and raise the level of our ambition. Tackling and facing up to global warming is not a matter that we will solve at the Paris meeting, but in Paris we have to create the instruments for long-lasting action towards fighting global warming throughout the century. We have to achieve full decarbonisation of our economies before the end of the century, and that requires a lot of effort. I want briefly to answer some remarks that Members made: Mr Eickhout, Mr Groote, Mr Gerbrandy, Mr Liese and Ms Guteland asked what will happen with maritime and navigation transport. The Commission considers that the international navigation and shipping sectors should also contribute to the global efforts for emissions reductions, because if we want a comprehensive and consistent agreement for below two degrees it must cover all sectors of the economy, including international transport. This should entail a mandate to the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) to deliver a concrete message on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from international aviation and shipping. Those emissions should also be subject to regular review so that the measures can be enhanced over time, in line with decarbonisation scenarios. There was also a question to the Commission concerning our position on earmarking EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) allowances for international climate finance. ETS auction revenues are one of the many public revenue sources that Member States may use to mobilise climate finance, and the Commission proposal for the ETS revision actively encourages Member States to use ETS auction revenues to finance climate action. Lastly, there was a question relating to fossil fuels. The Commission is in favour of phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, and in the G20 framework we supported the United States proposal for a target date of 2025.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, thank you to all the speakers.  Yes, we are in the fight of the century, a struggle of the century not only for our daily lives, but also for the future of our children and grandchildren. I would like to say to the climate sceptics that it is a good chance that our report will be widely adopted this evening. It is fortunate that we will have an agreement in Paris, because it will not only fight climate change, but also change the paradigm and establish a new economy based on green growth and a new energy policy, to allow an increase in purchasing power, especially for the most modest.  I would also like to confirm to several of our colleagues that, yes, this report wants the aviation sector and the maritime sector to be included in the Paris agreement and that yes, we also want to put an end to fossil fuel subsidies by 2020.  We have engaged in a balance of power. For us, the parliamentary democracy, to win this balance of power, we must adopt our report tonight with the largest possible majority.  We all overwhelmingly agree that the Paris Agreement should not only be a trial dialogue, but above all a dialogue to decide our future and that of our children.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 14 October 2015, immediately afterwards. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the run-up to COP 21 in Paris at the beginning of December 2015, Parliament stresses, through this resolution which I have approved, the extreme importance and seriousness of the threats caused by climate change and is concerned that the international community is significantly different from the way forward in limiting global warming to an increase of 2oC above pre-industrial levels. In particular, the rapporteur calls on the EU and its Member States to work with all civil society actors to develop initiatives in key sectors for warming mitigation and calls on companies to accept and actively exercise their responsibilities and to promote support for the climate agreement.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Global warming is one of mankind's biggest problems for sustainable development, health and the global economy. Rising temperatures, melting glaciers, increased drought and floods are signs that the climate has started to warm. Therefore, in response to global warming, an urgent, responsible and global solution based on solidarity from the international community is needed. On 6 March 2015, eu Member States' environment ministers formally committed themselves to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the European Union. The European Union and its Member States have jointly committed to meeting the binding target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union by at least 40% by 2030 compared to March 1990. The European Union has indicated to the Secretariat of the Climate Convention (UNFCCC) what the expected national contribution is. The Contribution of the European Union must inspire other countries to ensure clarity, transparency and the achievement of objectives. The European Union's ambitious commitments are crucial to ensuring its credibility in the negotiations. The EU must pursue an ambitious policy of effective policy to move towards a different energy system by 2050, with other areas such as transport, research, innovation, trade and development cooperation, not only through climate and energy policies.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. Climate change is a threat that could have irreversible effects on the biosphere and human society. That is why the Paris Climate Conference must lead to a very ambitious agreement with a universal and legally binding scope. Only an agreement with these characteristics can provide long-term solutions to the climate challenge and help achieve the goal of increasing temperatures below 2°C.  Recent years have shown that climate change has direct and often dramatic consequences for people's lives. From 2008 to 2013, storms, floods, earthquakes and other extreme weather events forced 166 million people to suddenly leave their homes and move. As Mr Juncker noted during his first State of the Union address, climate change could even contribute to a exacerbation of the Refugee Crisis in the Mediterranean. The next Summit in Paris must therefore strongly include environmental migration issues on international political agendas and must create a fertile ground for the recognition of the phenomenon of migration due to environmental changes and therefore for the recognition of environmental refugee status.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The climate conference scheduled for the end of the year in Paris is of enormous importance, as it is called upon to be the venue for the signing of the new international climate agreement. I very much welcomed the report presented on this subject, as it sets clear and shared objectives on energy efficiency, the use of renewables and the reduction of emissions, but, above all, it underlines the importance of concluding an ambitious and binding agreement. The issue of the environment and climate change has always been one of the key points of our battles, and I was therefore pleased to vote in favour of my colleague's report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – In the not-too-distant future, the world risks facing new challenges if appropriate action is not taken, and one of the problems will be fierce competition for resources generated by climate change. This competition also risks increasing the danger of population displacement, both within national and cross-border borders. According to a 2014 UNEP report on climate change adjustment gaps, developing countries will need to double or even triple the budgets allocated to this chapter from previous estimates of USD 70-100 billion per year by 2050. Particular attention should be paid to reducing deforestation and degrading forests that are responsible for 20% of global greenhouse gas emissions, as well as to meeting commitments to restore 350 million hectares of forest, which would reduce CO2 emissions by 4.5-8.8 billion tonnes per year by 2030.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. COP21 is an essential event in the fight against global warming. We need to set ambitious targets for reducing CO2 emissions. If climate change is already causing disruption and displacement, tomorrow, that is, in ten, thirty or one hundred years, these phenomena will be unmanageable. I emphasize the collective nature of the commitment. Europe alone accounts for only 11% of global CO2 emissions. We cannot be leaders in the energy transition and maintain the competitiveness of our economy without the commitment of emerging economies and developing countries. The ability of these countries to adapt to a "low carbon" economic model will therefore play a major role. To this end, we must guarantee an envelope of EUR 100 billion, using both public and private funding, in which the countries of the Union will take their fair share. In support of this report, however, I would like to point out that the key to the agreement lies in the feasibility of its objectives, however ambitious they may be. It is therefore essential to maintain an ongoing dialogue between the different entities in the public and private sectors, in order to build a comprehensive action against CO2.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Soon it will not only be the TRADITIONAL ANNUAL UN Climate Change Conference. Paris means much more than that, because our Earth is facing a historic step. A reasonable emission reduction agreement, signed and ratified by all CO2-emitting States, must therefore be reached in order to prevent a global temperature rise with irreversible consequences. The European Union has already made a firm commitment, which also requires the other countries in the developed and developing world to follow suit. I believe that the new agreement must be dynamic, which also provides for continuous monitoring and the possibility of reviewing reduction commitments. It is also important that richer countries with a better history help developing economies financially and with knowledge, so that they can take the path of environmentally conscious economic development by omitting the traditional fossil-based development phase and using new technologies. Fortunately, growing up in Hungary, there is a generation that considers the environment more important than its parents, avoids chemical, genetically modified food, likes local vegetables, eco-tourism, community gardens – and politicians have a job to do to help and support this process.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Although action to tackle climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions is a priority for the European Union, it is no longer the driving force behind the negotiations on climate change and global warming, as has been the case in the past. One reason is that the very carbon footprint of the 28 Member States of the Union is relatively small compared to some developing countries. According to the latest estimates, all indications are that reaching + 2 degrees in limiting the planet's global warming to + 2 degrees by 2050 is in sight, and with the current trajectory, warming could be as high as + 4-6 degrees at the end of the century. I therefore support the actions of the European Commission, which adopted the communication entitled 'The Paris Protocol – the concept of combating global climate change post-2020', which is part of the European Union's preparations for the last round of negotiations before the 21st United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris. We must not forget that the fight against climate change is a common European commitment and that climate change will be paid for by the poorest parts of the world, which have the least opportunities to combat climate change effectively.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: in writing. – To maintain a liveable earth we have to halt climate change now. As one of the main culprits of climate change, Europe carries a great responsibility in achieving global binding agreements on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Regrettably, the report ‘Towards a new international climate agreement’ only contains one single paragraph on agriculture, whose impact on climate change cannot be overstated enough. Especially, the negative impact of meat production on climate change persists, and prospects for the future are grim. The world population is estimated to reach 9.6 billion by 2050. Diets are predicted to become more affluent, containing more meat and dairy products. This shift towards unsustainable diets will entail a tremendous, if not impossible burden on the planet’s resources. There is a clear link between livestock farming and global warming. Meat and dairy production are responsible for at least 14% of all our greenhouse gas emissions. It would be negligent to not tackle this issue when fighting climate change – especially when we realise that people and animals in the poorer areas of the world will be affected first and the worst, owing to extreme weather conditions due to climate change.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – This December, not only will the TRADITIONAL ANNUAL UN Climate Change Conference take place. Paris means so much more than that. The Kyoto Protocol expires this year and a new, more ambitious emissions reduction agreement must be reached to prevent global temperature rises with irreversible consequences. With the resolution before us, the European Parliament is sending a clear message to the Paris negotiations. The Union has made a firm commitment, which requires significant sacrifices from European economies. Now in the developed and developing world it is your turn to follow this example. In my view, in order to achieve the 2°C target, the new convention must be dynamic, which also provides for continuous monitoring and the possibility of reviewing reduction commitments. It is also important that richer countries with a better history help developing economies financially and with knowledge, so that they can take the path of environmentally conscious economic development by omitting the traditional fossil-based development phase and using new technologies. Finally, allow me to refer to one of the very important references to the decision: my colleagues in the People's Party have made the reference to the encyclopedia Laudato Si' published this summer part of the resolution. The message of Pope Francis, that is to say, emphasising our personal responsibility, has, in my opinion, become indispensable in the international dialogue on climate change.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The new global international climate agreement expected in Paris is crucial for the future of our planet. The European Union must come to this conference with one vote and be at the forefront of the demands to reduce emissions caused by global climate change.  Member States and the European Union must continue with ambitious programmes and solutions to set an example for the many countries attending the Paris conference. Efforts so far and set targets must be given a new impulse to prevent radical climate change that will cause or already cause severe consequences in some areas of the planet.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – A global climate agreement such as COP 21 should be binding on all parties and equipped with an enforcement mechanism. Similarly, such an agreement should have the necessary sanctions to ensure that all signatory countries, regardless of their size and exposure to climate change, also comply with the mandatory conditions. On the way to COP 21, there was some good news at first glance, for example, that more than 80% of all countries have submitted their voluntary contributions and that US large corporations such as Procter&Gamble or Johnson&Johnson are committed to voluntary climate protection. Although too few national contractors are actually achieving the 2°C target, it will not be possible to achieve sustainable emission reductions without commitment and implementation assessments. Some major polluters have also made proposals that adapt so dynamically to their countries' economic growth and whose reduction targets are so disconnected from their pollution levels that they hardly need to meet any real climate action. For the EU and its Member States, this means imposing strict commitments – a fact that will certainly make it even more difficult to maintain the high level of global competitiveness in the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – Climate change is undoubtedly a threat to the environment and to humans. However, the way in which the forthcoming COP21 conference is held in Paris is not an answer to the problem, but an opportunity for the Franco-German axis to promote climate diplomacy in a more aggressive way in favour of Franco-German interests. The sole objective of these companies is to increase their exports to developing countries which are already suffering the devastating effects of climate change. A phenomenon caused mainly by carbon dioxide emissions from developed economies such as the US, China and Germany. Contrary to these interests, climate change must be tackled urgently because it will result in the creation of millions of climate refugees. It is estimated that between 2008 and 2013 climate refugees amount to 166 million. When today the EU and especially my country Greece cannot cope with refugee flows due to the war in Syria, imagine how difficult it will be in the future to cope with the huge refugee flows due to climate change. The first step in the future management of this issue is the international legal recognition of climate refugee status.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. – The conclusion of an adapted legally binding protocol, which is in fact complied with by each Party, would in principle be desirable. Unfortunately, the actual leaders (USA, China) will continue to fail to comply. The EU's unilateral adherence to this commitment leads to a tremendous competitive advantage for the US and China. In order to maintain the Union's competitiveness, I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – Climate change is one of humanity's biggest challenges today. Their consequences are felt by all through increasingly frequent droughts, floods and other natural disasters. Nearly 20 million people, according to a UN report, were forced to flee their homes last year due to natural disasters around the world. The damage suffered by the global economy due to climate change is up to €300 billion annually. Climate change is unquestionably one of the biggest threats to the future on earth.  A new global climate agreement is expected to be adopted in Paris in December, which must set a long-term global climate change mitigation target in line with the aim of limiting global temperature growth to no more than 2°C.  The European Union has taken a world-leading role in implementing greenhouse gas emissions reductions and has focused its overall policy on cleaner technologies, energy efficiency and renewables to contribute to the development of a low-carbon economy and create new green jobs. I hope that other countries in the world will follow the EU's ambitious objectives and strategies.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – I encourage the view that the Member States of the Union need to increase investment in public research in the energy sector in order to contribute to the creation of generations of low-carbon technologies. Stimulating innovation can also generate economic growth. That is why we need more political signals in this regard. Over the past 10 years, more than 150 million people have been forced to leave their residences due to natural disasters, thus creating a new category of refugees, that of climate refugees that, even if not legally recognised, exist. In the current context, which puts us in the face of the heavy management of war refugees, it is more than necessary to pay particular attention to combating climate change, so that we do not end up having to manage climate refugees as well. Climate change is a threat to global stability and security in all respects. I would like to stress that the lack of real action on climate change will affect all regions of the world differently, from economic, environmental and social losses to loss of life.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – Scaling up of developed countries’ funding for mitigation, adaptation, technology development and transfer, and capacity building in developing countries, in line with the commitment to provide new and additional such funding to reach USD 100 billion per year by 2020, while increasing official development aid to reach the long-since pledged level of 0.7% of gross national income is crucial and the EU and its Member States should fight for it.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – Climate change is no longer a matter of debate, but a problem that needs to be addressed right now. It is right that the European Union is taking the lead in setting ambitious targets to combat climate change. However, we must not forget that the most important thing in this fight is to attract solidarity from the international community as a whole. One effort by the European Union will not be enough, and it is therefore necessary to finally reach a global, binding agreement. In this global context, we should not forget the competitiveness of our industry and solve the problem of carbon leakage. I am convinced that the new energy model for energy efficiency and renewable energy sources that we have chosen to implement in Europe is the right way to combat climate change, and that the clear progress and new opportunities that have been made must be exploited in the negotiations in order to adopt a new international climate change agreement in Paris.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. – Mr Cañete, you, before you were Commissioner, you were Minister of Agriculture, so you are aware that our current agri-food system is incompatible with the fight against climate change. The mode of industrial production and a marketing that circulates our food thousands and thousands of kilometers are responsible for a very high volume of emissions. You know this, but surely the interests of a few transnational corporations prevent you from talking about this when looking for alternatives to contribute to the fight against climate change. I ask you, Mr Cañete, when another agricultural and food policy in Europe will be considered to contribute to cooling the planet, as broad sectors of peasantry and society are demanding; for when a common agricultural and food policy that promotes agroecology and short marketing circuits in the face of the increasing industrialization of the mode of production and the prioritization of the international market. Advancing these proposals means making an important contribute to cooling the planet, creating jobs and putting healthy, quality food on our tables.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – At the moment, few are as pressing issues as the increase in climate change on planet Earth. If we are not efficient in mitigating the effects and in resonating its consequences, this will be the last problem humanity will have to deal with. It's as bad as that. This report, by proposing a very significant increase in renewable energy and by imposing a roadmap for states, makes an effective contribution to reducing climate change.  However, in this declaration I want to attach particular importance to the proposal to end subsidies for petroleum products. This option has a deeper content than the simple end of a support. With this option we are, in fact, changing the paradigm, giving priority to benign energies for the environment and putting an early end to passive dependence on fossil fuels. Europe takes the initiative and contributes to a better world.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. – This report clearly shows more ambition than what european environment ministers agreed last month. The Greens tried to sharpen the stakes with a proposal to protect the Paris climate agreements from claims from large companies. Governments that take action to combat climate change should never be hindered by companies threatening ISDS claims. In the course of the Paris negotiations, it is crucial that developing countries receive more guarantees of financial support for their fight against climate change. Many rich countries use money from the development cooperation pot. That's not the point. Climate finance must be on top of development aid.
