In summary, the new climate treaty must be legally binding; to set the world on a path that will lead to the complete phase-out of CO2 emissions in 2050 or shortly thereafter; establish five-year review cycles to keep the ambition of the climate treaty in line with the latest scientific knowledge; aim to stop all fossil fuel subsidies by 2020; require international shipping and aviation to reduce their emissions; identify clear sources of climate finance (such as EU ETS and proceeds from additional fuel charges); guarantee that climate finance does not come at the expense of the development aid budget.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. First, the climate situation has deteriorated. A series of extreme weather events have been amplified. 2014 is the hottest year we have ever seen. And 2015 will probably be even hotter. The awareness of the need to act is therefore stronger. The adjective that best defines this negotiation is that of "vital." What arises, in the end, through these discussions, is the question of life in every sense of the word. Will our planet remain viable or not? It is also a vital issue in the sense that, if we do not act against climate change, the consequences of this phenomenon will be devastating: drought, famines, floods, mass migration. In the end, it is war or peace. Hundreds of thousands, but potentially tens of millions of people, would be affected by migration. But let's not fall into catastrophism. The financial, technological solutions are there, at hand and they can, they must, lead us to a rapid and positive change in our growth models, with what unions call a just transition in mind.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – In order to create an effective European energy union we need to diversify our energy supply, increase energy efficiency, and increase the use of indigenous resources, especially the renewable ones. However, some European energy companies are trying to undermine these goals by conspiring with Kremlin-controlled Gazprom to double the capacity of the North Stream pipeline, thereby making Europe even more dependent on Russian gas.  Russia has time after time demonstrated that it does not hesitate to wield energy supply as a political weapon. It would be foolish to make our energy supply even more dependent on such an unreliable partner. Furthermore, this project would allow Gazprom to bypass Ukraine as a transit route, which clearly serves the Kremlin in its attempts at further destabilising and sabotaging Ukraine. This foolish project would most certainly have negative repercussions on Europe’s security of supply and on the energy union as a whole. Ceterum censeo, Germany will certainly regret its decision to make Europe even more dependent on Russian gas, just as France regretted its decision to sell Mistral class warships to Russia.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. If we are already talking about climate protection and want to introduce binding rules for it, then all parties should also abide by it. The reality, however, is that China, and the US in particular, are not fulfilling these obligations, while the EU feels obliged to unilaterally comply with the conclusion of an adapted legally binding protocol. This detention by the EU leads to a distortion of competition and to a clear advantage for the main culprits, namely China and the United States. That is why I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The Paris Summit focuses on monitoring climate change, but underpinning this theme is the need to change the principles on which the current process of economic and social globalisation is taking place. The EP report sets out an appropriate path and a holistic approach to the problem. An ambitious and legally ambitious global agreement should be defined at the Paris Summit. It is also important that European policy for the decarbonisation of the economy and for the technical and social transition is exemplary for the world, and that it is possible to set up a support fund for developing countries that will have to make an increased effort to adapt their growth strategies to the new sustainability objectives of the planet.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: – Madam President, given the importance of transparency and the great interests that are at stake, I should like to move the following amendment after paragraph 80: ‘Points out that lobby activities before and during the COP 21 negotiations can have influence on the outcomes of the negotiations; stresses therefore that such activities should be transparent, clearly indicated in the UNFCCC daily agenda of the COP 21 and that the conference should allow equitable access to all relevant stakeholders’.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This closes Voting Time.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the consequences of the European Court of Justice's ruling invalidating the "safe harbor" decision for the United States (2015/2903 (RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you first of all for asking the Presidency to take part in this debate that you wished to have on the consequences of the Court's decision last week.  It will, of course, be up to the Commission to tell you its intentions for the coming months. This issue is not only about the Commission, it concerns the Council and it concerns Member States and European citizens in the first place. Let's not forget them. Let me begin by acknowledging that Parliament has regularly raised the shortcomings that existed in the transfer of data from the Union to the United States under the Safe Harbor Agreement. Indeed, even before the Snowden revelations, Parliament had expressed concern about the level of data protection and had called for the agreement to be suspended until its flaws were corrected. The Court of Justice has just declared the Security Commission's adequacy decision invalid. It clearly considered that this decision did not provide sufficient protection for the processing of the personal data of European citizens. The consequences of this judgment must be carefully analysed, including by the Council. The Commission presented an initial assessment of its potential consequences at the Justice and Home Affairs Council meeting on 9 October.  The Court's decision concerns a decision of the Commission. It is therefore up to the Court first to draw the consequences of the Court's invalidation of its decision - and I am sure the Commissioner will do so. The judgment also clarifies the powers of European supervisors when transferring data to third countries, which are made on the basis of a adequacy decision. It is important that the Commission works closely with these authorities to ensure that the judgment is interpreted and applied in a uniform manner. In the immediate future, citizens need to be reassured that their data is protected. In addition, companies need to be informed about other legal options for transferring data to the United States in light of the Court's ruling. In the longer term, the Commission will have to decide what will succeed the decision on the safe harbor that has just been invalidated. The answer to this question will have to be through a close dialogue with the US authorities.  Whatever formula is chosen to succeed the Safe Harbor decision, it will have to fully respect the Court's decision. While respecting the principles set out by the Court, the Commission will be able to take into account the importance to the economy of a regular and legal flow of data between the United States and the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, the Court of Justice has reiterated that any instrument of the European Union must respect a high level of protection of personal data and be in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, particularly when such data is transferred to third countries.  In this context, the Council and the European Parliament must continue their work on a new strong data protection framework, with the aim of concluding the negotiations by the end of this year. I consider that with this judgment, the finalisation of this reform before the end of the year becomes more urgent and necessary.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Last week’s ruling in the Schrems case reaffirmed the importance of data protection as a fundamental right in the EU, including when personal data is transferred to third countries. The Commission respects that ruling and will abide by it, as must all stakeholders. The Court has declared the 2000 Safe Harbour decision invalid, and it can no longer serve as a legal basis for transatlantic data transfers. There can be no ‘business as usual’ approach. Immediate steps have to be taken to ensure compliance with the ruling. These are: that citizens need to be assured that their personal data will be protected; and that European businesses needing to transfer personal data to the US need guidance about the remaining legal ways of doing so, with appropriate safeguards and the conditions to be fulfilled. The Commission is working closely with the European data protection supervisors in Working Party 29. We want to ensure clear guidance so that we avoid fragmentation in the internal market. There were good first discussions at technical level last week, and this will continue in the plenary tomorrow, which I will also attend. The Commission is also in dialogue with business on this issue. Today, together with Vice-President Ansip and Commissioner Oettinger, I met a delegation of business representatives to hear their practical concerns and to stress the need to comply with the ruling swiftly. They are worried about fragmentation, and they need guidance as a matter of urgency. I want to use the opportunity of this discussion today to assure you that my objective remains a renewed and robust arrangement for transatlantic data flows, taking into account the requirements set out by our highest court. The US side also needs to address these requirements in its own legal order and in practice. After my first discussions with Secretary of Commerce Penny Pritzker, I remain confident that this is possible. I am encouraged by reform steps such as the USA Freedom Act and the draft Judicial Redress Bill, which specifically addresses the situation of EU citizens. But we will be clear in our discussions with the US partners: we need guarantees that the right to data protection is respected when data is transferred to the US. Our benchmark is the court ruling. We will immediately resume and step up discussions with the US, building on the work done so far. I will myself go to Washington in mid—November to discuss the issue further with my counterparts there. This is an ongoing debate in the US, as it is in Europe. I would therefore ask you too, as Members of the European Parliament, to engage with your counterparts in the US Congress on this issue and to be a partner in this. This is important for our wider relationship with the United States of America, our key strategic partner both politically and economically. I want a more informed debate about this process and I see you as an essential partner in this process. I will keep you regularly informed about the next stages of these discussions.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank the Commission and also the Council most warmly for coming here this evening, at the suggestion of the PPE-DE, to discuss this judgment as well. We need legal certainty, and we also want to know what happens next. In the end, the verdict itself is no surprise. The Commission itself has recognised that it must act on this. We have also considered the SAME subject on the NSA report. The negotiations as such have not yet made progress on the very point that we in the European Parliament have also criticised, namely because of state surveillance, but not because of data transmission as such. In fact, we have always called for the abolition of Safe Harbour, but in my view it is, of course, always linked to a condition that it be improved, completely abolished, but then also replaced, because for us the free flow of data is also a fundamental thing. And that is in jeopardy at the moment. The judgment basically contains one or two points. Firstly, there was no possibility of transition at all. This, of course, puts our companies in serious legal difficulties. It is also problematic that the national data protection authorities themselves suddenly no longer have to follow this important principle of uniformity of European law. It is also critical to assess which legal obligations generally arise from this. That is why encryption of data may even be enough. I would therefore ask you to take European citizens back to a safe haven.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her European fundamental rights, the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, are the basis of all European laws, of all European action. The European Court of Justice has made this clear once again. We Social Democrats have been saying for years that the safe haven is not a safe haven for data, it is not a safe haven for the privacy of our citizens. The whole thing finally became a farce with the so-called NSA revelations. European data had become a self-service store for US security services – all in the name of so-called national security, without ever being questioned. It is also not only about metadata, which is already very sensitive, but also about the content of communication. What is clear is that the Commission could never have declared the United States a safe data port, almost in a stroke of the hand. Nor is it possible to completely restrict the control rights of national data protection authorities. A state whose authorities monitor people without cause and across the board cannot be a safe haven. It is now important to carefully examine and analyse the possible impact of this on other legal bases for the transfer of data to the United States. An adequate level of data protection, and this is also clear, must be a high level of data protection. In addition to the high level of data protection, we need a right of action in the event that data abuse nevertheless takes place. There are many consequences to be drawn from this judgment. The Irish Data Protection Authority can and must now investigate Max Schrems' complaint. It is also clear that the US itself must review its legislation and install effective controls. This is all the more so because even US representatives have admitted that their intelligence services have exceeded the already very broad powers. Nor can the Commission simply carry on as before and review the 13 recommendations as part of a review of Safe Harbour; we have to make a fresh start here. For our European data protection reform, of course, this also means, of course, that we must at least re-examine carefully the rules for the transfer of data to third countries. In our Member States, too, we need to re-consider national surveillance programmes in the light of this judgment. Conclusion: Once again, the ECJ has sent out a signal for the protection of European fundamental rights. The Commission, but also the Member States, must now implement this judgment consistently.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, this judgment is controversial and it has created a significant, burdensome and costly legal vacuum. Ironically enough, whilst the aim of this decision was to uphold individual privacy rights, it has made these rights more vague and more uncertain than ever. We must not make it more difficult for businesses to operate or more difficult to protect the data of individuals. Potentially we have opened the door to a patchwork of decision making across the EU. We repeatedly find ourselves in a situation where courts are determining policy before we legislate, and this has to stop. We now need to find fast, quality and effective solutions for commercial activity in data protection, which should not be overshadowed by any discussions relating to the activities of the intelligence community. This judgment certainly must not affect the need for a positive and forward-looking agenda regarding data and trade with the United States, and the EU and the US need to keep cool heads. The Commission needs to come forward with a clear and immediate plan for interim transfers and to make sure that it delivers a better and stronger Safe Harbour agreement as soon as possible.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I agree with the previous speaker’s last statement, that we quickly need a proper solution in compliance with the Court ruling. However, I disagree with his statement that it is the Court which is to blame, for upholding the law. That is actually what courts do in a liberal democracy, and I am grateful that at least the Court did it, because the real problem was known for many years. We have known for more than 10 years that the safeguards were not adequate, that compliance was weak if not absent, and that we were applying double standards. We apply different standards to our American friends than we apply to other countries. Fortunately, the Court has stopped this, and now we have to find a solution. We also need to study the implications for other policies and, in particular, transatlantic data flows. That would include the Passenger Name Records agreement, the Terrorist Finance Tracking Programme agreement, the umbrella agreement and possibly also public procurement arrangements. I think national governments should also check if their national surveillance laws actually meet the standards set by the Court. I would like to remind people that privacy and data protection – contrary to what I believe Mr Zuckerberg once said – is not a social convention. It is actually a legal right on a par with the right to free speech, the right to life, a ban on torture and all the other fundamental rights. It is a legal right, Mr Kirkhope. It is not something the Court invented: it is actually in the Treaties. We do not want a fence around the European internet. We want transatlantic data flows, but it takes two to tango – as Mr Juncker said in the previous debate – so that means our US counterparts will also have to move. Finally, this is also a governance issue. This is very much about the quality of legislation and about enforcement. Therefore I would also call on the Vice-President responsible for better law-making to look at it from that perspective.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The ECJ has made it clear that there is insufficient protection in the US for the data of European users. That is incompatible with European fundamental rights. Safe Harbour, it must be said, is definitely overturned, and no wonderful amendment to the agreement, however good, can eliminate the cancer damage that US intelligence agencies have access to the data at all times and at all times under the national security label. That's the problem. We do not need a new Safe Harbour, but a European binding set of rules that will make it clear that whoever processes European data must also comply with the rules here in Europe. And we need painful, effective sanctions and penalties for rule violations, because otherwise nothing will move. However, the ball is not primarily in Europe, but also on the playing field of the United States. We are asking the Commission and the Member States to ensure that respect for European fundamental rights becomes a central condition in the negotiations with the United States. After all, national security cannot be used as a manslaughter argument against effective data protection and undermine civil rights. This can't be. Finally, the Irish High Court cannot hide behind a Commission decision. In other words, he must take action when he is called. This strengthens the independence of data protection authorities, and that is a good thing.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I thought it was one-and-a-half minutes but I will try it in one. The good thing is that there is still a safe harbour: this is the safe harbour for digital rights and data protection, and it is called the European Court of Justice. The bad thing is that it needs a guy who invests quite a lot of money, quite a lot of time and energy for four years of his young life, to get justice for 500 million Europeans and everybody on the European market – after 15 years of injustice, obviously. This is very bad news, and I think we should not leave it there. We should not leave it there for another case like the long life of Max Schrems to fix it, again and again. There should be a solution which is solid, brought forward by the political leaders here present. That should be done quickly, but it cannot be just a quick fix – by saying that the presumption of adequate protection of privacy and data protection in the framework, for example, of US law, can be declared by a Commission decision. That is not how to do it: the Court has said it is not adequately protecting. So we need first to do own homework – on the regulation on data protection and the consistent application of our laws also to US companies – and then there needs to be another homework done on the other side of the Atlantic, by the United States Government, to fix the situation via consumer privacy laws and the Judicial Redress Act.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in a judgment last week, the Court of Justice of the European Union declared invalid the decision allowing the transfer of european citizens' data to the United States, because the level of data protection in the UNITED States was totally inadequate. These are the premises by which we are preparing to sign TTIP – the largest treaty in history – with a country that has spied on us, that has put our presidents under surveillance and that, with the worst mercantilistic approach, treats our data as a property and does not even protect the basic rules of privacy. What is more, this is the country with which we are going to sign the TISA, the agreement on the liberalisation of services, which will allow large companies to have free access to our data. And think that, among the future signatories to this treaty, the United States is even the first in the class, because the TISA wants to sign it with China, Mexico, Pakistan, countries that certainly do not shine for the defense of data or rights. This judgment, gentlemen, is a wake-up call. You cannot sell off rights to gain market share. My invitation is to stop this crazy race while we're in time.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done For two years, the European Commission has been negotiating with the US authorities to amend the Safe Harbour Agreement, and now this agreement has been overturned by the European Court of Justice. The ECJ agrees with Austrian Max Schrems, who says that US law does not provide sufficient protection for the monitoring of the data that Facebook forwards to US servers. However, the impact of the ECJ ruling is much more far-reaching than that. There is legal uncertainty among up to 5,000 companies that have so far exchanged customer data between Europe and the US under the Safe Harbour agreement. These are not just large U.S. cloud providers and social networks, but many start-ups with digital businesses and other small Internet companies. Us cloud providers have been completely stripped of their legal basis. The ECJ has also said that national data protection authorities will be strengthened, which can now even penalise possible breaches. On the other hand, the ECJ ruling will trigger billions of dollars in investment because Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple will build data centers in Europe. The plans are there. What we need now is a legal framework that provides security.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Madam President, this is the sign that the European People's Party reflects the concern that citizens have about the protection of their data and has therefore presented this oral question, the aim of which is to ask the Commission to clarify what steps it will take to address the legal uncertainty that has been created following the court's judgment invalidating the Safe Harbor Decision.  The Court's ruling comes to protect the right of citizens to have security over the protection of their data and that is why it is now the Commission's responsibility to start a negotiation of you with the United States, as we have long claimed from this Parliament. It's not about criticizing Americans here without providing solutions. It is a question of action, ladies and gentlemen, because our businesses and our citizens demand us, which must urgently have a secure framework.  This judgment has to be seen as an opportunity to push for more in-line and balanced privacy legislation, both by Europe and on the US side.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Madam President, I do not agree with Jan Albrecht that it is bad news that the young man Schrems spent four years achieving what our institutions could not achieve in 15 years. I think that is very good news, and I very much hope that there will be more and more young people like him, because this is the only way to ensure that the European standard of data protection is implemented in all Member States. This court decision is very important, and not only for our future transfers with the United States. We also have to look at the situation in our own Member States because, in the digital single market, more and more personal data of people from one Member State will be collected, stored and used in other Member States. Here we see the national security clause effectively removing from the data protection system the protection of those data. We have to be sure that the standards of the democratic system will be implemented and protected in all countries – for example, in the case of Hungary, where we are absolutely sure that this it is not the case. So we need – and we have also spent a very long time talking about this – a system of reporting and control over the rule of law in Member States, and we also have to have, from the Commission, some framework and some red lines in relation to the definition of national security in connection with data protection, because, more and more often, this is a very practical issue. The next Schrems might bring a case, not against America, but against Europe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, for fifteen years European citizens have entrusted the management of their personal data to companies based in the United States, on the basis of the Safe Harbour Decision. They considered in good faith that the European Commission had carried out a thorough review of the arrangements in the USA for the protection of personal data, that their personal data was secure and that it was being used for purposes for which they had expressly given their consent. It was enough for only one person to seek the judicial protection of his right to privacy in order to collapse like a paper tower the edifice of the supposedly safe harbour and to prove that European citizens have no means of judicial protection against the interference of the American authorities in their personal data. The European Commission must assume its responsibilities and become a guardian of fundamental rights. Instead, so far it has proved to be a tailsser, leaving citizens exposed.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, now that the institution responsible for ensuring compliance with European law has invalidated the substance of an agreement to which we have entrusted the protection of the privacy of our citizens, we can no longer delay. The European Commission, which is also the guarantor of the correct application of Community rules, is called upon to find timely solutions to compensate for the uncertainty surrounding the transfer of data to the United States. It is important and important to identify a renewed strategic approach to the negotiation of the new Safe Harbour agreement, taking into account what was established a few days ago by the Court of Justice, on the basis of the European Data Protection Directive itself. We must feel confident that we can live the network without worrying about how sensitive information will be used, free to exchange sensitive information with our loved ones as well. What is at stake is the fundamental rights of European citizens, which cannot be sacrificed in any way on the altar of other rights.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, faced with the verdict of the Court of Justice, which invalidates the Commission's decision on the transfer of data to the United States, we see two encouraging facts. The first is that there is a judge in Luxembourg who is allowing the Europe of rights to prevail over the arbiters of the markets. The second is that there are ordinary citizens to defend us against harassment and to achieve what Parliament has not achieved with so many resolutions. Young Schrems is one of them. Her battle to protect the law has led her in the wake of Edward Snowden, who was nominated by our sakharov prize group along with other whistleblowers. After three judgments of the Court, I believe that it is more necessary than ever to review all the relevant negotiations and promote a digital Eu ropean Bill of Rights, based on the principles already contained in the Charter, similar to the Marco Civil adopted in Brazil in 2014.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I welcome the ECJ decision, as most of us in this Chamber do, because it strengthens fundamental data protection rights. But the impact may be very far-reaching, and it can be huge. I therefore also do not really have any connection from the ECJ to real implementation, transitional arrangements or other measures. Furthermore, I consider it very critical that, in the current interpretation of this judgment, it is now possible for 28 data protection authorities in Europe to make different national rules. I believe that, in the trialogue negotiations on the new data protection law, the Council and the Commission have the first chance to move in this right direction. It is also a question of not weakening the digital economy and investing in European infrastructure. However, let me also express incomprehension about the voting behaviour of the left in this House. It is irresponsible that more than 4 000 sectors of the economy, and therefore hundreds of thousands of jobs, may be put at risk in the face of the threat of penalties. Quite apart from the impact on millions of citizens, this is not the work we have to do here in Parliament. Get on board quickly!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the transfer of personal data touches on the hard core of civil liberties and civil rights of the individual, such as the protection of personality. The European Parliament had already strongly opposed the transfer of data under the US "safe harbour". We therefore welcome the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which puts the brakes on the unacceptable regime for the transfer of personal data across the Atlantic. We therefore await the full and exceptional application of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union in Case C362/14 of 6 October, a decision to be applied by the European Union and by the United States. However, the letter and spirit of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union must also be applied in an indefaous way within the Member States of the Union, in order to stop the surveillance of citizens and activists within the European Union by the various secret services.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have already highlighted, in a speech in the last plenary session in relation to geo-blocking, the stimulus coming from the important decision-making decision of the Court of Justice of 6 October 2015. In invalidating safe harbour, the Court ruled on a further principle of living law relating to the fundamental freedom of the individual. Electronic communications of sensitive data must be considered part of the right to privacy and must be given back to domestic control over any violation and protection. The decision will affect more than you imagine, as a watershed between positive goals in supporting the digital and defensive single market strategy as its influence in TTIP agreements, and even more so in matters of maximum intelligence, such as the Prisma surveillance program that Snowden discovered is enabled to monitor all world Internet traffic. But the basic reflection is that when, as in the present case, justice intervenes as a substitute for politics and legislator, setting principles that neither one nor the other has been able to define, I understand that the injury to fundamental principles has long since occurred.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members very much for this discussion, which also gave me some more ideas and inspiration. You asked several times what the Commission is going to do. I tried to explain this at the beginning but perhaps I should go into more detail now.  I think we all understand the complexity of this matter. We Europeans value the right to privacy and the right to the protection of our private data as a fundamental right. In the United States, when we negotiate Safe Harbour and the protection of European data in the United States, we understand that there is a highly valued principle of security and also the fact that the data is a commercial commodity. This is the area in which we are acting and where we want to achieve strong commitments, from the side of the United States, that Europeans’ data will be very well protected – and at least as well as we do it in the European Union. This is our goal. You will understand that this is not easy to achieve because we are in the field of non-European jurisdiction. We also have to work with this fact.  So what are we going to do? I am working intensively on a strategy to find a solution to this situation. I see three stages. The short-term stage is now very much dependent on the strong and independent data protection authorities and on their unified pan-European approach in providing clear guidance to businesses which are expressing very strong concerns that they are in a situation of legal uncertainty. We all understand that this is the case for businesses. This is an uneasy situation.  In the medium term we need to achieve good results in negotiations on the new, safer Safe Harbour and the new adequacy decision. I will come back to this. In the long term – and I also spoke about this at the beginning – we need to put more pressure on the United States towards their reform of national intelligence and a higher level of protection of privacy. This will be for the long term. This is what I wanted to stress at the beginning, asking you to help with your counterparts in the United States at your level. Going back to Safe Harbour, Safe Harbour is a specific system which was created for transatlantic data flows. I am convinced that this system was created for a very good reason because the volume of the data transferred is extremely big and the data transfers are also extremely important for economic and commercial cooperation with the United States. This specific regime was declared invalid and now the conditions which are provided for by the Data Protection Directive protection for international transfers must be applied. This is where we are now. But we understand – and I am convinced – that we need this new requested decision which will represent a new system which is something like a safer Safe Harbour. Members are absolutely right that we need to look again at the 13 recommendations which were defined in 2013 as a reaction to the revelations about the extreme access of the security service to European data. We will look at those 13 recommendations in the light of the court ruling, which is the strong and clear benchmark for us in this retesting of these recommendations, because the Court is in fact giving us new criteria for the assessment of adequacy. This is exactly what we are doing now. We start the negotiations tomorrow after a very thorough analysis of the court ruling. The negotiations will start tomorrow, and on Friday on a technical level with our United States partners. We need to look again at all the recommendations regarding the commercial part and especially at those recommendations which concern national security considerations. We were very close to finalising the negotiations on Safe Harbour before the summer, but we knew that the court ruling would come soon so we waited for the decision in order to continue the negotiations. I can only conclude with the quite positive assessment that all the criteria which the court ruling contained regarding the adequacy of data protection in the United States are feasible to achieve, but we must be much more assertive and much stronger now in the negotiations. We are fully aware of the fact that time is against us and we need to step up our efforts.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – We are living in the digital age when the extent of the collection of the personal data is growing rapidly. Thus without a doubt a legal framework of a well-functioning data protection system is essential for our privacy. European citizens must be guaranteed that their personal data will be respected and well protected even when it is transmitted to third countries. Thus I call on all the responsible EU and US institutions to act and do everything in order to ensure that a prompt and solid solution for the robust arrangement of the transatlantic data flows would be set out in full compliance with the European Court of Justice ruling. Data protection is and must remain a major legal right in the EU.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. Commissioner Vera Jourová's statement reassured us by showing that the Commission has taken seriously the ruling of the European Court of Justice which led to the suspension of the Safe Harbor Agreement. This is an area, that of the protection of personal data, not a simple one: a typical case in which society and technologies evolve at a faster rate than the laws that should regulate them. On the one hand, it is essential to ensure respect for the privacy of European citizens' data but, on the other hand, we cannot fail to examine the difficulties that this judgment causes not only for companies but also for the future of the Internet. The legislative fragmentation created in this "vacatio legis", in fact, risks undermining the very principle on which the Web was born and developed: its intrinsic ability to be global and to connect various parts of the world. The Commissioner has assured us that the European Executive is already dealing with this issue, listening to all the parties involved and starting a dialogue with the United States, with the ultimate aim, which we can only support, of securing a new and solid agreement to guarantee the privacy of transatlantic data.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The Judgment of the European Court of Justice on the EU-US data exchange agreement creates a vague situation for technology companies. In this respect, guidelines need to be developed by the time further data exchange rules between the EU and the US are agreed. It is clear that the data of EU citizens must be protected and it must be clear under what conditions the US intelligence agencies will have access to this data. At the same time, talks with the US on an improved data protection agreement must be resumed as soon as possible, as it will help to develop both the European economy and the digital economy.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. – A challenge for the people is the attempt by the civil political parties to project the EU as a model, in the light of the Decision of the European Court of Justice which states that the US has a lower level of protection of personal data than the EU. For many years, not only the US, but also the EU has been establishing a huge network of suppression and monitoring mechanisms: the Schengen Convention, giant SIS I and II databases, VIS, the directive on the monitoring of telephone and electronic/internet communications in cooperation with their respective monopolies for their own interests. All kinds of monitoring, collection and processing of personal data, including biometrics, even children, are required above all those who develop political and trade union action, especially communists, trade unionists of the class labour movement, other fighters. Exchange and interconnection of information, but also fierce competition between all kinds of secret services of the Member States, the Europolice, as well as the respective third countries, in particular the USA and the CIA. This huge monitoring and envelope grid will take on nightmarish proportions in the coming period, with the "smart borders", the use of drones for surveillance, the system for the registration of personal data of air passengers in the EU, in accordance with the standards of the PNR agreement with the US.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – Directive 95/64/EC on data protection provides that personal data may be transferred to a third country only if it ensures an adequate level of data protection. Under the directive, the European Commission has the power to decide whether a particular third country meets the appropriate level of protection of personal data. Firstly, in the case of the Safe Harbour decision, the European Commission has determined that the US should ensure adequate protection of the personal data transferred under that scheme. Then, in 2015, the Court of Justice of the European Union delivered a judgment in a case concerning the transfer of data by EU citizens to the US via the social network Facebook based on the so-called Safe Harbor. The Court found that legislation allowing public authorities general access to the content of digital communications channels could significantly undermine the fundamental right to privacy and annulled the Commission's decision in the Safe Harbour case. The latter infringed the fundamental human right to the protection of personal data and allowed the transfer of a multitude of personal data of EU citizens. Following the clear communication given by the Court of Justice of the EU, I believe that a strong legal framework for the protection of personal data must be established. We need reliable common rules on the protection of personal data in the EU, which can also apply to internet operators and the online sector in the US, which would allow for the reform of EU legislation.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – The wee's decision annulling No. Commission Decision 'Safe Harbour', on the adequacy of protection in the processing of personal data transferred from the EU to the US, is of paramount importance for the future of personal data within the EU. The rationale for the decision, by setting out the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and Its No. 95/46/EC Directive, concluded that the USA does not ensure a level of protection of personal data equivalent to that of the Union and recognised the power of national supervisory authorities to assess compliance with the terms of the Directive when transferring data to third countries. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to redefine its priorities and to guarantee the high protection of the data transmitted by the EU of natural persons and companies, since such transfers are impossible to avoid and create a risk of legal ambiguity. At the same time, the European Parliament's questions on the impact of this court decision on other ongoing agreements directly or indirectly concerning personal data, such as the umbrella agreement with the US, TTIP and the new EU legislative package on data transfers in the context of police and judicial cooperation, are reasonable.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – The decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on 6 6 September, in the act of the European Commission's Decision No 2000/520/EC, known as the Safe Harbour Agreement, has obvious implications for the amendment of the rules on the transfer of personal data from the EU to the US. One consequence of this decision is that transfers of personal data to the USA under Safe Harbour are in principle prohibited, as the principles of this agreement are considered not to ensure an adequate and sufficient level of protection of personal data. In this sense, it is imperative that measures be taken to ensure that this procedure should be put to an end, ensuring the protection of individual data and, therefore, fundamental safeguards.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the statement of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine (2015/2869 (RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me thank you for this opportunity to discuss today the situation in Ukraine with the European Parliament. Much attention has been given to other pressing problems lately, but Ukraine remains a top priority for the EU. We must not underestimate what is at stake. First and foremost, it is human lives. The latest numbers are appalling: almost 8 000 people killed, 1.5 million displaced, and another 1.1 million have left the country since the start of the conflict. Secondly, basic principles of international law have been challenged: territorial integrity, sovereignty and the inviolability of borders – cornerstones of the European security order. Crimea and Sevastopol have been illegally annexed by the Russian Federation. I want to thank the European Parliament and its Members for keeping Ukraine high on the agenda.  The interparliamentary meetings, the recently—signed Memorandum of Understanding between the European Parliament and the Rada on parliamentary support and capacity building, and recent visits to Ukraine by the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Committee on International Trade, the Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Committee on Foreign Affairs are just a few examples. In less than two weeks, some of you will travel to Ukraine to monitor the local elections – another opportunity for the Ukrainian people to exercise their democratic rights. All of this strengthens EU-Ukraine relations. Your role cannot be overestimated. The European Parliament ratified the Association Agreement a bit more than a year ago, paving the way towards an era of new opportunities for citizens in Ukraine, based on its political association and economic integration with the European Union. During the last plenary debate on Ukraine in February, you discussed at length the Normandy Format and the Minsk Agreements. High Representative/Vice—President Mogherini stressed then that the diplomatic efforts led by Germany and France are genuinely European, and that we must remain united in our support of the Normandy Format and the Trilateral Contact Group in order to achieve results. A lot has happened since then. During spring and summer, the situation on the ground deteriorated. Nevertheless, Ukraine adopted decentralisation-related amendments to the constitution at first reading, including a provision enabling special arrangements for self-government in certain areas of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, in line with the Minsk Agreements. Since 1 September – following intense diplomatic efforts – the ceasefire, which was first agreed in September 2014, is at last being largely respected. Two weeks ago, an agreement was reached on the withdrawal of tanks and smaller weapons, implementation of which has already begun. The EU-supported Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) special monitoring mission is growing further to its full strength of 1 000 monitors on the ground to cope with all new tasks of verification and monitoring. We know, however, that it is not only the number of monitors but also, and above all, their full access to the territory which can make a real difference. That is why we strongly emphasise the need for it. Demining along both sides of the line of contact has started. The Normandy Summit of 2 October 2015 gave further impetus to the political process, and the separatist so-called ‘elections’ in Luhansk and Donetsk – which would have violated the Minsk Agreements – have now been deferred. Does this mean that the conflict is almost over? Clearly not. Cases of shooting and shelling still take place; people continue to die. Internally displaced persons are unable to return to their homes. The modalities of the local elections according to OSCE standards still need to be fixed under Ukrainian law. The special arrangement for self-government has to be agreed and an amnesty implemented. There should be no Russian forces on Ukrainian soil. Ukraine should regain control over the 450-kilometre-long segment of its border that it has been forced to abandon. Nevertheless, what we have now is a process that is moving in the right direction, albeit slowly and sometimes hesitantly. This is no small thing. The joint support of EU institutions and Member States for this process has certainly contributed substantially.  The EU will continue to support the process, including through financial and in-kind contributions to the OSCE special monitoring mission. Also, the EU and its Member States have contributed over EUR 242 million in humanitarian and recovery aid, including EUR 42 million provided by the Commission to all affected populations, including refugees in Russia and Belarus. In parallel, the Commission is engaging in trilateral talks on energy and on implementation of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area. They are ensuring that gas supplies to and through Ukraine remain uninterrupted during the winter season. They are also addressing Russia’s concerns about the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area without amending or delaying the implementation of the agreement from 1 January onwards. EU relations with Ukraine are developing dynamically despite the difficult realities of the conflict which its authorities and, above all, its people have to face. Our goal remains to help them create a well-functioning state and a successful economy. Just a few examples: the Support Group for Ukraine continues to focus EU advice, technical assistance and financial resources on the Ukrainian reform process; over six billion of the original EUR 11 billion support package announced by the EU in March 2014 has already been mobilised to launch the reforms that will secure the future. The EU Advisory Mission to Ukraine is doing important work to assist security-sector reforms. Its mandate is currently under review to further streamline its activities toward Ukraine’s most immediate needs. On visa liberalisation, we are moving towards the goal of visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens to the EU, an important step to enhance people-to-people contacts. Further progress is needed, notably in the fight against corruption. To sum up, we have reason to be cautiously optimistic about progress on the diplomatic track if we remain united, and we will continue to support Ukraine on its path to becoming a prosperous country. These are our joint objectives, and I look forward to working towards them together.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, since the last debate we had on Ukraine, more progress has been made. It is, of course, primarily about the arrangements for the withdrawal of several categories of armaments. That has brought a boost to security and we have to admit that. On the other hand, we have, of course, following the meeting mentioned by the Commissioner, an important political agreement to cancel the vote scheduled for 18 October. Keeping this vote would have made the situation in the eastern territories enormously complicated.  I believe that, in this context, we must welcome the implementation, even delayed, of the Minsk agreements, being aware, however, that the end of 2015 is being missed. The date will probably have to be extended in 2016.  On the other hand, we must note that, from a political point of view, Kiev's confidence in the Moscow authorities has not increased. The messages our friends, Poroshenko and others, send are not encouraging. That is why I think local elections are an important test; a test for central authorities, of course, but also an opportunity to see democratic engagement.  I am glad that we will have a European Parliament mission there, and I believe that we do not need to talk at this point about lifting sanctions.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The problem that Mr Preda has just rightly named is that nothing will really be finished this year. And yet the meeting in Paris has at least given us the hope that a peaceful and better solution will be brought closer, albeit in smaller steps than we would like. We have elections in Ukraine. Of course – and this goes without saying – elections can only take place where democratic principles are respected, so that those who want to stand for election can also stand for election, and not just those who want to stand for election. We have another positive development, namely the agreement on gas supplies and transmission, which, thank God, has also become possible because the Ukrainian Government has said that it will take more measures than before to limit the mass gas theft. You said something, Commissioner, about sums that have flowed and which are also important. Unfortunately, you have not said anything about the state of the necessary reforms, about the fight against corruption. Here I am most concerned that we are also very slow there and that we are not moving fast enough. Here, too, we should try to work with appropriate friendly pressure.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The United Nations Charter contains the principle of refraining from using force in international relations. Russia is responsible for aggression in Georgia, the annexation of Crimea, is the real party to the conflict in Ukraine, but it was at the UN that Vladimir Putin proposed a coalition in Syria to the West. These two cases, Ukraine and Syria, cannot be treated differently. This principle of the seedibility of cases was applied to Russia's predecessor – the Soviet Union – in Yalcie. We, the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe, will do everything to ensure that there is no second Yat.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the last Normandy meeting was an encouraging move forward and I would certainly like to welcome its results. The commitments made by all sides must be respected by all sides. This is the only way forward out of the madness. However, I would like to warn all of us not to be over-optimistic. Yesterday the ceasefire was breached. One Ukrainian soldier was killed. The silence is very fragile. I would like to remind you that the humanitarian aid organisations are still not able to resume their activities in the areas controlled by the pro-Kremlin militia. As the winter approaches, this may result in a humanitarian catastrophe on an unimaginable scale. We also observe the Kremlin puppets trying to bargain, or blackmail, over the local elections issue. No surprise, actually! But one thing is clear: the elections will simply be illegitimate unless they are held in accordance with Ukrainian legislation and with the participation of internally displaced persons.  I am absolutely sure that, at this juncture, sending any signals to Moscow about the possibilities of softening or lifting the sanctions would be far too premature and therefore harmful. The Kremlin would take it simply as a sign of our weakness. Instead, the EU should focus on demining, on sending a Common Security and Defence Policy mission to eastern Ukraine and on the secure delivery of humanitarian aid.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Thank you for your assessment. It is undisputed that the actions of the Normandy format show signs of détente, a general calming of the military situation in Donbass and now also the postponement of elections in that region. However, this progress has little to do with the European Parliament, which has, unfortunately, always refused to recognise that the weak point of Minsk II is precisely that its intermediate stages must first be negotiated with the various political oligarch iced structures in Ukraine. Whether and how this is done, and who is interested in this, was a recent easy task for EP delegations on the ground. EU think tanks are also increasingly expressing the fact that not only in Moldova, but also in Ukraine, much is increasingly out of control. There has been little real progress in social and ethnic pacification of society, in the fight against corruption and in the unbundling of political and economic interests. Much has also been started within the legal framework, but implementation of the reforms – the much-needed reforms – is progressing extremely slowly. It is also the responsibility of this House, the political rulers, in Ukraine, to take the margin of manoeuvre to end up doing only what they like. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I have just been in Kiev for three days and I have to say that The statement by President Juncker that we should no longer allow the United States to press into a strategy towards Russia, but that we should think about easing sanctions on Ukraine, has deeply unsettled many citizens who are now actively working in the reform process. And I would like to underline what Mr Austreviius said: what is happening at the moment with regard to the implementation of Minsk II is by no means an occasion to talk about easing sanctions; if something happens, it is still the result of a mixed strategy of diplomacy and sanctions. I hope that no decision will be taken in January – without significant changes in eastern Ukraine – to re-decide on the sanctions, but I would actually be in favour of putting an end to this whole debate. That would be much better for those who are involved in the reforms in Ukraine, because they need this commitment from the European Union for their work. And there is light and shadow. It is simply good to read in the newspaper that the Minister for Economic Affairs says that the oligarchs will no longer be involved in the next round of privatisation. That's a word, you can measure it against it.  It is good that an anti-corruption office has been set up. It is good that there is the new police that are being paid and that are no longer prone to corruption. But there is no lack of reform of the Public Prosecutor's Office, and the EU has to put precise pressure on and say: Hey, Poroshenko, what are you always talking about? You want to fight corruption and you don't reform the prosecutor's office - that's not how it works! So, sanctions and constructive cooperation on reforms!

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, irrespective of one’s position on this emotive subject, I hope that colleagues will share my relief that the ceasefire continues largely to hold, despite the tensions ahead of the 25 October 2015 local elections. I continue to question the practical viability of the two breakaway regions, bearing in mind the geography of the strategic points that remain in Ukrainian hands, and I am mindful that military units remain in easily—mobilised positions well within artillery range. Judging by the Syrian-dominated headlines, one would be mistaken for thinking that all is now well in Ukraine. This perfectly summarises the reactive manner in which the West is conducting itself in contrast to President Putin’s dramatic shift in foreign policy. We are now playing catch-up – always seemingly two steps behind, where he has taken the initiative. Regrettably, President Putin is pulling our strings – from Ukraine to the Baltic and down into Syria, not to mention in South Ossetia and Abkhazia and Georgia. These numerous serious security challenges mean that we must now move beyond the arguments of who is right and who is wrong, accepting that – whether we like it or not – President Putin is acting in what he perceives to be Russia’s interests. If we are to see a genuine workable peace, and not just frozen conflicts across borders, we are going to have to compromise on a solution to this conflict. That is real diplomacy. The fight against Islamic State is a perfect place to start that diplomacy.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, we all welcome the progress of peace in this fragile period. Nevertheless, the cumulative measures for Ukraine amount to 11 billion euros, financed from the European Union budget and by financial institutions. However, whether it pleases or not, in this country, nothing is clear: no transparency, no control. It was not until 25 August that the first 70 detectives from the anti-corruption office were chosen and they did not begin their work until 1 October 2015. Kiev will host an international anti-corruption conference on 16 November, when we know that Ukraine is making no effort in this area, as revealed by the OECD, which places Ukraine 142nd out of 175 in the corruption rankings. In May, we received in Parliament a delegation of Ukrainian opposition MEPs, whom Mr Schulz refused to receive, which is absolutely incredible. They have expressed the greatest reservations about the use of European funds and have denounced proven cases of embezzlement, published in Ukraine but unfortunately not in the European press. What are the constraints imposed by the European Union on Ukraine to date? Can the Union continue to provide uncontrollable and, to date, uncontrolled funds?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the nationalist opposition of the reactionary Ukrainian Government and the ongoing imperialist intervention by the European Union, the US and NATO are exacerbating the situation in Ukraine. Recently, Ukrainian President Poroshenko imposed, by decree, sanctions on hundreds of legal and natural persons, banned entry into the country to deputies, journalists, lawyers from other countries. Among them are Sotiris Zarianopoulos, MEP of the Communist Party of Greece, Giorgos Lambroulis, MEMBER of the Communist Party of Greece and Vice-President of the Greek Parliament, and George Maganas, a KKE official, with the funny accusation that they are turning against Ukraine's national interests and integrity, and this is because KKE officials were invited and went as observers to the elections held in Donpas in November 2014. The Ukrainian government's accusations against KKE officials are unsubstantiated and defamatory. They provoke, while they have come to the point of supporting the action of fascist forces by prohibiting the action of ukrainian communists. We demand here and now that the unacceptable Poroshenko decree be annulled.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would just like to say to the previous speakers that Russia has violated the territorial integrity of a country and has invaded it by military means. Secondly, you, Mr Aliot, and the supporting opposition people, who at that time, together with the Yanukovych government, squeezed out the country and gave in to corruption and made money disappear, please do not give us any advice. I would also like to say that we have had great success with the Minsk agreement. The conflict has been contained, weapons are being withdrawn, the election date has been cancelled. This is, for the first time, a pause, a ceasefire, which we have a positive view of. However, it must also be said that sanctions can only be lifted as agreed if Minsk as a whole is implemented. Finally, I would like to say that we must support this country so that, unlike others, it must first complete the reform process that it has begun and ensure the rule of law and democracy, and we must help it to establish a functioning economic order as a precondition for ending the destabilisation of the Putin system in Ukraine.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, weapons in Ukraine have remained silent for five weeks, and citizens everywhere, except in rebel-held areas in the east of the country, will express political will in local elections in ten days.  However, it would be quite wrong to attribute this situation to the agreement reached on lasting peace. Peace in Ukraine, as well as war, depend on Moscow's sense of geopolitical threat, and Russia is now more focused on the middle east whose chaos it wants to exploit to compensate the oil market, due to damages from sanctions and costly war operations in eastern Ukraine.  In Paris, Ukraine received a serious task from European peace brokers: reforming electoral legislation in line with the future decentralisation of a state that will be accepted by pro-Russian rebels. At the same time, this will be difficult to enforce due to resistance from political options that do not want such a loosening of Moscow.  The good news is that the agreed gas supply for the whole season is at reasonable prices. At least one less problem for the economically and politically overburdened Ukrainian people.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, as violations of the ceasefire decrease and the Russian offensive has partly abated, it is true that the situation in the Donbas area has improved, but the danger for Ukraine is far from over. Russia is seeking to assert its position in Crimea and to add the so-called People’s Republics of Luhansk and Donetsk to the list of breakaway territories classified internationally as frozen conflicts. Not content with this, however, Mr Putin is also trying to add to the destabilisation of Ukraine by seeking ways to undermine its economy with projects such as Nord Stream. In essence, unable to take Ukraine by force, Putin is reverting to the more traditional and subversive KGB tactics, in which he has been trained, of attempting to take Ukraine politically. As Russia now ensconces itself at the negotiating table in relation to Syria, it will seek to use its position there as leverage over the situation in Ukraine and the associated European Union sanctions. We in Europe must remain conscious of this, and not let the pressure of the migration crisis and the fight against terrorism in the Middle East divert our attention and allow Russia its way in Ukraine.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – It is dangerous to forget about Ukraine in the face of all the other problems we have in the world today. Our interest in Ukraine must be constant. We must also avoid the temptation to talk about Ukraine and its European future exclusively in the context of the Cold War, in which we have been in fact for a long time. Reforms are needed and we must support them. Reforms in terms of strengthening the rule of law are also being reformed . Ukraine owes us a response to the investigation into the political killings of Russian journalists and politicians in Ukraine. Political dialogue is needed. And a great diplomatic effort by all the players for dialogue with both the separatists and the neighbours if we want a democratic European Ukraine to flourish to its full extent.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Honourable Commissioner, honourable colleagues, it is necessary to send a strong signal to the European Parliament that Russia's intervention in Syria will in no way weaken Europe's commitments to Ukraine. So far, it is certainly not the time to talk about lifting sanctions against Russia, because the results of Russian aggression are still not being reversed. The territorial integrity of Ukraine, occupied Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk areas controlled by Russian-backed separatists, are still not restored. The occupied territories are regularly violated by human rights, ukrainian local government elections will not take place in the Luhansk and Donetsk area on 25 October. So in this context, it was very strange to hear the speech of the Head of the European Commission, and it is supposedly time to re-rebuild good relations with Russia. Russia has not yet demonstrated its determination to respect international law and to respect the right of its neighbours to choose their own future.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Ukraine, as seen from Paris, presents us with a picture of lights and shadows. Of course, geopolitical interests are increasingly tangled, even with the complicated Middle East chessboard. It is no secret, in fact, that Putin's decision to consolidate positions in Syria in support of Assad, and thus create a further stalemate, is an important negotiating card to spend perhaps on having softer positions in Ukraine itself. The news from the front would seem quite positive. The cease-fire seems to be holding, despite yesterday's dead and two wounded. The postponement of the Donetsk and Lugansk elections favours détente, there is still talk of a special statute for autonomy, there has been the gas agreement, and all in all Minsk II seems to be starting to work.  The real question, however, that we should ask ourselves is whether today's Ukrainian Government is a credible government and partner. I honestly see very, very little from this point of view. The reforms are completely bogged down and the European Union often looks more to those on liberalisation and economics than to the very important reforms on corruption, which is, moreover, rampant. The influence of the oligarchs is still incredible and the economic catastrophe remains behind the doors, despite the agreement with the IMF, and the conflict costs EUR 5 million a day, according to Poroshenko, but I believe a little more. Would we really like to negotiate the visa regime with them? Frankly, I would say no. Rather, I would say that it is time to make silent and public diplomacy speak loudly and that we also need détente on the sanctions front. I say this especially to those countries that continue to ... . (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Despite our efforts by the European Union, even more than a year after the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, the situation in the area remains frozen. The situation is significantly affecting eastern Europe from an economic and political point of view, and I believe that the Union's efforts to definitively regulate the situation must be stepped up. It is true that European diplomacy in general has taken significant steps towards bringing Ukraine down the European path. From The political statements of Viktor Yanukovych in 2011, when he told both the Russian Federation and the European Union, that "I am convinced that Ukraine will be a member of the European Union in about ten years", to the last success of the negotiations between the European Union and the Russian Federation, which last week led to the postponement of the elections for 2016, which were intended to be held in the separatist republics of eastern Ukraine , huge steps have been taken, indeed.  However, it is not enough! As a representative of Romania, a country in the vicinity of Ukraine, I believe that the short respite from postponing elections in the separatist provinces must be used to the fullest to prevent a new conflict in this region.  Basically the organization and ratification of elections in the separatist provinces will also mean the de facto consecration of the independence from Ukraine of these provinces and it will be the moment when conflicting tensions will break out. This is the moment when the European Union should do everything in its power to prevent it, because if this frozen conflict re-emerges, this area of Europe will become a hotbed of instability for many years to come, with incalculable consequences for the economies of the neighbouring member states of the European Union.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I will try to clarify the Polish: we have always been between two enemies, between Germany and Russia. At the moment everything has changed, independent Ukraine, Belarus and Lithuania have cut us off from Russia. At this point, however, our potential enemy was Ukraine, which has territorial pretensions to us, which during the war murdered several hundred thousand Poles, and these flag bearers were then stored in Germany, and therefore we are very afraid of a situation in which Poland will find itself between Germany, in which it is not known who will rule, because once there was the Weimar Republic, and then suddenly the Third Reich appeared. I don't know if there will ever be an 4th Reich – so for Polish potential ally is the enemy of our enemy, Russia, please understand that. We are very pleased that Ukraine has to keep a large part of its troops in the east and not on the border with Poland, because we do not know when the flag bearers can come to power in Ukraine.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – I fully support those of my colleagues who believe that the conflicts in Syria and Ukraine must not be linked in any way. The minsk ceasefire conditions must be fulfilled. It's non-decal. And on January 1, 2016, Ukraine must fully control the country's border. If this does not happen, no review of sanctions against Russia is possible.  I appreciate the contribution of Chancellor Merkel and President Olanda to the resolution of this conflict, but I would like to stress that the European Union must also be included in both the Minsk and Normandy formats and the High Foreign Affairs Representative must sit at the negotiating table.  I admire The Radu of Ukraine and the Government for the determination with which the country's legislation and reforms are reformed in times of war. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. – Dear Mrs Kalniete, thank you very much for your blue card question.  You were in Ukraine, both this year in July and in Maidan, when the events just started, and now, months and years later, you do not think that if, at the very beginning, in November 2013, the variant of violent overthrow is chosen, but extraordinary elections, this would avoid thousands of deaths both in Kiev and later in eastern Ukraine?

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: answer to the blue card question. – History can't be played a second time, so it's just speculation. Responsibility for what has happened lies entirely with Russia, which is a direct participant in this conflict. Instead of talking about beautiful words and insulting Ukraine in fascism and other incoient ness, Russia should think more about how to regulate its relations with Ukraine in a civilised and European way.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I would also like to join those who wish to separate soviet interventions in Syria and Crimea. I say Soviet interventions because they really remind us of an imperial sequence of steps. At the same time, it should also be seen that many people are interested in perhaps rewarding them for their involvement in Syria in order to have some better relations with the Russian side, or perhaps being more lenient in the case of Crimea. Not! We reject that. The other thing I would like to say is that there will be municipal elections in Ukraine next week, and unfortunately, despite all the reforms, the Ukrainian side is still ind payable for the development of electoral districts in which national minorities, in this case Hungarian and, in particular, Romanian national minorities, can have sufficient representation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to convince you that this is not really an exotic land there, but a country that is just beyond our borders, and this is absolutely about us. If russian intervention or the economic situation in Ukraine deteriorates, it will mean that tens, hundreds of thousands of refugees and expatriates from Ukraine will want to live in European countries, e.g. Poland. This is a serious problem, we must support Ukraine, including economic support, but also, let us be clear, we must require some real reforms from ukraine. This is a two-way street.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, the shooting-down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH 17 was an eye-opener for many societies on Russian aggression in Ukraine. Two hundred and ninety-eight lives were lost. Now we have the results of the investigation into this horrible crime: the missiles were launched from the so-called separatist-controlled areas in eastern Ukraine, from a missile system of Russian origin. The report brings us one step closer to finding those responsible for this crime and bringing them to justice. Also, political responsibility must not be forgotten. Russia’s behaviour has been strange during this whole investigation. It did not support the creation of a UN international tribunal but has, instead, been developing its own version of the shooting-down.
