We should not forget that this tragedy was possible only because of the Russian aggression in Ukraine. Every single day that this aggression continues we have new victims and refugees.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I congratulate our Ukrainian friends today on The Day of Ukrainian Defenders and all those who gave their lives for the freedom of Ukraine. It is second that I look back at the report that was published yesterday on the very clearly established fact that the MH-17 was brought down by a surface-to-air missile from the occupied territories and an investigation into the criminal responsibility of those guilty of the deaths of 298 people should be completed.  Ukraine must remain our priority, a clear political priority. Restrictive measures towards Russia should be tied not only to the implementation of the Minsk agreements, but also to peaceful reintegration and parts of the Donbass, but also to Crimea. This must be a clear political message from the European Parliament.  Let's observe local elections, help our friends consolidate, democracy and decentralise. It's a good thing the gas deal was reached. We want free trade agreements to enter into force. We also want a breakthrough that would allow visa liberalisation to enter into force, the implementation of the Association Agreement agenda, but also its entry into force, and I call on countries that have not ratified the Agreement to do so and our Dutch counterparts to be attenual to these initiatives on a referendum that I do not see as having any particular meaning, and can complicate the entry into force.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Undoubtedly, the implementation of the Minsk agreements and the fight against corruption are essential for Ukraine's prosperous development. Nevertheless, I would also like to draw attention in this debate to the economic and social situation within Ukraine. Because the situation there is worrying! Without massive support from the EU and the IMF, the country would be insolvent, but the social situation continues to worsen. High inflation, the rise in energy prices and the rise in unemployment mean that around a third of Ukrainians now live at or below the poverty line.  This creates a social explosive that urgently needs to be defused. The EU must also be more involved in this. In other words, we must not focus our economic attention solely on the implementation of the association agreements, the economic effects of which, above all, strengthen the export economy in Ukraine, and also not just to prevent state bankruptcy. Ukraine urgently needs support and promotion of domestic structures and demand in order to also address the fight against poverty and the promotion of employment.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: I would like to zoom in on two things, Commissioner. Firstly, we need full clarity on the MH17 disaster. Flemish victims were also among them. Fifteen months of research has been required to ensure that the aircraft was brought down by a Russian-made BUK. But we still don't know who fired the missile. The Russian disinformation machine has sown confusion for 15 months and spread conspiracy theories. There have been attempts to cover up the truth. We need to know everything and bring those responsible to justice. For this reason too, there can be no question of easing sanctions. Secondly, local elections will take place on 25 October, but not in Donetsk and Lugansk. By the end of this year, before 31 December, Minsk II must be given its final say, up to and including control over the border. But that deadline will not be met. So I want to know what the plan is. What will the EU do to prevent Donbass from being de facto abandoned, just as it did with Crimea, and to ensure that the region is reintegrated into Ukraine?

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, the people of Ukraine cannot be forgotten. The EU should be able to handle two crises at the same time: the refugee crisis and Ukraine. The humanitarian situation in Ukraine has escalated, with more than 1.5 million internally displaced people, 200 000 of whom are children. There are 5 million people in urgent need of aid. The majority of humanitarian organisations still do not have access to the occupied areas, and the EU should increase its efforts to ensure freedom of movement of aid to Donetsk and Luhansk. I also call on the Member States to do more to support the commendable process of reform undertaken by the authorities in Ukraine and to implement the Association Agreement. Ukraine and Syria are two separate conflicts and should be handled as such. The sanctions against Russia are linked to breaches of international law in Ukraine, and the EU should stand firm and united behind them until the Minsk Agreement is fully implemented. The local elections will be a test of Russia’s resolve to implement the agreement. Let me finish by saying that we want dialogue, we should have dialogue, we have dialogue – but it takes two to tango, and Russia is not playing by the rules.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Madam President, as Russia apparently cannot handle two conflicts at the same time, and the new priority is saving Assad’s regime, it has decided finally to allow for the implementation of the Minsk II Agreement – most probably in the hope that by starting to comply, sanctions would not be renewed at the end of the year. Certainly, those sanctions are technically tied to the implementation of the Minsk II Agreement, but one should not lose sight of the bigger strategic picture. That picture indicates not a change of heart on the part of Russia, and even less a change in behaviour, but rather a shift of focus from Eastern Europe – with the exception of a Moldova rocked by the demonstration of pro-Moscow forces – to the Middle East. As Russia is simply demonstrating that it is acting strategically in geopolitical terms, the West’s response should be in similar terms.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Unfortunately, Russia's policy of softening the Union's position seems to be bearing fruit. Because how do we understand Jean-Claude Juncker's appalling statement of 8 October that we need to seek a more useful relationship with Russia and that it cannot continue as it is? What did the President mean, because unfortunately it is probably not that Russia is finally about to end its aggression and that Crimea should return to Ukraine as an integral part of it in accordance with international law? What does it mean that, as President Juncker went on to say, russians need to be treated decently? Maybe it is Russia that should treat other countries, including Ukraine, but also Georgia, decently? Unfortunately, the fact that business with Gazprom was returned to business again with the expansion of Nord Stream, that there was pressure on Ukraine in Paris to unilaterally implement the political part of the Minsk agreements, even though the separatists and Russia are not fully fulfilling their obligations, shows that the Union's strong stance so far is becoming increasingly shaky.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, the situation in Ukraine is a ticking time bomb that can trigger a major migration wave . Only the Internal Displaced People (IDP) is almost two million in Ukraine. The never-ending war, the economic downturn, inflation are exacerbating living standards sharply. According to the UNHCR, five million people already need humanitarian aid. There is a growing flow of migrants in the self-proclaimed eastern Ukrainian republics. The so-called Luhansk government has decided to terminate ten UN agencies, including those such as the UNHCR. These denunciations mean stopping the distribution of 16,000 tons of vital humanitarian aid. Some 150,000 people have been stopped from humanitarian aid. People are fleeing war and misery. They're loosening the floodgates of the eastern refugee wave. To stop it is to stop the war. To stop the war is to help Ukraine win it.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I look at this debate a little bit from the experience of our last three months, and firstly, it must be said that it is good that we have not forgotten the issues of Ukraine, because there was a moment – we had the impression – that Ukraine was going down to the background.  Secondly, we must also be aware that we have started to understand Russia better during this time, and I think it is positive that the Minsk agreements are more or less being respected. I consciously say "more or less". This is also given for Ukraine for some time. I support those voices that have sounded here that Ukraine should use this moment for real reforms. We, as the European Union, expect a kind of economic, social vision, a concept of the Ukrainian state without corruption, because we are right, and on the other hand we must also be aware that we need quick support – I also agree with these views – poverty, deprivation and hunger, and winter in Ukraine, and let us remember: winter in Ukraine is not winter in Cannes.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I want to say in this one-minute speech that I feel as if Europe is being pursued by one crisis after another.  Ukraine's crisis is mingles with other crises – both refugee and Greek. In my opinion, it is important that we do not back down from those demands that have resulted in European sanctions against the Russian Federation for the procedure it has applied in Ukraine. In my opinion, it is very important to stick to this policy. Although, for example, I am personally a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, where these sanctions also provoke negative reactions, I want to say that I fully support them. Because such violations of international legal obligations, international legal sovereignty, cannot be allowed, triggering such a huge conflict that the Russian Federation has demonstrated in Ukraine. Until they proceed with the resumption of the situation in terms of the peaceful fulfilment of their obligations, I think that we cannot withdraw from these sanctions. It's going to cost us something, but I think that's our principled position.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – I fully support the previous speaker in the sense that we must not give in. We must not actually be fooled into the fact that the situation has improved now and everything is going well and we can start to take down sanctions and think only about other problems. We cannot let Russia defeat the Syrian Gami, which it is currently playing with the European Union.  However, I would very much like to draw attention to what was said– this internal flow of refugees, which is in Ukraine. We know that the next step could be exactly what we have seen in the south – that the flow of refugees is starting to move out of Ukraine. Which means that we have to deal with these internal refugees in Ukraine, there is a humanitarian catastrophe there! But we must also use the young people there, in the sense that we give them the opportunity to be training, to come here to the European Union, to raise this new young resource, who, even when he goes back to eastern Ukraine, can help build local life there. So I think it is very important that we also have a programme for training for young people who are currently refugees.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the European Union is constantly trying to take the initiative away from Member States in the foreign policy sphere, be it the military or diplomacy. It is precisely the attitude towards Russia that is the best indication that the Union does not have the necessary capacity. Our one-sided, fan-like approach in Ukraine without too much concrete action has left Moscow amply room to spread instability and its own influence in eastern Europe.  Similarly happened in Syria. Europe's inertia and leadership of partial interests and susceptibility to influence from the sidelines have left Putin's door wide open to playing the world's hero and righteous in the fight against the Islamic State. Everything Moscow has achieved in Ukraine and Syria has been made possible by western powers. Let's not keep looking for the culprit in the other one. Let's finally look in the mirror.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, Minsk 2 brought peace, loose, perhaps deceptive, but still brought peace. This is what we can determine and with which we can be satisfied. He also brought dialogue. He cleared the way for an election. It has paved the way for what we hope will be reforms, a better Ukrainian economy and the fight against corruption.  But what I have been warning about and what I have talked about in previous statements when it comes to Ukraine is the need to decentralize Ukraine, regionalise it, create conditions where all minorities will be entitled to their own language, the right to their rights and in territorial terms, which was also discussed by the High Commissioner in this hall at the time and I believe that this is the way to solve this problem in the east of Ukraine in the long term and permanently.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: The situation in Ukraine remains the same. The government has not been able to stimulate the economy, there is no stable state operation, corruption is flourishing, the power of the oligarchs remains unchanged. The European Union has not been able to contribute to the solution. This would require taking into account the interests of all parties concerned. There would be no armed separatists if the Ukrainian government had taken note in time of the efforts of the people of eastern Ukraine to self-determination. It is very popular in this Parliament to simply classify President Putin as an aggressor and to close the issue of Russia, but perhaps Russia's legitimate national security interests should also be taken into account, while the United States is slowly pushing nato's border to Russia's borders.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the international community and the European Union have decided to financially support Ukraine. In this context, they restructured Ukraine's public debt as follows: First, they imposed a 20% debt haircut, which led to a debt write-off of EUR 18 billion. Euro. Secondly, they linked the repayment of the remaining debt to a development clause, which means that Ukraine will only repay its debt when its economy grows. In fact, the international community and the European Union applied to Ukraine the debt write-off model applied in 1953 to cut West Germany's debt at the time. And while the European Union has implemented a write-off of part of the debt and repayment of the rest with a development clause for Ukraine, it refuses to do the same for Greece. Instead, it implements tough measures in Greece, memoranda that lead to armies of unemployed people and millions of poor Greek citizens. Why are tough measures being implemented against Greece and not debt write-offs like they did in Ukraine? Is this the so-called European solidarity with Greece? Shame!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members for this discussion, for their engagement on this issue and for their remarks here today.  Many Members commented on the reform process in Ukraine. Let me give you my update on what is going on in Ukraine in the field of judicial reform and reform of the public prosecutor’s office, and also in the field of the fight against corruption, which you mentioned several times. I can only confirm that the reforms are up-and-running. They are now working very intensively on the reform of the judiciary system and also on the reform of the public prosecutor’s office. They have set up a national bureau against corruption and also the anti-corruption team within the prosecutor’s office. The selection of detectives is ongoing. You know that these reforms also represent the steps forward which are the conditions for provision of the second and third tranche of EU financial support to Ukraine. So part of the purpose of my mission was to look at these reforms also from the perspective of financing. I spoke to the President, to the Prime Minister, to Members of the Ukrainian Parliament and to representatives of civil society, and they all understand that it is not only about the laws to be adopted and institutional changes to be undertaken, but it is also about the enforcement of laws. The reform simply must function and it must work in practice. It is also about the continuous pressure from civil society and from the media in the fight against corruption, because there must be very strong understanding of what corruption is and how the fight against this phenomenon, which is really killing the chances for further development of the country, must continue. I have good feelings from Ukraine and every time we speak of the reforms in Ukraine we must realise how difficult the conditions are under which the Ukrainian authorities are working for these reforms. I also want to stress again the importance of your engagement outside Brussels and Strasbourg. Your visits to Ukraine are important, as are your public statements, your meetings with civil society and, last but not least, your work with Members of the Ukrainian Parliament. In this context, I would like to wish Mr Plenković and the other Members of the European Parliament delegation success in their meeting in Kiev on 4-6 November 2015. Again, let me repeat that I am very pleased that the European Parliament remains as committed as ever to the future of Ukraine and its relationship with the European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Despite the positive news of the globally confirmed ceasefire, the situation in eastern Ukraine remains highly concerning, unstable and hardly predictable. A lot of Ukrainian citizens are still in need of humanitarian aid due to the poverty and displacement resulting from the recent conflicts. Therefore, the EU’s humanitarian and recovery aid is more than welcomed. With regard to the sanctions, I consider that these should not be removed until the situation in the Ukrainian crisis has been straightened out and the lasting peacemaking process fulfilled. The EU must keep its essential role by constantly supporting Ukraine on its democratic path. This can be achieved through a society built on shared European values, an operational state and a strong economy.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – We have heard many individuals discussing Ukraine’s slow progress. It is truly a slow process to implement the Minsk agreements with such a difficult counterpart. It is truly a slow process to withdraw tanks and smaller weapons, as agreed in September 2014, when your country’s territorial sovereignty and integrity have been violated. Peace is truly a slow process when more than 8 000 people have been killed and 1.5 million have been displaced. I hope that through the organisation of balanced and objective elections, Ukraine can show how far it has come on the path of democracy.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – The local elections in Ukraine on 25 October will practically hold a mirror to see if our diplomatic activities on the Ukrainian-Russian conflict make sense. Ukraine's struggle for autonomy and its approach to the West is extremely important, and we have a duty to help the country on the path to consolidation. Financially, but also morally, pointing and expecting compliance with the rule of law, the elimination of corruption and the implementation of economic reforms. For all our sakes. Otherwise, the future of the masses will be hopeless, and the Union will have to deal not only with the migration wave in the Middle East, but also with a humanitarian crisis in our neighbour, and it may well be that it will also have to deal with the millions of Ukrainians coming from hopelessness.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – Although the situation in Greece and then the migration crisis have caused less talk in world politics about events in Ukraine, the issue has not been resolved at all. It remains important to put the Minsk agreement into effect, and in this context we need not only pro-Russian rebels, but also consistent behaviour by the Ukrainian institutions. Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty must be ensured, but it must also be acknowledged by all: there is a large Russian community in the country, which must be given the opportunity to resolve important issues in their lives and respect their linguistic rights. It is not only the situation of the Russian minority that we need to pay attention to, since the Ukrainian authorities last set up the electoral districts in Carpathia, which was inhabited by 12 percent Hungarians, in September in order to prevent hungarians from entering the county council. This attitude does not suggest that the Ukrainian leadership feels the importance of a fair settlement of ethnic relations, nor does it explicitly violate the agreement concluded between the hungarian minority advocacy organisation there and Petro Poroshenko.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – I consider it a key finding of the Commission, which issued a report on the downing of a Malaysian aircraft, that it uncovered Russian lies and propaganda.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The ongoing crisis in Ukraine began almost exactly two years ago, when the then-president Yanukovych suspended preparations for the implementation of an Association Agreement with the European Union. Today, the crisis is still far from being resolved. The crisis has had many effects, both domestic and international. According to an October 2014 estimate by the World Bank, the economy of Ukraine contracted by 8% during the year 2014 as a result of the crisis.  From the beginning of this conflict situation I have supported Ukraine and strongly believed that the EU must provide all of the help and assistance to help to resolve the conflict in Ukraine. As in the independent State it is up to Ukrainians to determine their future, not Russia, nor the EU. Nonetheless the EU must continue to strengthen relations with Ukraine and assist its national authorities in any way needed.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the oral question referred by Calude Moraes to the Commission on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs entitled Anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and Hate Speech in Europe (2015/2848(RSP)) (B8-0765/2015)

name: Claude MORAES
text: author. – Madam President, this oral question, which I am honoured to present on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, finds its origin in the public hearing which took place on 29 June 2015. The question is very simple and is in two parts: firstly to ask the Commission to make specific policy commitments and enforcement plans to fight hate speech and discrimination; and, secondly, to ask the Commission to adopt national strategies with clear goals to address anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and other forms of racism, similar to the national Roma integration strategies that we already have in place in our community. Behind these questions are some profound truths. We have a very complex situation: in dealing with anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, and indeed other forms of hate, we are dealing with some of the oldest forms of hatred on our continent. To deal with such issues and to think that they are simplistic – or indeed that in each Member State they will be the same – is, of course, naive. But equally, to think that – as a European Union, a union of values – we cannot take action against such a phenomenon would be naive and wrong. So these questions are really asking the Commission to update its action to ensure that we are ready for the new forms of expression of hatred, of anti—Semitism and Islamophobia, which we see today. We are not being naive in thinking that there are always common denominators, but we do know that something has changed. No longer are these attacks anecdotal. Our Fundamental Rights Agency gives us the statistics. They tell us, for example, that 46% have experienced abuse, and 33% have experienced abuse if they are Jewish, in the European Union. We have one in three Muslims, according to the Fundamental Rights Agency in a 2009 survey, experiencing discrimination in a 12—month period. These are snapshot statistics but we know that no longer do we have anecdotal statistics. We know that our police forces and our enforcement agencies in Member States are doing their job so that we can now have proper statistics. What do they tell us? They tell us a very simple truth: that, while we say we are taking action on the basis of the Council framework decision of 2008, we are not doing it in every Member State. The Race Equality Directive of 1999, which was supposed to have been implemented across the European Union, remains untransposed and unimplemented. We have the tools to deal with racism. We have the tools here in the European Union but, sadly, not all Member States have used those tools. In the end, each Member State will have its own issues and its own forms of expression in terms of how to deal with discrimination. Again, no-one is being so naive as to say that each situation is the same. But I repeat that there are two important points here. One is that we must deal with the political messages at European level – we must deal with education at European level and we must send out clear messages from this Parliament – and also we must deal with the practicalities. Yesterday, in my own Member State, a young Muslim woman was doused in alcohol on a train while people sat watching. For that victim it was a very painful situation, but let me say, too, that for the people who were watching it was also a very bad situation. That is why, in my country, there are exemplary sentences for those who commit a crime with racial motivation. The reasoning is that such crimes have an extra effect on society, and that is why you have such exemplary sentences. There is a bigger effect on society through anti—Semitism and Islamophobia, and it is a matter of opinion in this Chamber – and many will have their opinions – as to what has happened in the recent refugee crisis and as to the responsibilities we all have to assume. These things will be matters of opinion, but what is important is that we realise we have to take action. We have the tools in the European Union. We see ourselves as a union of values. We will not always interfere in what Member States do in terms of taking action, but we must send the political messages, we must educate and, most of all, we must require Member States to take action when they are ready. We have the tools at European Union level to do that. We have not taken that action, and Member States must now act and the Commission must now act.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, together with First Vice-President Timmermans, I held our first Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights last week. I would like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Claude Moraes, and all the other Members who were present for their involvement and steady support. The colloquium drew in part on the public hearing on Anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and Hate Speech which was held in the Civil Liberties Committee in June this year.  The colloquium confirmed that anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, like other forms of hatred, are our common concern. We must not leave the communities targeted, or the groups directly affected by hate, to deal with it alone because only together can we find solutions.  And I can promise you that the Commission will play its part. The Commission has published the conclusions of the colloquium, which include a ‘to do’ list – a roadmap of actions to which we should jointly commit and on which we should work. Let me mention some of them.  We will monitor rigorously the transposition and implementation of the EU legislation on racist hate speech and crime. Where necessary, we will launch infringement proceedings, and we will also assist Member States. We will share best practice guidance, reinforce training support and encourage cooperation with civil society so that EU rules are applied correctly.  We have also decided to designate two coordinators with specific responsibility for issues relating to anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, respectively. They will be the contact points within the Commission for both communities. Furthermore, the Commission will convene a high-level EU group on racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. Together with Member States, civil society and both communities’ representatives, we will evaluate the added value and the feasibility of dedicated national strategies. Hate speech currently is the main manifestation of anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim hatred. It fuels fear, spreads misconceptions and incites violence. I have started to discuss with IT companies and civil society how to address the issue of hate speech as a matter of priority, with full respect for freedom of expression. I briefed Justice Ministers about this at the Justice Council last Friday: they shared our concern and appreciated a coordinated approach to this. We also intend to counter online hate speech through targeted funding, monitoring activities and by identifying the need for further regulatory measures. EUR 5 750 000 has been earmarked in 2015 to encourage the monitoring of online hate speech. Let me be clear: we are speaking of content which is manifestly illegal under EU rules and European Court of Human Rights jurisprudence. So this is not a move against offensive or disturbing content, but against actual incitement to violent acts and hatred. We also agreed to promote further a pluralistic, inclusive and non-discriminatory society by monitoring the correct application of EU legislation on combating racial discrimination. Once again, let me stress the importance of adopting the Equal Treatment Directive.  Fostering inclusive education, mutual understanding and intercultural dialogue are equally important. We will prioritise EU projects promoting European values and history, including Holocaust remembrance, citizenship education and religious and media literacy. We will continue to support youth, student, school and civil-society projects and networks favouring tolerance and intercultural understanding. For example, in 2016 the Erasmus+ programme will prioritise projects that promote inclusion in education, training, youth and sport, and prevent marginalisation and the radicalisation of young people I am also committed to making it easier for small grassroots organisations to identify relevant funding and projects related to intolerance and racism. To this end, I will set up an easy-to-access webpage.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, we are against any kind of discrimination on the basis of belief, profession of faith, racial or ethnic issue. According to a survey by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights, the Jewish population is increasingly afraid of being verbally harassed or physically assaulted: 46% and 33%.  Moreover, the increase in incidents motivated by Islamophobia in the Union is unacceptable. In this regard, I mean that Islam is a respectable religion and Jihad is a pathology of Islam. But we cannot put aside the cruel persecution and also elimination and expulsion suffered by the Christian community in more than fifty countries. Remember the expulsion of two thousand Christians from the Nineveh Plain, twenty-one Daesh-beheaded Christians in Libya in February, Hindu extremists attacking churches in Nepal, or the total flight of Christians in Syria and Iraq. In addition, today, the Daesh has two hundred and thirty Christians abducted. The expression of hatred is a deviation from reason, an aberration. We must ensure a Union and a free and plural world that promotes tolerance between religions and mutual respect; and the protection of Roma, too. The European Security Agenda, Commissioner, is happily dealing with these issues, but in pureness we are in the presence of a declaration of intent. That is why I subscribe, ratify and congratulate the initiative of Claude Moraes.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, at this time of night we are here in the plenary session of the European Parliament who share a very lively concern. Intolerance and anti-Semitism are strongly regrown throughout the European Union.  There's a contest of concausas and they've been exposed here over and over again. On the one hand, the lousy management of the crisis and the exasperation of inequalities have led to the radicalisation of a Muslim collective within the European Union prone to purely anti-Semitic and therefore persecutory attitudes of Jewish identity. But there is also impunity on the net, cowardly disguised in anonymity, which allows the pathogenic transmission of hate speech and hate politics and direct incitement to criminal violence.  We therefore have an obligation to deal with this matter, and that is the meaning of the public hearing that took place in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on 29 June. And above all, to seek an answer based on the data highlighted by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights relating to the paris, Brussels or Toulouse attacks, but also with the sense of vulnerability of Jewish communities throughout the European Union.  Therefore, answers are needed. On the one hand, the possibility, promoted by the Commission, of the appointment of a special envoy on anti-Semitism which could be part of the Commission's own organizational structure, with the participation of this Parliament; but above all, the development and implementation of national strategies that take as an example those established in relation to the Roma community – with European Roma – to deal with the multiple variations and possibilities for responding to this execrable phenomenon. What we need to be very aware of is that the Commission needs to be involved by taking legislative initiatives to classify hate speech, hate politics and incitement to violence as a transnational serious European crime, especially in digital networks.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we should not debate anti-Semitism and Islamophobia simultaneously because they are not symmetrical phenomena. In today’s Western Europe, anti-Jewish hate crime, be it violence or hate speech, is usually perpetrated by Muslims, not by neo-Nazis. The deadly attacks in Brussels, Toulouse and elsewhere are only the tip of an iceberg. In many European cities, Jewish communities must spend enormous sums on physical security. Many Jews consider emigrating because of everyday harassment. Anti-Semitic hatred is preached in many of the most popular mosques and other Muslim institutions in Europe, as has been revealed by the media and the authorities. The constant portrayal of Muslims as victims only makes Islamic anti-Semitism a sensitive subject – which in turn makes it much more difficult to do something about it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Europe must remain a space of freedom, a continent of freedom, a continent where everyone will be able to express their religious beliefs, in which everyone, especially a young man, will be able to bear their religious characteristics and who will not be punished for it. Europe has won this freedom and must continue to win it.  It is unacceptable to deny the Holocaust, to deny what is part of our history and it is unacceptable to glorify all those regimes that we had on European soil during World War II, their symbols, fascist, Nazi symbols that unfortunately we can still see at various gatherings, and young people are often part of these gatherings. That is why I want to emphasize in particular the importance and importance of educating young people so that they are exactly what europe's future freedom will be, the future tolerance of Europe, and of course media such as the internet play a special role.  Definitely together with anti-Semitism we also have Islamophobia in the European Union, we have those who use this refugee crisis in a way to say that there will be an Islamization of Europe, which is really scandalous because we should first of all look up to what the Pope was saying in this Parliament as well and what the Pope has otherwise said and he has spoken about this refugee crisis and I believe that is exactly how , through speech of tolerance, not hatred, we can achieve what we want, more security, more stability, better happiness for citizens living in the European Union.  For 25 years I have fought for minority rights, for the rights of languages, for the right to religion and I am convinced that this fight is worth it. And so, Madam Commissioner, let's support good examples, because Europe is full of good examples and let's support good examples. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I fully agree with the list of my Members and the list of problems, but I do have a question. Every time we touch on this subject, we only talk about the religious, although non-religious people and atheists suffer disadvantages very often, for example in my country, Hungary, there are many settlements where the state does not even maintain a lay school. What do you think of that?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Although I am not 100% sure whether the translation was fully accurate or that I understood the question well, but in any case atheists are part of our society.  I'm a believer myself, but that, I say very rarely because it doesn't matter at all. It is important that we respect each other, that we respect those who are jewish denominations, that we respect Muslims, of course we respect all those Christian churches that exist in Europe, there are many of them, and that we respect each other, and atheists are part of us and we are all here together, some are believers, some are atheists. In this context, I think we really need to show the maximum relationship of tolerance between us.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, on 9 February 2015, four men assault and burn a homeless person in Valencia; on August 8, 2015, a gang assaults a transgender woman in Madrid. These are just two examples of hate crimes in the Spanish state. According to the Statistical Yearbook of the Ministry of the Interior, which offers figures for 2014, hate crimes in Spain increased in the last year by 10%. Hate crimes for homophobia or transphobia, for racism, for gypsyphobia, for religious beliefs; assaults on people with disabilities or people in poverty. The Anti-Intolerance Movement stresses that more than four thousand hate crimes continue to occur every year in Spain.  In Europe, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights estimates that between 60% and 90% of victims do not report. Aggressors are mainly members of neo-Nazi and racist groups, groups that enjoy a high degree of impunity. As an example of this impunity is the acquittal, last July, of seventeen accused of belonging to a group of neo-Nazi ideology in the so-far-known as Operation Porzer. Among the band members was the killer of the young anti-phascist Guillem Agulló, who was sentenced in 1995 to seventeen years in prison, of which he served only four years.  The European Commission must continue to legislate against hate crimes. A specific and comprehensive directive which also serves to promote comprehensive laws to protect against hatred and discrimination in the Member States.   (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, which is Did I understand you correctly that you also want to eliminate hatred on the Internet? Hate crimes – no question, but also the so-called famous hate speech, hate speech on the Internet. Do you want to follow that? Should the Internet be exempted from so-called hate speech, and if so, I ask you how you feel about the amendment that your group will sign tomorrow, namely that Europol is to eliminate information about people smugglers on the Internet? Europol is to be asked to delete smuggling information on the Internet, and your group wants to change that because it believes that censorship on the Internet opens the door. How does this go together?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: "blue card" response. – Obviously, the fight against hate crimes, against speeches and against everything that promotes these hate crimes must be carried out in all areas and it is also a struggle that has to be carried out on social media, on the Internet. But, of course, the persecution of this incitement to hate crimes cannot be confused with freedom of expression. I think they're two perfectly compatible things and you shouldn't confuse one thing with the other.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this House has repeatedly called for the right to respect freedom of belief and the right to practice one’s faith, particularly when we are talking about other countries. The European Convention on Human Rights states in Article 9 that everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. As has been mentioned, the European Union has employment legislation relating to non—discrimination on grounds of freedom of belief – amongst other grounds – and general legislation concerning anti-discrimination on grounds of race or ethnic origin. Given all this, it is clear that the European Union and its Member States still have considerable work to do in tackling prejudice. We are seeing a rise in hate speech in general, even against people with disabilities. We are seeing a rise in anti-Semitism, as the US State Department reported today, and we are also seeing a rise in anti-Muslim prejudice, of which we hear far too much within this House. There is a gender dimension to the latter as well. A UK report published today says that Muslim women are more likely to be attacked, online and in real life, than men,  All of this hate speech and division and these acts of violence work against community cohesion, social peace and the quality of life. Member States certainly need to take action to promote respect for diversity in their parliaments, in their societies and in their classrooms. So I welcome the Commission’s statement and wish that Member States would actually implement the legislation that already exists.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card question. – Can I ask whether you agree that it is right to debate Islamophobia and anti-Semitism here together because, ultimately, any form of discrimination is a cancer and we, as a society, need to tackle that? Those who want to pitch Muslims and Jews against one another are actually doing a disservice when, in fact, both communities are suffering the same thing.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: blue-card answer. – I do think we should be debating them together. I also think we should be debating them in the wider discussion about discrimination as well. I think that the overwhelming majority of Muslims within our societies are also appalled by crimes of violence. Nobody has asked the Norwegian Church to apologise for the actions of its member, Anders Breivik, and I think that the attitude that we sometimes manifest here masks the real deep hatred that is there. We have to combat that, whether it is the old anti-Semitic hatred or the new one. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this oral question conflates the issues of anti-Semitism and Islamophobia and infers that they have the same cause. Now, the rise in anti-Semitism is in direct relation to the rise in fundamentalist Islam. Look at the ideology that inspires it. Let me quote, once again, the Hadith and the sayings of Mohammed: ‘Judgment day will not come until the Muslims fight the Jews. Jews will hide behind the rocks and the trees, and the rocks and the trees will cry out, “Oh Muslim, oh servant of Allah, there is a Jew hiding behind me, come and kill him.”’ Here is an extract from a more recent sermon by Sheikh Abid al-Rahman al-Sudayyis, an Imam at the al-Haram Mosque in Mecca. He reportedly described Jews as ‘the scum of the human race, the rats of the world, the violators of pacts and agreements, the murderers of prophets, and the offspring of pigs and apes’. Instead of asking the Commission what it is going to do to combat hate crime, the authors of this question should ask the Islamic leaders in Europe to publicly and unequivocally reject these hateful teachings.  As for Islamophobia, my dictionary describes a phobia as an irrational fear. Many people have a perfectly rational fear of the followers of the cult of Mohammed who subscribe to and hold the views I quoted.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, I would like to ask whether you agree with me when I ask you whether this oral question should be extended to include anti-Christianism, because many of these attacks are carried out in European countries and against Christians.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: blue-card answer. – I hold the old-fashioned view that we should have the same laws for everybody, so if somebody is abused or attacked in the street, they should be punished in the same way, whoever the victim is and whatever the reason that they are attacked or abused. We should all live under the same law and not differentiate that some crimes are worse than others in this respect, because if you are being abused or you are physically attacked, it does not matter to you what the reason is – it might be the colour of your skin, it might be religion, it might be the clothes that you are wearing – it is irrelevant. The law should treat everybody equally.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: ent group. – If anything has been shown in this debate and previous shams, it is that tackling anti-Semitism and defending freedom of expression in the European Union is in very bad hands. I do not think that anyone here will deny that rising anti-Semitism is a problem that must be dealt with harshly by the Member States. But in order to do that, it would first have to dawn on all of you that the ideological background of Islam is the biggest trigger of contemporary anti-Semitism. As long as the European Union continues to import this intolerance, anti-Semitism will not diminish. The growing trend towards dismissing legitimate citizens' fears about increasing Islamisation of their country as racism, hate speech or Islamophobia is a threat to freedom of expression. As easily as justified fear is dismissed as irrational and baseless, so easily criticism is equated with hatred, while real hatred is preached in the thousands of mosques. My party, the Party for Freedom, therefore has no need for any more plans from the European Commission that will be about addressing all those who have a politically incorrect opinion.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very strange, in fact, that another creeping enemy, not only in third countries but also in Europe, of Christianphobia has not been included. We as an Italian delegation wanted it to be included in the title of the oral question. Christians who are discriminated against, who are harassed in 151 countries around the world – are free in only 40 out of 193 countries. In Europe too, as my colleague has said, there are marginalisations, discrimination and restrictions on freedom. We are only looking at what is happening and at the very serious persecutory acts in third countries, but which, unfortunately, also take place in Europe. So these acts, which move from intolerance and discrimination to real criminal acts against Christians, must be punished and punished by European laws and conventions. Christianophobia must therefore also be included along with Islam and anti-Semitism.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – I think we can all agree that anti-Semitism and all kinds of hate speech are like cancerous tumors on the bodies of European societies, which we must cut out by radical means. We cannot tolerate hatred, intolerance or impatience incompatible with our core values. I must say that today in Europe, not only are far-right parties inciting hatred, but unfortunately hate speech and cultural impatience are also appearing among mainstream parties at a time when some parties are constantly talking about the need to protect Christian Europe. This term serves no purpose other than to exclude those who do not fall into this category from the European community. I must say that we must acknowledge that cultural diversity and tolerance are the main core values of the European community, and we must continue to insist on this in the strictest terms.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: " Madam President, I was raised to respect everyone, not to mock anyone, and there is no such thing as hate speech in my vocabulary. But in recent days I have only been subjected to hate speech because I am Christian and only because I have called for the protection of more than 100 million persecuted Christians. The attack on me is only in addition to statistics that last year recorded almost 500 cases of discrimination against Christians and more than 200 cases of destruction of Christian objects and symbols.  Therefore, here I would like to personally testify to you that with anti-Semitism and Islamophobia in Europe, christianophobia is becoming more common. Christians in Europe become the target of intolerance and discrimination due to the very fact that they are Christians and have their own system of values, patterns of behavior and religious beliefs.  Stereotypes, restricting freedom of thought and speech, disrespect for conscientious appeals in the workplace and discrimination at work, violent removal of crosses, vandalism over Christian symbols and churches are a school example of Christianophobia. Therefore, I call on you to condemn anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and Christianophobia because these are the three evils that are tearing Europe apart today.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Jourová, I would like to thank you for your support. Thanks for the latest colloquine. I think it was a very, very good meeting. There was much that was said and finally we got to gather around two forms of how racism manifests itself. I hope that we will then talk about racism in general. This includes several other groups. I am thinking of Afrophobia and anti-Gypsyism. Listening to the debate here; when I listen to Maeijer and Mussolini and others who talk about Christians – you know that ten million people in Europe have been discriminated against and socially and economically vulnerable by Christian people every day for 800 years. I feel great fear as a Roma woman of Jewish descent, in so many places and edges. I think that you who sit here have gained a trust, you have a responsibility for future generations. You must stop talking and use racism as a tool for political gain. You must take responsibility for tomorrow. I think we should work actively against all forms of racism and the constructed fear on which racism is based.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, let us remember that among us live citizens of the European Union who attack other citizens of the European Union. Unfortunately, anti-Semitism, as well as other hate speech, is becoming more common among the European population, as Claude Moraes said. And what have we done against this phenomenon? Us as MEPs, us as European Union? How do we combat these hate speech? How do we intend to focus on combating these challenges in the future? Unfortunately, I have yet to say that I have not seen any strategy at European Union level that corresponds to the seriousness of the problem. I do not know about you, but I consider each of these attacks to be a great loss for European society, a loss for European integration and a loss for ourselves. And here the role of the European Commission and the Member States themselves and of us MEPs is very crucial.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, it is easy to conclude that problems in Europe include anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or hate speech. What is important, however, is to see the underlying causes of these manifestations, because eliminating the causes leads to combating the effects.  An effective strategy against racism, xenophobia, anti-Semitism must be based on informing and educating citizens, as well as on protecting and promoting the rights of minority groups. We need concrete policies that eliminate discrimination and hate crimes against Jews, Muslims, Christians, that find viable solutions against violence, employment discrimination or social exclusion. We must demonstrate that Europe is a community of shared values, of which that of equality in dignity of all people and respect for this equal dignity is the foundation of any democratic society.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It's not just Islamophobia and anti-Semitism. Christians are persecuted too, and we must not be blind to this. So let it not just be about Jews and Muslims. Europe, as we can see from the perspective of 2015, is sweeping through a brown wave – a wave of hatred towards a stranger, to anyone who is a member of a minority, and the words of the online elites we have often spoken about today are just an emanation, their incredible scale is also the emanation of this wave of hatred.  In this context, I would like to ask the Commissioner about the criminal codes in the Member States. Does the European Commission monitor criminal law and how is criminal law used for hate crimes? Do Member States have the right rules? Are they used? Do cases that are fought on hate crimes end in the conviction of the perpetrators or just suspension? Are we training police officers and judicial staff in identifying hate crimes and interpreting the law properly in this area, because the education that has been talked about today is clearly not enough? We in Europe have been educating for decades, and it is clear that, despite this education, we now have a return to the xenophobia, racism, homophobia, sexism and various isms and phobias that are now accumulating. It seems to me that it is also time to look at the hard instruments that we have in the Member States, and that is the case with criminal law.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, anti-Semitism, Islamophobia, hatred of Christianity are all manifestations that we have to face by looking at the causes and trying to eliminate them. Thank you to the Commissioner for reminding me of the European programmes that are so pre-emptively targeted. European funds financed, for example, the ICEI project, which brought holocaust survivors to schools and, I think, indelibly positively influenced the minds of thousands of young people and their relationship to Judaism. I clearly consider education and education to be the solution. Let me quote the current text of Jan Graubner, Archbishop of Olomouc, who spoke about the current situation: "Why do we wonder about fear of foreigners and people of other religions in postcommunist countries? All living generations have either gone through a communist school that has built hatred of religion in children and towards Germans, especially those from the Sudeten, or they are shaped by young teachers who are well-trained in the spirit of neo-Marxism that still reigns in some pedagogical faculties. I still get testimonies from young people who have been bullied as schoolchildren for their faith."

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, can I first of all say that I welcome this debate. I would like to thank Claude Moraes for all the work he does, day in day out, including at the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs hearing held in June, which he put a lot of effort into. I would also like to thank the Vice-President for arranging the first Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, which dealt with this particular issue. I attended that and saw how useful it was. It is quite clear that the impact that this discrimination is having on both Muslims and the Jewish community is the same. Day in and day out, they experience discrimination in all sorts of different ways. The internet and social media do not help. What we need to do is to ensure that we have concrete follow—up to these hearings and debates. We need to make sure that the Member States have actually adopted the EU equal treatment directives and also we need to harmonise... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, antisemitism, Islamophobia and hate speech must disappear in Europe. However, today's debate on antisemitism brings to our memories the mass executions of thousands of Greek patriots by German occupying troops in Greece. It brings to our memories the thousands of Greek patriots, but also the Jews from Thessaloniki, who were murdered in the Nazi concentration camps of Auschwitz, in Dachau and elsewhere. Last Sunday, october 12th, the Greek people celebrated the 71st anniversary of the liberation of Athens from German occupation troops, while reminding all over Europe how timely it is to repay Germany's debts to Greece, including: German war reparations, forced occupation loan, reparations for relatives of victims executed by Nazi occupation troops and murdered in Nazi concentration camps. We therefore demand the repayment of Germany's debts to Greece, here and now, because Greece is the lender and Germany is the debtor.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – (microphone malfunction at the beginning of the speech)... respect for human rights and dignity, including the rights of different minorities. Unfortunately, however, in recent years the Union has begun to retreat from these fundamental values, and this has given voice to national populism, xenophobia and hate speech.  In many of our member states, including in my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria operates ultranationalist and fascist political parties that systematically insusate hatred. It's not my assessment, it's the Council of Europe.  It is with great concern that we note the numerous vandalism events against religious buildings and representatives of religious denominations, as well as the increasing language of hatred on the internet. This trend is exacerbated by the growing refugee wave in Europe.  This is the time to ask ourselves: Is the European Union moving away from its civilisational choices? I welcome the Commission's decision to finance projects to increase tolerance and mutual respect. I also consider it necessary, together with the Fundamental Rights Agency, to present a new strategy to combat xenophobia.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: "Ladies and ladies, we are ridiculous. Mr Jakovčić is talking here about the fight against Holocaust denial. After all, Mr Jakovčić, millions of copies of the Holocaust are published in Arabic in Europe. Was there at least one trial because of this? How are the Islamist demonstrations on the street, there are cries of hate – this is being filmed, these people are known – has anyone done a trial to those people who preach hate speech? Nobody. Arabs see us as a bunch of idiots who blunt it only at home, and they just slit our throats, because if someone can't defend themselves, as someone tolerates an attack on himself, and fights people who want to defend themselves against attacks, then at this point it's only worthy of just slit his throat. We have to take it for ourselves, the law must be one for everyone, including Muslims.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, the gentleman mentioned me directly and let me answer him at least in a few seconds, because he mentioned me directly twice. And when someone mentions you directly, they have a right to answer. At least that's the rules, as far as I know, in this Parliament.  Is there anything I can say to Mr. Korwin-Mikke or do you not allow me?  (The president took her word for it.) Madam Chairman, I understood very well what Godpodin Korwin-Mikke was saying, because he mentioned me twice, and in the end he said that we all sit here like fools. Let me say that I don't feel like a here, I believe that the vast majority, however few of us, do not feel that way, because we are talking about one of the most serious topics of our European history.  We're talking about the Holocaust and you mentioned it, please stick to the level of this home, and if you don't, then you really don't deserve to share these rooms with us, because nobody's stupid here. You may be thinking about yourself, but I don't want to insult you. So let me ask you not to insult this home in such a way.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner Jourova, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Only a few months ago I was in the desecrated cemetery of the Jewish community in Oldenburg. It was unbearable how anti-Semitic fools raged there, how they desecrated a holy place and trampled on people's religious feelings. Let us oppose any approach to ongoing anti-Semitic violence! Jews in the EU often live threatened and guarded enough, not really free.  Another point: when we talk about hatred and violence against religions, one group is deliberately ignored, namely Christians. My appeal to the Commission: please stop ignoring Christians! Up to 200 million persecuted Christians in the world, hatred, violence and discrimination also in Europe. Let's name it and do something about it. I say it with Ovid: Principiis obsta – resist the beginnings! To equate Islamophobia with anti-Semitism is a naughty thing! Tolerance to the tolerant, but no tolerance of the intolerant.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Many colleagues have spoken of numerous acts of anti-Christian hatred – they are indeed not lacking, not only in the world, but also in Europe. Many of us have heard of the holy pastor of Ars, one of the beautiful figures of our history. In the diocese where he is buried, the bishop had to remove the Eucharist from all churches because it was so often desecration. There have been numerous cases of hatred against Christians under our authority, even in refugee camps, and the Prime Minister of Thuringia recently spoke about it, perhaps rather enigmatically, about the need to separate certain communities, but after all, the public knows what is at stake. I would like to ask: what is the status of silence about anti-Christian hatred, silence during this debate, because we complain very much, and this silence itself is an act of contempt that disgraces the principles invoked by the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - Political and financial support must be coordinated in order to achieve the objectives pursued and to handle public money responsibly. The European Union is working towards a middle east peace process. It is therefore right to provide financial support to the NGOs that are pursuing it and to abolish support for those who threaten it. We cannot allow the peace process to be demolished by financial support to NGOs that threaten it.  When will we see a similar investigation at EU level to what has been done in the UK? In the United Kingdom, anti-semist statements by the head of one of the NGOs led to a report prepared by all political parties with a very clear message - the activity of NGOs should clearly follow their objectives, for which they also receive European funding. In view of the events we have seen over the last two weeks in Israel, I believe that it is high time for the Commission to act!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for their contributions, which demonstrate once more what a burning issue this is and how urgent our response must be. The Commission is determined to confront all forms of hatred with equal attention: anti-Semitism, Islamophobia, anti-Gypsyism, homophobia or other forms of hatred. I want to stress one thing: the law must be enforced, and laws in the EU prohibit discrimination. Criminal law is here to punish all forms of hate crime. I want to react to what Ms Kozłowska-Rajewicz said about using these repressive instruments. Yes, I must say we are looking at all ways of tackling the problem, and these are among the instruments which we need to use. You know that we are now enforcing the framework decision of 2008 which was adopted to combat all forms of intolerance and xenophobia. We have been able to enforce this as of 1 December last year. We carried out an inventory of the situation in the Member States and found that in many Member States this framework decision has not been implemented properly, and there are still Member States where Holocaust denial is not punishable under criminal law. That must be changed. I have already alerted the Member States, especially those where the framework decision has not been implemented in a satisfactory way, to the fact that we will strictly require its implementation. Let me add one personal remark. Yes, I agree with all who spoke here about the necessity of understanding the reasons why we are seeing such an extreme increase in intolerance in the EU – be it the financial crisis, or be it terrorist attacks that took place in Europe. There are many, many different reasons which we must understand. My personal view is that what I would term insufficiently smart budgetary policy is part of the problem. Just look at the public budgets: at how much we have invested in our stomachs, how much less in our brains, and how much we have invested in our hearts. In terms of culture, have we invested enough to sustain positive emotions in Europe, as hate is a negative emotion? We must change this, and we must urge the Member States, and all those who take decisions on the use of public money, to change it. We want to be in the lead here, and I am already working on the budget for next year prioritising these painful issues.  I also urged the Ministers of Justice last week to look at the structural funds: at where they are invested and whether they reflect current needs, because we made a horrible mistake with the structural funds in the last programming period. The funds did not reflect the financial crisis at all – it was as if nothing was happening. We should not now repeat the fatal mistake of failing to ensure that the use of EU money reflects our current and very urgent needs. Sorry for taking too long. I count on your support and I am looking forward to deepening our cooperation in tackling these issues.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This question, although not insignificant, is obviously a testament to the willingness of the right-thinking people to lock us in 'societal debates' to avoid turning to Europe's real problems.  The fight against anti-Semitic, Islamophobic and hate speech must, of course, be done; you cannot discriminate against someone for their religion or anything else. Nevertheless, such debates must not prevent us from all freedoms of expression and criticism of multiculturalism or mass immigration, for example, since any discourse on these subjects inevitably now refers to hate speech or discrimination, while our elites refuse to face reality.  This question tells us that "Jews are increasingly afraid of being verbally abused (46%) or physically (33%). In a 2009 survey conducted by the same agency, one in three Muslim respondents said they had been discriminated against in the previous 12 months. Unfortunately, this is also due to the current policies which, by sizing hatred, introducing austerity or causing Europe to lose its identity, are increasing tensions.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – As the world faces new challenges with the growing threat of violent extremism, schools and educators are confronted with expressions and sentiments on a scale that was never anticipated, ranging from personal identity conflicts to complex societal issues. Incidents of unprecedented mass arrivals of migrants lead to an increase in anti-Semitism, Islamophobia, and hate speech.  Schools are increasingly seen as being on the front-lines to prevent different forms of hatred and different forms of extremism. Educators are playing an important role in promoting mutual respect and understanding at schools and it is essential that teachers are able to identify children who may be vulnerable to radicalisation. Integrated quality education can play a critical role in helping young people distance themselves from extremism and resist the pull factors that may drive them to recruitment. These factors can be contrasted by education through awareness-raising, generating respect for others, and creating and maintaining cultures of peace and dialogue.  The EU needs to continue to support civil projects and networks favouring tolerance and intercultural understanding, fostering inclusive education, mutual understanding and intercultural dialogue. Erasmus programmes should promote inclusion in education, training, youth and sport, and prevent marginalisation and the radicalisation of young people.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The snoring and pompous title of this oral question is a reflection of the ostrich policy that characterizes the conduct of states. Violence based on religious or ethnic criteria today has a main origin: the disintegration of peoples and the failure of national cohesion. The European Union and associated governments are responsible for these tensions in our societies because of their support for mass immigration and the denial of our identities and cultures. I am not talking here about a political project or a philosophical dream, I am talking about a European civilization that could accommodate nuances; but from these few exceptions, you have made communitarianism widespread, institutional and in total break with the heart of this same civilization. The most perennial, violent and expansive hatred has only one name: Islamism. Hatred of the West, hatred of Europe, hatred of Christians, hatred of Jews, contempt for women, our laws, our cultures and our freedoms, this threat is growing. The political system in place, through its laxity and migration policy, has brought the wolf into the fold. Colleagues, brothers of Europe, wake up.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – As a representative of a nationalist and conservative party, I strongly oppose any claim that political parties like mine incite Islamophobic and xenophobic attitudes. Neoliberals stigmatize us as intolerant only because we oppose dividing citizens into equals and marginalized, with the former having more rights than the former.  The law must treat everyone equally and not favour each other, which actually discriminates and incites intolerance among citizens. European citizens do not want to be treated secondaryly. The Union's policy of prioritising and protecting certain groups of people, disadvantaged others, further contributes to the spread of Islamophobia, anti-Semitism and intolerance.  On the other hand, very little is said about the unhindered spread of books inciting hatred. Go to the Frankfurt International Book Fair and you will find numerous books by Arab publishers that incite anti-Semitism. Are these the European values we aspire to? Is that freedom of speech and opinion?  I, as a European citizen, am firmly against the radicalisation of societies in one direction or another. But radicalisation is not the cause of the rise of Islamophobia and anti-Semitism, it is the consequence. The root cause is inequality before the law. We live in a Union where law and law are the same for all.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. – As policymakers it is our responsibility to provide adequate instruments to protect the more vulnerable groups in our society and to empower law enforcement authorities to deal properly with cases of discrimination. Anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are both serious phenomena that can endanger peaceful cohabitation and destabilise our communities. I am therefore always supportive of initiatives which are put into place to defend religious, linguistic and national minorities.  Still a lot needs to be done to prevent and fight prejudice and hate speech. Prejudice and intolerance are mostly a consequence of ignorance and fear. It is therefore important to engage not only policymakers, but also academics, educators and members of civil society to address this issue, in order to develop possible approaches to countering this phenomenon, through education, interfaith exchanges and positive image building.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – Freedom of speech, freedom of confession of different ideas or beliefs, freedom to be different are manifestations of the principles on which the European project is built. And while fear of difference is a normal human reaction, we must be able to understand our differences more and rely on them, rather than primary reactions such as fear and hatred, in order to continue to be the mature European society based on traditional humane values that we all aspire to.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – Hate speech, racism, xenophobia, gypsy hatred and their incitation are all simplistic responses to social problems by political extremism. Sometimes the exclusion of a minority from society is too strong, its existing problems are too complicated, to which there are no quick, immediate answers. We need complex, long-term programmes that require the solidarity of society and, of course, taxpayers' money. The simplest answer is always incition of hatred. The same is true of the refugee crisis, which has swelled enormously in a relatively short period of time.  Unfortunately, we know more and more voices of hatred throughout Europe, from the most subtle language to the harsh, almost Nazi-like voices. These answers are the meanest because they build on the fears that all people have: the emotion that when we spend on those in need, the majority have fewer resources on their own. That's a lie. Hate and fear-mongering campaigns, the construction of walls and fences are not only inhumane, but cost no less than social assistance. Moreover, the case in Hungary proves that the anti-immigrant campaign and the construction of the fence cost more taxpayers' money than the support for refugees. In most countries of Europe, hate speech is banned by means of criminal law if it is committed by an individual, but so far nothing seems to prohibit it from being embodied in government communications! We must fight this together.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Human greatness can be defined as respect for difference. This difference is expressed primarily in a different color of skin, nationality, religion or gender. This leads us to another important word – tolerance, that is, respect for someone's views, beliefs, tastes different from our own. The etymology of the word can be found in latin tolerantia, meaning "patient perseverance", as well as in the verb tolerare – that is, to endure, endure, suffer. Nowadays, we use the word in the sense of endure and accept.  The opposite concept is intolerance, that is, discrimination, xenophobia, bigotry in all sorts of spheres, such as religion, politics, customs. The Internet has now become a tool for spreading hate speech, or so-called "hejtu". The feeling of anonymity, most often in combination with their own complexes, is the main reason for attacking others. Attacking through deeds, as well as words – both spoken and written. In addition, a factor that increases this phenomenon is the misconscious awareness of impunity for such actions.  It should be noted that "hejt" is no longer a phenomenon aimed exclusively at celebrities. We also meet with him every day. Whether in the form of offensive comments under photos of private people on Facebook, or in online forums, as well as in articles of popular social networking sites.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The rise of intolerance and increasingly unseeded hate speech command us to look for ways to stop them. Radicalisation is always fostered by growing fears. Today, economic and refugee crises are a breeding ground.  In the 1950s, the American psychologist Gordon Allport pointed out behaviors whose disregard could lead to escalation. His "pyramid of hate" consists of negative comments, avoidance, discrimination, physical attacks, extermination. Examples from history confirm the legitimacy of this model.  The Council of Europe, in turn, defined the term 'hate speech' as 'all forms of expression which disseminate, incite, promote or justify racial, religious, xenophobic, anti-Semitism or other forms of hatred resulting from intolerance, including intolerance expressed through aggressive nationalism and ethnocentrism, discrimination and hostility towards representatives of minorities, immigrants and persons of foreign origin'. Hatred and intolerance are manifested in many forms. These can be jokes told with friends, drawings on the walls, publications, advertisements, as well as increasingly – public statements of radical politicians translating into election spots in campaigns.  Therefore, each of us should respond to manifestations of hatred: demand the removal of hateful signs and inscriptions, internet entries, notify law enforcement agencies, which must be obliged to accept the notice. But the most important thing is to thoroughly investigate the causes of the phenomenon, in order to effectively act in three directions: prevention – education – law enforcement.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Hate speech thrives on fear and anxiety among different sectors of our population. They feel that they are inadequately protected against changing circumstances in their daily lives and must bear alone the brunt of economic slowdown or social dislocations. To contain and eradicate hate speech, anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, we must tackle the conditions that help them to spread. This is more difficult in times of economic stagnation or recession but it must be done.
