Problems multiply when massive immigration flows raise the perception that European lifestyles will be submerged under alien cultures and that scarce jobs will be appropriated by newcomers. Such anxiety and fears should be addressed. They should be seen as grounded in concrete concerns, not in innate prejudices. The extremists who fan hate and xenophobia have understood this. They play on such concerns to drive people towards irrational and violent action. Those who combat extremism and hate-mongering, should equally face up to people’s concerns. They should put upfront strategies and plans based on consistent efforts to remove the causes of fear and anxiety. Simply saying ‘Wir schaffen das’, though encouraging, is not enough. Much more needs to be done.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – Each of us is watching hate speech in the world with concern, but also in Europe, the rise of parties that spread anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and intolerance. With the arrival of migrants, these manifestations have become even more sharp, so we must fight them very effectively, explaining, above all, to young people that faith, race or ethnic origin cannot be a cause of hatred. This year we commemorated the end of the Second World War in Europe and around the world. We should also use this anniversary to explain to generations who have not experienced the horrors of war that hate speech, intolerance, anti-Semitism, xenophobia and intolerance were the birthers of wars. If we want to prosper in Europe and live in peace, we must tolerate each other, show solidarity and make policy so as to convince every european citizen that the EU was rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2012.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Ethnic and religious discrimination are increasingly growing across Europe. According to the Commission, in the past year one in five Europeans has experienced discrimination or harassment on a religious ground. Moreover, the Commission’s Annual Report against Racism and Intolerance (ECRI) demonstrates a dramatic increase in anti-Semitism, Islamophobia, online hate speech and xenophobic political discourse in 2014. According to the ECRI report numbers have more than doubled for insults and physical attacks on Jewish persons and institutions in 2014, particularly after renewed violence in the Middle East in 2014.  Another recent Eurobarometer survey showed that Muslims are least accepted in European societies among religious groups. These sentiments are further fuelled by the refugee crisis. The fact that in Europe today anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are still a reality points to a wider problem that must be confronted. We must tackle anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and hate speech by taking all means to ensure the implementation of the EU directives on this matter in individual countries, and for the entire EU. More needs to be done to promote non-discrimination and inclusion, while strengthening the role of education and the civil society. If left unchallenged, anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and hate speech will create a much bigger problem for Europe.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – The European Commission's annual report against racism and intolerance reflects alarming situations within our borders. Every day we witness how hatred and bigotry are sowing chaos and terror in Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan. We cannot allow this discourse of hatred to spread across our borders, we cannot allow fear to dominate European citizens. The conclusions of the Commission's report are very significant, there is an increase in aggression and hate speech on religious issues in all Member States. There are even populist politicians who incite these behaviors. Social media has also been decisive in this boom, but they can also be the solution. As can the politicians themselves and the measures they carry out. That is why I request from here that all Member States ratify Protocol No 12 to the European Convention on Human Rights prohibiting discrimination in general. And that appropriate mechanisms are put in place to combat this phenomenon in each Member State.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – In its 2014 report, the Romanian intelligence service, like The Securitate, a former secret police of dictator Ceauşescu, still considers hungarians in Transylvania, which has a 1.5 million people, and their legitimate autonomy and legal claims to be a state security threat. The recent summit of the extreme chauvinistic organization of Romanians in Szeklerland demanded an increased presence of Romanian state bodies – law enforcement and the army – in the predominantly Hungarian Szekler land, and Defense Minister Mircea Duşa launched a threatening attack on the Szekler autonomy effort. The renewed anti-Hungarian power propaganda and incitement is believed to be in the run-up to the mass protest on 24 October, which will illuminate the 750 kilometres of the Szekler-Hungarian region with guard fires. I ask for their protection for the Hungarians threatened in Romania!

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent days, the new mechanism for the relocation of refugees has been activated and several 'hot spots' are being developed. In fact, it is an organisational model that has long been developed in my country, particularly in Sicily where, in Catania, the new frontex headquarters is located.  These are important measures, of course, but they are insufficient and not without problematic aspects. It is necessary, in fact, to avoid the risk of a short circuit of the 'hot spot' system which, due to the contradictions of the current regulatory framework, could lead to hasty returns or an illegal extension of the period of stay in the centres. We therefore need means, both financial and non-financial, to reconcile efficiency and full respect for the rights of all migrants, regardless of their formal status and with particular attention to the most vulnerable, especially minors. While the new mechanisms will facilitate the relocation of a number of refugees, we must remember that, with regard to all other migrants, there are still no concrete solutions, which I think we need to think about.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Last Friday, five days ago, the United Nations Security Council adopted Resolution 2240 , a resolution on the competences of our countries in eunavfor med operations in the Mediterranean. But that's not what I want to talk about. This resolution states, among other things, that among the people, among the migrants who are currently in camps in Europe, there are also people who fall within the Treaty definition of refugees. This was not the opposite of the fact that among refugees there are people who do not fall into this category, but that among immigrants there are also people qualified as refugees. Nevertheless, although the whole world sees the facts, today the President of the European Commission reiterated that he will present proposals as early as next year to open the way to some partial legalisation of illegal immigration. These are declarations that undermine the very meaning of our cooperation– I respect.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Chairman, Europe is united in diversity. Europe has 60 regional and minority languages. 10% of europe's population speaks one of these regional or minority languages. Many of these languages we speak here are minority or regional languages in some countries. However, as many as 49 such regional or minority languages are seriously at risk. Language is a human right, language is part of our identity and that is why I think we need to protect it to the maximum and that the Commission, member states, regional and local authorities in Europe must protect regional and minority languages, because it is part of our European identity, united in diversity, but in diversity that we will respect each other, and languages are exactly what we must respect each other to the maximum.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, there are questions to answer over the largest ever property sale in the North of Ireland. The National Asset Management Agency (NAMA) was set up by the Irish Government to absorb toxic loans. It recently sold its portfolio in the North for a record EUR 1.3 billion to US investment giant Cerberus. There are allegations over millions paid for fixers’ fees, political access and sensitive commercial information. We need to know who got the money and what for. There is a paper trail showing that Joint First Minister Martin McGuinness was not kept in the loop. Sinn Féin will expose the dirty, underhand practices and support investigations into alleged misuse of public funds. The two former Stormont Finance Ministers, plus any other minister, politician or senior civil servant, including NAMA officials involved, should make themselves and all documentation available to the Finance Committee inquiry in the North and to the Public Accounts Committee in Dublin.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I still wanted to say two words about refugees. Well, there is a belief that these are people who are fleeing Syria to Greece. Look at the map, these people are not fleeing Syria to Greece. This is impossible – to take a dinghy from Syria to Greece. They are coming out of Turkey, these people have already been to Turkey, and the right to asylum is granted in the first country to which they have fled. This explains why they are mainly men – they leave their wives and children not in Syria, but in camps in Turkey, but themselves come to Greece and the rest of Europe. That's so much for clarification.  Mr Jakovčić came out unfortunately, and I wanted to make it clear that this was a misunderstanding, I did not say that we here are idiots, our whole civilization was stupid, because it condemns, for example, the denial of the Holocaust, and the Arabs in Arabic in millions of copies deny the Holocaust, and we do not react. We are ridiculous because of this.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I will also address Commissioner Jourová in my speech. In the Czech Republic, as the Commissioner may know, there is a public debate about the ban on fur farms, that is, the behaviour of animals only on the skin. Animals are kept and then commercially killed only for fur coats. I personally believe that this form of business at the beginning of the twenty-first century is une ethical, as some Member States of the European Union perceive it, and already in a third of the European Union states this form of business is prohibited. Entrepreneurs who run this form of business then move to countries that still allow this form of business by their legal system. I wanted to take advantage of this opportunity to call on the European Commission to address this issue and, where appropriate, to consider a comprehensive arrangement that would lead to a restriction or prohibition of this, in my opinion, unethical way of doing business.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I fully support the setting—up of the Task Force Mediterranean to identify lines of action and to prevent such incidents as the deaths of thousands of migrants in the Mediterranean Sea from occurring in the future. We must protect those who are in need and are seeking political asylum and send back economic migrants. We also have to prevent a further loss of life in the future by targeting the criminal networks of people smugglers and traffickers, addressing the root causes of illegal migration and improving avenues for legal migration. In order to address the causes of illegal migration we must increase the political dialogue with countries of origin and cooperate on a crisis prevention system. In reality, the European Union does not have a real crisis response management system for situations like this migration which is flooding Europe.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In view of the difficult situation on the EU livestock markets, the European Commission has proposed emergency support for milk and meat producers and has allocated EUR 420 million for this purpose. For the farmers of my country, Polish, less than 7% of this amount, or nearly EUR 29 million, is foreseen, and I believe that such a distribution of resources does not take into account the huge consequences of the drought that has occurred in our country. To date, plant production losses have been estimated at more than EUR 1 billion, and in the coming months, due to the lack of roughage, producers of beef cattle and dairy cows will also suffer serious losses, which will only dramatically increase these losses.  In a situation where profitability in Polish agriculture is among the lowest of all EU countries, when Polish producers pay penalties for overproduction of milk for the second time in a row, the Commission's proposal is even discriminatory. Once again, I ask the Commission to analyse the effects of drought in Polish agriculture and to provide adequate support to the extent of the losses suffered by farmers.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – To date, estonian and British national ship defenders have been detained in India by the Indian authorities for two years. There is no accusation against them, and it is unacceptable that india, the partner country of the European Union, treats the citizens of the European Union in this way and does not allow them, as I said, to return to their home country for two years.  The release of Estonian and British ship protectors must be dealt with at all meetings between the European Union and India until our citizens finally have the opportunity to return to their home country. Given that the citizens of the European Union have been stuck in India for so long, the European Union should stand up more clearly for the release of its citizens. The European Commission should put forward proposals for a possible freeze on some joint EU-India programmes and agreements until Estonian and British citizens are guaranteed the opportunity to return home. The European Union must not stand by this treatment of its citizens in an inaction.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, this week, several Members of this Parliament, members of the Intergroup of Western Sahara, visited the Saharan refugee camps. We have known the hospitality of the Saharawi people on their National Unity Day. But above all, we have seen first-hand a very serious humanitarian crisis. Both UNHCR and the Red Crescent informed us of the severe scarcity of resources: 25% of refugees are chronically malnourished. The food budget is virtually exhausted and eleven million dollars are needed to meet basic needs until the end of 2016.  Unfortunately, propaganda is encovering this humanitarian catastrophe. False allegations of mismanagement and corruption, aired in this house, have served as a screen to hide reality. But we have endorsed the words of the Commission and UNHCR on the spot: food distribution and humanitarian aid management is impeccable.  It is essential to make an urgent allocation of funds for Sahrawi refugees and I appeal to the responsibility of the European Union and Spain to respond to an unfairly forgotten crisis.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the multi-bill tabled by the Greek Government of SYRIZA-ANEL in Parliament, implementing the third barbaric memorandum signed with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, serves the needs of the capital and provides for barbaric measures against the people. Pensions are already being cut, age limits are being raised further, insurance funds are being strangled by the continuation of employer tax evasion, tax evasion against working-class families is escalating, and the provocative tax exemption of large groups continues. So the gift shot is given to the poor to share the misery with the poor. In practice, it turns out that the application of the Best Practices of the European Union means slavery for workers in order to ensure the profitability of monopolies. The working people do not consent to the slaughter which the government defiantly claims to have approved with their vote, nor to accept the mockery of the equivalent vehement measures against them. Co-government and the European Union to find him on the streets of the organized struggle against the new anti-labour storm.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, in the European Parliament, I must once again draw attention to the great injustice that is happening in the protection of the rights of children, citizens of the European Union, who are being unlawfully detained and entrusted for adoption. It is particularly glaring these days when Europeans are trying to help refugees. Among other things, by trying to ensure the integrity of their families. Last week, the Norwegian authorities decided to withdraw parental rights from the Czech mother. Her children, two brothers, separated and handed one of them over for adoption. At the same time, there are relatives of the two boys living in the European Union, who seem very interested in them. The Czech State has even guaranteed their integrity and integrity, which in itself can be considered something special. It is tragic that we will allow such social experiments in the Twenty-First Century in the European Union, and I think we will have a fundamental reflection on how to prevent these mistakes and this injustice in the future.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, this week the official receiver managing the liquidation of the SSI plant at Redcar in my constituency announced the full closure of the site after 175 years of steelmaking: 2 200 direct jobs have gone, with potentially 6 000 further job losses in the supply chain. This is a major blow for our regional economy and for the whole of the UK steel industry. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established for exactly this sort of situation. In 2011, Dutch print workers were able to access those funds, providing workers negatively affected by globalisation with the funds needed to support them. However, the Tory Government in the UK is refusing to apply for this funding. The Tories are sacrificing Redcar steel workers on the altar of Thatcherite dogma. If Mr Cameron wants to be remembered as a socially compassionate Conservative, his deeds fly in the face of this practice. The UK Government should make a sectoral application right now to support our steel industry.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We talk a lot about human rights here in this House, and it is astonishing that an organisation that tramples on human rights, even more so – which is a criminal organisation. Ten American states have just cut off public money. It is about the IPPF, the International Planned Parenthood Federation, the umbrella organization of Pro Familia. The IPPF engages in human trafficking, but trafficking in human beings does not quite affect it. Because before the IPPF sells the people or the pieces of it, you kill those people. The IPPF is therefore more closely involved in a morgue. Aborted fetuses are squandered. This is just as criminal as it is perverse!  Mr President, President Schulz, I call on you to withdraw the official accreditation of the IPPF as an authorised organisation in this Parliament. The IPPF is a criminal organization. It is damaging the reputation of this House, it is a matter of being drained and criminally condemned and not courted.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European authorities must remind Spain that the Basque Economic Concert and the Navarrese Convention fit into Community legality. Its maintenance is key to avoiding new and irreversible territorial tensions in Spain. Contribute to avoiding them by preventing them from using the European Union to attack – in a campaign as crude as it is intense and fallacious – institutions useful and positive for citizens.  The Luxembourg Court, on 11 September 2008, considered both systems legal as institutional, procedural and economically autonomous. They have internal legal support. They make their tax decisions from independent bodies and the economic effects of them cannot be compensated by the State authority. It is the doctrine of the "Azores case". In this Parliament we have supported the fiscal federalism on which the Concert and the Convention are based. Both are the result of bilateral agreements that update historical rights, stand in solidarity and promote accountability. That's why they have massive social support in the Basque Country and Navarra.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – The Volkswagen scandal affects not only the car industry, but also the national economies of some countries. German car assembly plants, which build on cheap and skilled labour, play a significant role in Hungarian GDP. Minister János Lázár spoke at a press conference about the consequences of the expected decline in production. He said planned GDP growth was at risk and it was a question of whether next year's budget figures could be held. The lesson is obvious, and we have said it many times. Instead of accepting the colonial situation, we need an independent Hungarian economy, especially the development of the food industry. However, it is possible that, together with Volkswagen's exhaust fumes, next year's Hungarian budget has also been lost.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, yesterday an international team of investigators published the final report of its investigation into the tragedy of Flight MH17, according to which the aircraft was hit by a Russian Buk missile fired from territory controlled by pro-Russian separatists.  He takes for account the version presented by Russian state television, according to which the Malaysian aircraft was shot down by a Ukrainian fighter jet. None of the members of the International Commission of Inquiry disputed the findings, only Russia. This corresponds to the way Moscow now performs in international relations. It is not so much about convincing others of its version of the truth, but rather about creating chaos in which the truth disappears. We can't let that happen. Similarly, we must not allow us to lift the sanctions imposed on Russia until the conditions that have been declared by the European Union have been met. Currently, the strongest argument for maintaining them is moscow's conduct in this case of investigating the tragedy of Flight MH17.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government, at the behest of the troika, is implementing the disastrous third memorandum that turns Greece into a vast social graveyard. Already the neo-monumental co-government is launching these days the adoption of the famous prerequisites, which cut wages and pensions, break up the insurance system, launch a tax break on the private property of Greeks, deepen the recession and lead to the padlocks of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises, while opening the way for banks to hammer the homes of Greek citizens. With the Agricultural Memorandum, the troika and the Memorandum: SYRIZA-ANEL, SW, PASOK, POTAMI, dissolve the primary sector, over-tax agricultural land, increase production costs and put even tsipouro and tsikoudia under tax evasion. Our political movement, the anti-monumental citizens, will stand up to the third memorandum and give the present to the new struggles of our people to throw the troika out of our homeland and take Greece back.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The agenda item concludes with this.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Oral explanations of vote

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report will enable the competent authorities of the Member States to continue to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS), in particular in the context of the fight against terrorism and other serious criminal offences. The proposed decision is intended to replace the 2013/392/EU Decision of the Council, which was censured by the European Court of Justice. On 1 September 2013, when the 2008/633/JAI decision took effect, should be upheld as it is in Article 1 of the 2013/392/EU decision. This draft decision is more technical than political. It does not address the Schengen area or the Visa Information System (VIS).  As the Member States are not stripped of their sovereignty, I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that there are sufficient and appropriate safeguards to enable this information to be shared properly. In addition, I believe that international cooperation on such matters should take place via the appropriate agency (Interpol) rather than be dealt with by the European Union. For that reason I considered it appropriate to vote against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to allow the authorities designated by the Member States and Europol to use the Visa Information System for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure that Member States and Europol have access to the Visa Information System (VIS). It is about better detection, and therefore better prevention of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. This seems to me to be much more useful and fundamental than the collection of passenger name record data.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In line with the European Union's desire to establish an area of freedom, security and justice, the Visa Information System (VIS) is a data exchange system between the Schengen states. In line with the position of the group, I believe that improving border management and cross-border travel requires the promotion of instruments such as the VIS or the Schengen Information System (SIS II).  In order to ensure the best possible security of citizens, these existing instruments must be strengthened by ensuring that they respect the fundamental rights of travellers and, in particular, the protection of their data. The report supports the Council's proposal to allow Member States-designated authorities access to VIS data to prevent terrorist acts or serious criminal offences, as the previous access authorization was overturned by a ECJ ruling. That is why I support this report which contributes to the exchange of data between Member States for greater efficiency and security.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report sets the effective date for the 2008/633/JAI decision on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the designated authorities of the Member States and the European Police Office (Europol) for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as well as for the purposes of investigations in this area. This decision should ensure the continuity of Member States' and Europol's access rights to the visa information system. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential to give maximum support and freedom of action to European police forces in the fight against terrorism. With this vote, I support the Kirkhope report in order to ensure that the competent authorities have access to the Visa Information System (VIS), so that they can carry out the necessary checks in cases suspected of serious crimes and terrorism in the best possible way and as effectively as possible.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European Parliament is positioned in this report on a Council implementation decision determining the date from which the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol will have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) in order to facilitate the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorism offences and other serious crimes.  From the point of view of content, the question does not pose any problem since it is the mere determination of the entry into force of a Council legal act and the abbreviated procedure of Article 150 has been followed and my vote has been welcomed. However, the entry into force of this Decision has been postponed when the question of the lack of taking into account the European Parliament's view on the adoption of the decision implementing the measure is raised before the COURT of Justice of the EU. I hope that this vote will resolve these procedural issues and the Decision will be able to enter into force as soon as possible.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported parliament's decision to allow the authorities designated by the Member States and Europol to use the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purposes of the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. This Decision contributes to the creation of a common EU area of freedom, security and justice, in which EU citizens, workers and capital can move freely, but which must be protected from both external and internal threats. Denmark, Ireland and Great Britain have not joined in this Decision.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the report is to give the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol the opportunity to access the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. I agree that we should give our competent authorities the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in order to protect our citizens.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The proposed decision establishing the date of entry into force of procedures relating to the search for data for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences is a purely technical matter, i.e. confirmation of the continuation of access to the visa information system by the competent authorities of the Member States and Europol. Ensuring the safety of EU citizens must remain the highest priority of European security policy, which is currently on high trial as a result of the migrant crisis. The constant flow of visa information between the security authorities of the EU Member States and Europol is one of the most important links to ensure security within the EU and to further maintain such a flow of information is crucial. For the reasons set out above, I supported the proposed report.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. A report has been submitted for an enforcement decision to ensure that Member States and Europol have the continuity of access rights to the Visa Information System (VIS); I voted for this report which allows the prevention and detection of acts of terrorism.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, in the context of the fight against terrorism that we are carrying out, access for consultation to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the authorities of the Member States and Europol is a fundamental tool. It is important that the counter-terrorism authorities of each Member State work together to make the fight against terrorism more effective and efficient.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Visa Information System (VIS) is the system for the exchange of data relating to visas for entry into the Schengen Area between the states that are part of it. The availability of exchange and comparison of this data by Europol and the visa and border control authorities of the Member States is important in the prevention and combating of terrorist activities and other serious criminal actions. In the fight against terrorism and criminal organisations, it is essential that the relevant services have the most comprehensive and up-to-date information possible in their respective areas in good time. The availability of information and the speed of action make the difference between foiling an attack or mourning its consequences. Creating a single protocol regulating data management and access to data by police and investigation forces is important in reconciling the need for security and combating terrorist and criminal organisations with the right to privacy of every European citizen.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This text is merely an enforcement decision aimed at ensuring the continuity of Member States' and Europol's access rights to the visa information system with the aim of preventing and detecting potential terrorist acts early enough. This draft decision is therefore above all technical. On the substance of the matter, we believe that the Schengen area must be put directly to an end in order to give Member States the levers to act and control individuals entering the national territory. Europe is a sieve and the massive influx of illegal migrants from Africa and the Middle East, including terrorists, shows us. In no way will the adoption of this enforcement decision change this reality.  Although this measure is paltry, I still supported this proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Visa Information System established the VIS as a visa data exchange system between Member States. The aim of establishing this system is to improve the methods of implementing the common visa policy and to contribute to the strengthening of internal security and the fight against terrorism under clearly defined and supervised conditions. Thus, this initiative is a key point in the European Union's policies establishing an area of justice, freedom and security. Another argument in favour of this system is the need for the competent services to have at their disposal the most comprehensive and up-to-date information in their areas of competence in the fight against terrorism and other serious crimes. It is therefore important to designate the competent authorities of the Member States, which are authorised to access the VIS for specific purposes in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist offences. I was in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to have clear policies that contribute to strengthening internal security and the fight against terrorism.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The authorities will be able to carry out cross-checks in the event of serious crimes or terrorism. Citizens need more security.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the draft resolution to establish the effect of the decision on access for consultation to the Visa Information System (VIS). This structure should aim to improve the implementation of the common visa policy, including by contributing to internal security and the fight against terrorism, according to well-defined and controlled parameters.  In order to combat terrorism and other serious crimes effectively, it is essential that the relevant services have comprehensive and up-to-date information in their respective areas, so that they can properly carry out their duties.  The data contained in the VIS system should therefore be available for consultation by national authorities and also by Europol, which plays a key role in cooperation between Member States' authorities in investigating cross-border crime.  This decision also has the merit of pursuing its objectives with full respect for the fundamental rights and principles set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which is aimed at setting the date of entry into force of an EU decision. The decision in question is aimed at allowing Europol and other authorities to consult the Visa Information System. As I am opposed to any law—enforcement authority accessing the Visa Information System or any other non-legal enforcement databases, I abstained on this decision setting a date of entry into force. Such interference has a stigmatising effect on migrants and foreign travellers. Given my opposition to the main legal text, I abstained on when it should come into effect.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it aims to improve and accelerate the processes of prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist activities. International cooperation and exchange of information between different agencies and countries is crucial in fighting terrorism.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Council implementing decision aims to replace Decision 2013/392/EU, annulled by a judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU for failure to consult the European Parliament (Judgment of the Court of Justice of 16 April 2015 in Case C-540/13 Parliament v Council). In that judgment, however, the Court maintained the effects of the first Decision 2013/392/EU until the entry into force of a new act intended to replace it. This act is the decision voted on today which, in the final analysis, only sets the date of entry into force of the decision. I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. The decision in question is an enforcement decision aimed at ensuring the continuity of access rights in consultation to the visa information system of the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol. This would allow for the establishment of a mechanism to help combat terrorism. So I voted for it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Council's draft, the resolution of 9 July 2015 on the European Agenda for Security, as well as the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we supported and adopted the Council's draft.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal concerning the date of entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JHA on access for consultation to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol, with a view to preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious crimes. This decision replaces Council Decision 2013/392/EU, which had been annulled by a judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU. With the judgment, the Court maintained the effects of Decision 2013/392/EU until the entry into force of a new act to replace it. Consequently, Decision 2008/633/JHA replaces Decision 2013/392/EU and the latter ceases to have effects.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote setting out the entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JHA on the exchange of visa information between different Member States and authorities. I object to access by the security forces to any database that collects non-crime issues, such as a visa registration. I understand that this Decision criminalizes migrants and foreign nationals travelling or residing in the Union. In any case, since the date from which the files are accessed is being voted on, I abstained as it was a technical issue within a decision which I do not share.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that it goes in the right direction, namely to defend countries from the possibility of being victims of certain acts of violence. In my view, it is important, even before dealing with certain serious situations, to be able to prevent them and, if possible, to avoid them by relying on the appropriate authorities.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Council implementation decision aims to allow the continued access of national police to the SIV for the purpose of preventing, detaining and investigating terrorist acts and serious crime. This access is the result of a concerted strategy to combat these phenomena.  The SIV is a European visa database, created to enter applicant data as well as assigned visas. In this way, the whole procedure is faster, the visa safer and combats the so-called "visa shopping".  The legal basis for this access had already been granted by amending the regulation on the basis of its establishment and of which I was rapporteur. This decision - to which Parliament must give its opinion - only approves its date of entry into force and technical elements.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The intensification of migration, the possible infiltration of terrorist cells and the attacks that have taken place in recent years in Europe represent a threat to the security of European citizens. It is essential to improve border control and prevent possible terrorist attacks. I am therefore in favour of this report, which aims to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the Visa Information System (VIS) by the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report addresses the date of effect of Decision 2008/633/JHA. It allows relevant Member State authorities and Europol access to Visa Information Systems (VIS) to prevent, detect, and deter terrorist or serious criminal offences. I have voted in favour of it as a result.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today to give the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for consultation. The present security challenges, terrorism and other serious crimes call on Member States to cooperate more closely. In order to address these challenges effectively and to prevent, detect and investigate criminal offences, special measures need to be put in place. It is important that we give the competent authorities the means to take effective action against organised crime and terrorism in order to protect our citizens. The AIM of the VIS is to improve the implementation of the common visa policy, consular cooperation and consultation between central visa authorities by facilitating the exchange of data on applications and related decisions between Member States in order to facilitate the visa application procedure, prevent 'visashopping', facilitate the fight against fraud and carry out checks at external border crossing points and in the territory of the Member States. The VIS shall also assist in identifying persons who may not or may no longer fulfil the conditions for entry, residence or establishment in the territory of the Member States.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents the European Parliament’s position on a draft Council Implementing Decision which determines the date (1 September 2013) from which designated authorities and Europol have access to the Visa Information System (VIS). This technical report in itself is uncontroversial, as the implementing decision merely confirms legally the date from which the Member States’ designated authorities and Europol have access to the VIS under certain conditions, that access having already been established in the VIS Regulation. Therefore I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur's position on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for consultation by the designated authorities of the Member States and europol for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious offences.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's position on the implementation of EU legislation on access to visa information system consultation by designated national authorities and the European agency Europol. These measures aim to strengthen cooperation between national and European authorities in the fight against terrorism and serious crimes. I support these objectives and I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This report aims to ensure the continuity of access rights in consultation of visa information system (VIS) data by the designated authorities of the Member States and by Europol. I supported this text because it is necessary to be able to rely on the visa information system to strengthen the prevention and detection of terrorist offences at European level.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in the protection of our citizens.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The Visa Information System (VIS), established in 2004, aimed to strengthen European cooperation on the issue of control at the EU's external borders. By creating a common fingerprint database, the VIS was supposed to facilitate visa application procedures and strengthen controls. This resolution was then more of a technical formality than anything else. However, it seems necessary to question this visa information system, especially in view of the unprecedented illegal migration that Member States are facing. The usefulness of the VIS is indeed relative, as states no longer even have control of borders - although by necessity, controls have been re-established in Hungary, for example, under the Schengen agreements, which are clearly not effective. I think it is important, notwithstanding the apparent emptiness of this resolution, to do everything possible to combat the dogma of absolute free movement, in the face of the constant risk of terrorism. That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Kirkhope's report on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for consultation by member states' authorised authorities and Europol in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious criminal offences, as the new Council Decision updates the existing legal framework.  I also support the objectives of this Decision to ensure an appropriate and effective exchange of information between Member States and Europol in order to combat cross-border crime. In relation to cross-border crime, and especially the growing problem of illegal immigration, it is important that we work towards greater security in the Member States and protect our citizens.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The VIS visa system of the Council proposal needs a comprehensive review, as does the Schengen Treaty. It concerns not only the VIS, SIS II and EYRODAC systems but mainly the Schengen and Dublin Treaties 2. The absence of the systems was clearly evident in the recent administrations of travel documents of illegal immigrants who did not possess travel documents, refused to give fingerprints and after examination through the biometrics recognition and identification system, turned out to be ISIS fighters.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in the protection of our citizens.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirm with a positive vote the report expressing support for the Council's decision to approve access by the competent authorities to the VIS (Visa Information System), so that the competent authorities can carry out cross-checks in cases suspected of serious crimes or terrorism.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The VIS visa system of the Council proposal needs a comprehensive review, as does the Schengen Treaty. It concerns not only the VIS, SIS II and EYRODAC systems but mainly the Schengen and Dublin Treaties 2. The absence of the systems was clearly evident in the recent administrations of travel documents of illegal immigrants who did not possess travel documents, refused to give fingerprints and, after examination through the biometric recognition and identification system, turned out to be ISIS fighters. For the above reasons my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents the European Parliament’s position on a draft Council Implementing Decision which determines the date (1 September 2013) from which designated authorities and Europol have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) in accordance with Council Decision 2008/633/JHA. This is the Council’s second attempt to fix the date of effect of the Council Decision. Its first attempt to fix the date of effect was successfully challenged by the European Parliament before the Court of Justice of the European Union because the Council had failed to consult the Parliament before adopting its implementing decision. The report itself is uncontroversial as the implementing decision merely confirms legally the date from which the Member States’ designated authorities and Europol have access to the VIS under certain conditions, that access having already been established in the VIS Regulation and Council Decision 2008/633/JHA. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in the protection of our citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in order to protect our citizens.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this request, given the current situation in Europe. In particular, the significant influx of people currently being observed in the individual Member States requires reliable protection of EU citizens from the dangers of terrorism and the excesses of crime. That is why I am committed to the optimal equipment and cooperation of the competent authorities. This is a clear step towards the prevention of terrorist activities and the protection of citizens within Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This is consent to a Council proposal on the date on which Decision 2008/633/JHA governing access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the competent authorities will enter into force. The objective is to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and by Europol for the purposes of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorism offences and other serious crimes. Obviously I am not opposed to the prevention of terrorism offences, but I question the order of priorities in the management of migration flows and reject the perverse effects of such measures. The GUE/NGL Group has always opposed legal artifacts that prioritize migrant identification mechanisms, either through access to the VIS or other databases, as it has a stigmatizing effect on them. It is, moreover, a decision affecting the date of entry into force; the content of this regulation is no longer being valued. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the Council Implementing Decision concerning the setting of a date for the entry into force of Decision 2008/633/ESIS on access to, detection and prosecution of designated authorities of the Member States and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purpose of viewing it, in order to prevent, detect and prosecute terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as this is an extremely important issue for public security. I supported the Council's implementing decision and its retroactive application from 1 September 2013, as I consider it extremely important that law enforcement authorities ensure continuity of access to the VIS. The adoption of a Council Decision is important to ensure the effective exchange of information between the Member States of the European Union and Europol with a view to effectively combating crime.  Most of my compatriots want to live in a safe country. That is why, as a Polish, I voted in favour of this Council decision, which, in my opinion, proposes appropriate standards for the protection of public safety.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents the European Parliament’s position on a draft Council Implementing Decision which determines the date (1 September 2013) from which designated authorities and Europol have access to the Visa Information System (VIS). This technical report in itself is uncontroversial, as the implementing decision merely confirms legally the date from which the Member States’ designated authorities and Europol have access to the VIS under certain conditions, that access having already been established in the VIS Regulation. Therefore I voted in favour of the report.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the Council Implementing Decision fixing the date of effect of Decision 2008/633/JHA concerning access for consultation of the Visa Information System (VIS) by Member States and Europol for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and of other serious criminal offences. This would help to build a more safe, free and just Europe. It allows people to move freely but at the same time reinforces the required protection from any possible threats.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 With today's vote, we have given the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to introduce special measures so that the competent authorities can carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes.  As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of access to the VIS in order to give the competent authorities the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in the protection of our citizens.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted overwhelmingly in favour of the decision on access to the VIS, in consultation, by the designated authorities of the Member States and by Europol for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as well as for the purposes of investigating them. I am pleased that Parliament is consulted on this decision and can express its support for this approach. Indeed, I believe that all the instruments at our disposal must be mobilised to fight terrorism, given the strong threats facing the European continent, in particular France. There would be an inconsistency in keeping information systems, such as the VIS, inaccessible to police forces. However, the deadlock we are having on the "smart borders" package lies precisely in the fact that some Socialist MEPs are vehemently opposed to the access to the future entry/exit system being accessible to the police authorities. How can we effectively protect people if our police forces are kept out of the means to prevent the threat?

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, I support the report on the draft Council implementing decision on access to the Visa Information System for consultation by authorised authorities of the Member States and by Europol in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious criminal offences. I believe that the European authorities and the authorities of the Member States are called upon to cooperate effectively and exchange information in a coordinated manner in order to ensure as much as possible the security of all persons within the European Union. In addition, respect for fundamental human rights, especially in view of personal freedoms, the protection of personal data and the need for all security measures to be carried out in accordance with the requirements and practice of European law, is equally important.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. This is consent to a Council proposal on the date on which Decision 2008/633/JHA governing access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the competent authorities will enter into force. The objective is to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and by Europol for the purposes of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorism offences and other serious crimes. Obviously I am not opposed to the prevention of terrorism offences, but I question the order of priorities in the management of migration flows and reject the perverse effects of such measures. The GUE/NGL Group has always opposed legal artifacts that prioritize migrant identification mechanisms, either through access to the VIS or other databases, as it has a stigmatizing effect on them. It is, moreover, a decision affecting the date of entry into force; the content of this regulation is no longer being valued. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Council’s draft regarding the consultation of the VIS by authorities of Member States and by Europol in order to prevent and counter terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision establishing the date from which Decision 2008/633/PUP on access by certain Member State authorities and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) to request data for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious crimes is taking effect, as this accepts the aforementioned Council draft that will strengthen the space of freedom, security and justice.  I think it is of utmost importance to improve the implementation of the common visa policy for the stability of Member States and the EU, especially in the case of serious crimes. Shared synergies and cooperation in this area contribute to the advancement of internal security and to increasing the credibility of national and European institutions.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This is a report on the draft enforcement decision aimed at ensuring the continuity of access rights by Member States and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purpose of preventing and detecting terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. The proposed decision is intended to replace the 2013/392/EU Council decision, which was censured by the European Court of Justice. On 1 September 2013, when the 2008/633/JAI decision took effect, should be upheld as it is in Article 1 of the 2013/392/EU decision. The draft decision therefore has a technical dimension without colouring. It does not address the Schengen area or the Visa Information System (VIS).  Yet, while in Europe the tendency is to question the usefulness of borders, the usefulness of the VIS may seem incongruous. However, voting against this project would be misinterpreted as not participating in the fight against terrorism. So I voted for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Timothy Kirkhope's report on access to visa information by Member States and Europol to prevent terrorist and other serious criminal offences, as well as for investigations. The aim was to replace a Council decision which had been overturned by the Eu Court of Justice because of the lack of consultation with the European Parliament. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report aims to strengthen the visa regime at European level. It also proposes good transparency measures and incorporates the decision-making powers of the Member States. The result is a round proposal, particularly in the area of prevention, against the entry of criminals and terrorists. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it only confirms legally the date from which the Member States’ designated authorities and Europol have access to the VIS under certain conditions.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in order to protect our citizens.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative act (decision) concerns the date of effect of the Visa Information System (VIS). VIS was designated by the Member States and Europol in order to prevent terrorist offences. Legally, this legislative act on VIS’ access should take effect once the Member States will be able to exchange data between them. I am opposed to any law—enforcement authority to access VIS, since it can stigmatize migrants. This is why I chose to abstain.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of Mr Kirkhope's report. It aims to further strengthen the right of access for consultation of the Visa Information System (VIS) by the Shengen States and Europol. The aim of the VIS is to ensure an area of freedom, security and justice, as well as the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist and other serious crimes.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This is a report expressing Parliament's view on a draft Council Implementation Decision to determine the date from which designated authorities of Member States and Europol will have access to the Visa Information System to facilitate the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist crimes and other serious crimes , a measure for which I am.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote setting out the entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JHA on the exchange of visa information between different Member States and authorities. I object to access by the security forces to any database that collects non-crime issues, such as a visa registration. I understand that this Decision criminalizes migrants and foreign nationals travelling or residing in the Union. In any case, since the date from which the files are accessed is being voted on, I abstained as it was a technical issue within a decision which I do not share.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Decision 2008/633 of the Justice and Home Affairs Council replaces Council Decision 2013/392/EU1 which was annulled by a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union. The effects of Decision 2013/392 will last until its replacement takes effect. The purpose of the Decision is to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist offences and other serious crimes.  The effective date is set out in Article 1. Decisions 2013/392, which is 1 September 2013. As this applies to the Schengen acquis, Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein will also participate in the application. Denmark does not participate in the adoption, but within six months of the Decision of the Council of the European Union it can decide on the implementation in national legislation. I supported MP Timothy Kirkhope's report as it is necessary to elaborate in detail on all legal issues in order to achieve as much legal certainty as possible, especially when it comes to such sensitive matters as terrorism and other serious crimes.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Terrorism is undoubtedly a plague of modern humanity. Combating it – active, transnational and coordinated – is the moral obligation of any country, especially in view of the fact that no country, including in Europe, is fully protected from it. The sharing of information and inter-institutional advice between several countries are absolutely necessary for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences. Consequently, it is certainly worth confirming access to the Visa Information System by Europol and the designated authorities of the Member States of the European Union. While it is perfectly logical that we should help the needy, europe's borders must not be allowed to be crossed by terrorists and other criminals. And if it has taken its place one way or another, it is necessary to coordinate cross-border efforts to implement law-based actions that would help to take steps for the safety of Europeans.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision establishing the start of production of the results of Council Decision 2008/633/5EE on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) of the appointed authorities of the Member States as well as Europol, in order to search for data on the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, because it is sufficiently documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Parliament's legislative resolution on the draft decision setting the effective date of Decision 2008/633/JHA on access for consultation to the visa information system by the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol with a view to preventing the detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious crimes. The establishment of the VIS is one of the priority initiatives of the European Union's policies aimed at improving the implementation of the common internal security policy and in the fight against terrorism and other serious crimes. The information contained in the VIS system is necessary for the prevention and fight against terrorism and other serious crimes and must therefore be available for consultation by the designated authorities. In order, therefore, to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and Europol, with a view to preventing, detecting and investigating serious crimes, it is therefore appropriate that the date from which Decision 2008/633 JHA entered into force should be maintained.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 By voting in favour, I intend to support the Council's implementing decision to set a precise date for Decision 2008/633/JHA on the possibility for the authorities designated by the Member States and Europol to consult the Visa Information System.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Preventive measures against terrorists and other criminals are to be welcomed. Although the report strengthens the Commission, it is transparent and worthy of approval because of the involvement of the member states' decisions.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This is a technical report that sets the effective date of the Council's decision allowing the authorities of the Member States responsible for internal security and Europol to access the Visa Information System (VIS). This decision aims to facilitate the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences within the framework of the Union. Nevertheless, this legal authority to centralize and share data on visas or any other databases de facto stigmatizes migrants and foreign travellers on a security basis. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is a report on the draft enforcement decision aimed at ensuring the continuity of access rights by Member States and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purpose of preventing and detecting terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. The proposed decision is intended to replace the 2013/392/EU Council decision, which was censured by the European Court of Justice. On 1 September 2013, when the 2008/633/JAI decision took effect, should be upheld as it is in Article 1 of the 2013/392/EU decision. The draft decision therefore has a technical dimension without colouring. It does not address the Schengen area or the Visa Information System (VIS).  Yet, while in Europe the tendency is to question the usefulness of borders, the usefulness of the VIS may seem incongruous. However, voting against this project would be misinterpreted as not participating in the fight against terrorism. So I voted for it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it aims to ensure that the competent and relevant authorities designated by Member States and Europol have access rights to the Visa Information System. This system connects the central European system to national systems. This interconnectivity enables border guards to identify people in Schengen territory with either fraudulent or no documents.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The data exchange system between the Schengen Member States allows the Union to establish not only an area of freedom and justice, but also an area of security. Thanks to this system, border controls are simplified but, in return, security is strengthened. From now on, thanks to this decision, Europol and the relevant national authorities will be allowed to consult the VIS database. This is another step in the prevention of terrorism and in the fight against crime.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on access for consultation of the Visa Information System by Member States and Europol because it is essential for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and of other serious criminal offences.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft decision setting the date of application of Decision 2008/633/IB of 23 June 2008 on access to the visa information system for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, and presented the draft to Parliament for consultation. The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends the draft to Parliament for approval and I voted in favour of it.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This enforcement decision will allow the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol to continue to have access to the visa information system in consultation. It is a technical decision that is not substantive and allows institutions to be given more resources in the fight against terrorism.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the draft Council implementation decision setting the effective date for the 2008/633/JAI decision on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by member authorities and Europol with the aim of preventing and investigating terrorist activities and other serious criminal offences. A purely technical resolution, it does not deal with substance but with the modalities of a procedure which, in fact, already exists. At a time when Schengen is obsolete and the countries of entry for migrants (Italy, Greece) are struggling to manage flows, it is still necessary to reaffirm our commitment against terrorism. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on access to the Visa Information System (VIS). The aim is to authorise the consultation of this system by Member States and Europol for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as well as for the purposes of investigating it. The Council adopted an enforcement decision on the matter in 2013 but did not consult the European Parliament. As a result, the Court of Justice of the Union had overturned the decision while maintaining its effects until a new act came into force. This decision replaces the overturned decision. This measure, adopted by a large majority, will better combat terrorist crimes and attacks that try to destabilise European democracies.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Visa Information System (VIS) allows Schengen States to exchange visa data. It consists of a central IT system and of a communication infrastructure that links this central system to national systems. I have voted for this report that has for its purpose to facilitate the checking and the issuance of visas, the fight against abuses, the protection of travellers, support with asylum applications and the enhancing of security.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although the report also strengthens the Commission, it is nevertheless transparent and incorporates the decisions of the Member States. It supports prevention against criminals and terrorists and has therefore obtained my support.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to set an effective date for the Council's 2008/633/JHA decision on access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the relevant authorities designated by the Member States and Europol. Access to the consultation of this system which centralizes visa information would allow better prevention and detection of terrorist offences, but would also facilitate their investigation. But, in reality, it will allow a legal authority to centralize and share visa data, which poses a real risk of stigmatization against migrant or foreign populations.  It is not a question of deciding on the very content of the decision, but on a very technical point, which is the date of its entry into force. So I decided to abstain.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the growing terrorist threat to which the European Union has long been exposed, also as a result of the rise in the level of alertness in areas such as Crimea, Syria, the Maghreb, etc., I am certainly voting in favour. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur, who has been able to strike the right balance on such a sensitive issue.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 This resolution aims to establish the effective date of Decision 2008/633/JHA. The decision speaks of the possibility for Member States to consult vis (Visa Information System) for the purpose of preventing, identifying and researching terrorist or other criminal acts. This decision would replac Decision 2013/392/EU. The provision represents a positive shift towards promoting the joint work of member states and their institutions. I think this has made progress in the fight against terrorism and crime because it allows all Member States to have access to the VIS. If member states have access to the VIS, they are also given access to various data useful in the fight against terrorism and crime. By accessing certain data, Member States may have better control over the entry and exit of persons from the country, in a person suspected of having links to terrorism or having committed other criminal acts. This enables the prevention, detection, investigation and detection of people linked to terrorist and other criminal acts. It is also significant that member states are allowed to participate jointly in preventing terrorism and crime. In my view, it is also significant that this provision addresss the shortcomings that existed in the previous provision, such as the improvement of the common visa policy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the draft Council implementation decision setting the effective date for the 2008/633/JAI decision on consultation access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by Member State authorities and Europol with the aim of preventing and investigating terrorist activities and other serious criminal offences. It is a technical resolution that does not deal with the substance but with the modalities of a procedure which, in reality, already exists. At a time when Schengen is obsolete and the countries of entry for migrants (Italy, Greece) are struggling to manage flows, this is not going to change the situation. Nevertheless, I want to reaffirm my commitment to fighting terrorism. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tonino PICULA
