text: Written. ‒ In line with the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I consider it important to set without delay the date from which Decision 2008/633/PUP enters into force in order to ensure the continuity of access by member state authorities and Europol to the VIS for the purpose of preventing, detecting and researching terrorist offences and other serious crimes.  As Council Decision 2013/392/EU has been annulled by the Court of Justice of the EU, it is having effects until a new decision to replace it enters into force, and it should be adopted as early as all the necessary conditions are now met for its implementation.  Access to the visa information system by Member States and Europol must not be suspended or delayed for any period, especially given the security and terrorist threats and risks that re-emerge before the European Union. Therefore, the procedure for establishing that date should be continued, avoiding unnecessary waste of time.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support my colleague Timothy Kirkhope's report on the council's draft decision setting a date from which Decision 2008/633/PUP on access by certain Member State authorities and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) to request data for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious crimes is ingesting. The request relates to a change in the date from when Decision 2008/633/JHA enters into force, taking into account that all the necessary conditions have been met. The proposed decision should replace Council Decision 2013/392/EU, which was annulled by a ruling of the European Court of Justice. That ruling ruled that Decision 2013/392/EU should be implemented until the new one enters into force.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of access to the VIS (Visa Information System) by the designated authorities of the Member States responsible for security. I believe that in the fight against terrorism, as well as for other serious crimes, it is important that the competent authorities have the most comprehensive and up-to-date information possible. Better access to sensitive information could lead to an improvement in the common visa policy and contribute to the EU's internal security. I also believe that Europol, which through its work contributes to the prevention, analysis and investigation of criminal activities on a European scale, should also be able to benefit from access to VIS data, while respecting adequate protection of personal data.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I have expressed my support for the report to allow consultation access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by Member States and Europol for the prevention and detection of terrorist and other serious criminal offences. The aim of this text is to strengthen surveillance mechanisms within the Union and gives Member States one more way to ensure the safety of European citizens.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision 2008/633/JAI, on access to the visa information system (SIV) consultation by the designated authorities of the Member States and by Europol for the purpose of preventing, detection and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, provides for its effect from the date to be determined by the Council, when the Commission has informed it that Regulation (EC) No 767/2008 of the European Parliament and the Council has entered into force and is fully applicable. In view of the time, by letter of 2 July 2013, the Commission informed the Council that such a Regulation has entered into force and is fully applicable since 27 September 2011, the conditions triggering the exercise by the Council of the implementing powers laid down in Decision 2008/633/JAI are fulfilled. The Commission's proposal is precisely intended to set the date from which Decision 2008/633/JAI takes effect. In order to ensure continued access for consultation with the SIV, the proposal, now submitted to Parliament's consultation, maintained the date of 1 September 2013 set out in the previous Decision 2013/392/EU, which was annulled by the CJEU. I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In line with the European Union's desire to establish an area of freedom, security and justice, the visa information system is a system for exchanging data between the Member States of the Schengen area. The report voted today supports the Council's proposal and thus allows the authorities designated by the Member States to have access to vis data to prevent terrorist acts, serious criminal offences, etc. These existing instruments should be strengthened by ensuring that they respect the fundamental rights of travellers, including the protection of their personal data.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative motion for a resolution deals with the draft Council Implementing Decision, which sets the date from which the Decision on access to the Visa Information System, by the designated authorities of the Member States and by Europol, takes effect. The adoption of this measure aims to establish a uniform strategy capable of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist acts and other serious criminal offences. In the case of a special legislative consultation procedure, Parliament is called upon to pass on its position on the adoption of the date of entry into force and other technical aspects of this proposal, with a view to ensuring the continuity of access rights for consultation of the European visa database by law enforcement authorities. Since there has been a broad consensus of all the political groups on this matter and there are no reasons to support the adoption of this report, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the need to ensure and increase both personal and collective security by improving the prevention of terrorist offences and other serious crimes within the European Union. It is important that the authorities of the Member States responsible for international control and security and Europol have at their disposal precise and comprehensive information tools, such as access to the Visa Information System (VIS), in order to prevent the occurrence of any form of terrorist act.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I recognise the usefulness of the VIS system in terms of combating terrorism and crime.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. This is consent to a Council proposal on the date on which Decision 2008/633/JHA governing access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the competent authorities will enter into force. The objective is to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and by Europol for the purposes of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorism offences and other serious crimes. Obviously I am not opposed to the prevention of terrorism offences, but I question the order of priorities in the management of migration flows and reject the perverse effects of such measures. The GUE/NGL Group has always opposed legal artifacts that prioritize migrant identification mechanisms, either through access to the VIS or other databases, as it has a stigmatizing effect on them. It is, moreover, a decision affecting the date of entry into force; the content of this regulation is no longer being valued. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote setting out the entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JHA on the exchange of visa information between different Member States and authorities. I object to access by the security forces to any database that collects non-crime issues, such as a visa registration. I understand that this Decision criminalizes migrants and foreign nationals travelling or residing in the Union. In any case, since the date from which the files are accessed is being voted on, I abstained as it was a technical issue within a decision which I do not share.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Visa Information System (VIS) is one of the key initiatives of the European Union's policies to create an area of justice, freedom and security. The VIS must aim to improve the implementation of the common visa policy and to contribute to internal security and the fight against terrorism. I have therefore decided to give my assent to the Council's decision, as it ensures continued access to the VIS by Europol and the authorities designated by the Member States.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ There are already ample agreements on access to personal information across the EU without adding to them. This is a further erosion of the privacy of private individuals.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Visa Information System (VIS) is a visa data exchange system between Member States, which is one of the key initiatives in the context of EU policies aimed at establishing an area of justice, freedom and security. This system is intended to improve the implementation of the common visa policy and to contribute to improving internal security and the fight against terrorism.  In the fight against terrorism and other serious crime, it is essential that the relevant authorities (national and Europol) have as complete and up-to-date information as they can from their respective areas of work. I agree that the information contained in the VIS could make a key contribution to preventing terrorism and serious crime. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of setting the date on which Council Decision 2008/633/JHA is implemented, which is already in force.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this report on the grounds that council Decision 2008/633/PUP on access by certain Member State authorities and Europol to the visa information system for data search to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist offences should be taken into account. The Resolution on the European Agenda on Security and the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs should certainly be taken into account.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of the report is to establish the date of action of Decision 2008/633/JHA relating to access to visa information system (VIS) consultation by designated member state authorities and by Europol for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. This highly technical report was consensually supported by all groups, no amendments were tabled, and the committee used a prompt procedure to meet council requirements and to react as soon as possible. I fully support the proposal to establish the effective date of Decision 2008/633/JHA, as the main objective of the report is to ensure the continued right of access to VIS counselling for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The VIS visa system of the Council proposal needs a comprehensive review, as does the Schengen Treaty. It concerns not only the VIS, SIS II and EYRODAC systems but mainly the Schengen and Dublin Treaties 2. The absence of the systems was clearly evident in the recent administrations of travel documents of illegal immigrants, who did not possess travel documents, refused to give fingerprints and after examination through the biometrics recognition and identification system, turned out to be ISIS fighters.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote gave the green light to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol to have access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for inspection in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious crimes. The unprecedented challenges we are currently facing pose a serious threat to the EU's internal security, which is why we need to put in place special measures to allow the competent authorities to carry out investigations to prevent terrorist attacks and other serious crimes. We, the members of the Fidesz delegation, want our competent authorities to be provided with the means to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism in order to protect our citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents the European Parliament’s position on a draft Council Implementing Decision which determines 1 September 2013, as the date from which designated authorities and Europol have access to the Visa Information system (VIS) in accordance with Council Decision 2008/633/JHA. Even though the Council Decision from 2008, laid down in Articles 5 and 6, sets out the conditions under which the designated authorities in the Member States and Europol were entitled to have access to the VIS, the exact date of effect of that decision was dependent on the full implementation of VIS Regulation (EC) 767/2008. As all the necessary procedures have now been complied with, it has become possible to fix the date of from which the Member States’ designated authorities and Europol have access to the VIS under certain conditions. The current report, which I voted in favour of, legally confirms the chosen date of 1 September 2013.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported the draft Council implementation decision setting the effective date for the 2008/633/JAI decision on consultation access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the designated authorities of the Member States and by the European Police Office (Europol) for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, and for the purposes of investigations in this area. We validate the Council's draft access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the designated authorities of the Member States and By Europol for the prevention and detection of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as well as for the purposes of investigations in this area. This technical adaptation of the EU budget's revenues is validly based on the most recent statistical developments and respects the agreed distribution between the Member States.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which calls for fixing the date of effect of Decision 2008/633/JHA. The Decision concerns access for consultation of the Visa Information System (VIS) by designated authorities of Member States and by Europol when all the requisite conditions have been met. It aims to replace Council Decision 2013/392/EU, which was annulled by the Court of Justice of the European Union. In its judgment, the Court maintained the effects of Decision 2013/392/EU until the entry into force of a new act intended to replace it. The purpose of the access to the VIS is to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist offences and other serious crimes, facilitating thus the European Security Agenda.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted yes because the report supports the supplementary Council Decision on access by certain Member State bodies and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) to request data for the purpose of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious crimes, as this replaces the original 2013 Decision annulled by the European Court of Justice.  In fact, during the adoption of the original Decision, the Council did not involve the European Parliament in the process of adopting it, thus significantly infringing the procedure.  Nevertheless, I believe that the expected change only in the process of adoption of this Decision is particularly important, as is the fact that the new Decision, as well as the original one, clearly defines the conditions for the accession of certain authorities of the Member States and Europol to vis data, but also the obligation to protect personal data and ensure data security.  In my view, this ensures a purposeful and effective exchange of information between Member States and Europol in the fight against cross-border crime.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal on access by the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol to the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purpose of data search for the purposes of the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences, as I believe that the designated authorities of the Member States and Europol will have a greater opportunity to supervise criminals and terrorist threats.  All this will be able to have a positive impact and prevent any future attacks on European values and institutions. At the same time, our citizens will be more protected and safer.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This is consent to a Council proposal on the date on which Decision 2008/633/JHA governing access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the competent authorities will enter into force. The objective is to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and by Europol for the purposes of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorism offences and other serious crimes. Obviously I am not opposed to the prevention of terrorism offences, but I question the order of priorities in the management of migration flows and reject the perverse effects of such measures. The GUE/NGL Group has always opposed legal artifacts that prioritize migrant identification mechanisms, either through access to the VIS or other databases, as it has a stigmatizing effect on them. It is, moreover, a decision affecting the date of entry into force; the content of this regulation is no longer being valued. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support any measure to increase personal and collective security and improve the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious offences within the European Union.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report tabled by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Access to the Visa Information System (VIS) for the purpose of access to the designated authorities of the Member States and europol in order to prevent, detect and investigate terrorist acts and other serious criminal offences.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. This is consent to a Council proposal on the date on which Decision 2008/633/JHA governing access to the Visa Information System (VIS) by the competent authorities will enter into force. The objective is to ensure the continuity of access rights for consultation of the VIS by the authorities designated by the Member States and by Europol for the purposes of preventing, detecting and investigating terrorism offences and other serious crimes. Obviously I am not opposed to the prevention of terrorism offences, but I question the order of priorities in the management of migration flows and reject the perverse effects of such measures. The GUE/NGL Group has always opposed legal artifacts that prioritize migrant identification mechanisms, either through access to the VIS or other databases, as it has a stigmatizing effect on them. It is, moreover, a decision affecting the date of entry into force; the content of this regulation is no longer being valued. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because of the importance of insuring safety and at the same time fair and appropriate access to data relevant for safety. Access by national authorities will be designed in such a way that the operating units within the designated national authorities may access VIS data through central access points assigned by EU countries. Access to the data will be applied for on a case-by-case basis with reasoned written or electronic requests. The requests will be verified and processed by the central access points prior to querying the VIS. They would then transfer the data obtained from the query to the operation units. Only in urgent cases may the requests be submitted in written, electronic or oral form, with the verifications carried out ex-post.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This is a very technical report on which Parliament is only consulted and which aims to ensure the continuity of the access rights of consultation of the Visa Information System (VIS) by the authorities designated by the Member States and Europol for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and other serious crimes. In view of the broad consensus reached by the groups and the absence of amendments on this subject, I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote setting out the entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JHA on the exchange of visa information between different Member States and authorities. I object to access by the security forces to any database that collects non-crime issues, such as a visa registration. I understand that this Decision criminalizes migrants and foreign nationals travelling or residing in the Union. In any case, since the date from which the files are accessed is being voted on, I abstained as it was a technical issue within a decision which I do not share.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this approval of the Committee draft proposal. In our globalised age organised crime has no respect for borders. They reach out in networks that span the whole of Europe. Terrorist groups also liaise and transfer ideas transnationally as never before. Therefore, the nations of Europe need to work together to solve these problems more closely than before and share data properly. However, considering this we must beware of mission creep and the possibility of the undermining of civil liberties, therefore it is important that the mandate laid out in this proposal is not stretched and is adhered to in both letter and spirit. Furthermore, any changes must be brought before Parliament. We guard against threats, without becoming our own jailers and losing the way of life we are fighting for.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. It is extremely important that we give criminals and terrorists as little chance as possible to mingle with genuine refugees. By sharing information better, we need to be able to counter this. So I voted in favour of this solution, in the hope that we can minimise the risks.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is an implementing decision of the Council setting the date from which Decision 2008/633/JAI on access to visa information system (SIV) shall take effect by the designated authorities of the Member States and by Europol for the purpose of preventing, detaling and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Preventive measures against terrorists and other criminals are to be welcomed. Although the report strengthens the Commission, it is transparent and worthy of approval because of the involvement of the member states' decisions.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Council Implementing Decision fixing the date of effect of Decision 2008/633/JHA concerning access for consultation of the visa information system (VIS) by designated authorities of Member States or by Europol for the purpose of the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offences and of other serious criminal offences.  Generally, the proposed Decision seeks to replace the Decision 2013/392/EU which was annulled by the judgment of Court of Justice of the European Union, in which the Court maintained that effects of the Decision 2013/392/EU until the entry into force of a new act intended to replace it.  I see no contraindications why this Decision should not be implemented. It is pretty straightforward, it does not cover any controversial issues, and it aims to protect the Union, which is one of our fundamental goals.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the resolution is to express an opinion on the date of entry into force of the new implementing decision, which aims to ensure an adequate and effective exchange of information between Member States and Europol in order to combat cross-border crime (so-called Visa Information System). The adoption of the decision follows a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which declared the original Council Decision No 2013/392 null and invalid. Until the date of entry into force of the new decision has been set, the Court has upheld the effects of the existing decision. In order to ensure the continuity of the VIS, the Council proposes to apply the new Decision 2008/633/ VIS from 1 September 2013.  I therefore voted in favour of the resolution approving the draft Decision 2008/633/ESM.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is only intended to set the date of entry into force of Decision 2008/633/JAI on access to the Visa Information System (SIV) by the designated authorities of the Member States and by EUROPOL for the purpose of preventing, deving and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences. The establishment of a Visa Information System (SIV) is part of the Schengen Information System (SIS) and EURODAC, within the framework of the communitisation of the so-called "third pillar", i.e. Justice and Home Affairs, seeking to remove central competences from Member States. The SIV aims to be a system of exchange between Member States of visa data. Since we have always spoken out against the EU-set-up system of corporate surveillance and securitization, often on the pretext of citizens' security but indeed against their fundamental freedoms and guarantees, we voted against this report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents a technical change which will ensure the proper functioning of different funds managed by the European Commission. The report seeks to adapt the changes in revenue from the European Union budget generated by the agreements with the United Kingdom in addition to the increase in own resources collected by the Commission to improve the allocation of certain items. These include different development cooperation funds through external action and funds for the operation of the Office of the Agency for European Electronic Communications Regulators. By bringing about a technical change to ensure the proper functioning of the funds, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The draft amending budget for the future foresees a reduction in France's participation in the European Union budget. The initial budget for 2015 was 22.5 billion, while the amending budget number 6 announced a contribution of 21.8 billion euros, a decrease of 0.7 million euros.   Not being in favour of the technocratic European Union, I logically voted in favour of this project.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose Draft Amending Budget No 6/2015: partly because it creates two new budget items to which I am opposed but also because it will result in a reduced UK rebate and therefore in more British taxpayers’ money being spent.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for amending budget No 6/2015. It concerns the revision of traditional forecasts of own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgetisation of the relevant corrections to the United Kingdom and their financing, which alter the distribution of Member States' contributions to the Union budget.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it includes plans to reduce France's participation in the EU budget: this follows the increase in revenues from traditional resources (customs duties and contributions in the sugar sector in particular). With France's contribution rising from 22.5 billion euros to 21.8 billion euros, we would thus save some 700 million euros, that is, according to the Court of Auditors, roughly what the irresponsible asylum policy put in place by our current leaders will have cost us in 2013.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's position on this technical budgetary adjustment, which reduces GNI-based own resources by EUR 2.26 billion on the grounds that revenues from traditional own resources (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) are higher than expected and that the 2014 surplus has been included in the budget. This adjustment has no impact on the expenditure in the 2015 budget and its impact on revenues is only a change in the distribution of Member States' contributions.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report taking note of the amending budget No 6/2015 submitted by the Commission as well as the Council's position. Compared to the initial 2015 budget, national contributions to the GNI-based budget can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion through traditional own resources revenues exceeding forecasts of EUR 1.133.5 million. This technical adaptation of the revenues of the Union budget is based on recent statistical developments and is in line with the distribution agreed between the Member States.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the draft amending budget 6/2015 covers the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and the VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the corresponding UK corrections and their funding, which have the effect of changing the distribution of their contributions to the EU budget between Member States. This PBR 6/2015 has no impact on spending in 2015. The revenue impact is reflected in a change in the distribution of their own resource contributions among Member States. As a result, France's participation is expected to fall from 22.5 billion euros to 21.8 billion as a result of higher-than-expected own revenues (tariffs and sugar contributions). So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support with my vote this report analysing draft amending budget No 6 for the financial year 2015, because I do not agree with the measures envisaged the inclusion of a trust fund to facilitate yet another enlargement of the Member States.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 6/2015 comprises a review of traditional own resources forecasts, the basis of VAT and GNI, the budgeting of relevant British corrections and their financing, all of which entails a change in the distribution of Member States' contributions to the EU budget.  It also includes the creation of two new budget items for expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission in the areas of development and cooperation, and enlargement, respectively, while introducing an amendment to the staffing of the ORECE Office, with no impact on the total number of posts or their budget. As set out in the report, none of the elements of the draft amending budget have an impact on the expenditure of the 2015 budget, where while revenue is only a change in the distribution among Member States of their contributions.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorses the draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union, which makes the necessary amendments to certain sections of the 2015 budget. This draft amending budget concerns the revision of traditional forecasts of own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgetisation and financing of the corresponding corrections to the United Kingdom, which alter the distribution of Member States' contributions to the Union budget. This amending budget also includes the creation of two new budget items to support the expenditure of trust funds managed by the European Commission in the fields of development and cooperation and development policy, respectively. The last amendment to this draft amending budget is that the establishment plan of the Office of the European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) is amended without changing the total number of posts or the amount of the budget allocated to the Office.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 The adopted draft amending budget No 6/2015, which I also supported, concerns the change in forecasts in the basics of traditional own resources, VAT and GDP, and includes some corrections to the financing of the EU budget by the UNITED KINGDOM. The latter results in a change in the distribution of contributions to the EU budget between Member States. The proposed amending budget also concerns the introduction of two new budget lines to support trust funds managed by the Commission in the fields of development policy, cooperation policy or enlargement policy, and adapts the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC). The adopted amending budget will have no impact on the budget expenditure for 2015.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I also voted for the draft amending budget No. 6, which reduces France's participation in the European Union budget (initial budget 2015: 22.5 billion euros; draft amending budget: 21.8 billion euros), as a result of revenue from traditional own resources.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the new allocation of resources from the 2015 budget, which does not provide for any increase in costs, allows the entire European apparatus to function more efficiently.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This text deals with the revision of the European Union's revenue forecasts. According to the latest studies, the own resources from tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector may be higher than expected. This additional revenue would reduce the contribution of Member States by EUR 2.26 billion. This draft amending budget is based on the most recent statistics and has no impact on the expenditures in the 2015 budget. Only the distribution of Member States' contributions is changed but still respects the rules agreed in advance. In addition, this report provides for a change in the ORECE Office's workforce table but does not change the number of jobs and the budget allocated. We consider these changes to be positive, as member states' contributions will be reduced. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget refers to a review of forecasts for traditional own resources, value added tax and gross national income (NVS) calculation bases, seeking solutions for the inclusion in the budget of and funding relevant UK corrections, following the result of a change in the allocation of their contribution to the EU budget between Member States. At the level of the European Parliament, it has been noted that, compared to the current year's budget, national contributions to the budget, which are based on NVs, could be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion due to higher than expected revenues from traditional own resources, amounting to EUR 1 133.5 million. 6/2015 of the European Union for the 2015 financial year, as this technical adjustment of the revenue part of the EU budget is very well based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed allocation between Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote was no. I am opposed to the provision of a trust fund for EU enlargement.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the debate in this House and careful consideration, I voted in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, concerning the use of own resources, Union trust funds for external action and the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. The analysis of supporting documentation shows that this technical adjustment to the revenue side of the budget is necessary on the basis of recent statistical developments and in accordance with the distribution agreed between the Member States, with reference to the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and the creation of two new budget headings for expenditure on funds in the areas of 'development and cooperation' and 'enlargement'. It should also be considered that this technical adjustment has no impact on 2015 budgetary expenditure and that, on the revenue side too, it is only a change in the distribution of their contributions among the Member States. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 6/2015 is a compulsory annual report and is primarily technical in nature. The report concerns the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases (EU budget revenue side). Essentially, the UK made a mistake in their national budget contribution to the annual EU budget. In practice, this meant that several Member States had to pay more than they were supposed to, due to this mistake. Therefore, this DAB 6/2015 has no impact on the expenditure aspect of the 2015 EU budget, it instead concerns the distribution between the Member States’ own resources contributions due to the facts outlined above. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budget as it would review the UK rebate. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of the collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. UKIP opposes any further money being handed to the EU and we also oppose any moves for the EU to raise funding, which can only be done through taxation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it makes no changes to the agreed expenditure for the year 2015, but clarifies the structure of the support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report verifies that draft amending budget No 6/2015 has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget. The change results in revenue: the distribution of own resources contributions among the 28 Member States is being changed and our country is expected to reduce its annual contribution by EUR 452 million. I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted for this draft budget because it aims to reduce France's participation in the European Union budget as a result of higher-than-expected revenue from traditional own resources (tariffs and sugar contributions).

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Draft Amending Budget concerns a revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the entry in the budget of the relevant corrections in favour of the UK, as well as their financing, which result in a change in the payment of contributions to the Union budget between Member States. The report stresses that the Draft Amending Budget No. 6/2015 in all its elements has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and that its impact on the revenue side is only one change in the distribution of contributions between Member States. We therefore approve the Council's draft amending budget No 1/2004. 6/2015.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6/2015. The draft contains a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and VAT and GNI bases, as well as the accounting of relevant UK corrections and their financing, the creation of two new budget items for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission, intended to accommodate compensation for management costs related to EU trust funds for external action, and a change in the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal mainly because I am pleased to see, for once, that states (and therefore citizens) can save EUR 2.26 billion, or on average EUR 4.50 per head. In an institution that costs citizens less than 1% of their GDP, it is a fine sign of careful administration, but one that cannot make us sleep on our laurels: we must make good use of the resources that the EU administers, continue to contain costs by reducing waste and finally ensure that there is no temptation to increase withdrawals from citizens' pockets.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budget as it would review the UK rebate. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of the collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. UKIP opposes any further money being handed to the EU and we also oppose any moves for the EU to raise funding, which can only be done through taxation.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the multiple measures put forward by the Commission to deal with the refugee crisis, it was necessary to make its budgetary provision. As the funds are needed as soon as possible, this Parliament has used the urgent procedure, approving this amendment to the budget in record time. A €100 million boost is approved for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, a total increase of 120 staff for Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol, as well as a contribution of EUR 300 million to the Syrian Support Fund.  These measures are not sufficient, should be framed in the most comprehensive strategy for migration. On the other hand, it also fits into a strategy of using unused resources and anticipating funds, necessarily with impacts on the multiannual financial framework. The Council must therefore not only deliver on the promises of extra-budget financial contributions to deal with this crisis, but - in the short period - make up for this anticipation of funds, avoiding the use of today and then missing tomorrow.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budget as it would review the UK rebate. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of the collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. UKIP opposes any further money being handed to the EU and we also oppose any moves for the EU to raise funding, which can only be done through taxation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 as it concerns a revision of the forecasts relating to traditional own resources, as well as the accounting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom and the distribution among the Member States of their contributions to the European budget. This technical adjustment to the revenue side of the Union budget is based on recent statistical developments and is in line with the distribution agreed between the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report tabling the draft amending budget No 6/2015 details the contributions of traditional own resources (TOR), VAT and GNI to the European Union’s budget. This report is a technical adjustment to modify and better distribute such contributions collected from established measures and does not have an impact on the expenditure of the 2015 budget. I thus voted in favour of this report

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget (PBR) No 6 deals essentially with a technical amendment and updating of the revenue items for EU budget resources, as well as the accounting of the relevant UK corrections and their financing, which involve a change in the distribution between Member States of contributions to the EU budget from own resources. PBR No 6/2015 has no impact on expenditure in 2015, while the impact on revenue is a change in the distribution of own resources contributions among Member States. For the explanations set out above, I shall vote in favour.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the European People's Party, I voted in favour of draft budget amendment No 6/2015, which includes a technical adjustment of the revenue side of the EU budget. Compared to the original budget for 2015, GNI-based national budget contributions can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion due to higher than expected revenues (EUR 1133.5 million) from traditional own resources (duties and sugar market levies). The draft takes into account the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and added value tax and GNI resources, the corresponding corrections for the United Kingdom, thus modifying the distribution of contributions to the EU budget between Member States.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This amendment to the EU budget mostly concerns a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the budget, which is soundly based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed distribution among Member States. There is no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget. Therefore I voted in favour of this report, which was also supported by the majority of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate the fact that draft amending budget No. 6/2015 covers the creation of two new budget items for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the European Commission in the policy areas 'Development and cooperation' and 'Expansion', and I believe that this technical adaptation of the revenue part of the EU budget is well founded.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes an amendment to the 2015 budget to mobilise an additional EUR 401.3 million to deal with the refugee crisis, by revising the allocation of Member States' contribution to the European budget. Considering that this report aims to provide the necessary means to implement the recent decisions of the European Union to respond to the migration crisis, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This project does not change the expenditure in the 2015 budget, but only proposes a change in the allocation of contributions between Member States. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, which does not involve additional expenditure for Member States in 2015.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Draft araking budget No 6/2015 mainly includes technical adjustments to the revenue side of the EU budget. It takes into account the revision of forecasts for traditional own resources and added value tax and GNI resources, the transfer of appropriate corrections for the United Kingdom to the budget and their financing, thus altering the distribution of contributions to the EU budget between Member States. Draft araking 6/2015 was adopted by the Council. Compared to the original budget for 2015, GNI-based national budget contributions can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion, as revenues from traditional own resources (duties and sugar market levies) have increased by EUR 1 133.5 million than expected and since the 2014 surplus was included in the budget by a 3/2015 arakt. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against because budget resources are not managed properly.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal covers a review of the forecasts of traditional own resources, VAT bases and GNI, the budgeting of the corresponding corrections for the United Kingdom and their financing, resulting in the change in the allocation between Member States of contributions to the EU budget. Compared to the initial budget of 2015, national contributions to the GNI-based budget could be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion, thanks to revenue from traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) which exceeded forecasts by EUR 1133.5 million. This technical adjustment on the revenue side of the Union budget is solidly based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the distribution agreed between Member States. None of the elements of draft amending budget No 6/2015 have an impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and that its impact on the revenue side is limited to a change in the distribution between Member States' contributions

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget in question will have absolutely no technical impact on the expenditure side of the budget for 2015 and its impact on the revenue side will only be reflected in the change in the distribution of Member States' contributions. Compared to the initial budget for 2015, Member States' contributions to the GNI budget may be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion, given the higher than expected revenue from traditional own resources.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against these budgetary changes that do not convince our movement, as in the case of the use and management of the trust fund.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against Draft Amending Budget No 1/2012. 6/2015: own resources - Union trust fund for external action - service of the European regulatory body for electronic communications, because budget resources are not managed properly.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget No 6/2015 mostly concerns a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU budget which is soundly based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed distribution between Member States. There is no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget. Due to a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar sector levies), VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom, as well as their financing, there is a need for a change in the distribution between Member States’ contributions to the EU budget. Compared to the initial 2015 budget, national contributions to the budget based on GNI can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion due to higher than expected revenues from traditional own resources of EUR 1 133.5 million and the budgeting of the 2014 surplus (through Amending Budget 3/2015). I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Amending Budget No 6 2015. Due to the fact that revenue from customs duties and sugar levies is well above the forecasts of the original budget for 2015, it is necessary to adjust the current budget. This is the only way to plan reliably for the future. The corrections will not lead to increased expenditure in the European Union budget. Only the contributions of the individual Member States can be reduced retrospectively.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In connection with the review of traditional own-resource revenues financing the budget, there has been revenues greater than expected of EUR 2.6 billion (mainly sugar taxes and customs obligations). Corrections to the UK's mistakes in its calculation of its own domestic national income (and which meant that it contributed less than was appropriate) are also envisaged and that it will have to be compensated. The meaning of this is that almost all Member States will have to provide fewer resources as it stipulates that an increase in this income leads to a need for lesser input. That's why I voted for it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group, voted in favour of this report as it mostly concerns a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU budget. This adjustment is soundly based on the latest statistical developments and is in line with the agreed distribution between Member States. There is no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Own Resources, Union Trust Funds for External Action, Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. This necessary draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 concerns a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom, as well as their financing, thereby resulting in a change in the distribution between Member States of their contribution to the EU budget. Furthermore it covers the creation of two new budget items for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission, in the policy areas ‘Development and Cooperation’ and ‘Enlargement’, both with a token entry.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Arak 6/2015 mainly contains technical adjustments to the revenue side of the EU budget. It takes into account the revision of forecasts for traditional own resources and added value tax and GNI resources, the transfer of appropriate corrections for the United Kingdom to the budget and their financing, thus altering the distribution of contributions to the EU budget between Member States. Draft araking 6/2015 was adopted by the Council. Compared to the original budget for 2015, GNI-based national contributions could be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion, as a larger-than-expected EUR 1 133.5 million in revenue from traditional own resources (duties and sugar market levies) and since the 2014 surplus was included in the budget by a budget amendment 3/2015. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 is a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, and that this results in a change in the allocation of contributions to the Union budget between member States. Two new budget lines will be established - support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission in the development and cooperation policy areas and "enlargement" policy areas, which will be accompanied by a memorandum; an amendment to the establishment plan of the BeREC Bureau, with no change in the total number of posts and in the budget. Member States' contributions to the budget compared to those foreseen in the original 2015 budget will be reduced by €2.26 billion as a result of revenue from traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies), which exceed the expected revenue by €1 133.5 million. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. In connection with the review of traditional own-resource revenues financing the budget, there has been revenues greater than expected of EUR 2.6 billion (mainly sugar taxes and customs obligations). Corrections to the UK's mistakes in its calculation of its own domestic national income (and which meant that it contributed less than was appropriate) are also envisaged and that it will have to be compensated. The meaning of this is that almost all Member States will have to provide fewer resources as it stipulates that an increase in this income leads to a need for lesser input. That's why I voted for it.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Firstly, this concerns a revision of the forecast of Traditional Own Resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom, and their financing – resulting in a change in the distribution among Member States of their contribution to the Union budget. Secondly, this technical adjustment to the revenue side of the Union budget is based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed distribution among Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Council's position on draft budget amendments No 2012/2013. 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, own resources, Union external action trust funds, the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, as this amendment creates two budget items to support trust funds concerning development and cooperation policy, and enlargement policy. Furthermore, the job plan in BEREC is changing, but the total number of jobs or the budget of the same is unchanged.  Therefore, I support changes to budget No. 6/2015 which do not affect expenditure for 2015, i.e. the distribution between member states as regards their own resources contributions changes.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The draft summary budget 6 has the merit of reducing the initial budget of 2015 by 2.26 billion euros. This is justified by higher-than-expected revenues from traditional own resources, such as tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector. So I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. The EU has plenty of money and we also oppose the need to raise more funding.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the EU's own resources amending budget. This text aims to revise the forecasts on the EU's traditional own resources (customs duties) and VAT bases, without consequence for 2015 expenditure or Member States' contributions. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In principle, due to the current exceptional circumstances, I am in favour of increasing the resources of Frontex, EASO and Europol to secure Europe's borders and stem the flow of refugees, but this report, with its demands to increase the EU budget due to the refugee crisis, goes too far, both in terms of the budget and in the areas in which these funds are to be channelled. I am voting against the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is only a technical adjustment to the EU budget without any impact on the expenditure.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 is a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, and that this results in a change in the allocation of contributions to the Union budget between member States. Two new budget lines will be established - support expenditure on trust funds managed by the Commission in the development and cooperation policy areas and "enlargement" policy areas, which will be accompanied by a memorandum; an amendment to the establishment plan of the BeREC Bureau, with no change in the total number of posts and in the budget. Member States' contributions to the budget compared to those foreseen in the original 2015 budget will be reduced by €2.26 billion as a result of revenue from traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies), which exceed the expected revenue by €1 133.5 million. Draft amending budget No 6/2015 has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and, on the revenue side, only changes in the allocation of contributions between Member States. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – PBR No 6/2015 involves a change in the distribution of their contributions to the Union budget among the Member States. I voted in favour because it has no consequences for expenditure in 2015 and only changes the distribution between Member States of their contributions to the European budget. National contributions to the budget on the basis of GNI can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion thanks to higher than expected revenue from traditional own resources.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this amending budget because it reduces France's contribution to the European Union by 700 million euros. One of the reasons for this is that the tariffs levied by the EU have yielded more than expected. As a result, France's contribution rises from 22.5 billion euros to 21.8 billion euros.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The project refers to a technical adjustment in revenue from the EU budget. It includes a review of traditional own resources forecasts, the basis of VAT and GNI, the budgeting of British corrections and their financing. This implies an amendment to Member States' own resources contributions to the EU budget.  From the Socialist Group we have been satisfied with the outcome of the report and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents a technical change which will ensure the proper functioning of different funds managed by the European Commission. The report seeks to adapt the changes in revenue from the European Union budget generated by the agreements with the United Kingdom in addition to the increase in own resources collected by the Commission to improve the allocation of certain items. These include different development cooperation funds through external action and funds for the operation of the Office of the Agency for European Electronic Communications Regulators. By bringing about a technical change to ensure the proper functioning of the funds, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 is a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, and that this results in a change in the allocation of contributions to the Union budget among the individual Member States. Two new budget lines will be established - support expenditure on trust funds managed by the Commission in the development and cooperation policy areas and "enlargement" policy areas, which will be accompanied by a memorandum; an amendment to the establishment plan of the BeREC Bureau, with no change in the total number of posts and in the budget. Member States' contributions to the budget compared to those foreseen in the original 2015 budget will be reduced by €2.26 billion as a result of revenue from traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies), which exceed the expected revenue by €1 133.5 million. Draft amending budget No 6/2015 has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and, on the revenue side, only causes a change in the allocation of contributions between Member States. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The report covers the creation of two new budget items of expenditure relating to support for foundations under the authority of the European Commission in the areas of development and cooperation policy and enlargement policy. It also proposes to amend the BEREC Office plan without changing the total number of posts or budgets. Compared to the 2015 budget, national contributions to the GNI budget can be reduced by €2.26 billion - due to customs revenues on imports from EU countries and higher-than-expected sugar levies.  These amendments have no impact on budget expenditure, only on revenues and relate to distribution changes related to contributions from only member states. I supported Eider Gardiazábal Rubial's report on the importance of a well-developed budget that allows EU policy to be implemented in practice.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcoming both my colleague's report and the European Commission's proposal for budgetary changes, to which this report is concerned through the council's view, I would like to note in particular one moment for me as a Member representing Latvia. Fully realizing that, on the basis of existing negotiations, the European Union is trying, on the principle of maintaining a relative balance, to establish and deploy various official bodies in the territories of the EU Member States, I am pleased that the choice of the Authority of european regulators for electronic communications fell to Riga some 6 years ago. Our capital is undoubtedly a great place where \u2012 by the way, as in Latvia as a whole \u2012, there is one of the best internet infrastructures in the world. Consequently, the placement of a structure relevant to electronic communications with us fills my heart with joy and hope that our country will continue to be chosen to deploy important institutions and also to organise a number of European and international events.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, "Own Resources, Union Trust Fund for External Action, Service of the Agency of European Regulators for Electronic Communications", because it is well documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support draft amending budget No 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 from 'own resources, Union trust funds for external action, Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications'. The draft budget in question corrects the distribution of their contributions to the European Union budget among the Member States. It also provides for the establishment of two new budget headings for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission in the areas of development and cooperation.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my agreement to the adoption of draft amending budget No 6/2015 aimed at making technical adjustments. Draft amending budget No 6/2015 has no impact on expenditure in the 2015 budget, but introduces the creation of two new budget items to support the Trust Funds managed by the Commission in the field of development and cooperation and enlargement and revises the accounting for the United Kingdom and its financing. With this adjustment, the expected revenue will see a change in the distribution of their contributions among the Member States.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible why Austria has to pay far higher contributions than roughly the same size and economically comparable countries. The proposed correction of the budget in favour of the United Kingdom entails a difference in treatment between the other Member States. That is why this report has no support.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This 2015 EU amending budget for 2015 plans to reduce member states' contributions by 2.26 billion euros this year compared to what was planned. This artifice is only possible thanks to a surplus of customs revenue and the large surplus of the 2014 budget (1.4 billion) postponed in 2015. This situation is aberrant when the Union has accumulated more than 20 billion unpaid under its various programmes. This European mismanagement jeopardizes many national and local actions that relied on European funds that never arrive. These surpluses are the result of the austerity imposed over the year by the Commission and the Council in the management of expenditure. Budget reports usually deplore this budgetary cavalry, while always approving it in the end. The Social Democrat rapporteur no longer makes any criticism of these errors. While the 2015 budget was supposed to reduce unpaid debts, a condition that Parliament had put in place to vote on it, it will be even more difficult by reducing budget revenues. I'm voting against this austere maneuver in disguise.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The draft summary budget No. 6 has the merit of reducing France's participation in the European Union budget by 1.3 billion euros. This is justified by higher-than-expected revenues from traditional own resources, such as tariffs and sugar premiums. I voted for it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it concerns an adjustment to the revenue side of the European Union’s budget which was soundly based on statistical developments that are in sync with the agreed distribution between Member States and has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I fully support Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker's decision to create a new EUR 1.8 billion emergency trust fund for Africa to resolve crises in the Sahel, Lake Chad, Horn of Africa and North Africa to facilitate the return and reintegration of migrants and to avoid further departures. We must, as Jean-Claude Juncker said, "bring stability back to life ... creating employment opportunities in local communities, and thus solving the root causes of instability, forced displacement and illegal migration."

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Draft amending budget No 6/2015 on own resources, Union trust funds for external action, Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, which mostly concerns a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU budget which is soundly based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed distribution between Member States. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council's draft focuses on the technical adjustment of the budget, which has become necessary as a result of the revision of the forecasts based on the most recent statistics, and is in order to transfer corrections to the budget corresponding to the agreed allocation between The United Kingdom. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This draft amending budget aims to reduce France's participation in the EU budget, so we support it. The latter will increase from 22.5 billion euros to 21.8 billion euros as a result of higher-than-expected revenues from traditional own resources (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector).

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 6/2015 (PBR) changes the forecasts for traditional own resources (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) and VAT and GNI bases, as well as the budgeting and financing of UK corrections, thereby reducing member states' contribution to the EU budget. Revenues from traditional own resources turned out to be EUR 1.1335 billion higher than expected. In addition, the 2014 budget surplus was included in the 2015 budget by PBR 3/2015. This leads to a reduction of 2.26 billion euros in the contribution of states to the EU budget, or for France about 0.7 billion euros. The PBR also creates two budgetary items relating to expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission, in the areas of "Development and Cooperation" and "Enlargement", and finally changes the staff of the Office of the Body of European Telecommunications Regulators. Considering that the reduction in France's contribution to the EU budget is substantial, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the draft amending budget on own resources, the Union's trust funds for external actions and the office of the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators. This revision of traditional own resource forecasts is the result of corrections made by the United Kingdom. It changes the distribution of contributions to the EU budget of Member States but has no impact on expenditure in 2015.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 6/2015 concerns a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, as well as the accounting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom and their financing. This revision therefore involves a change in the distribution of their contributions to the Union budget between the Member States and the creation of two new budget headings for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission in the areas of 'development and cooperation' and 'enlargement'. I voted in favour because this technical adjustment to the revenue side of the Union budget is strongly based on the most recent statistical developments and in line with the distribution agreed between the Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that consists of a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the relevant corrections concerning the United Kingdom, as well as their financing, thereby resulting in a change in the distribution between Member States of their contribution to the European Union budget.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report's content is to increase financial resources, including for electronic communications. Since I consider this measure unnecessary and regard it as just another means of inflating the Union budget, I voted against it.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budget as it would review the UK rebate. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of the collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. UKIP opposes any further money being handed to the EU and we also oppose any moves for the EU to raise funding, which can only be done through taxation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported amending Draft Budget Amendment No. 6/2015: Own resources, Union external action trust funds, the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications foreseeing the creation of two new budget items, amendments to the job plan of the BEREC office and a review of traditional own resources forecasts.  I believe that this draft needs to be amended because of the new obstacles and challenges facing the European Union so that they can better, more equal and fairer allocate funds to the Budget of the European Union.  Member States' own resources are one of the most important items that fill the revenue side of the budget and should be defined correctly and fairly so that the functioning of the administrative and institutional department of the European Union can take place in the best possible and more acceptable way for citizens. Other items of this amendment to the budget, such as union external action trust funds and the offices of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications contributing to the quality of the work of the European Union, should also not be ignored.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This draft amending budget 6/2015 (PBR) changes the forecasts for traditional own resources (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) and VAT and GNI bases, as well as budgeting and financing of UK corrections, thereby reducing Member States' contribution to the EU budget. Revenues from traditional own resources amounted to EUR 1.1335 billion more than expected. In addition, the 2014 budget surplus was included in the 2015 budget by PBR 3/2015. This leads to a reduction of 2.26 billion euros in the contribution of states to the EU budget, or, for France, about 0.7 billion euros. The PBR also creates two budgetary items relating to expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission, in the areas of "Development and Cooperation" and "Enlargement", and finally changes the staff of the Office of the Body of European Telecommunications Regulators. Considering that the reduction in France's contribution to the EU budget is substantial, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The proposed draft refers to the revision of the traditional own resources forecast and VAT and GNI contributions, which opens the possibility to reduce national contributions to the GNI budget by €2.26 billion compared to the original 2015 budget due to revenues from traditional own resources that are higher than expected, as well as the introduction of a surplus from 2014. Therefore, the draft on the revenue side regulates the amendment in the distribution of member states' contributions, which was previously agreed between Member States and, according to statistical indicators, adequate, without changing the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and not imposing an additional burden on Member States. In addition, the draft covers the creation of two new budget items for expenditure supporting trust funds under the European Commission's competence in the areas of development and cooperation policy and enlargement policy. It also provides for the regulation of the structure of jobs in the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications without amending its budget or the total number of posts in it.  Taking all of the above into account, the draft budget amendment seeks to regulate the revenue side of the budget more clearly and clearly, without withholding and imposing additional obligations, facilitating the burden on many Member States on the basis of VAT, GNI and traditional own resources, which is why I supported it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I agree with colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's draft report on the Council's position on draft budget amendment No 1009/2013. 6/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015: own resources, Union external action trust funds, Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.
