The draft budget amendment refers to revising the forecasts of traditional own resources and contributions based on VAT and GNI, creating two new budget items for expenditure supported by Trust Funds managed by the Commission in the field of development and cooperation policy, and amending the job plan in the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. In addition, it relates to the budget entry and funding of the relevant corrections for the United Kingdom in four years: 2011, 2012, 2013 and 2014.  The result will be an amendment to the distribution of contributions from own resources to the European Union budget between Member States. The technical adjustment of the revenue side of the budget is based on the latest statistics and is in line with the agreed allocation between Member States.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft EU amending budget No 6/ 2015. This correction concerns a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources, the creation of two new budget headings for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission in the areas of development and cooperation and "enlargement", a change in the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) and, above all, a slight change in the distribution of Member States' contributions to the Union budget. This draft budget provides for the amounts to be returned to the Member States. My vote in favour stems mainly from the fact that I believe that the balances of this budget are perfectly in line with the parameters of previous years. In particular, compared to the 2015 budget, national contributions to the budget on the basis of GNI will be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion and it will therefore be possible to repay more contributions to the Member States. This is particularly important for those states that are currently suffering the economic crisis more than others.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Since the Lisbon Treaty came into force in 2009, Parliament has been given the power to co-decision with the Council on the EU budget. Parliament must then vote on every change to the budget. In this context, I voted in favour of the draft amending budget 6/2015 on own resources, the Union's trust funds for external actions and the Office of the European Electronic Communications Regulatory Body. This text has no impact on expenditure in 2015 and only changes the distribution of Member States' contributions to the EU budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 6/2015 covers a review of the forecasts of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the corresponding corrections for the United Kingdom and its financing, resulting in the change in the allocation between Member States of contributions to the EU budget. It also includes the creation of two new budget lines for expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission in the policy areas 'Development and Cooperation' and 'Enlargement', as well as a change in the staff of the BEREC Office, without changes in the total number of posts or budget. However, considering that none of the elements of draft amending budget No 6/2015 have an impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and that their impact on the revenue side is limited to a change in the distribution of member states' contributions, and on the basis of the report of the Committee on Budgets, I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budget as it would review the UK rebate. The original revision had a higher estimation for the UK rebate, however this final budget has a much lower allocation. The cost of the collection of VAT which we pay to the EU was not counted towards the calculation, nor was the bill the UK ‘secretly’ paid to the EU of GBP 1.7 billion. UKIP opposes any further money being handed to the EU and we also oppose any moves for the EU to raise funding, which can only be done through taxation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The draft amending budget 6/2015 covers the revision of forecasts for traditional own resources and VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of the corresponding UK corrections and their funding, which have the effect of changing the distribution of their contributions to the EU budget among Member States. The text of the draft amending budget also provides for the opening of two new budget items for expenditure on trust funds managed by the Commission, in the areas of 'Development and Cooperation' and 'Expansion', as well as a change in the staffing table of the Office of the European Electronic Communications Regulators' Authority (which does not, however, change the total number of jobs or the Budget of the Office). This is therefore the vote on a technical adaptation of the EU budget's revenues, which is based on the most recent statistical developments and respects the agreed allocation between Member States and which has no impact on the expenditure in the 2015 budget.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to present a draft amending budget to the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, which covers a review of the provision of traditional own resources, a review of the bases of VAT and GNI, the budgeting of corrections for the United Kingdom and its financing.  To that extent, such corrections result in a change in the allocation between Member States of their contributions to the general budget of the European Union. Two new budget lines for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the European Commission are also created to offset management costs related to Union trust funds for external action. I would stress that none of the elements of this draft amending budget has an impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget, and it is certain that the effects on the revenue side are restricted to a change in the distribution between member states' contributions and i therefore voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as technical adjustments to draft amending budget No 6/2015 would result in a reduction in national contributions to the budget. Specifically, the Committee on Budgets has verified that revenues from traditional own resources, such as customs duties and sugar levies, have been higher than expected.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In connection with the review of traditional own-resource revenues financing the budget, there has been revenues greater than expected of EUR 2.6 billion (mainly sugar taxes and customs obligations). Corrections to the UK's mistakes in its calculation of its own domestic national income (and which meant that it contributed less than was appropriate) are also envisaged and that it will have to be compensated. The meaning of this is that almost all Member States will have to provide fewer resources as it stipulates that an increase in this income leads to a need for lesser input. That's why I voted for it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents a technical change which will ensure the proper functioning of different funds managed by the European Commission. The report seeks to adapt the changes in revenue from the European Union budget generated by the agreements with the United Kingdom in addition to the increase in own resources collected by the Commission to improve the allocation of certain items. These include different development cooperation funds through external action and funds for the operation of the Office of the Agency for European Electronic Communications Regulators. By bringing about a technical change to ensure the proper functioning of the funds, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6/2015 of the European Union, since this is a technical adjustment, with no impact on expenditure in 2015. It provides for a change in the distribution of own resources contributions (TOR, i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) among Member States and a revision of the forecasts for the bases of value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) in 2015.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal seeks to create new budget items that will add further spending which I would not support.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The commission's draft amending budget No 6/2015 brings with some innovations relating to the amendment of the forecasts concerning the basics of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI. The proposal also includes the introduction of two new budget lines with a note (p.m.) to support trust funds and to amend the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.  The draft amending budget also contains a technical change in revenue in the EU budget, which I believe has a solid basis in recent statistical developments and is in line with the agreed distribution across member states. The proposal does not affect expenditure in the 2015 budget with all its elements, and its impact on revenue has only led to a change in the distribution of contributions across Member States. As a result of the described, I supported draft amending budget No 6/2015.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the increase in funds to the emergency fund and to the capacity increase of the three relevant agencies.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report because draft budget modification No. 6/2015 refers to the revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources and contributions based on VAT and GNI and the entry and financing of the relevant corrections budget for the United Kingdom.  Furthermore, the draft budget amendment covers the creation of two new budget items for expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission, covering areas of development and cooperation policy and enlargement policies. It should be noted that compared to the original 2015 budget, national contributions to the budget can be reduced by €2.26 billion due to revenues from traditional own resources.  Therefore, in accordance with the procedure, the President of parliament should declare an amendment to budget No 1000/2013. 6/2015 adopted and forward this resolution to the Council, the Commission, the Court of Auditors and national parliaments.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 Draft budget amendment 06/2015 revises the forecasts of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies), the basis of VAT and GNI, and the budget planning of essential CORRECTIONS of the United Kingdom. It also includes two budget lines that should receive management costs charges related to EU external action funds as well as a complement to the job plan of the Office of the European Regulators' Electronic Communications Authority (BEREC).  I fully support this draft because it revises the current situation and improves the current situation and promises a more efficient budget allocation.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 As this is a measure of a technical nature that does not increase European Union expenditure, I supported the proposal.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this technical adjustment as it concerns the reallocation of resources resulting from the inflow of more own resources into the Union's funds in 2014, which means that Member States' contributions to the Union budget can be reduced.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Budget resources are not managed correctly.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending Budget No 6/2015 is a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU budget, following the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources (customs duties, levies and VAT), and GNI bases. This revision changes the distribution of the Member States’ contributions to the EU Budget. In practice, this adjustment reduces the national contribution, based on the GNI, by EUR 2.26 billion, as a result of higher than expected revenues from the traditional own resources. DAB 6/2015 also includes the creation of two budget lines intended to receive compensation for management costs related to the EU Trust Funds for external actions, as well as an amendment to the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC). Because DAB 6/2015 is a technical adjustment, it has no impact on the expenditure side of the EU 2015 budget. For this reason I voted in support of the report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 6/2015 for the 2015 financial year - Own Resources, Union Trust Fund for External Actions, Office of the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators. It should be noted that, compared to the original 2015 budget, national contributions to the GNI-based own resource budget can be reduced by EUR 2.26 billion on the basis that revenues from traditional own resources (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) are higher than expected, EUR 1,133.5 million, and that the 2014 surplus was budgeted in accordance with amending budget 3/2015; This technical adaptation of the EU budget's revenues is validly based on the most recent statistical developments and respects the agreed allocation between Member States.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This budget amendment is a technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU’s Budget. I supported its adoption, drawing on Parliament’s stance that it is soundly based on statistical data and in line with agreed distribution between Member States. Overall, Draft amending budget No 6/2015 will not affect the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and its impact on the revenue side is only a change in the distribution between Member States’ contributions. It concerns a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, covers the creation of two new budget items for support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission, and provides for a change to the establishment plan of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the amendment of the budget relating to the area of own resources, union external action trust funds and the European Regulators' Office for Electronic Communications, as I believe these amendments will bring the most benefits to Member States.  These amendments will lead to the allocation of Member States' contributions to the Budget of the European Union in the form of gross national income of own resources in such a way that those contributions can be greatly reduced due to an increase in revenues from traditional own resources which turned out to be higher than expected and due to the 2014 surplus. Given that these changes will have a positive impact on reducing the financial burden on Member States without affecting expenditure, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ u2012 Draft amending budget No 6/2015: own resources, Union External Action Trust Fund, I supported the Office of the Body of european regulators for electronic communications because the amending budget does not affect expenditure in the 2015 budget. The impact on revenues has led to a change in the distribution of contributions across Member States. It also includes the introduction of two new budget lines to support trust funds, which support the development of the economy, which is of added importance for both the Union and Slovenia as a whole.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In connection with the review of traditional own-resource revenues financing the budget, there has been revenues greater than expected of EUR 2.6 billion (mainly sugar taxes and customs obligations). Corrections to the UK's mistakes in its calculation of its own domestic national income (and which meant that it contributed less than was appropriate) are also envisaged and that it will have to be compensated. The meaning of this is that almost all Member States will have to provide fewer resources as it stipulates that an increase in this income leads to a need for lesser input. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In connection with the review of traditional own-resource revenues financing the budget, there has been revenues greater than expected of EUR 2.6 billion (mainly sugar taxes and customs obligations). Corrections to the UK's mistakes in its calculation of its own domestic national income (and which meant that it contributed less than was appropriate) are also envisaged and that it will have to be compensated. The meaning of this is that almost all Member States will have to provide fewer resources as it stipulates that an increase in this income leads to a need for lesser input. That's why I voted for it.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report concerning own resources, European Union trust funds for external action, the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications as it covers the creation of two new budget items, to support expenditure for trust funds managed by the Commission in the policy areas of ‘Development and Cooperation’ and ‘Enlargement’. This technical adjustment to the revenue side of the EU budget is soundly based on the latest statistical developments and in line with the agreed distribution between Member States. It is also important to note that Draft amending budget No 6/2015, in all its elements, has no impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget and that its impact on the revenue side is a change in the distribution between Member States’ contributions only.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The measures contained in this draft amending budget focus on corrections that have no cost implications for expenditure in 2015. It also includes the creation of two budget lines that seek compensation for management costs related to EU trust funds for external actions, as well as amendments relating to the STAFF plan of the ORECE Office. We are therefore talking about a matter which has not presented problems, having not had any amendments in the Committee on Budgets and having been approved by a large majority in that committee. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents a technical change which will ensure the proper functioning of different funds managed by the European Commission. The report seeks to adapt the changes in revenue from the European Union budget generated by the agreements with the United Kingdom in addition to the increase in own resources collected by the Commission to improve the allocation of certain items. These include different development cooperation funds through external action and funds for the operation of the Office of the Agency for European Electronic Communications Regulators. By bringing about a technical change to ensure the proper functioning of the funds, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 6/2015 covers a review of the forecasts of traditional own resources, VAT bases and GNI, as well as the budgeting of the corresponding corrections for the United Kingdom and its financing, which result in the change in the allocation between Member States of contributions to the EU budget. None of the elements of draft amending budget No 6/2015 have an impact on the expenditure side of the 2015 budget. Its impact on the revenue side is limited to a change in the distribution between member states' contributions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. It is incomprehensible why Austria has to pay far higher contributions than roughly the same size and economically comparable countries. The proposed correction of the budget in favour of the United Kingdom entails a difference in treatment between the other Member States. That is why this report has no support.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On draft amending budget No 6/2015, I voted in favour of the proposals tabled. The document provides an overview of member states' projections of contributions to the budget: from traditional own resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI), as well as an overview of some of the deductions available to selected countries. Such verification is carried out annually – amending budget No 6/2015 is routine. The amendments will reduce the overall level of Member States' contributions by EUR 1.4 billion compared to the EU budget adopted in 2015 and will also change member states' contributions. In view of last year's budget, both the total unlimited VAT base and the total capped VAT base have been reduced by 1.3%. Total GNI base increased by 0.4%.  In addition, the proposal foresees the introduction of two new budgetary institutions for trust funds managed by the committee and modifies the establishment plan at berec's office.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 6 covers a review of the forecasts of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of corrections for the United Kingdom and their financing, resulting in the change in the allocation between Member States of contributions to the EU budget. These national contributions can be reduced compared to the initial 2015 budget by EUR 2.26 billion, as traditional own resources revenues exceeded forecasts by EUR 1133.5 million, accumulating the 2014 surplus through amending budget 3. It also creates two new budget lines for expenditure to support trust funds managed by the European Commission in the policy areas "Development and Cooperation" and "Enlargement", both with a mention of pro memoria (e.m.), in addition to amending the staff of the Office of the Office of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, without changes in the total number of posts or budget. We voted for it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The amendment to the budget aims to mobilisation European funds in order to meet the urgent needs faced by migrants in the European Union. While I share the concern about the situation of these people and support the idea of more resources being provided to the Office for Refugee Support, I find it a huge hypocrisy that, while this will provide more resources for Frontex and Europol. I believe that the policies of the European Union and the action of its Frontex agency have much to do with the humanitarian emergency situation we are currently witnessing, and strengthening Europe's instruments of strength can in no way contribute to improving the situation. I abstained not to give my full support to the European Union's criminal policies on migration and asylum.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the humanitarian crisis facing refugees and the urgent need for funding I voted in favour of this report. The report caters for an extra EUR 401.3 million in EU funding to manage the refugee crisis; funding will go to provide immediate resources to respond to demands from the UNHCR and the World Food Programme and other relevant organisations. This will provide immediate support to refugees.  The funding will also go towards helping with the coastguard effort to rescue floundering vessels and reduce ocean fatalities. The passing of this report and increased funding is the right step in tackling the EU’s incapacity to deal with the current refugee crisis in a more humane, efficient and effective way. That includes enhancing solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument, as this makes it possible to financially support the measures decided by the Council and the European Council to tackle the refugee crisis.  In Greece last summer we experienced the inability of the state and European mechanism to deal with this unprecedented refugee crisis, which is not expected to be contained immediately.  As the money originally budgeted for refugee support actions proved insufficient, it was considered necessary to use the flexibility instrument to provide additional money.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text will authorize the mobilization of 66.1 million euros. That sum will be drawn from the flexibility instrument, that is, the financing mechanism available for unforeseen expenses in the European Union. In this case, this extension will be used to finance the recent immigration measures taken by the European Council with the support of the Commission.  This sum of 66.1 million euros will be in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros already redeployed for this purpose. So of course I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the European Union is addressing the migration issue in the right way, and therefore I cannot support a proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument – spending taxpayers’ money – for this purpose.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to allocate an additional EUR 66.1 million to the European Union. Eur 100 million to finance measures to manage the refugee and migration crisis. This support can be expected both from the flow of migrants in the eu countries most affected and by third countries that have sheltered Syrian refugees, as well as eu agencies involved in crisis management. It is also important to review the frames of the EU budget for 2014-2020 in order to respond more flexibly to emerging crises.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. We have been asked to vote for the mobilization of an additional EUR 66.1 million to finance EU immigration measures: this is in addition to the 330.7 million of a new ad hoc fund and the 70.6 million that have been "re-deployed". Immigrationist madness against the peoples of Europe. I obviously voted against this report by Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial, an obscure Spanish socialist who has received the outspoken and overwhelming support of her EPP colleagues. In Paris as in Brussels, the UMPS leads us into the wall.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The flexibility instrument is used to finance certain expenditures that could not be met within the ceilings available in the multi-year financial framework. In order to finance support for measures to manage the refugee crisis, the Commission proposes to mobilise this instrument to the tune of EUR 66.1 million above the spending ceiling under Security and Citizenship (Rub 3). Given the urgency and seriousness of the consequences of the migration crisis, it is imperative to provide adequate financial support to implement the necessary measures. I have therefore spoken in favour of this initiative.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution to support the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in the amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations as the 2015 deadline for heading 3 does not allow adequate funding of the Union's important and urgent political priorities, such as the refugee crisis.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 11/2013 of 2 December 2013 setting out the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020 provides for the possibility of mobilising the flexibility instrument to enable the financing of precisely identified expenditures that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more of the headings of the multi-year financial framework. Payment appropriations for the proposed mobilization of the flexibility instrument amount to EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017 to finance support for measures to manage the refugee crisis. This is in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros redeployed. So of course I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this measure because, although unfortunately only in part, it finances direct and targeted interventions in the countries from which migration flows start.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 66.1 million of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate action to respond to refugee crises. These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it decided by Parliament, together with the Council of the European Union, to support the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for urgent budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. The general rules of the EU budget allow the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument up to a maximum of EUR 471 million. In order to ensure the possibility of financing clearly identified additional, unforeseen expenditure in a given area which could not be financed within the ceilings set for one or more other headings, eur 100 million (in 2011 prices) After examining all options for reallocating appropriations under the ceiling for the heading 'Security and citizenship', the main EU institutions decided that it was necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the financing provided for in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million. Eur 100 million to finance measures in the field of migration. This Decision also stipulates that eur 52.9 million will be mobilised from the Flexibility Instrument for migration in 2016. Eur 13.2 million in payment appropriations and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. In 2005, the Commission adopted a request for a

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - We have voted practically unanimously on an additional €66 million, which we use through the Flexibility Instrument to address the consequences of the refugee crisis. A little, all too little, I can argue for that sum, given the dimensions we see on the ground today. This conclusion, which I have, of course, supported, because this 66 million are also much better than nothing, also shows this rigidity, the inflexibility of the entire European Union to a rapidly changing situation. Maybe when we started talking about it, that sum wasn't that little money. But we already know today that we will need much, much more to rehabilitate and manage the migration crisis. I would like us to be able to adopt solutions in the European Parliament as soon as possible, which will have mitigating effects as early as tomorrow, and which will give the European future hope and faith that we can solve every problem, even as much as this, through cooperation and in the European spirit.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against mobilising EUR 66.1 billion from the Flexibility Instrument (a financing mechanism available for unforeseen expenses that exceed the EU budget). This mobilization of 66.1 billion euros is done with the aim of financing the immigration measures decided by the European Council.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the humanitarian crisis facing refugees and the urgent need for funding I voted in favour of this report. The report caters for an extra EUR 401.3 million in EU funding to manage the refugee crisis; funding will go to provide immediate resources to respond to demands from the UNHCR and the World Food Programme and other relevant organisations. This will provide immediate support to refugees.  The funding will also go towards helping with the coastguard effort to rescue floundering vessels and reduce ocean fatalities. The passing of this report and increased funding is the right step in tackling the EU’s incapacity to deal with the current refugee crisis in a more humane, efficient and effective way. That includes enhancing solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I very much welcome the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to promote immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. It is important for the Union to work to deal with this emergency which concerns us all closely.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed mobilising the flexibility instrument beyond the ceilings set out in the multi-year financial framework for an amount of 66.1 million in commitments to finance the reception of illegal migrants. It also endorses the Council's proposal to allocate EUR 52.9 million for 2016 and EUR 13.2 million for 2017 in payment credits.  It is absolutely scandalous to see European technocrats squandering taxpayers' money on illegal migrants at a time when the EU Member States are mostly experiencing a GDP growth rate of close to 0%, a structurally high unemployment rate and an increasing poverty rate. This migration submersion, which the Commission is calling for to meet the needs of large firms, will increase the deficit in our social accounts and put additional pressure on the labour market to the detriment of the lowest-skilled unemployed.  I therefore voted against this unacceptable text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget envisages the management of the refugee crisis by immediately adopting budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. As I have argued so far, I believe that solidarity must be the principle that will prevail in finding solutions to the migrant crisis, and it is necessary to show solidarity and by taking budgetary measures to address this phenomenon, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this project. The amending draft budget mobilises the Flexibility Instrument to make available EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations for measures to manage the migrant crisis for the financial year 2015, and for 2016 the Flexibility Instrument will allocate related payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. The mobilisation of this instrument therefore highlights once again the urgent need for the Union budget to be more flexible, precisely in order to be able to manage crisis situations in the spirit and in line with the values promoted by the Union.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The fund will deal with the growing needs for resilience and stabilisation in Syria's neighbours, in particular Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey, Iraq and Egypt, and also within Syria itself.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The humanitarian crisis caused by the massive influx of refugees into the European Union requires rapid action. In this report, the European Parliament accepts the Council's decision to mobilise the flexibility instrument to help manage the refugee crisis. The flexibility instrument corresponds to a provision in the European budget to unlock funds in the event of an emergency. It is undeniable that the mobilization of this instrument is justified and necessary. I voted in favour of this report. I also welcome the willingness of the European institutions to act to manage this crisis.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today decided to vote in favour of this proposal because it is necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument for commitment appropriations in order to supplement the funding provided for in the general budget of the European Union, for the 2015 financial year, of €66.1 million in commitment appropriations, amounting to €52.9 million in 2016 and €13.2 million in 2017, to fund measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. It should be noted, however, that the mobilisation of this instrument once again reveals the absolute need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union budget. Council Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013 establishes the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, authorising the use of the flexibility instrument to finance expenditure that would not find any other cover within the available ceilings of one or more headings of the multiannual financial framework. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the humanitarian crisis facing refugees and the urgent need for funding I voted in favour of this report. The report caters for an extra EUR 401.3 million in EU funding to manage the refugee crisis; funding will go to provide immediate resources to respond to demands from the UNHCR and the World Food Programme and other relevant organisations. This will provide immediate support to refugees.  The funding will also go towards helping with the coastguard effort to rescue floundering vessels and reduce ocean fatalities. The passing of this report and increased funding is the right step in tackling the EU’s incapacity to deal with the current refugee crisis in a more humane, efficient and effective way. That includes enhancing solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Sufficient funds need to be provided to the relevant Member States in order to deal effectively with the migration crisis that Europe is currently facing. I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the need to redeploy and mobilise enough funds to address this emergency situation currently facing the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The tragedy of immigration has shocked Europe in recent months and we have tried to find ready and immediate responses to deal with this emergency. I therefore voted in favour of the call for a special instrument, provided for in the Multiannual Financial Framework, to be mobilised in support of budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. I hope that in this way it will be possible to allow the financing of measures aimed at managing the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, because it aims to mobilise EUR 66.1 million which would be drawn from the flexibility instrument and would benefit the immigration measures decided by the European Council.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The consolidated view is reiterated that without prejudice to the possibility of mobilising payment appropriations for specific budget lines using the flexibility instrument, without prior mobilisations in commitments, payments resulting from commitments, which had been mobilised at an earlier stage using the flexibility instrument, can only be calculated above the ceilings.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. The total amount was EUR 66.1 million, of which EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it is appropriate to make it possible to mobilise new funds in support of the problem of migration. The problem is clear to everyone: thousands and thousands of people are trying to enter Europe. At last, the Council is able to give the green light to ensure that the problem is tackled by all countries together, rather than individually by landing countries, and a great deal of resources are needed for this. It is almost an act that we had to vote in favour of this proposal, and I have certainly not backed down.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the multiple measures put forward by the Commission to deal with the refugee crisis, it was necessary to make its budgetary provision. As the funds are needed as soon as possible, this Parliament has used the urgent procedure, approving this amendment to the budget in record time. A €100 million boost is approved for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, a total increase of 120 staff for Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol, as well as a contribution of EUR 300 million to the Syrian Support Fund.  These measures are not sufficient, should be framed in the most comprehensive strategy for migration. On the other hand, it also fits into a strategy of using unused resources and anticipating funds, necessarily with impacts on the multiannual financial framework. The Council must therefore not only deliver on the promises of extra-budget financial contributions to deal with this crisis, but also - in the short way - compensate for this anticipation of funds, avoiding the use of today and then to miss tomorrow.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I welcome the immediate measures to implement the decisions of the EU summit on the refugee crisis of 23 September. We urgently need to provide our municipalities with the necessary support and resources to enable them to make effective progress in local management. The same applies to our neighbouring countries. However, I would like to stress that there are other measures to be taken in addition to the financial ones: we must fight together the causes of flight! The current situation requires a special effort, and this task will occupy us for years to come. I therefore also see the need to revise the budget for the coming years so that we have funds at our disposal in the long term.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the mobilisation of over EUR 66 million to support an EU—wide migration/refugee policy. We oppose the EU taking more powers on migration and asylum and spending more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to manage the migration crisis and the reception of refugees, it is essential to make available adequate and targeted economic resources, different from those currently existing to support reception centres, local agencies and police forces carrying out checks at the external borders. In this respect, provision is made for the strengthening of emergency assistance provided by the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund of the Internal Security Fund.  I voted in favour of this report mainly because it aims to increase the economic resources to be used in the management of the current migration crisis. It should be borne in hand that the exponential increase in the number of migrants and asylum seekers was not foreseeable at the time of the approval of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 and that, given the engraving and spread of the phenomenon in the long term, it is necessary to carry out a review of the annual budgetary procedure and multiannual funding.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because it is an instrument aimed at financing certain measures to deal with the refugee crisis. The European Commission, having examined all possibilities for reallooted appropriations under the heading 'Security and citizenship' (heading 3), proposes mobilising EUR 66.1 million under the flexibility instrument above the expenditure ceiling for this heading. Payment appropriations corresponding to the proposed mobilisation of the flexibility instrument amount to EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The EUR 66.1 million from the use of the Flexibility Instrument should be used to finance measures to address the refugee crisis, Parliament has decided. In connection with the realloding of commitment appropriations within Chapter 3 proposed in draft araking budget 7/2015, it has become necessary to make use of the Flexibility Instrument. The European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument. In addition to the MED ceiling, €66.1 million will be allocated to the eu budget for 2015 to address the refugee and migration crisis. In line with the European People's Party, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Flexibility Instrument is being mobilised in order to finance measures in connection with managing the refugee crisis, and was proposed together with the draft amending budget, which I also voted for in this plenary session. The mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument partially covers the amount requested in the amending budget (EUR 66.1 million out of EUR 401.3 million). As this immediate injection helps EU Member States tackling the crisis, while equipping our agencies better, I have supported it with my vote.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument above the ceilings set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to supplement the financing provided for in the general budget of the Union for the 2015 financial year for measures to manage the refugee and migration crisis with EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations is a solution for financing the refugee crisis management measures.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument planned within the multi-year financial framework and allowing a change in the 2015 budget to mobilise an additional EUR 401.3 million to deal with the refugee crisis. These funds will be allocated to EU countries affected by these exceptional migration flows, to third countries hosting the most Syrian refugees and to the three European agencies in charge of migrant management. The rapporteur also proposes to undertake a seven-year review of the EU budgetary framework, in order to provide for additional long-term funds. Considering that this report aims to provide the necessary means to implement the recent decisions of the European Union in response to the migration crisis, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The emergency situation generated by the migration crisis of recent months requires an upward revision of EU spending. I supported the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European migration agenda. It is essential to support and allocate the necessary funds for the various measures to manage the refugee crisis.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In connection with the transfer of commitment appropriations within Chapter 3 proposed in draft ara up to Budget No 7/2015, it has become necessary to make use of the Flexibility Instrument. The European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument because, in addition to the MNT ceiling, eur 66.1 million of commitment appropriations will be used to increase the resources in its 2015 EU budget in the area of managing the refugee and migration crisis. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I am against the quota redistribution of refugees and the call of these people refugees at all, I supported the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument because it was created precisely to be used in such special cases and, if necessary, to react quickly. Just as quota redistribution is not a lasting solution to the issue, so will the current mobilised funds cover only part of the costs that await us. The real financial burden will fall on the Member States themselves and their budgets, because the integration process of these people will be very long, we will have to pay for their training for years and we will pay huge amounts for social benefits.  Who's going to cover these expenses? The amount that the EU will provide for each redistribented refugee is symbolic of the costs we will all have to pay. Poor Bulgaria cannot support illegal immigrants and refugees.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because we are calling for the strengthening of the Asylum and Integration Funds for illegal immigrants. The solution proposed to manage the situation is purely temporary.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument by an amount higher than the ceilings to complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 with an additional EUR 66.1 million in authorisation appropriations to finance measures to manage the refugee and migration crisis, a proposal which deserves my approval, as well as the corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 According to Frontex, more than 710 000 migrants crossed the EU's borders between the beginning of the year and the end of September, two and a half times as many as last year, when 282 000 migrants crossed the Union's external borders. A total of 170,000 were recorded in September alone, down slightly from 190,000 in August. It is indisputable that the European Union will have to release additional resources to cope with the migration crisis in Europe. The European Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument beyond the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework in order to complement the appropriations in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 with EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures related to the management of the refugee and migration crisis.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is asked to approve the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument with corresponding payment appropriations for the 2015 financial year to an amount of 66.1 million, to 52.9 million in 2016 and to 13.2 million in 2017 to finance some measures in the field of migration. As everyone knows, we are firmly opposed to this immigration policy, which we consider to be harmful and unholy, but, in particular, these budget increases, including more aid on the ground, especially on the border with Syria, will receive our vote in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, because it calls for the strengthening of the Asylum and Integration Funds for illegal immigrants. The solution proposed to manage the situation is purely temporary.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Flexibility Instrument has been mobilised to finance support for measures for managing the refugee crisis, and was proposed together with Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 7/2015. The mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument partially covers the amount requested in DAB No 7/2015 (EUR 66.1 million out of EUR 401.3 million; in commitment appropriations) This mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriation beyond the annual ceiling of Heading 3 (Security and citizenship) under the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020. The payment appropriations corresponding to the proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument are EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 Council Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013, from 2 December 2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 to use the Flexibility Instrument with a view to financing clearly defined expenditures that cannot be financed within the ceiling available under one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Having examined all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations and exhausted any unssigned margins under the heading of Security and Citizenship expenditure (heading 3), the Commission proposes to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument by an amount of EUR 66.1 million above the maximum limit under heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  The payment appropriations for the proposal for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amount to EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017 and are intended to finance support for measures to manage the refugee crisis, which is why, as rapporteur, I have proposed to the European Parliament the processing with the utmost urgency to allow the release of funds as soon as possible.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is very pleased that the vote has been positive, allowing the flexibility instrument to be mobilised within the annual ceiling. The mobilisation of these instruments has complemented funding in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 by EUR 66.1 million. This will make it possible to finance precisely defined expenditure that could not be covered by the ceilings. This amount will be used to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis, which, above all, shows the european institutions' agreement to act in this area. The vast majority of Parliamentarians voted in favour of this solution – this reflects the importance of the situation and the conviction of the importance of time here.  It is clear that the migration crisis will be a problem for the whole of Europe for a few, maybe even a dozen years to come. The decisions taken today by Parliament show our long-term preparation for the challenges we face.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have agreed to the use of the flexibility instrument. At a time of increasing refugee immigration to Europe, it is crucial that the European Union remains responsive and shows that it can respond adequately to an ever-changing situation. Since it is not possible to reallocate funds due to certain ceilings of the individual budget lines, some of the money from the flexibility instrument must be used to provide financial support. The use of this instrument is expected to amount to EUR 66.1 million in 2015 and eur 52.9 million in 2016. This money will go to security and European citizenship in order to play a part in dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this and this should be interpreted in conjunction with the following draft amending budget (No 7/2015). The Flexibility Instrument allows the redistribution of resources that, in this case, address the issue of the refugee crisis.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management because it allows the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for an amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations. Furthermore, I agree to the proposed allocation of the corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. The mobilisation of this instrument, as provided for in Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, shows, once more, the crucial need for the European Union budget to be more flexible.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In connection with the transfer of commitment appropriations within Chapter 3 proposed in draft ara up to budget no. 7/2015, it has become necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument. The European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument because, in addition to the MNT ceiling, eur 66.1 million of commitment appropriations will be used to increase the resources in the EU budget for 2015 to address the refugee and migration crises. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this and this should be interpreted in conjunction with the following draft amending budget (No 7/2015). The Flexibility Instrument allows the redistribution of resources that, in this case, address the issue of the refugee crisis.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I salute the decision of Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. However, it is of great importance that the European Union’s budget becomes more flexible in order to be able to mobilise when needed.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the flexibility instrument for urgent budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration in accordance with point 12. Interinstitutional agreement on budgetary discipline, cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as this allows for the financing of the European Union's extremely important and urgent political priority.  The mobilisation of €66.1 million will certainly contribute to alleviation of the refugee and migration crisis, although of course these funds are insufficient. However, I consider that the crisis in question has proven once again that it is essential to ensure flexibility in the Union budget in order to be able to counter such crises and circumstances that directly affect its stability and functioning, and I therefore support this proposal.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text mobilises the sum of 66.1 million euros drawn from the flexibility instrument, or in unforeseen expenditures of the European Union, in order to finance the immigration measures of the European Council.  This sum of 66.1 million euros will be in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros redeployed. All supported by national taxpayers. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against the mobilisation of over 66 million euro to support an EU wide migration /refugee policy. The EU wants to have more powers on migration and asylum and wants to spend more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on mobilising the flexibility instrument under the European migration agenda. This instrument will mobilise an additional EUR 66 million to support European migration policy. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The current refugee crisis poses major difficulties for the budgets of the countries concerned; however, I think it is wrong to introduce flexibility measures in this context, thereby weakening the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it aims to reinforce the EU’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis, allowing swift implementation on the ground.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 allows for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance specific expenditure that could not be incurred within the ceiling of one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. In accordance with Article 11 of Council Regulation No 1311/2013 and Point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management, the Commission proposes to use the flexibility instrument after examining all the possibilities of redeployment within the expenditure heading 'Security and Citizenship' (heading 3) and after exhausting the remaining margin. The mobilisation relates to an amount of EUR 66.1 million, which exceeds the ceiling of Heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the aim of providing financial support for measures to deal with the refugee crisis. Payments corresponding to this proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amount to €52.9 million in 2016 and €13.2 million in 2017. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a combination of an exceptional and urgent procedure to enable a transfer to mobilise the Emergency Aid Reserve to enable transfer and to help refugees and migrants immediately. The Commission proposed the transfer of EUR 175 million, to provide immediate humanitarian aid. Nevertheless, the Commission also proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument in 2015. I voted in favour of this report, since I believe that the multiannual financial framework needed to be revised in order to reply to the migration crisis. By voting yes, I support the revision and an immediate reply to the migration crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The urgent mobilisation of the flexibility instrument is necessary in order to have an additional EUR 401.3 million for the management of the immigration emergency. As a Sicilian, I am fully aware of the situation of migrants and I believe it is necessary to act promptly in order to manage this unprecedented flow, while ensuring reception, in full compliance with the rules, and the safety of our citizens. Today's proposal, given the emergency conditions, will make it possible to allocate the necessary resources to deal with an unprecedented number of refugees and migrants arriving on the south and east borders of the European continent.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this decision to draw more than 66 million euros from the "flexibility instrument" fund, because it is about allocating them to the reception of migrants.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Council Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013, from 2 December 2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 to use the Flexibility Instrument with a view to financing clearly defined expenditures that cannot be financed within the ceiling available under one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  Having examined all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations and exhausted any unssigned margins under the heading of Security and Citizenship expenditure (heading 3), the Commission proposes to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument by an amount of EUR 66.1 million above the maximum limit under heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  The mobilisation aims to finance support for measures to manage the refugee crisis. Also in this case the report has been dealt with with the utmost urgency to allow the funds to be released as soon as possible. In full accordance with the measure and urgency, I voted in favour of it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The amendment to the budget aims to mobilisation European funds in order to meet the urgent needs faced by migrants in the European Union. While I share the concern about the situation of these people and support the idea of more resources being provided to the Office for Refugee Support, I find it a huge hypocrisy that, while this will provide more resources for Frontex and Europol. I believe that the policies of the European Union and the action of its Frontex agency have much to do with the humanitarian emergency situation we are currently witnessing, and strengthening Europe's instruments of strength can in no way contribute to improving the situation. I abstained not to give my full support to the European Union's criminal policies on migration and asylum.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for Emergency Fiscal Action under the European Agenda on Migration. Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 allows for the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance specific expenditure that could not be incurred within the ceiling of one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. In accordance with Article 11 of Council Regulation No 1311/2013 and Point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management, the Commission proposes to use the flexibility instrument after examining all the possibilities of redeployment within the expenditure heading 'Security and Citizenship' (heading 3) and after exhausting the remaining margin. The mobilisation relates to an amount of EUR 66.1 million, which exceeds the ceiling of Heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the aim of providing financial support for measures to deal with the refugee crisis. Payments corresponding to this proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amount to €52.9 million in 2016 and €13.2 million in 2017. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Council Regulation No 2012 1311/2013 as of 2 December 2013, a multiannual financial framework is being set and flexibility instruments proposed to be mobilised. The mobilisation relates to €66.1 million to finance migration measures. €52.9 million is earmarked for 2016 and €13.2 million for 2017. I support this report by MP Eider Gardiazábal Rubial because Croatia is directly faced with the arrival of immigrants who have entered the country since the beginning of the crisis in mid-September to today, and it is not certain until the crisis could last. It is therefore crucial that the Union budget is more flexible in order to respond in a timely manner to the security challenges faced by the entire European Union since April 2015, when the first large wave of refugees headed for Europe.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The approval of the European Union's annual budget is a very complex political and bureaucratic process, so that the allocation of financial resources to activities that were not included in this budget or were, but with less resources, is rather difficult to achieve. That is why there is also the Flexibility Instrument. In particular, with regard to the proposal under this report to increase the General Budget of the Union for 2016 and 2017 from the resources of the Flexibility Instrument, which are intended to be used to finance measures to finance measures to deal with the refugee and migration crisis management, I consider this to be fully motivated and logical. Given the serious ity of the crisis Europe now needs to fight, the allocation of additional funds and their subsequent effective use to overcome this crisis is absolutely necessary.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the financial rules to support measures in the context of the refugee crisis, the Flexibility Instrument of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 is mobilised for a total amount of EUR 66.1 million. These are commitment appropriations, of which EUR 52.9 million is earmarked for 2016 and EUR 13.2 million for 2017.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for direct budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management because I agree with the proposed allocation of the corresponding payment appropriations EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017 despite the fact that these are crumbs that do not solve the migration problem. That is why we are demanding the abolition of Dublin III here and now.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument, within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration and Cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, for commitment appropriations to supplement the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million, in order to finance measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. The mobilisation of this instrument indicates the urgent need to ensure greater flexibility for the European Union budget.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed the issue of an immediate increase in budget appropriations for the Migration Agency. I recognise that the refugee crisis is a phenomenon for which urgent solutions must be found. The report contains some measures with which I agree, it is necessary to find funding for stabilising the countries of origin of refugees and supporting transit countries, as well as for the expansion of so-called hotspots. I also agree with the increase in frontex or Europol staff. At the same time, however, I have a fundamental problem with the fact that, at a time of economic crisis, when unemployment is rising and many people are below the poverty line and when strict austerity measures are announced, suddenly there is such huge sums of money in the EU budget to finance projects linked to the refugee wave. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. In view of the scale of relocations and the financial commitment that such a situation requires, it is easy to understand the need to integrate the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, by a sum of EUR 66.1 million, with a view to better management of the refugee crisis.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In view of the exorbitant amounts of money already required by the Union and the Member States to deal with the refugee crisis, the report does not agree that a further EUR 66.1 million, which has not yet been budgeted, will be used for action in the Migration Agenda through a flexibility instrument. On the contrary, the report shows that the Union and its Member States are also reaching their financial limits as a result of this crisis. In addition, the report leaves open the question of what exactly the funds are to be used for. I cannot support such a non-transparent report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report endorses various budgetary tinkering to fund the immigration measures contained in the 7th amending budget. Under the 'flexibility instrument', the Commission will be allowed to exceed the ceiling of appropriation commitments previously set on the programmes concerned. But to cover the corresponding payments, it is only proposed to reallocate existing credits in 2016 and 2017. This is already to anticipate and accept that emergency actions initiated in 2015 will only be paid in two years. This is likely to greatly reduce the effectiveness of these actions, which may not be completed at a time when we are in the midst of a migrant crisis. It will also exacerbate the shortage of payment credits available to pay for programmes already decided and to pay off the mountain of unpaid debts accumulated by the EU. I am opposed to these budgetary remedies which will not solve any of the urgent problems and will further exacerbate the EU's budgetary difficulties in the medium term. But, given the object and malice of the media observers, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text mobilises the sum of 66.1 million euros drawn from the flexibility instrument, or in unforeseen expenditures on the European Union, in order to finance the immigration measures of the European Council.  This sum of 66.1 million euros will be in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros redeployed. All supported by national taxpayers. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which supports the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument as it is a positive step towards solidarity between Member Steps in tackling the migration crisis. The resolution also highlights the need for the European Union budget to be more flexible to adequately handle the various unforeseen challenges that arise.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration because it is urgent and very important to provide financial support for measures for managing the refugee crisis. The mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations beyond the annual ceiling of Heading 3 (Security and citizenship) under the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020. The payment appropriations corresponding to the proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument are EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to be taken under the European Agenda on Migration. The aim of the proposal is to provide eur 66.1 million in commitment appropriations in addition to the MTM ceiling to finance measures to address the refugee and migration crises in the General Budget of the European Union for 2015. The Report of the Committee on Budgets notes that the ceiling for the relevant commitment appropriations for the 2015 budget does not allow for satisfactory funding of important and urgent EU priorities, and recommends that Parliament agree with this use of the Flexibility Instrument. I voted in favour of the motion accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. As part of the immigration measures decided by the European Council, it is proposed to increase by 66.1 million euros the 330.7 million euros of new funds and the 70.6 million euros already deployed for the reception of refugees. This increase will come from the Flexibility Instrument, which is a funding mechanism available for unforeseen expenses that exceed the EU budget. Consistent with our opposition to the suicidal decisions of the European institutions to take in all migrants who come to our borders, we categorically reject the use of this instrument for these purposes.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Following the European Council on 23 September 2015, which detailed the measures envisaged by the EU to deal with migration submersion, the Committee on Budgets decided to draw EUR 66.1 million from the Flexibility Instrument (which is a funding mechanism available for unforeseen expenses that exceed the EU budget) in order to finance the immigration measures decided by the European Council. This is in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros redeployed. This proposal is both politically outrageous, as it aims to have the taxpayer of European countries finance the immigrationist delusions of their European leaders, but also because this budget increase violates the obligation of the members of the Council to obtain unanimity in order to change the multi-year financial framework. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the use of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European migration agenda. This text, which accompanies the draft amending budget No. 7/2015, is purely accounting and approves the Commission's proposal to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2015 for an amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations. The corresponding payment credits amounted to 52.9 million euros in 2016 and 13.2 million in 2017. The demand for payments for 2015 related to this report and the draft amending budget remains unchanged and will be reflected in the 2016 budget.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report because, having examined all the possibilities for reassigning commitment appropriations under heading 3, it is necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument, as proposed by the Commission, in order to supplement the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million to support measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. On this occasion, we would also like to reiterate that the mobilisation of this instrument, in accordance with Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, once again indicates the absolute need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union budget.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
