text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed mobilising the flexibility instrument to supplement the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. The mobilisation of this instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration once again indicates the need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union budget. I therefore voted in favour.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcome to the report. The union's credibility is an indicator of its ability to assess and deal with the situation as a global actor, not only at the level of fine words, but also through actions, and to respond to challenges. Today's flood of migration and the related problems that need to be re-established are without precedent in the history of the European Union. The management of the situation will not be delayed. I am therefore pleased that serious EU funds, including EUR 100 million, will be redirected to crisis management to help the most burdened Member States; We will increase the budgets of institutions involved in the management of the situation, such as Frontex, the External Action Service and Europol, by EUR 1.3 million, and commit an additional EUR 300 million to help third countries involved in dealing with the conflict in Syria.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will allow adequate financing of important and urgent political priorities of the European Union, particularly immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – As a result of the humanitarian crisis facing refugees and the urgent need for funding I voted in favour of this report. The report caters for an extra EUR 401.3 million in EU funding to manage the refugee crisis, funding will go to provide immediate resources to respond to demands from the UNHCR and the World Food Programme and other relevant organisations. This will provide immediate support to refugees.  The funding will also go towards helping with the coastguard effort to rescue floundering vessels and reduce ocean fatalities. The passing of this report and increased funding is the right step in tackling the EU’s incapacity to deal with the current refugee crisis in a more humane, efficient and effective way. That includes enhancing solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report aims to free up financial resources for the European Agenda for Integration. I voted against because I believe that the European agenda for migration is totally unsuitable to offer solutions in the face of the current wave of refugees.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The report proposes to approve the Commission's decision to take emergency financial measures to allow for an over-the-ceiling appropriations limit set for the various European programmes. This flexibility instrument would enable the release of EUR 66.1 million for this year and the next two to help Member States, particularly Greece and Italy, carry out the policy of relocating migrants to the rest of the EU. As relocation plans have already begun, the legitimacy of this exceptional measure is not to be questioned. Given the scale of Europe's migration crisis management policy, financial support must be up to scratch. I therefore support this report.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. I agree both with the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to the amount of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations, and with the proposed allocation of corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.  I am convinced that the mobilisation of this instrument once again indicates the absolute need to ensure greater flexibility in the Union's budget. Finally, I believe it is necessary to emphasise my established position that payments arising from commitments previously mobilised through the flexibility instrument can only be entered in the budget beyond the limits of the ceilings.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the mobilisation of over EUR 66 million to support an EU-wide migration/refugee policy. We oppose the EU taking more powers on migration and asylum and spending more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Coming from a constituency like that of southern Italy, I am well aware of the significance of the migration emergency and the enormous efforts required of the populations, regions and host states. I welcome the rapporteur's work and am convinced that the issue of immigration cannot be dealt with only from an economic point of view. We are experiencing a human tragedy and I am convinced that we are voting positively for this report and continue to call for effective and immediate measures.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Immigration and terrorism are among the biggest challenges facing the EU for Europeans. This was also pointed to very recent Eurobarometer data, which showed that concerns about these topics increased by a third compared to last year.   Our citizens give us a clear sign that we need to take timely and concrete measures to tackle the refugee crisis. The dedication of additional funds of EUR 401.3 million is a clear step in the right direction and I was happy to support the report. I believe that this financial support should be followed by long-term budgetary measures to address the problem, which we may need to review and revise the seven-year EU budgetary framework.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I supported the measure because we need to be humane with those who are really in need and in solidarity with the countries that are more affected. The measure of the use of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures will provide EUR 66.1 million to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis from the EU budget.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of flexibility instruments for urgent budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration of €66.1 million. I believe this is necessary precisely because of the urgency of the refugee crisis situation and for the purpose of resolving it. The funds related to the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument amount to EUR 52.9 million for 2016 and €13.2 million for 2017. Europe is affected by the current migration crisis and unless it takes active action to mitigate it, there will be large-scale consequences.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. After the European Council on 23 September 2015, which detailed the measures envisaged by the EU to deal with migration submersion, the Committee on Budgets decided to draw EUR 66.1 million from the Flexibility Instrument (which is a financing mechanism available for unforeseen expenses that exceed the EU budget) in order to finance the immigration measures decided by the European Council. This is in addition to the 330.7 million euros of new funds as well as the 70.6 million euros redeployed. This proposal is both politically outrageous, as it aims to have the taxpayer of European countries finance the immigrationist delusions of their leaders, but also because this budget increase violates the obligation to obtain the unanimity of the members of the Council to change the multi-year financial framework. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the decision allowing for the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, namely the provision of commitment funds under Heading 3. (Security and citizenship) of €66.1 million, and as the 2015 cap did not provide sufficient funding to finance important EU political priorities, not particularly in terms of funding measures to deal with the refugee and migration crisis. This decision ensures the more generous financial support needed to better cope with the refugee crisis, which is especially important for the countries worst affected, primarily countries of origin and transit countries such as Croatia.  So far, Croatia has spent HRK 22m for the care and transport of refugees, for which it has been provided with assistance from European funds in the amount of 5m euros. While this amount is projected to be sufficient to cover the costs of the next two months, the unpredictability and the possibility of increasing the pace of refugee inflows require flexibility and guarantees of additional financial resources, as Croatia has committed to cover all further costs, regardless of the source of the funds to cover them.  With this decision, the EU demonstrates its readiness and determination to adapt to changing circumstances and to provide much-needed assistance to those hardest hit by the refugee crisis in conditions of inequality between countries facing the burden of the crisis.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The Commission has proposed to mobilise a flexibility instrument to complement funding from the Union's general budget by €66.1 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures to deal with the refugee and migration crisis for the 2015-2020 financial year. Mobilisation seems necessary after considering all options for redistributing commitment appropriations.  The allocation of adequate payment appropriations of €52.9 million for 2016 and €13.2 million for 2017 has been proposed and the mobilisation of this instrument once again confirms how crucial it is for the Union budget to be more flexible. After examining all options for the redistribution of appropriations under the ceiling, it seemed necessary to mobilise a flexibility instrument to complement funding in the General Budget of the Union.  Consequently, I support rapporteur Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of using the flexibility instrument to finance certain urgent measures in the area of migration in view of the fact that the expenditure ceiling provided for in the 2015 budget was not sufficient. The amount envisaged, amounting to EUR 66.1 million, is above the expenditure ceiling allowed under the heading "Security and Citizenship" (heading 3) of the EU budget. These additional resources will be used to finance some measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. To this end, an allocation of EUR 52.9 million is expected for 2016 and EUR 13.2 million for 2017. I also believe that the use of this instrument is a clear signal of the need to ensure greater flexibility in the EU budget, so as to be more responsive in providing responses to crisis situations.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In order to be able to respond quickly and effectively to the migration issues currently facing the Union, the Commission proposed to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2015 to the tune of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations. The European Parliament approved this budget amendment. I stress the importance of having a flexible budget in order to be able to deal with exceptional situations and to be able to provide the Union with adequate financial resources to deal with these situations.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 11 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 provides for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument up to an annual ceiling of EUR 471 million (2011 prices) to allow the financing of specifically identified expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more of the other headings. After an analysis of all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations within the expenditure ceiling under Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship), it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 with EUR 66.1 million to finance migration measures. To this end, and on the basis of the report of the Committee on Budgets, I voted in favour of the decision on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for the provision of immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this initiative which allows the granting of EUR 66.1 million as commitment appropriations, entered under heading 3, Security and citizens for the 2015 financial year, in order to continue financing migration measures, as the money provided for crisis management is not enough. I am not against managing the refugee crisis that will face the winter season on European soil, but these financial resources are normally set as resources to spend on unpredictable situations. When Europe's doors opened, the costs needed to support the wave of immigrants were not properly foreseen, and now we all, whether we want to or not, have to pay for some decisions that we did not agree with. This migrant crisis is not an unpredictable phenomenon.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the mobilisation of over EUR 66 million to support an EU-wide migration/refugee policy. We oppose the EU taking more powers on migration and asylum and spending more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The refugee crisis is not just a migration problem. It involves our notion of humanity and how we are prepared to defend it, to protect it. Nor is it a European problem alone. Every state in the world must step up to its potential. At European level, we must put in place a responsible and inclusive migration policy, in the long term, and actively combat the causes of migration flows. The Dublin II regulation has shown its limits. The debate must be refused and, on the contrary, asylum policies and procedures for the protection of persons must be harmonised, by sanctifying refugee status in line with the Geneva Convention. States must act together in the Council and enable the Commission's proposals to be implemented quickly. Moreover, the list of countries with which to work closely must be unique. We cannot accept blackmail from third countries. Only a European policy guided by community spirit and respect for the individual can allow us to significantly improve the situation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This Resolution of the European Parliament concerns the proposal for a decision of the EP and the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for the provision of immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration.  The Commission's proposal to mobilise this Flexibility Instrument by an amount above the MFF ceilings to complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 with an additional EUR 66.1 million in authorisation appropriations to finance measures to manage the refugee and migration crisis and the allocation of corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. This being one of several positive measures put forward by the Commission to deal with the refugee crisis, It has deserved my approval and a vote in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to deal with the continuing emergence of migratory phenomena, I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European immigration agenda. The mobilisation of this instrument will involve EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations necessary for the management of the refugee and migrant crisis. Specifically, this funding will amount to EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour and this should be interpreted in conjunction with the following draft amending budget (No 7/2015). The Flexibility Instrument allows the redistribution of resources that, in this case, address the issue of the refugee crisis.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The amendment to the budget aims to mobilisation European funds in order to meet the urgent needs faced by migrants in the European Union. While I share the concern about the situation of these people and support the idea of more resources being provided to the Office for Refugee Support, I find it a huge hypocrisy that, while this will provide more resources for Frontex and Europol. I believe that the policies of the European Union and the action of its Frontex agency have much to do with the humanitarian emergency situation we are currently witnessing, and strengthening Europe's instruments of strength can in no way contribute to improving the situation. I abstained not to give my full support to the European Union's criminal policies on migration and asylum.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The flexibility instrument allows the financing of expenditure that could not otherwise be financed within the ceilings provided for in the multiannual financial framework. I voted in favour of mobilising these funds as they will be used to ensure support for some immediate budgetary measures aimed at managing the current migration crisis.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is adding to the tax burden on citizens of Member States, and I would support a reduction in spending.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument beyond the MFF ceiling to complement the financing from the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations for managing the refugee and migration crisis. The draft report shall contain an important emphasis that payments resulting from commitments previously made through the Flexibility Instrument can only be taken into account above the ceiling, without prejudice to the possibility of using payment appropriations for specific budget lines through the Flexibility Instrument without pre-existing commitments.  The use of the flexibility instrument is necessary in the case of the case. I agree with the proposed allocation of the corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017, which is why I supported the draft report. However, I believe that the Union budget should be more flexible. Access to and use of funds should be immediate in such and similar situations, as this is the only way to prevent further damage and additional unnecessary use of funds.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report given the urgency of the European Agenda on Migration. A flexibility instrument should be mobilised to complement funding in the Union's general budget for the 2015 financial year of €66.1 million in order to finance migration measures.  After considering all possible options concerning the redistribution of funds, in this situation the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument is required. Funding for measures to manage the refugee crisis should be regulated and the budget should answer the humanitarian issue related to refugees.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Due to the latest developments in migration, the European Commission has proposed amending the draft budget 07/2015 to increase the amount of commitment appropriations by redistributing €70.6 million within the budget itself. This redistribution provides €100 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI) and the Internal Security Fund (FUS). A further €1.3 million should go to finance more jobs in the FRONTEX job plan (+60 jobs), EASO (+30) and EUROPOL (+30). Finally, €300 million is earmarked for additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument.  Given the urgency of the migration situation, I fully support this report in the hope of contributing to a better resolution of the current migrant crisis.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The strengthening of asylum and integration funds for illegal immigrants should contain actions of a permanent nature and no temporary solutions should be proposed.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current situation of the influx of refugees into Europe is one of the most serious challenges facing the European Union today. The European Commission's proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument beyond the Multiannual Financial Framework to finance the management of the migration and refugee crisis seems most appropriate. The EU budget should be a flexible tool to respond to emerging needs and challenges. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of launching this instrument and handing over an additional 66 million to manage the current crisis.  It is worth noting on this occasion that some Member States supporting and declaring support for the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis and the EU Trust Fund for Africa are delaying the transfer of adequate funds to these funds.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal is linked to Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 7/2015. It allows mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for an amount of EUR 66.1 million beyond the ceiling of Heading 3, to finance the measures included in DAB 7/2015. That means in practice that payment appropriations corresponding to the proposed mobilisation will be EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. I welcome the fact that the Council adopted the Commission position on the use of the Flexibility Instrument unmodified on 8 October. This action clearly shows that Member States have finally understood the urgency of tackling the migration crisis Europe is experiencing. The adoption of the current report in the plenary now paves the way for the reallocation of 160 000 refugees across all Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European migration agenda (text BUDG by Mr Gardiazabal Rubial).

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which seeks to find additional resources under the 2016 and 2017 European Union Budgets, in order to fund the European Agenda on Migration. To this end, the Commission has proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument, over and above the multiannual financial framework ceilings. The aim is to complement the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 by EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures for managing the refugee and migration crisis. There will be an allocation of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. On 30 September the Commission published two proposals concerning the further financing of measures to deal with the migration crisis – one proposal concerns the draft amendment to budget 7/2015 and the other concerns the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument. The €66.1 million fund under the flexibility instrument is earmarked for emergency assistance within the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, primarily to support those Member States of the Union currently most affected by the migration crisis, such as Croatia, Germany, Greece and Austria. Since this instrument was created precisely for such emergencies and emergencies and crises, I believe that its mobilization is fully justified and fit for purpose. So I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to use the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, as I believe that sufficient resources must be provided to finance the measures, precisely with a view to managing and resolving the refugee problem.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this and this should be interpreted in conjunction with the following draft amending budget (No 7/2015). The Flexibility Instrument allows the redistribution of resources that, in this case, address the issue of the refugee crisis.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 allows for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance specific expenditure that could not be incurred within the ceiling of one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. In accordance with Article 11 of Council Regulation No 1311/2013 and Point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management, the Commission proposes to use the flexibility instrument after examining all the possibilities of redeployment within the expenditure heading 'Security and Citizenship' (heading 3) and after exhausting the remaining margin. The mobilisation relates to an amount of EUR 66.1 million, which exceeds the ceiling of Heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the aim of providing financial support for measures to deal with the refugee crisis. Payments corresponding to this proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amount to €52.9 million in 2016 and €13.2 million in 2017. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ In order to finance measures to manage migration and refugee crises, the Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument above the ceilings provided for in the Multiannual Financial Framework. I support the proposal for immediate budgetary measures, within the framework of the European Agenda for Migration, to address the management of migration and refugee crises in the Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this and this should be interpreted in conjunction with the following draft amending budget (No 7/2015). The Flexibility Instrument allows the redistribution of resources that, in this case, address the issue of the refugee crisis.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. As this topic is very important for all Member States, all citizens and, most importantly, for all refugees and migrants, efficient measures have to be adopted and also financially supported. Therefore I agree that it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement financing in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 by EUR 66.1 million, in order to finance measures in the field of migration, and more specifically for managing the refugee crisis.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, EUR 66.1 million will be mobilised to finance measures to manage the migrant and refugee crisis. Europe is currently having to move from words to deeds, fulfilling its duty of solidarity and using its economic resources to take appropriate and targeted action against the massive migratory phenomenon that is taking place. So far, the situation has been dealt with in a disorganised manner and without a plan for the future: the funds provided for are nothing more than a buffer measure. We need to discuss a plan for the future, reviewing the Dublin Treaty and not leaving a few Member States alone in dealing with this humanitarian crisis. Although I believe that the solution is still a long way off, mobilising these funds is a first step towards a European response and for these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The amendment to the budget aims to mobilisation European funds in order to meet the urgent needs faced by migrants in the European Union. While I share the concern about the situation of these people and support the idea of more resources being provided to the Office for Refugee Support, I find it a huge hypocrisy that, while this will provide more resources for Frontex and Europol. I believe that the policies of the European Union and the action of its Frontex agency have much to do with the humanitarian emergency situation we are currently witnessing, and strengthening Europe's instruments of strength can in no way contribute to improving the situation. I abstained not to give my full support to the European Union's criminal policies on migration and asylum.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Despite opposition from a number of Member States to the plan to relocate asylum seekers within the European Union from EU border countries to all Member States, the first relocations took place at the beginning of October.  It should be remembered that 160,000 asylum seekers, potential refugees, since they are only Syrian, Eritrean and Iraqi asylum seekers, should be affected by this proposal and be able to benefit from relocation on European territory from Italy and Greece to other EU Member States.  In order to promote the integration of these refugees and their reception in other Member States, the European Commission has called for exceptional measures, including financial measures. As relocations have already begun, it is more than necessary to make this funding available to the Member States, especially Greece and Italy. This is what the Commission is proposing by mobilising the so-called flexibility instrument, which allows for changes to this year's budget and the next two years for this exceptional instrument.  The release of this EUR 66.1 million is necessary. I'm voting for.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Flexibility Instrument is mobilised in order to provide an amount of EUR 66.1 million in authorisation appropriations to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis. In view of the crisis and the urgent need for action to be taken to cope with the arrival of these thousands of refugees, we voted in favour.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In view of the exorbitant amounts of money already required by the Union and the Member States to deal with the refugee crisis, the report does not agree that a further EUR 66.1 million, which has not yet been budgeted, will be used for action in the Migration Agenda through a flexibility instrument. On the contrary, the report shows that the Union and its Member States are also reaching their financial limits as a result of this crisis. In addition, the report leaves what exactly the funds are to be used for. I cannot support such a non-transparent report.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 7/2015 concerning the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate measures under the European Agenda on Migration. Considering the current migration crisis and the urgency to find the quickest and the most effective solutions, I believe that adopting the DAB No 7/2015 is crucial.  Even though I understand that not all of us may agree with what is happening with the migration crisis and are sceptical of the decisions made by the EU in that regard, we have to consider the fact that steps have already been taken. And since there is no ʽgoing backʼ from those decisions, it is important not to stay firm and actually help to find ways that will burden our economy as little as possible. Indeed, I believe that this mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument will help us activate all the necessary measures needed for dealing with the current migration process without harming the economy of the EU.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal. On 30th September the Commission proposed two solutions to further finance actions related to the refugee crisis: draft amending budget No 7/2015 and the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument. As the increase in the number of refugees and migrants was not foreseeable at the time of adoption of the current Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, and this cannot be considered a temporary phenomenon, long-term solutions have become required. The Commission has proposed to mobilise this instrument under Heading 3 at a total cost of EUR 66.1 million above the limits of the Multiannual Financial Framework (EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017). This approended draft amending budget No 7/2015, amounting to EUR 801.3 million, mainly dedicated to sealing borders, and will be used for emergency assistance.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration, as it is necessary to strengthen financially both the Member States receiving the largest influx of refugees and the Union institutions responsible in this area.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to finance certain measures to manage the refugee crisis, the European Commission, having examined all possibilities for reallooted appropriations under the heading "Security and Citizenship" (heading 3), proposes to mobilise EUR 66.1 million under the flexibility instrument above the expenditure ceiling for this heading. Payment appropriations corresponding to the proposed mobilisation of the flexibility instrument amount to EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017. In the Committee on Budgets, too, I supported this text, which was adopted in record time, having less than 15 days since the European Commission presented its proposal. This is the request to mobilise a special instrument provided for in the Multiannual Financial Framework to cover certain items of expenditure beyond the ceilings established by that framework agreement. Given the importance of migration, I believe it is right to support the use of this instrument to allow the financing of measures aimed at managing the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 After adhering to all the possibilities for reallocation of authorisation appropriations under heading 3 of the 2015 Budget, it has become necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for authorisation appropriations amounting to EUR 66.1 million in authorisation appropriations, once again highlighting the need for the EU budget to be more flexible and larger. The Commission then proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument by an amount higher than the MFF ceilings in order to complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 with an additional EUR 66.1 million in authorisation appropriations so that measures to manage the refugee and migration crisis could be financed. It is also proposed that the corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 52.9 million in 2016 and EUR 13.2 million in 2017 are also proposed. We have voted in favour of this mobilisation in order to speed up and speed up this process, so that the means reach where they are needed.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained because, despite sharing the need to allocate resources to alleviate the emergency situation in refugees and asylum seekers, I understand that the way we do so cannot continue to fund the agencies responsible for European political criminals at their external borders, but that there really needs to be a change in the way we deal with this reality based on compliance with the Geneva Convention respect for human rights.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this given the urgent need to adequately address the humanitarian refugee crisis in Europe and at its borders. The report calls for the European Union to do more to address the current refugee crisis, stating that the current measures proposed are insufficient. I welcome the call for the Commission to present a sustainable long-term plan for the crisis and particularly welcome and support the focus on search and rescue operations. We need an immediate response as more people than ever are seeking protection in Europe.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The amending budget 7 for 2015 is making the necessary changes to enable the actions decided on 23 September to deal with the refugee crisis to be financed.  The amendments made increase for 2015 by EUR 400 million the funding of the Agencies related to the assistance of The Member States in the field of asylum, such as the Fund for Asylum, Migration and Integration, the European Asylum Office, Frontex, Europol and the Tools of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report discusses the Council's position on draft amending budget 7, which deals with the management of the current migration crisis. The project plans to allocate more than 455 million euros under the 2015 budget to immigration policy.  At no time did he mention the closure of internal borders to solve the thorny problem of immigration. However, the suspension of the Schengen area would certainly have a significant deterrent effect. A lot of money is allocated to the reception of illegal immigrants while a large part of the Member States are unable to turn back illegal aliens... So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this draft amending budget, which seeks additional funds to assist the migration crisis but which fails to understand the nature of the current issue. Where the solution is incorrect, I cannot support an increase in funding.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the additional increase in the emergency funding adding EUR 100 million to this budget for 2015. A number of measures have already been introduced in order to address the consequences of the migration crisis; however, the unprecedented number of refugees requires further and immediate actions. In order to manage the sudden rise in the refugee flows, political decisions need to result in the smooth implementation of operational actions which cannot be carried out without a rapid allocation of adequate financial resources.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for amending budget No 7/2015. Its aim is to increase the Union's resources to address the current refugee and migrant crisis. I support this project, which increases emergency aid from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund, totalling EUR 100 million. The amount of the commitment appropriations, while maintaining the necessary resources and other programmes financed by amif funds.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Another 455 million euros for "migrants"...  I obviously voted against this report by Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial, an obscure Spanish socialist who has received the outspoken and overwhelming support of her EPP colleagues. In Paris as in Brussels, the UMPS leads us into the wall. To solve the migration crisis we are experiencing, it is urgent and essential to restore our borders. As Frontex has proved incapable of protecting the EU's internal borders, Schengen must be suspended before our nations finally descend into migration chaos. Everything else is just literature... and gabegie.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have supported this budgetary adjustment, which aims to strengthen the eu's capacity to deal with the migration crisis it is experiencing. This envisages an increase of 100 million euros in emergency aid under the "Asylum, Asylum, migration and integration" and the Internal Security Fund, the creation of 120 new jobs at Frontex, EASO and Europol, additional appropriations for the European Neighbourhood Instrument to the tune of EUR 300 million, payment credits for humanitarian aid amounting to EUR 55.7 million ,... The rapporteur underlines the Commission's rapid response to the current refugee crisis and believes that the proposed measures must go hand in hand with initiatives to address the root causes of the migration and refugee crisis. It calls on the Union to redouble its efforts to overcome the current situation by contributing to the stabilisation of countries of origin and by helping transit countries. It also welcomes the commitment made by Member States to mobilise EUR 1 billion to respond to the humanitarian situation of migrants and refugees.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the management of the refugee crisis, immediate operational, budgetary and legal measures under the European Agenda on Migration. Parliament's commitment has always been to work with the utmost diligence in line with its budgetary responsibilities and by proposing measures to address the root causes of the migrant and refugee crisis. The Union needs to work harder to resolve the current situation, stabilise countries of origin and help transit countries.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The draft amending budget (PBR) 7 for the 2015 financial year aims to introduce the necessary changes to take immediate action in the final months of 2015, using all the possibilities of redeployment of credits at this stage of the year.  A budget of 455 million euros is planned to deal with the "migrant" crisis. This includes staff increases for various agencies, such as Frontex, AMFI and FSI funds for 100 million euros, the European Neighbourhood Instrument for 300 million, etc. Of course, this is not a sustainable solution and only a firm policy in the face of migration submersion is necessary. The Schengen agreements must be abolished in order to restore controls, illegal aliens must be systematically re-elected at the border and based on Australia's migration policy. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the increase in budget appropriations in favour of the Syrian crisis is the first sign of openness to what the Northern League has always supported: intervening by helping these populations in their places of origin. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it confirms the draft amending budget No 7/2015 proposed by the Council, which aims to increase the Union's resources to address the current refugee and migrant crisis. The draft amending budget increases emergency assistance from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund by a total of EUR 100 million. The amount of the commitment appropriations, while maintaining the necessary resources and other programmes financed by AMIF. An additional increase is also foreseen for Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Europol, a total of 120 posts, as well as corresponding appropriations for remuneration by the end of the year.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As with the vote on immediate budgetary measures to deal with the migrant crisis, I also supported the proposed amending budget. With the amendment adopted, we are providing an additional EUR 100 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund, EUR 300 million for additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument and reallocated EUR 55.7 million for payment appropriations for humanitarian aid. In addition, the adopted amending budget increases the number of posts at Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol by 120. All these measures are, of course, welcome, but given the current situation, where, for example, the european Union is in a state of emergency. Slovenia is among the busiest countries, and its struggle with the wave of migrants is already on the brink of capacity, significantly short. We will need much more resources to deal with the migrant crisis, which has completely out of control, as well as a plethora of swift and effective measures. This will not be the case without closer cooperation between the Member States, so it is the task of the European Parliament, within the limits of its powers, to put pressure on the Council to adopt as soon as possible appropriate and effective solutions to deal with the migrant crisis. We need unity in protecting the EU's external border, for which all available resources must be provided. Without this, the EU as we know it will no longer be.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 7/2015, approved by the College of Commissioners at the end of September last year, concerns the resources to be allocated to emergency measures for the management of the migration crisis. The draft budget aims to strengthen EU funds with the aim of reaching €1.7 billion (around €800 million for 2015 and €900 million in 2016). Measures are also expected to encourage stronger action by EU agencies, with an increase of 120 additional resources for Frontex (60), EASO (30) and Europol (30). A plan capable of influencing such a complex phenomenon requires that all parties be actively involved in a continuous, constructive and proactive dialogue. That is why it is important that additional funds should be allocated to the budget item dedicated to the Mediterranean countries for the European Neighbourhood Instrument. The adoption of this document following the Commission communication is a necessary measure, which I support, to ensure a truly effective strategy for managing one of the wider crises facing the EU.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I also voted against the draft amending budget No. 7, which provides for the allocating more than EUR 455 million under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. These funds are reckless and doomed to loss. The only solution is a suspension of the Schengen agreements (re-establishment of internal border controls) and the return of irregular aliens to the border.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to make direct use of the refugee crisis that is affecting our continent. It is important that immediate budgetary measures are implemented to enable operators to deal with this situation in the best possible way.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This text aims to strengthen the European Union's financial resources to deal with migration submersion. In detail, the report plans to increase the budget allocated to the Internal Security Fund by 100 million euros, increase the budget for the European Neighbourhood Instrument by 300 million euros and increase humanitarian aid by 55.7 million euros. Finally, there are plans to increase the number of frontex, EASO and Europol staff with an additional 120 positions, with an estimated annual cost of 1.3 million euros. At a time when Europeans are facing mass unemployment, poverty and the abolition of an increasing share of their social gains, it is absolutely indecent to provide additional funds for the reception of illegal migrants. We know that the massive influx of illegal immigrants meets the needs of multinationals, who see it as an opportunity to increase their competitiveness. We believe that only the immediate cessation of the Schengen area, together with a foreign policy aimed at stabilizing the Middle East, will effectively combat this migratory submersion. I therefore voted against this outrageous text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The fund will deal with the growing needs for resilience and stabilisation in Syria's neighbours, in particular Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey, Iraq and Egypt, and also within Syria itself.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on draft amending budget No 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 as it helps to finance the management of the current refugee crisis. The European Union must do more to manage the current migrant and refugee crisis, helping to stabilise their countries of origin and assisting transit countries. The proposed measures are likely to prove insufficient, given the overall number of people seeking protection in the Union, but it is clear that all the institutions want to increase budgetary appropriations for migration and asylum, as well as to use foreign policy instruments to address the root causes of the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this given the urgent need to adequately address the humanitarian refugee crisis in Europe and at its borders. The report calls for the European Union to do more to address the current refugee crisis, stating that the current measures proposed are insufficient. I welcome the call for the Commission to present a sustainable long-term plan for the crisis and particularly welcome and support the focus on search and rescue operations. We need an immediate response as more people than ever are seeking protection in Europe.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the mobilisation of over EUR 66 million to support an EU—wide migration/refugee policy. We oppose the EU taking more powers on migration and asylum and spending more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as we need to increase spending on assistance to the countries of transit which are currently experiencing an influx of refugees. Funds should be provided under the Asylum, Integration and Migration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) in accordance with their fundamental purpose. I also welcome the strengthening of agencies like Frontex, EASO and Europol which are crucial to the effective management of the crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Amending budget No 7 is concerned with allocating resources to deal with the migration crisis that the EU has been facing on a massive scale for some months. The measures provided for in this amending regulation include, firstly, the strengthening of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). It is also proposed to increase the number of posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol in order to increase their capacity to operate on the ground, and finally to provide for additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument. This is certainly not a decisive measure, but I hope that it will be useful in trying to improve the management of the migrant and refugee crisis at European level. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it provides for an allocation of more than 455 million euros under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. This allowance is not a reasonable solution. The European Union should deal with the migration problem by first going through internal border control.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Lagging behind the phenomenon and the growing and continuous migratory flows that have affected several Eu ropean States in recent years, the European Commission has recently proposed a package of measures, legislative and non-legislative, to deal with the crisis. In addition to these, there has also been its commitment to strengthen financial support by allocating EUR 401.3 million from the 2015 budget to immigration. As the budgetary authority, Parliament voted to ratify the budget for this year, in order to allow, through the transfer of expenditure items, to increase the financial resources of the funds for asylum and internal security, but also to increase the human resources of the European agency Frontex and EASO, which will provide support to those Member States that are still at the forefront of managing the refugee crisis. It is clear that this is not a decisive act, but it is already a first concrete response to the consequences of one of the greatest humanitarian emergencies that the European Union has known since its constitution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the commitment made by member states at the informal European Council of 23 September 2015 to mobilise EUR 1 billion in response to the humanitarian situation of migrants and refugees, calling on Member States to extend and continue their commitment to provide the necessary funds in the coming years. It is also stressed that if additional aid is needed during this year to deal with the migration and refugee crisis, Parliament will be ready to accept further mobilisation of the flexibility provisions provided for in the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 7/2015. The draft budget provides for the strengthening of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Immigration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for a total amount of EUR 100 million, an increase of 120 posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol and the corresponding salary appropriations up to the end of the year of EUR 1.3 million, additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument totalling EUR 300 million and an increase of EUR 55.7 million in payment appropriations for humanitarian aid through realisation. The European Parliament believes that the European Union should help stabilise the countries of origin of refugees and assist transit countries, and calls on the Commission to present a long-term financial plan to respond to the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it aims to strengthen EU resources for managing the current migrant and refugee crisis, addressing the current lack of funding. In addition, the proposal provides for the strengthening of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for a total amount of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations, while maintaining the necessary resources, as well as other programmes financed under AMIF. Finally, I believe that the Eu ropean Union must do more to manage the current migrant and refugee crisis, including by helping to stabilise the countries of origin and assist the transit countries, as the measures proposed will certainly not be sufficient given the total number of people seeking protection in the Union.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the mobilisation of over EUR 66 million to support an EU—wide migration/refugee policy. We oppose the EU taking more powers on migration and asylum and spending more money. Each country should manage its own policy and work together on a bilateral basis to deal with the current crisis. EU policy on the current crisis has been a disaster and will only lead to more deaths on the journey to Europe.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report as it calls for EUR 100 million to be mobilised for the Asylum and Integration Fund in commitment appropriations, 120 posts to be created for the EU’s FRONTEX border agency, and increased money for the EU Neighbourhood countries and increased EU spending on aid.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the flexibility instrument to supplement the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 of EUR 66.1 million in commitment appropriations, in order to finance measures to manage the refugee and migrant crisis. It will also be essential to strengthen measures in favour of asylum, border security and refugee reception policies. The mobilisation of this instrument once again indicates the need to ensure greater flexibility in the European budget.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ As more and more asylum seekers enter the European Union, efficient action becomes imperative and I support this report because of its approach. The budget allocation to come from this report will help implement the pledges outlined by the European Council on 23 September, putting the European Union on right track towards managing the crisis. The pledges to gain monetary assistance include the European Neighbourhood Instrument, various European trust funds established after the Syrian Crisis (Madad Fund), and frontline institutions such as identification and registration institutions that are in desperate need of more personnel to make sure the process runs with efficiency. This document amending the budget will provide agencies, including the World Food Programme, with funds to directly bring aid to the refugees.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Amending budget No 7 is concerned with allocating resources to deal with the migration crisis facing the EU on a massive scale for some months. The measures provided for in this amending budget include, firstly, the strengthening of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for a total amount of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations, and it is proposed to increase the number of posts for Frontex, EASO and EUROPOL in order to increase their capacity to operate on the ground. Further funding is also provided for the European Neighbourhood Instrument (EUR 300 million in commitment appropriations), so that the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ("Madad Fund") can count on at least EUR 500 million, and finally an increase of EUR 55.7 million in payment appropriations for humanitarian aid through realisation is proposed. In view of the reasons I have just given and given that this is emergency assistance, I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The araking of the budget aims to strengthen EU funds for the refugee and migration crisis. The amendment increases the amount of emergency aid under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund by EUR 100 million. The amendment increases posts by 120 for frontex, easo and europol agencies and increases the resources of the European Neighbourhood Instrument by EUR 300 million. Payment appropriations for humanitarian aid will be increasing by EUR 55.7 million through redeployment. In line with the European People's Party, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This budget amendment aims to reinforce the EU’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migration crisis, allowing for swift implementation on the ground. It is proposed to dedicate an extra EUR 401.3 million to addressing the crisis. This will be distributed as emergency assistance to the most affected EU Member States, to increase the staffing by 120 posts in the three relevant EU frontline agencies (Frontex, the European External Action Service and Europol) and to help tackle the Syrian refugee crisis in EU Neighbourhood countries. While the urgency of the cause is understood, the report also mentions that there is political consensus among the main political Groups on the need to find a long-term response to the migration and refugee crisis. As I agree with both parts – the urgent need for financial help and the importance of better planning to address the crisis – I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Commission's swift response to the management of the current refugee crisis, and I believe that the European Parliament must act in a timely manner, in line with its budget responsibilities, to combat the root causes of the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes an amendment to the 2015 budget to mobilise an additional EUR 401.3 million to deal with the refugee crisis. These funds will be allocated to EU countries affected by these exceptional migration flows, to third countries hosting the most Syrian refugees and to the three European agencies in charge of migrant management. The rapporteur also proposes to undertake a seven-year review of the EU budgetary framework, in order to provide for additional long-term funds. Considering that this report aims to provide the necessary means to implement the recent decisions of the European Union in response to the migration crisis, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Member States, at the informal European Council on 23 September 2015, announced the mobilization of eur 1 billion in response to the humanitarian situation of migrants. Through my vote, I supported the provision of additional funds to help countries hosting refugees.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The amendment aims to strengthen EU funds dealing with the current refugee and migration crisis, thereby addressing the current underfunding of chapters 3 and 4 in domestic and foreign policy. The amendment raises the amount of emergency aid under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund by EUR 100 million (commitments).  For FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL agencies, it will increase posts by 120 and propose an increase of EUR 1.3 million in commitment and payment appropriations by the end of the year. It raises the resources of the European Neighbourhood Instrument by EUR 300 million. It will increase humanitarian aid payment appropriations by an additional EUR 55.7 million through redeployment. The draft araking 7/2015 relates to the report on the use of the Flexibility Instrument up to a commitment appropriation of EUR 66.1 million for the above measures to be taken under the European Agenda on Migration. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal to adjust the EU budget for 2015 because the European Frontex, Europol and European Asylum Support Offices play a key role in resolving the refugee crisis and urgently need additional funds. Similarly, the additional funds allocated under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and under the Internal Security Fund are of utmost importance and will support Member States.  The first fund will improve the capacity to accept refugees and the second will improve border management. For Bulgaria, these funds are of utmost importance because we need additional assistance for our reception centers as well as for the construction of the EU's external border. With respect to the funds allocated to the Regional Fund for Syria and the UN agencies, I believe that the EU cannot cover the needs of these agencies on its own, and should not be held responsible for what is happening on its own. The whole international community needs to rally and provide funds, because both the Commission's quota redistribution plan for refugees is a temporary measure and will not solve the problem, and the current funds are just the beginning of the financial burden that we will all bear as a result of our policy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the draft amending budget 07/2015 because it calls for the strengthening of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Funds as well as the creation of additional jobs to support the above Funds. We believe that it is wrong for the Institutions to manage the refugee crisis, because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union must practice internal and external solidarity in the refugee crisis. Further efforts are needed to host and further action to stabilise countries of origin. The funds, programmes, instruments and agencies involved should be strengthened and better articulated. I therefore agree with the strengthening of the emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) totaling EUR 100 million; with the increase in the number of posts in the organisation chart of FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL (120 in total), as well as the corresponding salary appropriations by the end of the year, amounting to EUR 1.3 million in commitments and payments; with additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument (totaling EUR 300 million); with the increase of EUR 55.7 million in payment appropriations for Humanitarian Aid and finally with the provision of immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration amounting to EUR 66.1 million.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries.  On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the draft amending budget in question, which envisages strengthening the emergency aid provided by the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund by EUR 80 million and the Internal Security Fund by EUR 20 million. In addition, the proposals include 120 additional posts to expand the capacities of the three Frontex, EASO and Europol agencies. The European Parliament has long pointed to a significant underestimation of the number of staff in the agencies in question, which are constantly required for additional and additional tasks. The European Commission's proposals in question need to be addressed urgently in order to allow funding and additional staff to be made available during 2015.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 As everyone knows, we are firmly opposed to this immigration policy which we consider harmful and unholy but, specifically, these budget increases, including more aid on the ground, especially on the border with Syria, will receive our vote in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the draft amending budget 07/2015, because it calls for the strengthening of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Funds, as well as the creation of additional jobs to support these funds. I believe that the institutions' management of the refugee crisis is wrong, because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 7/2015 aims to reinforce the EU’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis allowing swift implementation on the ground. DAB 7/2015 proposes increasing commitment appropriations by EUR 401.3 million, to be distributed as follows: • EUR 100 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (EUR 80 million) and the Internal Security Fund (EUR 20 million) as emergency assistance to the most affected EU Member States; • EUR 1.3 million to increase staffing by 120 posts in the three relevant EU front line agencies (Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Europol); • EUR 300 million to the European Neighbourhood Instrument (contribution to the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis). Furthermore DAB 7/2015 proposes increasing payment appropriations for an amount of EUR 57 million (EUR 55.7 million for Humanitarian Aid and EUR 1.3 million for the abovementioned agencies) which is to be covered through redeployment. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. This report gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis. These funds will provide emergency assistance to the EU Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address the issue of the refugee crisis, I would like to recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany the money to finance immediate measures.  The current management of the crisis by the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in our countries.  We must show citizens what the EU can do. By adopting this report, Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis. National governments must now act with the same urgency and use these resources to improve the situation on the ground.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on draft amending budget No 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, managing the refugee crisis: immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration, because I believe that the decision to provide for additional EU funding of EUR 401.3 million for the EU countries most affected by the influx of refugees mainly from Syria, third countries hosting the majority of Syrian refugees and the three European agencies (EASO, Europol, Frontex) that are at the forefront of dealing with this crisis is of fundamental importance. I fully share the position of the European Parliament rapporteur to go beyond these measures, which are also important, because they transpose the decisions of the informal European Council on migrants of 23 September, and therefore to ensure that during the review of the Union's multiannual financial framework in 2016, the review takes account of the fact that the refugee problem could prove to be a long-term problem. In parallel with this increase, EUR 55.7 million was approved in payments for humanitarian aid. This will make it possible to implement aid to refugees. The states most directly concerned now have the means to deal with the crisis.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The vote on the draft EU amending budget for 2015 to increase financial resources is Parliament's response to the crisis of the massive influx of migrants into Europe. The project foresees an increase of EUR 80 million in assistance from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and EUR 20 million in assistance from the Internal Security Fund (ISF). In addition, 120 additional posts are foreseen for Frontex, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO).  Since the beginning of 2015, more than 500 000 migrants have entered EU countries. The costs associated with this unexpected wave of newcomers were not foreseeable at the time of the adoption of the current Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. A budget adjustment was needed in response to requests from those Member States with the highest numbers of migrants – Italy, Spain and Greece. These countries should be provided with immediate assistance from the Community, as it has been the largest economic and economic burden of receiving a wave of immigrants.  The European Union should strive to resolve the current crisis as soon as possible. It will be necessary to mobilise additional financial resources to ensure effective protection of our Community's borders. Long-term solutions are also required to be taken into account in the annual budgetary procedures and in the review of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have approved this application in its sum and the accompanying approval of the grants. In order to deal with the current refugee crisis, it is crucial that the EU provides substantial aid and emergency measures to all relevant institutions. Amending Budget No 7/2015 establishes a comprehensive package of various measures that will be effective in the short and long term.
