For example, funding for humanitarian projects will be increased and emergency aid will be made available to affected neighbouring countries. At the same time, other existing support measures will be maintained. An important recognition of this motion is the observation that the refugee crisis will continue to have an impact on Europe in the coming years and that this fact must be taken into account by the Council in the budgets for the coming years.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No. 7/2015, together with the request for the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, are combined requirements that operate within an urgent and exceptional procedure for transferring resources to the Emergency Aid Reserve in the face of the humanitarian aid needs expressed by UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other relevant organizations to assist refugees and immigrants immediately. It would have to start before the end of 2015 and that aid could be provided before the end of the year. It should be noted that I voted in favour because the balance sheet is that most of the resources go to urgent and immediate humanitarian aid, although part will go to security, border control and return initiatives. The place where it is appropriate to amend the functions of Frontex or Europol is in other committees, in particular in the LIBE Commission, where further work must be carried out to change the non-humanitarian functions they perform.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015: managing the refugee crisis: immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration because it welcomes the swift response from the Commission in dealing with the current refugee crisis, reiterates the readiness of the European Parliament to act in due time in accordance with its budgetary responsibilities, and points out that the proposed measures have to be coupled with initiatives aimed at addressing the root causes of the migration and refugee crisis. Fundamentally, all of the EU’s Member States need to work together to deal with refugees arriving in Europe. Solidarity and shared responsibility is crucial during this uneasy time.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The amendment aims to strengthen EU funds dealing with the current refugee and migration crisis, thereby addressing the current underfunding of chapters 3 and 4 in domestic and foreign policy. The amendment increases the amount of emergency aid under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund by EUR 100 million (commitments). It proposes to create 120 new jobs for FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL agencies and an increase of EUR 1.3 million in commitment and payment appropriations by the end of the year. It will also increase the resources of the European Neighbourhood Instrument by EUR 300 million. It will increase humanitarian aid payment appropriations by an additional EUR 55.7 million through redeployment. The draft araking of budget no 7/2015 is also linked to the Flexibility Instrument report on the above measures under the European Agenda on Migration, which relates to the use of a commitment appropriation of EUR 66.1 million. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The draft amending budget (EAW) No 7 for the financial year 2015 is intended to create conditions for the immediate action to be implemented in 2015; all possibilities for redeployment are used without compromising the execution of other expenditure programmes. A total of EUR 801.3 million will be made available. The requested increases for AMIF, isF and humanitarian aid will be partially offset by the redeployment. These funds come from the European Union Solidarity Fund, from various budget lines under heading 2 and from the 'Food and Feed' programme. In addition to the reallocations, the existing margins of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Europe in the World) will be exhausted and the flexibility instrument will be used to finance emergency measures. The level of payments will remain unchanged in 2015 as a large part of the payments will be made in 2016. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No. 7/2015, together with the request for the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, are combined requirements that operate within an urgent and exceptional procedure for transferring resources to the Emergency Aid Reserve in the face of the humanitarian aid needs expressed by UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other relevant organizations to assist refugees and immigrants immediately. It would have to start before the end of 2015 and that aid could be provided before the end of the year. It should be noted that I voted in favour because the balance sheet is that most of the resources go to urgent and immediate humanitarian aid, although part will go to security, border control and return initiatives. The place where it is appropriate to amend the functions of Frontex or Europol is in other committees, in particular in the LIBE Commission, where further work must be carried out to change the non-humanitarian functions they perform.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly agree that the Commission’s measures have to be met with initiatives aimed at addressing the root causes of the refugee crisis. The Commission’s rapid response to the current crisis should be acknowledged. I would like to further salute the commitment of Member States to mobilise EUR 1 billion in order to tackle the humanitarian situation. However, I believe that the Commission must take further steps regarding this crisis by truly helping countries of origin to stabilise.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council's position report on draft budget amendment No 2012. 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, the management of the refugee crisis: urgent operational, budgetary and legal measures of the European Agenda on Migration, as, given the day-to-day migration situation, there was a need to increase emergency financial assistance under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI), the Internal Security Fund and the European Neighbourhood Facility.  Furthermore, the flexibility instrument for urgent operational, budgetary and legal measures of the European Agenda on Migration and the increase in the number of jobs of Frontex, the European Asylum Office and Europol is needed. I consider it necessary for the Commission to present a long-term financial plan to respond to the migration and refugee crisis. The European Union must be able to react promptly and efficiently to such crises, and provide an effective response in the form of a realistic and concrete solution to this situation.  Therefore, I support this draft budget change because I believe that the current situation is really alarming and that financial and other measures need to be implemented urgently.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This is the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No. 7 on the management of the refugee crisis. In addition to allocating additional resources to the European Asylum Support Office, the report calls into question Operation Frontex, which would ignore the fundamental rights of migrants, and allocates more than EUR 455 million under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. It is important for taxpayers to understand that these lavish financings they support are "money thrown out the window."  Indeed, the only realistic and effective solution remains, not to the displeasure, the suspension of the Schengen agreements and the systematic return to the border of illegal aliens. I voted against most of the provisions and abstained for some.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. It calls for EUR 100 million to be mobilised for the Asylum and Integration Fund in commitment appropriations, 120 posts created for the EU’s FRONTEX border agency, and increased money for EU neighbourhood countries and increased EU spending on aid.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the amending budget under the European Migration Agenda. The text strengthens the budget lines necessary to implement the immediate measures required to welcome refugees. These budget increases will provide financial support to the Member States most affected by the migration crisis, strengthen Frontex's resources and strengthen aid to third countries hosting Syrian refugees. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ These proposals foresee the reinforcement of the emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Integration and Migration Fund (AMIF) by EUR 80 million and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) Borders by EUR 20 million. Furthermore the proposals provide for 120 additional posts to increase the capacity of three agencies: 60 posts for Frontex, 30 for EASO and 30 for Europol for 2015. Further reinforcement is foreseen for a number of external measures as well (additional funding in commitments for the European Neighbourhood Instrument and additional payments for humanitarian aid). EH Bildu opposes the additional staff for Frontex, EASO and Europol; indeed, our coalition opposes the nature of those agencies. Nevertheless for the time being, the main issue with this vote is to try to get the necessary funding available in time to provide nurturing and healthcare for migrants and refugees before the end of the month. Hence, EH Bildu voted in favour of the immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In my opinion, the report misses its objective and must therefore be rejected. A sustainable solution can only be achieved if the causes of the migration or refugee movement are tackled.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it aims to reinforce the EU’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis allowing swift implementation on the ground.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The draft amending budget (EAW) No 7 for the financial year 2015 is intended to create conditions for the immediate action to be implemented in 2015; all possibilities for redeployment are used without compromising the execution of other expenditure programmes. It includes an increase of a total of EUR 100 million in emergency aid under AMIF and ISF, an additional 120 posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol, and an additional EUR 300 million in commitments to the European Neighbourhood Instrument to provide at least €500 million to the European Union Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ("Madad Fund"). A total of EUR 801.3 million will be made available. The requested increases for AMIF, isF and humanitarian aid will be partially offset by the redeployment. These funds come from the European Union Solidarity Fund, from various budget lines under heading 2 and from the 'Food and Feed' programme. In addition to the reallocations, the existing margins of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Europe in the World) will be exhausted and the flexibility instrument will be used to finance emergency measures. The level of payments will remain unchanged in 2015 as a large part of the payments will be made in 2016. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because we are facing an unprecedented refugee wave and the faster we understand that there is no national solution to this complex problem, but only a common approach, the faster we will help the thousands of children and mothers. This is not only a European but also a regional and global crisis, and this requires us to include in the resolution all the countries neighbouring the EU that bear much of the brunt of the refugee wave. In this regard, I welcome the decision to re-place 120 000 refugees within the EU, as well as the decision to provide assistance to 2 million refugees in Turkey. We also need to increase resources to deal with the refugee flow and review the seven-year EU budgetary framework in order to implement long-term budgetary measures to tackle the problem. Of course, these measures must be combined with initiatives aimed at addressing the root causes of the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial's report. Amending budget No 7/2015 provides for an allocation of additional resources for the European management of migration. This is based on a further taking of responsibility on the part of Europe towards those Member States, primarily Italy, which, for geographical reasons, have to face the migrant and refugee emergency. In concrete terms, the measure involves a strengthening of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) to the amount of EUR 80 million and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) to the amount of EUR 20 million. The proposals also generate the creation of 120 new staff posts in order to increase the capacity of three agencies: 60 posts for Frontex, 30 for EASO and 30 for Europol in 2015.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this amending budget No. 7 for a number of reasons, not least because it plans to allocate more than 455 million euros to the reception of migrants. It thus helps to maintain an "air call" for immigration.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I welcome the budgetary initiative on budgetary remedies in relation to the syrian refugee crisis and mass migration to Europe. For almost a year, I have been highlighting the need for humanitarian and preventive action in various Community for a in areas outside the EU, in countries that have already received several million refugees. We must appreciate the efforts already made by Lebanon, Jordan or Turkey. Financial support is an expression of real effort, not just moral support. By working for refugees in these countries, we are also easing the pressure of immigration to Europe. We are aware that the appropriations are not sufficient, they do not solve the problem (they cannot provide a solution), but they make the lives of refugees more human, and they also bring relief to the countries in which the refugees reside.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. On 23 September 2015, Member States took the decision to relocate 120 000 refugees from Italy, Greece and other Member States directly affected by the refugee crisis. On 30 September the Commission presented a battery of priority measures to be taken in the next six months to manage the refugee crisis.  This is a first group of concrete proposals to be allocated in 2015 and 2016 to EUR 1.7 billion of EU funds to deal with the refugee crisis. The proposals submitted for 2015 amount to EUR 801.3 million to support priority actions. The second group of proposals for the remaining EUR 900 million for 2016 will be included in an amending letter to the 2016 draft budget in October. Both Parliament and the Council have dealt with this dossier with the utmost urgency to enable the funds to be released as soon as possible. Agreeing with the measures and urgency, I voted in favour of it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries.  On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained because, despite sharing the need to allocate resources to alleviate the emergency situation in refugees and asylum seekers, I understand that the way we do so cannot continue to fund the agencies responsible for European political criminals at their external borders, but that there really needs to be a change in the way we deal with this reality based on compliance with the Geneva Convention respect for human rights.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The draft amending budget (EAW) No 7 for the financial year 2015 is intended to create conditions for the immediate action to be implemented in 2015; all possibilities for redeployment are used without compromising the execution of other expenditure programmes. It includes an increase of a total of EUR 100 million in emergency aid under AMIF and ISF, an additional 120 posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol, and an additional EUR 300 million in commitments to the European Neighbourhood Instrument to provide at least €500 million to the European Union Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ("Madad Fund"). A total of EUR 801.3 million will be made available. The requested increases for AMIF, isF and humanitarian aid will be partially offset by the redeployment. These funds come from the European Union Solidarity Fund, from various budget lines under heading 2 and from the 'Food and Feed' programme. In addition to the reallocations, the existing margins of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Europe in the World) will be exhausted and the flexibility instrument will be used to finance emergency measures. The level of payments will remain unchanged in 2015 as a large part of the payments will be made in 2016. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In September 2015, the Commission presented a statement on the management of the refugee crisis, namely on immediate operational, budgetary and legal measures. These are actions to be taken in the next 6 months, including adjustments to the 2015 budget and draft budget proposals for 2016.  The purpose of the proposal on amendments to the budget (DAB) is to introduce the necessary change for immediate measures in the remaining months of 2015. This includes stepping up emergency assistance provided by the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the 100m-euro Internal Security Fund (ISF) in financial commitments. Then, an increase of 55.7m euros in humanitarian aid. EU migration agencies need to step up their capacity, as there are now calls for far more active on the ground than originally planned.  The Commission therefore proposes to further increase human resources in three key EU agencies with a combined increase of 120 additional jobs. I supported the report of Eider Gardizábal Rubial because of the necessity of resolving the refugee crisis by adopting concrete financial plans to achieve stability, both in the Member States and in Croatia.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 While Europe has been a magnet for several migrants and refugees for many years, the events of 2015 are undoubtedly the most unprecedented in the history of our Union. And if, on the basis of purely geographical logic, it is perfectly understandable why the absolute majority of these people end up in Europe in its south and south-east, greece, Italy, Hungary and now Croatia and other countries without help must not leave. I fully support this change in the budget, because they are aimed not only at trying to stabilise the situation in Europe itself, but also in the countries from which the majority of migrants and refugees also go to us. No attempt should be made to deal with the problem without its fundamental reasons being wound up. Frontex, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office, as well as other important bodies, are at the heart of overcoming this crisis and should therefore be supported, including through staffing, in order to be able to tackle the migrant and refugee crisis more effectively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, "Managing the refugee crisis: immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration", because the Union must do more to address the current migration and refugee crisis, as the proposed measures are not comprehensive and adequate. For this reason, the Commission should present a long-term financial programme to tackle the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support draft amending budget No 7/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, concerning immediate budgetary measures within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. Draft amending budget No 7/2015 aims to consolidate Union resources for the management of the current migrant and refugee crisis. The commitment of all institutions to increase budgetary appropriations for migration and asylum is essential, as well as to use foreign policy instruments to address the causes of the refugee and migrant crisis. Providing the necessary funding, strengthening the emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund for a total amount of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations in response to the humanitarian situation of migrants and refugees must be a priority for all Member States. The European Union must contribute to the management of the current migrant and refugee crisis, assist the countries of origin and assist transit countries.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote in favour I supported the adoption of draft amending budget No 7 to the 2015 general budget, aimed at providing longer-term solutions, considering that the increase in refugees and migrants was not yet foreseeable at the time of the adoption of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The introduction of changes such as the strengthening of emergency assistance under the Asylum Fund, the increase in the number of posts for the three Frontex, EASO and Europol agencies, and the increase in payment appropriations for humanitarian aid are the aims of the project that we had a duty to accept as a matter of urgency.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. There is no support for an increase in the financial resources for the refugee problem, which will continue to address only the symptoms and not the causes of the problem. Parliament's willingness, mentioned in the report, to accept further application of the flexibility provisions if further increase is necessary is like a bottomless pit. The report lacks concrete measures that could contribute to a sustainable solution to the problem. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This 7th amending budget for 2015 provides for various budgetary dusting measures to abound the various European programmes on asylum and migration, including the Frontex agency, whose purely bureaucratic and security vision of migration flows I denounce. In passing, the report gives the Commission a satisfaction for its action, while it is totally ineffective in the face of an ever-increasing crisis. He even congratulates the European Council for committing states to free up an additional billion to deal with the migrant crisis. A pure lie when the current reality of the Union budget is to reduce the contribution of states by more than 2 billion, as evidenced by the 6th amending budget. I should vote against this hypocritical report which will not solve the current crisis in any way, but, given the object and malice of the media observers, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No. 7 on the management of the refugee crisis. In addition to allocating additional resources to the European Asylum Support Office, the report calls into question Operation Frontex, which would ignore the fundamental rights of migrants, and allocates more than EUR 455 million under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. It is important for taxpayers to understand that these lavish financings they support are "money thrown out the window."  Indeed, the only realistic and effective solution remains, not to the displeasure, the suspension of the Schengen agreements and the systematic return to the border of illegal aliens. I voted against most of the provisions and abstained for some.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the urgency of the situation and the need to reinforce the emergency assistance to the Member States affected by the migration crisis, there was cross-party support for this resolution. I therefore supported the measures it proposed and also hope that the Member States continue to express solidarity in not only financial terms.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of the draft amending budget 7/2015 on the management of the refugee crisis. Parliament intends to make up for the lack of funding that is currently affecting the management of the migration crisis. I am particularly pleased that this amending budget proposes, among other things, to create 120 new jobs within the Frontex, Europol and EASO agencies. We also believe that more staff should be made available to the latter agency, given its essential functions in the management of asylum claims. In the context of the implementation of a real migration policy at European level, EASO is indeed expected to play a crucial role. From this perspective and to the extent that the management of migration flows must be the subject of a long-term policy, we must give this agency the mandate and the means (financial and personnel) to effectively carry out the missions assigned to it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget No 7/2015 because it is important to reinforce the EU’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis allowing swift implementation on the ground. It addresses in part the needs mentioned in the ʽCommunication on managing the refugee crisisʼ of 23 September 2015.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On 30 September 2015, the Commission adopted draft a draft arak 7/2015 aimed at strengthening EU funds to address the current refugee and migration crisis. The draft also provides for an increase in the amount of emergency aid under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund in the form of commitment appropriations totalling EUR 100 million and additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument totalling EUR 300 million. The Committee on Budgets recommends that Parliament approve the Council's position on draft ara up to budget 7/2015. I voted in favour of the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This draft budget envisages allocating more than 455 million euros from the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. We vehemently oppose it, because it is an unnecessary expense that does not address the real problems and generates a call for air for other migrants. The only solution to the waves of migration that our countries are experiencing is the suspension of the Schengen agreements and the re-establishment of internal border controls. Moreover, the systematic return of illegal aliens must be introduced, not their accommodation at the expense of European citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Council adopted the amendment to the 2015 EU budget on 8 October. In particular, it plans to allocate more than 455 million euros under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. In detail, EUR 300 million will be allocated to the European Neighbourhood Instrument (EIEV), EUR 100 million to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund (ISF), EUR 55.7 million to the Humanitarian Aid Payment Credits and EUR 1.3 million for the 120 new posts at Frontex agencies. Needless to say, these funds are dressings on a wooden leg and that a lasting solution can only be achieved by suspending the Schengen agreements in order to restore internal border controls, as well as by systematically returning irregular aliens to the border who would abuse the asylum procedure. The report recalls that "the increase in the number of refugees and migrants was not foreseeable at the time of the adoption of the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework", while the National Front warned as early as 2011 about the migration submersion in the making. I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the correction of the 2015 budget to finance the immediate measures recommended by the Commission under the European migration agenda. It proposes an increase in commitment appropriations of 401.3 million euros, offset by redeployments of EUR 70.6 million identified elsewhere in the budget, a net increase of EUR 330.7 million, for the following measures: EUR 300 million to finance the EU's regional trust fund in response to the Syrian crisis and assistance to third countries hosting Syrian refugees; EUR 100 million to fund the Asylum and Migration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) to urgently assist member states most affected by the migration crisis; EUR 1.3 million to increase the staff of Frontex, EASO and Europol. This text is balanced and aims to address the causes of the migration tragedy with measures that provide for the stabilization of countries of origin, the fight against migrant trafficking, the securing of borders and the reception of refugees in neighbouring countries.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we take note of the draft amending budget presented by the Commission and of the Council's position on this subject, which are intended to manage the current refugee crisis. We have always offered our willingness to act in good time in accordance with our budgetary responsibilities. On this occasion, too, we would like to stress that the proposed measures must be accompanied by initiatives to address the root causes of the migrant and refugee crisis. The European Union will have to work in managing the current crisis, stabilising the countries of origin and assisting the transit countries. The proposed measures will certainly not be sufficient, given the total number of people seeking protection in the Union. We therefore call on the Commission to present a long-term financial plan to respond to the migrant and refugee crisis, including search and rescue operations, and to propose, consequently, a revision of the multiannual financial framework.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 7/2015 aims to strengthen union resources for managing the current migrant and refugee crisis, addressing the current funding shortfall, emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for a total amount of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations. I voted in favour of this report in order to respond promptly to the current refugee crisis, but at the same time initiatives must be created to address the root causes of this emergency by helping to stabilise the countries of origin and to assist transit countries.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that foresees the reinforcement of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Integration and Migration Fund (AMIF), and provides for 120 additional posts to increase capacity as follows: 60 posts for Frontex, 30 for EASO and 30 for Europol, for 2015.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this, given the urgent need to adequately address the humanitarian refugee crisis in Europe and at its borders. The report calls for the European Union to do more to address the current refugee crisis, stating that the current measures proposed are insufficient. I welcome the call for the Commission to present a sustainable long-term plan for the crisis, and particularly welcome and support the focus on search and rescue operations. We need an immediate response as more people than ever are seeking protection in Europe.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report calls for immediate budgetary action to address the refugee crisis. Since most of the funds allocated in the Member States are already being used incorrectly and are only intended to enrich agencies, I voted against and voted against.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The report proposes to review the 2015 budget of the European Union in order to increase emergency aid to Member States by EUR 100 million and humanitarian aid to respond to the current migration crisis by EUR 55.7 million. These envelopes will be used to finance the various European programmes on asylum and migration. This emergency measure is necessary so that the bodies that are now being called upon to resolve this crisis in an effective and dignified manner have sufficient financial means to act quickly, given the seriousness of the situation. EUR 66.1 million is also planned to support the relocation plan adopted by the European Union.  Despite the heated controversies surrounding the actual use of these funds, their release is urgent and necessary. So I support this project.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis and inefficient governance are today identified as a fundamental problem for the European Union, from which economic and social problems arise.  The old Europe faces serious challenges and challenges as refugee flows flow. Long-term decision-making measures should therefore be provided and a financial plan should be envisaged. In order to address the current refugee and migrant crisis, it is appropriate to increase the Union's resources. Additional financial support is particularly needed for the EU countries most affected by the flow of migrants. It could also be used by third countries that sheltered Syrian refugees. This would contribute to the stabilisation of the countries of origin and to assist transit countries.  Greater attention must be paid to frontex activities. It is necessary to ensure better protection of the external borders and to manage the flow of migrants by preventing smuggling.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 The current migratory flow affecting the Mediterranean region highlights Europe's structural unprepared ion in crisis management. In terms of operational reality, this is reflected in a lack of economic appropriations to deal with this phenomenon. At the time of the adoption of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, an increase of this magnitude in the number of refugees and migrants seeking refuge within Europe's borders was not foreseeable. This phenomenon, which can no longer be considered temporary, requires concerted and long-term solutions. This resolution addresses the problem of the current lack of funding and provides for an increase in both economic and personnel resources. The proposed measures must be accompanied by initiatives to address the root causes of the migrant and refugee crisis through the stabilisation of countries of origin and assistance in transit countries. We therefore need a leap of sensitivity towards the Euro-Mediterranean issue on the part of individual countries, especially from a European systemic perspective.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The allocation of increased funding from the EU budget to deal with refugee flows is not intended to relieve refugees of acute problems, to create infrastructure for their accommodation and human living, but to strengthen their repression and persecution. The increased funds will go towards strengthening FRONTEX, Europol and the EU's Security Agency. For surveillance mechanisms at the external borders, as expressed in the unacceptable position of the joint Greek-Turkish patrols, promoted by the EU, insisting on the dangerous road to co-management in the Aegean. For new repressive forces, such as the pre-prepared Euro-coast Guard. They are directed at the creation of so-called 'hot spots', sorting and deportation centres for unhappy migrants and refugees, the so-called 'EU Special Fund for Syria' and the financial instruments of the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy, which finance the EU's imperialist intervention in that country and the wider region. For these reasons, the JRC voted against the report and the amending budget and reiterates its demand for EU and government funds to be allocated to the creation of infrastructures for the accommodation, care and care of migrants and refugees, their rapid and safe transfer to their countries of destination.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report as it calls for EUR 100 million to be mobilised for the Asylum and Integration Fund in commitment appropriations, 120 posts created for the EU’s FRONTEX border agency, increased money for the EU Neighbourhood countries and increased EU spending on aid.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As reiterated earlier, given the emergency of the migrant crisis, I agree with the strengthening of the staff available to Frontex, EASO and Europol for their action in the Mediterranean, especially in the field of aid to the victims of shipwrecks and, with conviction, I vote positively. Finally, I would like to take advantage of the intervention in the highest European Parliamentary assembly to pay tribute to these women and men for the work they do on a daily basis in saving lives.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. - I supported Draft Amending Budget No 7/2015 because we need to be humane with those who are really in need and in solidarity with the countries that are more affected. By amending budget No 7/2015, we are strengthening the resources of the EEO to tackle the refugee and migration crisis by addressing the lack of funding within the general budget of the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The need for urgent assistance to refugees due to the years-long conflict in Syria and caring for people in distress and assistance at precisely the moment when this assistance is most necessary is our obligation. I therefore welcome the €100 million increase in emergency financial assistance to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. Aware of the experience of the exile crisis that Croatia encountered during the Homeland War and the refugee crisis that Croatia is coping with every day, I also consider it necessary to increase the funds for humanitarian aid to refugees in the amount of 55.7 million euros. There is also a need to work on the routes refugees take to Europe, and I therefore welcome the increase in jobs for FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL and the related increase in wage expenditure in these three agencies of €1.3 million.  After all, we need to understand that this is all just firefighting. Action should be taken at the source of the problem and the nearest neighborhood. I welcome the additional €300 million funding of the European Neighbourhood Instrument to make the EU's Madad Fund, set up to react to the Syrian crisis, at least €500 million.  But money will not solve the problem, as the problem needs to be addressed at its source and the EU needs to play a more active role.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The European Council adopted the amendment to the 2015 EU budget on 8 October. In particular, it plans to allocate more than 455 million euros under the 2015 budget to the migrant crisis. In detail, EUR 300 million will be allocated to the European Neighbourhood Instrument (EIEV), EUR 100 million to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund (ISF), EUR 55.7 million to the Humanitarian Aid Payment Credits and EUR 1.3 million for the 120 new posts at Frontex agencies. Needless to say, these funds are dressings on a wooden leg and that a lasting solution can only be achieved by suspending the Schengen agreements in order to restore internal border controls, as well as by systematically returning irregular aliens to the border who would abuse the asylum procedure. The report recalls that "the increase in the number of refugees and migrants was not foreseeable at the time of the adoption of the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework", while the National Front warned as early as 2011 about the future migration submersion. I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the budget changes aimed at strengthening the EU's financial resources and capacities to tackle the refugee and migration crisis, not particularly the increase in aid under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund, as well as the proposal to recruit new frontex staff. Support for the use of flexibility provisions is also commendable.  There are two fundamental preconditions for successful EU action in relation to the refugee crisis: combining humanitarian and preventive measures with a much more complex approach to addressing the root causes of the crisis itself, and providing assistance and stabilising transit countries and countries of origin. Croatia can serve as an example of good practice in handling the refugee crisis by acting humanely and in solidarity, even as it faces border militarization and barbed wire in the nearest neighbourhood. However, Croatia cannot deal with this problem alone until a political decision of all members is adopted and only five EU member states accept around 70% of refugees, as long as the principle of blame and burden on others is not replaced by the principle of solidarity support and assistance. In this regard, I welcome efforts to present a longer-term and more financially generous plan to help countries of origin and transit so that border closures, ignoring problems and repressive action cannot be justified by a lack of resources.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Draft budget amendment No. 7/2015 The Union's resources to address the current refugee and migration crisis are to be strengthened, addressing the current under-allocation in Headings 3 and 4. This draft sets out an increase in emergency financial assistance under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI) and the Internal Security Fund totalling €100 million in commitment appropriations, while maintaining the necessary resources and other programmes funded by the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. It also sets out job increases for Frontex, the European Asylum Office and Europol by a total of 120 jobs as well as related salary appropriations by the end of the year of €1.3 million in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations.  It also sets out additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument totalling €300 million and increases appropriations for humanitarian aid payments of €55.7 million. Taking into account that the Union must do more to respond to the current migration and refugee crisis and help stabilise countries of origin and provide assistance to transit countries, increasing funding is of utmost importance. For all of the above, I support rapporteur Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 The current migration crisis requires that practical measures be taken without urgent action to realistically improve the situation at the external borders, transit countries and destination states of refugees. I therefore supported the 7th draft amending budget for 2015. On the basis of this proposal, the staffing of the three agencies directly involved in managing migration flows will be increased by 120 staff. The measure concerns the European Asylum Support Office, Frontex and Europol. There will also be an increase in the commitments of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. Since it is clear that the European Neighbourhood Policy must undergo fundamental reform and become much more pronounced beyond Europe's borders, I also supported an increase in its budget. However, I am very distasteful to accept the solution to this issue simply by shifting financial commitments from one budget line to another, without in parallel increasing the necessary means of payment. This system is unsustainable in the long term and member states need to realise this as soon as possible. I therefore appeal to the Commission to take the necessary steps in this regard and to include this need in the next draft amending budget which it will submit.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft amending budget, as I consider it an obligation of the European Parliament to push for a practical solution to the migration crisis as quickly as possible. In this respect, I very much welcome the action of the European Commission, which has managed to prepare the relevant legislation in an extremely short timeframe. Any delay only aggravates the situation, not only from the human but also from the financial aspect. Parliament's decision made it possible to take the first concrete steps in favour of better managing the migration wave. At the same time, it called on the Member States to mobilise their financial resources to improve the humanitarian situation as soon as possible.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget (PBR) No 7/2015 identifies a number of priority actions to be adopted, by the coming months of 2015, using all possibilities for realocation of appropriations. The effects of the current refugee crisis, which has led to a significant increase in the number of asylum seekers and migrants, were not adequately foreseen when the financial framework for 2014-2020 was adopted. The management of this crisis has called for greater flexibility in the budget appropriations for migration and asylum. For this reason, I believe it is necessary to approve a 2016 budget adapted to the real extent of this emergency and, above all, to be able to give concrete follow-up to the commitments made by the European institutions. In particular, I am very much in favour of an increase in EASO staff, bearing in mind that this Agency has been given a key role in the implementation of the common European asylum system. I also support the call in the report for the Commission to propose a medium- and long-term strategy concerning the actions of the agencies in the field of justice and home affairs with regard to their objectives, their coordination, the development of hot spots and their financial resources. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I spoke in favour of the draft amending budget 7/2015 on the management of the refugee crisis. This project aims to unlock an additional EUR 401.3 million (in commitment appropriations) to support measures to support the refugee crisis. The main objectives of these funds will be to support the Asylum and Migration Fund, the Internal Security Fund, Frontex, the European Support Office (EASO), Europol and the European Neighbourhood Instrument. The European Parliament congratulated the Member States on this budgetary mobilization in response to the humanitarian and migration crisis affecting the Union and all European citizens.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 7/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of the current migrant and refugee crisis, thereby addressing this insufficient funding in categories 3 and 4. In this regard, it provides: a strengthening of the emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) by a total of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations, maintaining the necessary resources, as well as other programmes financed under the AMIF; the increase in the number of posts in the organisation chart of FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL (120 in total), as well as the corresponding salary appropriations by the end of the year, amounting to EUR 1.3 million in commitments and payments; additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument (EUR 300 million); and an increase of EUR 55.7 million in appropriations for payments for humanitarian aid through reallocation. In view of the need to give a full response to the current migrant and refugee crisis, I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the Council's position on draft amending budget No 7/2015.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report as it calls for EUR 100 million to be mobilised for the Asylum and Integration Fund in commitment appropriations, 120 posts created for the EU’s FRONTEX border agency, increased money for the EU Neighbourhood countries and increased EU spending on aid.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. The European Union is currently facing a major refugee crisis. Its resources therefore needed to be strengthened immediately so that it could respond responsibly, comprehensively and coherently. That is why I voted in favour of this draft amending budget 7/2015, which aims to increase the funding capacity of headings 3 and 4 of the EU budget. In concrete terms, this budgetary change includes a EUR 100 million increase in aid for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund; it creates 120 new jobs in the Frontex and Europol agencies as well as in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) through an increase in appropriations of 1.3 million euros; it increases the appropriations available for the European Neighbourhood Instrument by 300 million euros.  This vote provides the Union with additional resources to deal with the refugee crisis. A new step has been taken, but efforts will need to continue, including in the development of the 2016 budget, in order to reach a long-term solution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The refugee crisis is not just a migration problem. It involves our notion of humanity and how we are prepared to defend it, to protect it. Nor is it a European problem alone. Every state in the world must step up to its potential. At European level, we must put in place a responsible and inclusive migration policy, in the long term, and actively combat the causes of migration flows. The Dublin II regulation has shown its limits. The debate must be refused and, on the contrary, asylum policies and procedures for the protection of persons must be harmonised, by sanctifying refugee status in line with the Geneva Convention. States must act together in the Council and enable the Commission's proposals to be implemented quickly. Moreover, the list of countries with which to work closely must be unique. We cannot accept blackmail from third countries. Only a European policy guided by community spirit and respect for the individual can allow us to significantly improve the situation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The humanitarian legacy of Europe is rooted in the principle of solidarity between peoples. The aid that the EU must provide in the field of migration must be based on technical and financial support, capable of alleviating the negative effects of this wave of refugees, so that the funds, programmes, instruments and agencies involved in these actions should be strengthened and strengthened so that, in the near future, we can have a truly comprehensive and coherent European asylum policy , refugees and migration. To that extent, I am in favour of this Commission proposal to strengthen the emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF), amounting to a total of EUR 100 million, and to make a total increase of 120 staff for Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol , as well as to increase payment appropriations for Humanitarian Aid by EUR 55.7 million and to make immediate budgetary measures available under the European Agenda on Migration amounting to EUR 66.1 million.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, which allocates an additional EUR 401.3 million for the management of the refugee crisis.  The European Union must show solidarity and act at the international level to find solutions to this crisis and its origin. The Fund for the Management of the Refugee Crisis is intended not only for countries in the European Union that face significant migration challenges, but also for certain third countries and finally for the three European agencies in charge of these issues. Among the third states, Jordan, for example, currently hosts more than 630,000 refugees, or nearly 10% of its population, or Lebanon, which hosts more than 1.3 million refugees, or 20% of its population.  The additional budget that has just been released will help to partially respond to the migratory pressure that some States are under and to strengthen humanitarian action. Europe must continue to work towards resolving the refugee crisis, the worst crisis it has experienced since 1945, and show solidarity.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 7/2015 as it aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the containment and management of migrants and refugees. I welcome the draft amending budget which will bring financial aid totaling EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations which will be used to improve assistance under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). In addition, this project will increase the number of posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the text has, among other objectives, to address the Syrian crisis with targeted interventions on the ground aimed at stabilising the area.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No. 7/2015, together with the request for the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, are combined requirements that operate within an urgent and exceptional procedure for transferring resources to the Emergency Aid Reserve in the face of the humanitarian aid needs expressed by UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other relevant organizations to assist refugees and immigrants immediately. It would have to start before the end of 2015 and that aid could be provided before the end of the year. It should be noted that I voted in favour because the balance sheet is that most of the resources go to urgent and immediate humanitarian aid, although part will go to security, border control and return initiatives. The place where it is appropriate to amend the functions of Frontex or Europol is in other committees, in particular in the LIBE Commission, where further work must be carried out to change the non-humanitarian functions they perform.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained because, despite sharing the need to allocate resources to alleviate the emergency situation in refugees and asylum seekers, I understand that the way we do so cannot continue to fund the agencies responsible for European political criminals at their external borders, but that there really needs to be a change in the way we deal with this reality based on compliance with the Geneva Convention respect for human rights.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the number of refugees and migrants was not foreseeable at the time of the adoption of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 and cannot be considered a temporary phenomenon. Precisely for this reason, draft amending budget No 7/2015 aims to strengthen the European Union's resources for managing the current migrant and refugee crisis, addressing the current lack of funding. Since I believe that we must tackle this crisis by finding longer-term solutions and that the proposal voted on today in Parliament takes this perspective into account, I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This will add to the call for further increases in contributions from Member States, and add to the tax burden on families and business.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis does not have simple solutions, but the instruments available to national governments should be put into operation as quickly as possible. In order for EU Member States to cope with the current migration wave, it is essential that the agencies set up to protect the external borders and facilitate the asylum process are also strengthened. I therefore supported the draft amending budget, which will release more than EUR 400 million for the European Agenda on Migration. This package envisages strengthening the emergency assistance provided by the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund by EUR 80 million and the Internal Security Fund by EUR 20 million. In addition, the proposals include 120 additional posts to expand the capacities of the three agencies as early as this year: 60 for Frontex, 30 for the European asylum agency EASO and 30 for Europol. Additional funding will also be directed to the European Neighbourhood Instrument and additional payments will also go to humanitarian aid. The protection of external borders and the management of migration flows will be challenges for Member States, which they will have to cope with by cooperating with each other. The funds released today by the EP should also call on the Member States to be more flexibility in dealing with this urgent situation.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ Considering that Europe today faces one of the biggest crises in its recent history, I am glad that the European Union and the European Parliament acted fast in order to reduce the gap between the financial needs and the resources available. The fast-track amendment of the EU budget to provide emergency assistance to the EU Member States affected, to tackle critical underfunding and staffing problems in front-line EU agencies dealing with migration, and to provide assistance and humanitarian aid in third countries hosting refugees, was an imperative. However, the recourse to the Flexibility Instrument in this case also highlights the need to revise the EU budget for the future. In order to be able to respond to the migration and refugee crisis and to help stabilise the countries of origin, a long-term financial framework is needed.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. On 23.9.2015, the Commission presented draft budget No 7 for 2015, which aims to introduce the necessary amendments for immediate action in the remaining months of 2015 and to make use of all possibilities for reallocating appropriations at this stage of the budgetary procedure without compromising the implementation of other spending programmes.  The proposal includes strengthening emergency assistance under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF), increasing the number of posts from the establishment plan for FRONTEX, the European Asylum Support Office and EUROPOL to increase their capacity on the ground, additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument and an increase in payment appropriations for humanitarian aid of EUR 55.7 million through redeployment. These are measures which have become necessary as a result of the current refugee and migrant crisis and form a fundamental basis for dealing with pressing problems, which is why I supported Amendment No 7 to the general budget for 2015.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Addressing the migration situation also requires strengthening resources for border security and the organisation of detention camps. However, it is also a pressure on resources in the Member States for the integration of refugees and on social systems and their effectiveness.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this report because the budget needs to respond to the humanitarian situation with migrants and refugees. This case should focus primarily on the 2016 budget. The European Union's general budget for the 2015 financial year uses the flexibility instrument to increase commitment appropriations by €66.1 million above the ceiling on security and citizenship expenditure. This amount should finance measures to manage the refugee crisis.  European Union agencies dealing with migration issues need to step up their capacity as they are required to engage in much more activity than originally planned.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The change to draft budget 7/2015 aims to maximise the mobilising of available EU funds in deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis and provides for additional funding, including for the Asylum Fund, Migration and Integration (AMI), the Internal Security Fund (FUS), as well as the increase in jobs in frontex (+60 jobs), EASO (+30) and Europol (+30) and finally the European Neighbourhood Facility.  A significant increase in the number of migrants and refugees was not foreseen when adopting the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 and cannot be considered a short-term phenomenon. It is therefore necessary to revise the existing financial framework and find longer-lasting solutions to be taken into account during the upcoming annual budgetary procedures.  I fully support this report, as it aims to deal with the current migrant and refugee crisis and ensure a better approach to addressing it.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. I welcome the increase in funds to deal with the refugee crisis and particularly welcome the fact that a substantial part of this money is to be transferred from other parts of the EU budget. However, I do not agree that a not insignificant part of this expenditure is to be financed by increasing the EU budget by EUR 330.7 million. Given that the European Union budget has huge reserves of cuts, I find this unacceptable.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget is relevant to the issue of the refugee crisis and proposes a series of measures by increasing funds by 401.3 million, to be allocated to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (100 million), FRONTEX, Europol and EASO (1.3 million), and the EU Special Fund for the Syrian Crisis (300 million). GUE/NGL has tabled amendments, which were not voted for, on the role of FRONTEX and Europol, with which we disagree. For us, the answer to the refugee crisis is not to make Europe a fortress by strengthening borders, but to strengthen humanitarian aid in terms of protecting refugees coming to the EU but also the support that can be given to promote development in refugee countries. But we voted in favour of the amending budget because the funds to support the Asylum and Syrian Crisis Funds are very important in dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We think it is wrong for the institutions to manage the refugee crisis because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal for a decision, which complies in all way with the budgetary discipline requirements of the interinstitutional agreement between the EP, the Council and the Commission. I have taken into account the fact that the additional expenditure recently associated with an unexpected surge in the number of refugees and migrants at the EU's external borders is not covered by the framework set out in Chapter 3 of the 2015 Community budget allocation. For some Member States particularly affected, additional EU funding may be the only source of response to actual crisis situations. I therefore consider the Commission's proposal to mobilise, on an additional basis, EUR 66.1 million, in addition to the General Budget Ceiling of the Union, using the Flexibility Instrument, specifically for measures aimed at trespassing on the refugee and migration crisis, to be justified and justified. For me, this decision and the measure that has now become necessary also confirms the need for greater flexibility in eu budgetary planning, in perspective and in general.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 7/2015 concerns the allocation of EUR 401.3 million for tackling the refugee crisis by financing the reallocation of 160 000 refugees in Europe. DAB 7/2015 includes EUR 100 million designated to enhanced solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States in handling the large number of incoming refugees; EUR 300 million for helping neighbouring countries to tackle the crisis in a more efficient and humane way; and EUR 1.3 million for increasing the staffing levels at the agencies working on the front line (Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol).  Moreover, EUR 55.7 million in payment appropriations have been secured for humanitarian aid in order to ensure immediate help to refugees in need. I voted in favour of this report as it will improve the ability of Member States to deal with the large influx of refugees, migrants and asylum seekers into the EU. At the same time I believe we must continue looking for efficient and effective ways to tackle such situations in the future. As long as war and poverty remains a daily reality in so many parts of the world, Europe will continue to attract persons wanting a better life. We must be able to have the means to aid them.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the draft amending budget 7/2015 (management of the refugee crisis: immediate budget measures under the European migration agenda), verified by the experts in my political group.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ There is a strong need for more financial resources to tackle the immigration crisis and I therefore voted in favour of increasing the EU 2015 Budget for this purpose. The report proposes raising the budget by EUR 330.7 million with a view to funding the implementation of the European Agenda on Migration. Specifically, it will contribute to the reinforcement of emergency assistance and an increase in staff for the European Agencies Frontex, EASO and Europol. Furthermore the additional funds will be used to foster the response to the situation in Syria and for humanitarian aid for the refugees in need.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒The budget amendment 7 contains various budgetary measures to deal with the 2015 migrant crisis. The Commission's proposal for the year 2015 is EUR 801.3 million, of which EUR 100 million is earmarked for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund; 300 million are earmarked for the European Neighbourhood Policy; 200 million for the Syria Fund; 200 million for unhcr; and 1.3 million for an additional 120 people employed by migration agencies, not primarily FRONTEX, EASO and EUROPOL. While most of the funds are primarily supported by those seeking asylum (as opposed to those seeking economic opportunities), I must highlight concerns about the insufficient time available to examine the details of these proposals and to ensure that the funds are used correctly and in a targeted manner. However, given the gravity of the crisis facing Europe and the pressure to use these funds as soon as possible, I nevertheless hold it justified and will support the proposal.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ Draft amending budget No 7/2015 - Managing the refugee crisis: I supported the immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration because this amendment seeks to strengthen the Union's resources to deal with the current refugee crisis, which means that this proposal will support countries of origin and transit and help them stabilise. More funds for humanitarian aid to refugees or asylum seekers will also be allocated, and this amending budget will also mean an increase in jobs in Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No. 7/2015, together with the request for the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, are combined requirements that operate within an urgent and exceptional procedure for transferring resources to the Emergency Aid Reserve in the face of the humanitarian aid needs expressed by UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other relevant organizations to assist refugees and immigrants immediately. It would have to start before the end of 2015 and that aid could be provided before the end of the year. It should be noted that I voted in favour because the balance sheet is that most of the resources go to urgent and immediate humanitarian aid, although part will go to security, border control and return initiatives. The place where it is appropriate to amend the functions of Frontex or Europol is in other committees, in particular in the LIBE Commission, where further work must be carried out to change the non-humanitarian functions they perform.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The draft amending budget (EAW) No 7 for the financial year 2015 is intended to create conditions for the immediate action to be implemented in 2015; all possibilities for redeployment are used without compromising the execution of other expenditure programmes. It includes an increase of a total of EUR 100 million in emergency aid under AMIF and ISF, an additional 120 posts for Frontex, EASO and Europol, and an additional EUR 300 million in commitments to the European Neighbourhood Instrument to provide at least €500 million to the European Union Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ("Madad Fund"). A total of EUR 801.3 million will be made available. The requested increases for AMIF, isF and humanitarian aid will be partially offset by the redeployment. These funds come from the European Union Solidarity Fund, from various budget lines under heading 2 and from the 'Food and Feed' programme. In addition to the reallocations, the existing margins of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Europe in the World) will be exhausted and the flexibility instrument will be used to finance emergency measures. The level of payments will remain unchanged in 2015 as a large part of the payments will be made in 2016. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The increase in the number of refugees and migrants was not foreseeable when the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 was adopted. I am satisfied with the speed with which the Commission has reacted to the current refugee crisis. This report reaffirms the willingness of the European Parliament to act expeditiously in accordance with its budgetary responsibilities. I hope that Member States honour their commitments. I challenge the competent authorities to work to help stabilise the countries of origin and assist countries of transit – for surely the proposed measures will not be enough given the total number of people seeking protection in the Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No. 7/2015, together with the request for the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, are combined requirements that operate within an urgent and exceptional procedure for transferring resources to the Emergency Aid Reserve in the face of the humanitarian aid needs expressed by UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other relevant organizations to assist refugees and immigrants immediately. It would have to start before the end of 2015 and that aid could be provided before the end of the year. It should be noted that I voted in favour because the balance sheet is that most of the resources go to urgent and immediate humanitarian aid, although part will go to security, border control and return initiatives. The place where it is appropriate to amend the functions of Frontex or Europol is in other committees, in particular in the LIBE Commission, where further work must be carried out to change the non-humanitarian functions they perform.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it aims to reinforce the European Union’s resources to deal with the current refugee and migrant crisis, thereby addressing current underfunding. This provides a reinforcement of emergency assistance provided under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund for a total amount of EUR 100 million in commitment appropriations while maintaining the necessary resources. It also provides additional funding for the European Neighbourhood Instrument for a total amount of EUR 300 million, and EUR 1.3 million in commitment and payment appropriations for 120 new posts at the FRONTEX border agency, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Europol. I also welcome the swift response from the Commission in dealing with the current refugee crisis and the readiness of Parliament to act in due time in accordance with its budgetary responsibilities. The proposed measures have to be coupled with initiatives aimed at addressing the root causes of the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 After the last events in the field of migration, commitment appropriations of EUR 401.3 million are intended for the following measures: strengthening asylum and migration and internal security funds to the Member States most affected (EUR 100 million), increasing staff in the three agencies managing this area: Frontex, EASO and Europol (EUR 1.3 million) and increased European Neighbourhood Instrument for the Syrian crisis (EUR 300 million) euros). Due to the crisis situation we are facing and the urgency of the situation, it is necessary to vote in favour of this measure in order to be able to show this House's commitment to the current migration crisis.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of EUR 400 million for immediate action to respond to the refugee crisis.  These funds will provide emergency assistance to the Member States most affected, increase staff from EU agencies at the front line and provide humanitarian assistance and assistance in third countries. On the eve of the EU Summit of Heads of State and Government which will address this issue, from the Spanish Socialist Delegation we recall that the great agreements for the relocation of refugees are of no use if they do not accompany themselves with money to finance immediate measures. The current management of the crisis for the Twenty-eight has been wholly inadequate and its inefficiency has affected the EU's credibility over our ability to cope with the number of refugees arriving in Europe.  We must show citizens what the EU can do and that is why we welcome the broad support of this House for the Gardiazabal Rubial report. Parliament has shown that there is political will and the resources to respond to this crisis.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I abstained because, despite sharing the need to allocate resources to alleviate the emergency situation in refugees and asylum seekers, I understand that the way we do so cannot continue to fund the agencies responsible for European political criminals at their external borders, but that there really needs to be a change in the way we deal with this reality based on compliance with the Geneva Convention respect for human rights.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Tackling the current refugee crisis naturally has financial consequences, of course, which require urgent approval of measures. That is what we did at the mini-session in Brussels.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. For years, the European Union's budget on migration and asylum has been governed by the same leitmotif: ever less for integration and solidarity and ever more for fortress Europe. The budget increases have been made to the benefit of security policies and to the detriment of the fundamental rights of migrants and refugees.
