text: In writing. I voted in favour of Ms. Iliyana Tsanova's candidacy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliament’s approval of the appointment of Ms Iliyana Tsanova for the position of Deputy Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Ms Tsanova has over 12 years of development banking experience with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), where she currently holds the position of Director responsible for EU co-financing and Financial Engineering. In 2013 and 2014, she was appointed Deputy Prime Minister in two separate caretaker governments of Bulgaria, with special responsibility for European structural and investment funds.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I supported the proposal of the Steering Committee of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) on Iliyana Tsaova's candidacy for the position of Deputy Director-General of the EFSI. Following the hearing of the candidate, the Committee on Budgets and the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee approved her appointment as Deputy Director-General of the EFSI.  I believe that her extensive experience in structuring, negotiating and implementing investments and co-financing EUROPEAN Union projects is important for the performance of this duty. In addition, I believe that the cooperation it has achieved with governments and international financial institutions can help bring about a change in the sharp decline in investment across Europe caused by the economic crisis and, accordingly, the beginning of a stable economic recovery.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to appoint a Deputy Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because Article 7(6) of Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 provides that the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments shall be appointed by the European Investment Bank, with the prior approval of the European Parliament, on the basis of an open and transparent procedure in accordance with eib procedures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Bulgarian economist Iliyana Tsanova and, despite her extensive experience, I voted against her precisely with the development and infrastructure sector (European Bank for Reconstruction and Development), a land to which THE EEF will engage, and for the risks of conflict of interest that could arise.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this nomination with the hope that the appointee will behave independently from the interests of Member States. The EU does not need a European Fund for Strategic Investment that just continues business as usual, building more airports without planes, and high-speed trains without passengers.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the appointment of the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Managing strategic developments in the coming years requires serious professional skills. I voted in favour of the committees.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Bulgarian economist Iliyana Tsanova and, despite her extensive experience, I voted against her precisely with the development and infrastructure sector (European Bank for Reconstruction and Development), a land to which THE EEF will engage, and for the risks of conflict of interest that could arise.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report concerning the appointment of deputy Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), in which we confirmed Iliyana Tsanova for the position of Deputy Managing Director of the EFSI. The EFSI aims to overcome the current investment gap in the EU by mobilising private financing for strategic investments which the market cannot finance alone. It will support strategic investments in infrastructure as well as risk finance for small businesses. The fund will focus its financing on investments in infrastructure and innovation, as well as finance for SMEs, which are very important for the European economy. Therefore I believe the managing of this Fund should be done with great responsibility.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the appointment of Iliyana Tsanova as Deputy Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as a result of decisions taken from above and without any real democratic control. Article 7 of the EFSI Regulation provides for the Deputy Director of the Fund to be elected through an open and transparent selection procedure, with the active participation of the European Parliament. However, the selective process has been unclear and transparent and entirely manipulated by the EIB, with a Parliament relegated to a mere ratification role. As with the appointment of the Director-General, we have been faced with a complete event, with no other option but to approve or reject the only existing candidate.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the candidate for Deputy Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, because her professional career is closely related to infrastructure investment projects. This path is giving a clear signal of the potential direction that EIE investments will take, which will seek to replace public investments in infrastructure with public-private consortia that in the long run are much more expensive for taxpayers. In addition, he was the only candidate presented by the Council, which is a procedure that leaves much to be desired for the democratic will expressed by the European Parliament. That's why I haven't been able to vote for him.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We have no principled opposition to the name that is proposed. We abstain because we disagree with this instrument and the operating standards associated with it. As it is set up, this investment fund will help to further widen the gap between richer and poorer regions. It is based on the principle of public-private partnerships that drain public resources and fatten the profits of large economic groups.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. EFSI is an illusory project that is not feasible. Since the whole project must be rejected, I cannot support the proposed deputy managing director either.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for the appointment of the Deputy Director-General of EFSI, as set out in Article 7 of the EFSI Regulation, which provides for the Director-General and Deputy Director-General of EFSI to be appointed by the EIB, subject to approval by the European Parliament (following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures) was voted on today. , during which the European Parliament should be duly informed, in a timely manner, at all stages). In fact, the selection process has not been particularly clear, let alone transparent. On the substance, the candidate for Deputy Director-General is by no means sustainable because, unfortunately, this choice is perhaps precisely in order to respect a gender balance more than for her own abilities, as demonstrated also by the hearing held on 13 October, in which she showed numerous gaps and shortcomings of competence.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the candidate for Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because of his political career, which is closely related to the European People's Party. His strong political ties to the Austrian People's Party are a clear sign of the political orientation that the candidate will print to the activity of the FEIE. His professional career within the EED implies the continuation of the line of work of the Bank, which during its management has approved projects such as Castor in Spain, which has generated so many problems. In addition, he was the only candidate presented by the Council, which is a procedure that leaves much to be desired for the democratic will expressed by the European Parliament. That's why I haven't been able to vote for him.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Executive Director of the European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI). Indeed, the EFSI (or Juncker Plan) has just been created by the President of the Commission and aims to strengthen projects favourable to the European Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is by secret ballot; I do not believe in the principle of a secret ballot here. Members of the public have the right to know how their democratically-elected representatives voted. Therefore wish to clarify for the record that I voted against – on the grounds in this case that I do not support the EFSI, rather than making any value judgement in respect of the candidate.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. The EIB shall appoint the Executive Director of the EFSI with the consent of the European Parliament. October 13, 2015 The Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the proposed candidate for the post of Executive Director of the EFSI. I support the appointment of Mr Molterer as executive director of the EFSI.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The vote was by secret ballot, but it's easy to guess mine.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved Mr. Molterer's appointment as Executive Director of the EFSI. This is, of course, an essential function for the implementation of the Fund, which must, among other things, ensure job creation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to appoint Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Mr Molterer has already overcome the hearing of the Committee on Budgets and Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and responded to the questions successfully asked, showing his worth for the position assigned to him. I wish you a good career in your new work.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation should enable Wilhelm Molterer to be appointed as Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I voted against this appointment, not wanting to endorse European policy and this body.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. At a joint hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Budgets, Mr Molterer was able to demonstrate that he met the necessary requirements for the post of Director-General of THE EIE ANDSI and clearly showed his competence for the post. That is why I voted in favour of your appointment.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament approves the appointment of Mr Molterer as Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). In particular, the proposal for the appointment of the Efsi Executive Director and the Deputy Executive Director was adopted by the EFSI Management Board on 2 October 2015 and forwarded this proposal to the European Parliament. Then, in the European Parliament on 13 October 2015. The Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the proposed candidate for the post of Executive Director of the EFSI, during which the candidate gave an introductory speech and then answered questions put by committee members. During the plenary session of the European Parliament, his candidacy was approved.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report approves the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as head of the European Fund for Strategic Investments on the recommendation of the European Investment Bank. Deeply pro-European, which led to his losing major elections in Austria in 2008, the 60-year-old has been vice-president of the EIB since 2011. This appointment is clearly a form of political recycling.  That is why I voted against this proposal.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. I am sceptical about the functionality and usefulness of the Juncker plan, regardless of the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I have a number of concerns with the EFSI Plan and I believe that many of its provisions are fundamentally flawed.  The plan contains no provision in which to boost public investment, and for the most part the EFSI is a pilot project dressed up as a structural fund. There is no real increase in funds being made available. It is simply picking up money that the European Budget and the EIB had already allocated to attract private investment, weakening its legal framework and thereby increasing the exposure of public resources in the interests of the private sector. The EFSI, with sufficient political will and a commitment to boost public investment, could be used as a positive tool for much needed investment. Unfortunately, no such commitment has been displayed and as it stands this project is merely style over substance.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the appointment of a Managing Director as we do not support the EU’s EFSI programme or any post created for it. This ‘European Fund for Strategic Investment’ seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Wilhelm Molterer is the right candidate for the post of Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 From the outset, we opposed the Juncker plan, because we believe that the premises on which it is based are wrong, starting with the expenditure chapters from which to find some of the funds and the identification of the system that should lead to their multiplication. This candidacy only confirms the negative premises, as the person indicated is a purely political figure belonging to a party that has no other interest than to continue in the direction announced. I have therefore voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the proposal of the Governing Council of the European Fund for Strategic Investments of 2 October 2015 concerning the appointment of the Executive Director and participating in and attending the hearing in the Committee on Budgets, we approve the appointment of the Director of the EFSI.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Article 7(6) of Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 provides for the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to be appointed by the EIB, subject to authorisation by the European Parliament, following open and transparent selection. On 2 October 2015, the EFSI Steering Committee adopted a proposal on the appointment of the Director-General of EFSI and forwarded it to the European Parliament. On 13 October 2015, the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing of the candidate proposed for the role of Director-General of EFSI, Wilhelm Molterer.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I followed the advice of my colleagues who attended Wilhelm Molterer's hearing and decided to vote in favour of his appointment. Although Parliament only expresses an opinion on this, I found this transparency positive and appreciated the procedure. On paper it seems that Molterer has all the requirements. In sending him my "good luck", I assure him of my constant commitment to monitoring his work.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the appointment of a Managing Director as we do not support the EU’s EFSI programme or any post created for it. This ‘European Fund for Strategic Investment’ seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. –  UKIP voted against the appointment of a Managing Director as we do not support the EU’s EFSI programme or any post created for it. This ‘European Fund for Strategic Investment’ seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased to hear the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. My warm congratulations and best wishes for the new post go to the manager.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the proposal concerning the appointment of the Director-General of EFSI in accordance with Article 7 of the EFSI Regulation, which provides for the appointment by the EIB, subject to the approval of the European Parliament (following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with the EIB's procedures, during which the European Parliament should be duly informed, in a timely manner , at all stages). In fact, the selection process has not been particularly clear, let alone transparent, and that is why I am voting against it.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to appoint the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.  Under Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI) the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the ESII shall be appointed by the EIB following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures and after approval by the European Parliament.  On 2 October 2015, the MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE of the SII adopted a proposal for its appointment, which it forwarded to the European Parliament. On 13 October, the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the candidate proposed for the position of Executive Director of the ESI. Following the hearing, the European Parliament approved the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Executive Director of the ESI.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Article 7(6) of Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 provides that the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the EIB shall be appointed by the EIB following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures and after approval by the European Parliament. On 2 October 2015, the ESII Steering Committee adopted a proposal for the appointment of the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the SII, which it forwarded to the European Parliament. On 13 October 2015, the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the candidate proposed for the position of Executive Director of the ESI, who made an introductory statement and answered questions put by the members of the Committee. The European Parliament approved the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Executive Director of the ESI. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We consider mocking the "election" of a person without a co-candidate. Such election systems apply in North Korea.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I do not support the appointment of the Executive Director of the EFSI as his election is imposed without democratic means. Such election systems apply in North Korea.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of approving the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer for the position of Managing Director of the EFSI.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Wilhelm Molterer and, despite his sufficient professional profile, I voted against him for his flirt with the Austrian People's Party and his continuing perspective.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the candidacy of Wilhelm Molterer.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for the appointment of the Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments(EFSI). Having regard to the proposal of the Steering Board of the European Fund for Strategic Investments  of 2 October 2015 for the appointment of its Managing Director and of Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 provides that the Managing Director and Deputy Managing Director of the EFSI are to be appointed by the EIB after approval by the European Parliament following an open and transparent selection process in line with EIB procedures, during which the European Parliament shall be kept duly informed in a timely manner at all stages. Due to this I voted for the decision to approve the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer for the position of Managing Director of the EFSI.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 7(6) of Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 provides that the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the EIB shall be appointed by the EIB following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures and after approval by the European Parliament. On 2 October 2015, the ESII Steering Committee adopted a proposal for the appointment of the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the SII, which it forwarded to the European Parliament. On 13 October 2015, the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the candidate proposed for the position of Executive Director of the ESI, who made an introductory statement and answered questions put by the members of the Committee. The European Parliament approved the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Executive Director of the ESI. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Wilhelm Molterer and, despite his sufficient professional profile, I voted against him for his flirt with the Austrian People's Party and his continuing perspective.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the proposal for the appointment of the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments on the view that I consider mr Wilhelm Molterer's competences and readiness to be adequate for the function in question. His previous experience and engagements indicate that Mr Molterer is professionally prepared to serve as Director-General and will carry it out responsibly and conscientiously.  EFSI has a very important role to play for the coming period, and knowing Mr Molterer personally, who also has affinity for southeast Europe, I have confidence that it will meet our expectations and will bear in mind the needs of this part of Europe. Therefore, I support mr. Molterer's appointment.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against the appointment of a Managing Director. This European Fund for Strategic Investment seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Jean Arthuis and Roberto Gualtieri on the appointment of the Director General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which funds the Juncker Plan. This text approves the application proposed by the European Investment Bank for this position. This appointment was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I support the election of Mr Wilhelm Molterer as Managing Director of EFSI.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – EFSI, established under the European Investment Bank (EIB), mobilises additional investment in the real economy in areas such as infrastructure, education, research, innovation, renewable energy and energy efficiency. The appointment of its Director-General therefore deserves special attention and I welcome the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of EFSI.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Molterer's appointment as head of the European Strategic Investment Fund. I am indeed opposed to the very principle of this Fund, which was created as part of the Juncker Plan. But I am not questioning mr Molterer's qualities, which is merely the workings of a flawed system.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the candidate for Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because of his political career, which is closely related to the European People's Party. His strong political ties to the Austrian People's Party are a clear sign of the political orientation that the candidate will print to the activity of the FEIE. His professional career within the EED implies the continuation of the line of work of the Bank, which during its management has approved projects such as Castor in Spain, which has generated so many problems. In addition, he was the only candidate presented by the Council, which is a procedure that leaves much to be desired for the democratic will expressed by the European Parliament. That's why I haven't been able to vote for him.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission has created the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) with the aim of mobilising funding in cooperation with the European Investment Bank (EIB), with the aim of investing in riskier projects in research, innovation, energy, transport and social infrastructure, education and science. It is stipulated that the Director-General is appointed by the EIB following the approval of the European Parliament. The Fund's Steering Board submitted to Parliament a proposal to appoint Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General. I supported the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments is one of the most important elements of the Investment Plan for Europe, the main objective of which is to stimulate long-term economic growth and competitiveness in the European Union. The fund's role is to use public funding to attract private investment more actively as a result. As the success and further development of the European Union's economy depends on the functioning of this fund, I support the appointment of a highly qualified professional, Mr Wilhelm Molterer, as Managing Director.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments is an important part of the package of measures aimed at boosting growth and jobs in the EU. The post of Managing Director of EFSI will be crucial for coping with all processes that, if successful, will lead to high added value. This function should therefore be performed by a person who is a first-class manager. I expected the Commission to require a thorough examination of the candidate's qualities – psychotests, management tests ... The actual hearing of the candidates could not provide us with a comprehensive view of the quality and abilities of the candidate. Such practices make me feel that this is purely a political nomination that carries risks. These risks fall on the shoulders of the Commission, which will bear full responsibility for the final outcome.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal to appoint the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, because I do not agree with this proposal.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to appoint Wilhelm Molterer as the new Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Molterer's acquired skills and professional experience are to be considered an added value towards the operation of the fund.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of wilhelm molterer being appointed Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, convinced that he can be our best representative in the challenge of EFSI to improve the competitiveness of the European Union, to relaunch innovation and to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. EFSI is an illusory project that is not feasible. Since the whole project must be rejected, I cannot support the proposed managing director either.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This vote concerns the appointment of the Director General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). There is only one candidate: the Austrian economist Whilhem Molterer was a member of the Austrian People's Party (OVP), the Austrian right-wing party that governed with the far-right FP-of-Haider in Haider's time. Miserable! I'm voting against it.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I congratulate Mr Wilhelm Molterer, EIB Vice-President since 2011, for his appointment as Executive Director, responsible for the day-to-day management of the EFSI, as well as the preparation and chair of the investment committee meetings. With this appointment, which has garnered broad support in the Committees on Budgets and Economic Affairs, we can begin financing the projects selected under the Juncker plan that meet the real needs of the economy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this nomination for the Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because I believe that Wilhelm Molterer is a good candidate for this position.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal to appoint the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The relevant parliamentary committees have approved the candidacy of Wilhelm Molterer, presented by the European Investment Bank. I voted in accordance with the opinion of these committees.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the appointment of the Managing Director of EFSI based on the evaluation and the discussion in the Budgets Committee.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I have abstained from voting in this candidacy, as I am extremely critical of the EFSI, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and have also voted against its establishment.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the appointment of a Managing Director as we do not support the EU’s EFSI programme or any post created for it. This ‘European Fund for Strategic Investment’ seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given my esteem for Wilhelm Molterer, I am convinced that he will do an excellent job as Director-General of EFSI and that he will make the most of its potential for a better Europe. Satisfied with your appointment, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The current state of the EU economy and the decline in investment compared to 2007 of around 15%, as well as the slow recovery due to insufficient investment momentum, have a negative impact on growth potential, productivity, employment and job creation. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is a key lever of the Juncker Investment Plan, but also of this term between the European Commission and Parliament in launching the European economy and further strengthening it. Appointing the heads of the Fund to manage €8 billion of the EU budget as a deposit for further investment, which, according to European Commission estimates, can provide an additional €330 billion to €410 billion and create 1 to 1.3 million new jobs, is a very important decision. I welcome and support this decision authorising the appointment of the Efsi Director by the European Parliament. I call on Mr Wilhelm Molterer to carry out his, at this time for the European economy, a crucial role. As chair of the Investment Committee, together with his colleagues, he is invited to select the best projects and to ensure that taxpayers' money in the Union is invested in those projects that will be sustainable and those that will contribute to the recovery of the economy to the fullest extent.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the EFSI Steering Committee on 2 October 2013 On 1 October 2015, the Commission for Budgets and the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee adopted a proposal for the appointment of the Director-General and Deputy Director-General of the EFSI and forwarded this proposal to the European Parliament, and whereas the Committee on Budgets and the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee held a keynote speech on 13 October 2015 and then answered questions from members of the , I support this proposal to appoint Mr. Molterer and wish him success in performing this extremely important function.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – The Director-General and Deputy Director-General of the EFSI shall be appointed by the EIB following the approval of the European Parliament and following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures, which shall be reported to the European Parliament in a timely and at all stages of the procedure.  On 13 October 2015, the Committee on Budgets and the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee held a hearing of Wilhelm Molterer, the proposed candidate for the post of Director-General of the EFSI, at which he gave a keynote address and then answered questions from committee members.  As I believe that the proposed candidate has demonstrated expertise, extensive experience and excellent knowledge of EFSI, I support the report of fellow MEPs Jean Arthuis and Robert Gualtieri on the proposal for the appointment of the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 7 of Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 provides for the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to be appointed by the EIB, subject to the approval of the European Parliament. The EFSI is the main mobilisation vehicle for at least EUR 315 billion of additional investment in the real economy over the next three years. This fund will finance projects with the aim of maximising the impact of public spending and unlocking private investment. The Fund will be set up within the framework of the European Investment Bank (EIB). I hope that, following today's vote, the new Director of EFSI, Wilhelm Molterer, will be able to start working as soon as possible to ensure that the EU is able to overcome the current economic difficulties by providing an immediate stimulus to the real economy.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This vote reflects the position of the ECON and BUDG committees of Parliament which approved this appointment in advance.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the proposal of the Governing Board of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) of 2 October 2015 on the appointment of its Executive Director, as well as the joint deliberations of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, made following the hearing of the proposed candidate to carry out those functions, I voted in favour of appointing Wilhelm Molterer to the post of Executive Director of the EFSI.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the appointment of a Managing Director as we do not support the EU’s EFSI programme or any post created for it. This ‘European Fund for Strategic Investment’ seeks to raise EUR 315 billion, but is based on taxpayers’ money being used as a guarantee and on wafer—thin assumptions on how much private businesses will put in. It is another grand EU project that will cost billions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the candidacy of Mr Wilhelm Molterer (Austria, EIB Vice-President since 2011) as Executive Director of the EFSI Steering Committee. It had already been auditioned and pre-selected by the parliamentary committees ECON and BUDG. Among other things, he will be responsible for the day-to-day management of the EFSI and the preparation and chair of the investment committee meetings.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Decision on the proposal for the appointment of the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, taking into account the proposal presented by the EFSI Governing Board on 2 October 2015 and the fact that the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer was based on an open and transparent selection process, in line with the procedures of the European Investment Bank.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to appoint Wilhelm Molterer as the new Director-General of EFSI as Article 7, paragraph 6 of Regulation (EU) No 2015/1017 provides that the Director-General of EFSI shall be appointed by the European Investment Bank (EIB), subject to the approval of the European Parliament, following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with EIB procedures and under the monitoring of the European Parliament.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Wilhelm Molterer and, despite his sufficient professional profile, I voted against him for his flirt with the Austrian People's Party and his continuing perspective.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the candidate for Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because of his political career, which is closely related to the European People's Party. His strong political ties to the Austrian People's Party are a clear sign of the political orientation that the candidate will print to the activity of the FEIE. His professional career within the EED implies the continuation of the line of work of the Bank, which during its management has approved projects such as Castor in Spain, which has generated so many problems. In addition, he was the only candidate presented by the Council, which is a procedure that leaves much to be desired for the democratic will expressed by the European Parliament. That's why I haven't been able to vote for him.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support addition of new EU posts or, therefore, this position.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support the decision to appoint Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as I believe that this fulfils the criteria for this function and is the appropriate candidate for this function through my qualifications.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. In view of Article 7(6) of regulation (EU) 2015/1017, the Director-General and Deputy Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments were appointed by the EIB following the consent of the European Parliament.  On 2 October 2015, the Board of Directors of the European Fund for Strategic Investments adopted a proposal for the appointment of the Director-General and Deputy Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and forwarded this proposal to the European Parliament.  On 13 October 2015, the Budget Committee and the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee held a hearing with Wilhelm Molterer, the proposed candidate for the post of Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, during which he presented the initial report and answered questions from the members of the Committee.  Following an open and transparent selection process in line with EIB procedures, during which the European Parliament must be informed in a timely way at all stages, I fully supported the proposal for the appointment of Wilhelm Molterer as Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. Even the best staffing of EFSI cannot make EFSI really help the economy and encourage investment and job creation. Efsi does not bring any new resources, it only redistributes existing ones. Any "achievements" of efsi will thus come solely at the expense of a corresponding reduction in investment in the private sector.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We consider the "election" of a person without co-candidates undemocratic.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament giving its consent to the appointment of the Executive Director of the European Fund For Strategic Investment. I have done so in the knowledge that some people have continued to raise questions about the candidate Mr Molterer, but it is in the primary interest that the management of the new fund, which is key to our plans to boost the European economy, can start its work and present proposals on the effective operation of the Fund without further delay. In the case of personal decisions to fill positions that wish to be politically agreed, I generally believe that the interest in promoting a common cause predates subjective aspects, and I have enforced this principle in the current vote.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Wilhelm Molterer's candidacy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report giving consent to the appointment of Mr Wilhelm Molterer for the position of Managing Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Wilhelm Molterer is a former Vice-President of the European Investment Bank (2011-2015), where he was responsible for cohesion and for advisory services. Before joining the EIB, he was a Member of the Austrian Parliament. He has been Vice—Chancellor and Finance Minister of Austria and Chairman of the Austrian People’s Party. Wilhelm Molterer has a degree and postgraduate qualifications in economics and social sciences from the University of Linz.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. – I supported Wilhelm Molterer's candidacy for the position of Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as I believe that the candidate has the qualifications and abilities required for this position. Namely, his many years of political experience during which he was Minister of Agriculture, Finance and Deputy Prime Minister of Austria brought him numerous political acquaintances, but also experience in areas related to finance.  Given that the main function of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is precisely to assume a certain risk related to the activities carried out by the European Investment Bank and the European Investment Fund, I believe that the Management Board has taken a logical decision by selecting Molterer as a candidate for this position since he was vice-president of the European Investment Bank and is directly familiar with this topic.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to appoint the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because Article 7(6) of Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 provides that the Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments shall be appointed by the European Investment Bank, with the prior approval of the European Parliament, on the basis of an open and transparent procedure in accordance with eib procedures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Wilhelm Molterer and, despite his sufficient professional profile, I voted against him for his flirt with the Austrian People's Party and his continuing perspective.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this nomination with the hope that he will behave independently from the interests of Member States. Europe does not need an EFSI that just continues business as usual building more airports without planes and high-speed trains without passengers.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the appointment of the Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Managing strategic developments in the coming years is a task requiring serious professional competence. I voted in favour of the committees.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The only candidate proposed has been Wilhelm Molterer and, despite his sufficient professional profile, I voted against him for his flirt with the Austrian People's Party and his continuing perspective.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report concerning the appointment of Managing Director of The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), in which we confirmed Mr Wilhelm Molterer for the position of Managing Director of the EFSI. The EFSI aims to overcome the current investment gap in the EU by mobilising private financing for strategic investments which the market cannot finance alone. It will support strategic investments in infrastructure as well as risk finance for small businesses. The fund will focus its financing on investments in infrastructure and innovation, as well as finance for SMEs, which are very important for the European economy. Therefore I believe the managing of this Fund should be done with great responsibility.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Director-General of EFSI, in accordance with Article 7 of the Rules of Procedure, is appointed by the EIB after approval by the European Parliament. This approval requires an open and transparent candidate selection procedure, which keeps Parliament informed promptly and at all stages. However, the Parliamentary Assembly has not taken part in this selective process in the slightest, other than to ratify decisions taken from above without any democratic consultation. Moreover, the newly elected Director-General Wilhelm Molterer is a member of the Austrian People's Party (member of the EPP) and is therefore a purely political figure, whose investiture serves only to pave the way for the implementation of the failed Juncker Plan.  The 5-Star Movement has always fought against the logic of power that achieves political objectives through the allocation of seats, without any democratic consultation. I have therefore chosen to vote against this appointment.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the candidate for Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments because of his political career, which is closely related to the European People's Party. His strong political ties to the Austrian People's Party are a clear sign of the political orientation that the candidate will print to the activity of the FEIE. His professional career within the EED implies the continuation of the line of work of the Bank, which during its management has approved projects such as Castor in Spain, which has generated so many problems. In addition, he was the only candidate presented by the Council, which is a procedure that leaves much to be desired for the democratic will expressed by the European Parliament. That's why I haven't been able to vote for him.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We have no principled opposition to the name that is proposed. We abstain because we disagree with this instrument and the operating standards associated with it. As it is set up, this investment fund will help to further widen the gap between richer and poorer regions. It is based on the principle of public-private partnerships that drain public resources and fatten the profits of large economic groups.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. EFSI is an illusory project that is not feasible. Since the whole project must be rejected, I cannot support the proposed managing director either.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for the appointment of the Director-General of EFSI, as set out in Article 7 of the EFSI Regulation, which provides for the Director-General and Deputy Director-General of EFSI to be appointed by the EIB, subject to the approval of the European Parliament (following an open and transparent selection procedure in accordance with eib procedures, during which the European Parliament should be duly informed) was voted on today. , in a timely manner, at all stages). In fact, the selection process has not been particularly clear, let alone transparent. On the substance, the candidate for Director-General is by no means sustainable as he will be a purely political figure who will guarantee only the continuation of the "business as usual".

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I would like to speak on a point concerning the preparation of a mandate for negotiations on a new global climate agreement. I ultimately supported the mandate, although some, in my opinion, the key amendments supported by my faction did not pass. I believe that a new treaty, which would be in force in 2020, is a necessity. On the other hand, I say here in advance that a treaty that will be adopted and binding should, firstly, set limits that are achievable, that are not only met by certain states and do not lead to European industry being less competitive or to remain competitive with the industries of other emerging or developed countries. This is, in my opinion, a very key criterion according to which I will assess the final form of the treaty. Furthermore, it is important that as many countries as possible sign the Treaty, especially third world countries, which are major polluters.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report to make Parliament stand firm by demanding legal obligations for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.  However, the European Union's position is not without paradoxes. How can we think that the market, and especially the financial market, can be the path to a sustainable society? How can we imagine that the same instrument that encourages infinite consumption and irresponsible investment can replace the State in the ecological transition? I cannot deny that I have doubts about the European Union's ability to implement the recommendations of this report in the face of the interests of wilder capitalism. I hope that this report will not be left alone in words.  Other policies do, but also another economic model, another way of life. Otherwise, the fight against climate change is lost in advance.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also want to comment on the mandate that we have approved today. I supported the vote with my vote. However, I am a little embarrassed that the position of the PPE has not been supported precisely in the area of the requirement that Europe should not be alone in its proposals, so that there is global agreement between the widest possible number of UN Member States on the limits that will be globally valid. It is simply not possible for some Member States to assume commitments that others will not accept and thus gain a competitive advantage, even if, of course, in relation to our fate, they do not treat our future responsibly. We must find an international consensus that does not exclude European businesses from competition, which Is what I wanted to ask.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Global climate change, i.e. changes in regional temperature dynamics at global level, more severe droughts and floods, as well as a number of other natural disasters, make it clear that such processes cannot simply be written off to natural changes, as it would otherwise take at least a hundred years, rather than decades, if not less. Although there are already a whole series of international documents in the world relating to countries' efforts to positively influence climate change, the Kyoto Protocol is one of the best known, the actions currently being implemented cannot be classified as truly effective. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, increasing the production and use of renewable energy sources and technological developments all show that it is imperative that we think about climate change. I voted in favour.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I finally supported the European Parliament's common position on the climate agreement.  For me, this agreement is proof that the European Union has the will to go against climate change, which means, among other things, warming and subsequent ecological and economic impacts, on all continents. That is why Europe can lead by example, but unfortunately Europe alone will not reverse these developments. That is why I have also supported the proposals that are turning to the world's big emitters to take equally ambitious measures. Unfortunately, these proposals have not been adopted. I fully support the attempt to conclude a legally binding treaty for all to replace the Kyoto Protocol, but which would not jeopardise the competitiveness of the European economy. I also appreciate that our report relates to Pope Francis' encyclical "Laudato si", which has the apt subtitle "On the care of a common home", which criticises consumer society and irresponsible development and calls for swift and unified global action.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires legal obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions rather than non-binding commitments which are unfortunately the usual rule in this area. However, I believe that privileging its implementation through market instruments and, in particular, the financial market is incompatible with the commitment to effectively reduce emissions. On the contrary, these will accelerate the breakdown of the traditional productive fabric, without guaranteeing in any case a transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. That is why I doubt the European Union's ability to implement the recommendations of this report or to combine them with its commitment to neoliberal policies.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. A new protocol on climate change will be negotiated at the United Nations COP 21 Climate Change Conference in Paris from 7 to 12 December 2015. The agreed resolution gives the European Parliament delegation the mandate to negotiate; among other things, Parliament is proposing a climate fund for the trading of emission allowances, financed by Member States and by the taxation of exhaust gases from international aviation and shipping. I deliberately voted in favour of the resolution here in order to give Europe a strong position towards other partners, to encourage them to make equal efforts. However, I am also in favour of an ambitious and, above all, mandatory reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is in line with the right path of climate change. Once again, it is a question of distilling fear by using global warming as a pretext, a warming that is greatly exaggerated and whose human origins are not scientifically proven at all. The consequence of this climate alarmism is the deindustrialization of Europe, which de facto leads to an increase in imports and thus the navigation of large cargo ships hungry for fuel... The hypocrisy is obvious but, as a result of several years of ideological and pseudo-scientific bludgeoning on the part of the IPCC in particular, no one dares to take it away, except for a few courageous scientists and a few journalists.  What about these countries, which, like the United States, say they are concerned about the climate and impose international constraints that they themselves do not respect?  These great climate masses are sources of colossal waste in the service of globalism. Today, we no longer teach the defence of the homeland, but the defence of the climate and the need for global governance! I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, because the targets set will have a massive negative impact upon the economies of the nation states which are members of the European Union. The EU accounts for just 12% of global CO2 emissions; the UK for just 2%. Unilateral action will not impact upon the global concentration of CO2 in any meaningful way, but it will have a significant impact upon the economy.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change is a present and real problem which can be addressed only by a joint international effort. The previous agreements such as Kyoto proved to be effective to some extent – especially in the case of Europe, which despite the steady GDP growth has reduced its emission levels by 19% since 1990.  However, as a result of the new—growing economies in the East and other world economic activity, overall emission levels in the world have doubled and the costs of inaction might be very high. Therefore, I very much support this resolution’s call for an ambitious, global and binding agreement. It is time to reconsider the action plan which could help mitigate climate change.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which sets out a mandate for the Delegation of the European Parliament to the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris at the end of the year. I support the calls for binding targets to combat the effects of climate change: a 40% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2030, a 30% reduction in energy from renewable sources and a 40% increase in energy efficiency. The EU's climate policy needs to be intensified as it meets the eu's ceiling for a 80-95% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. Measures to combat climate change need to be reviewed by 2020 in line with the latest scientific assessments. In 2015, the EU and its Member States should agree on a plan to contribute in good faith to the commitment to allocate EUR 100 billion by 2020. US dollars to fight climate change. It is important to use additional sources of funding to defer part of the placing on the market of allowances or to generate revenues from the control of pollutants in the aviation and shipping sectors.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Bad tools for bad decisions to avoid challenging globalist dogmas. Yet it is the globalist ideology that is killing our planet.  The proposals are counterproductive and harmful: they only move low-polluting production to less standardised countries, encourage globalisation (always more trade, therefore transport... emissions) and remove Europe's industrial and therefore economic power.   If we want to save our ecosystem, we must first relocate our economies: this is a prerequisite. Errare humanum is, perseverare diabolicum.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the run-up to COP 21 in Paris at the beginning of December 2015, Parliament stresses, through this resolution I have approved, the extreme importance and seriousness of the threats caused by climate change and is concerned that the international community is significantly de departing from the way forward in limiting global warming to a rise of 2oC above pre-industrial levels.  In particular, the rapporteur calls on the EU and its Member States to work with all civil society actors to develop initiatives in key sectors for warming mitigation and calls on companies to accept and actively exercise their responsibilities and to promote support for the climate agreement.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on a new international climate agreement in Paris drawn up by the associated committees within Parliament. On the other hand, I voted against my group's line on two amendments. The first is Amendment No 5 to paragraph 10, which supported the PPE Group's amendment which underlines the importance of an effective and binding global agreement at the Paris Conference, and notes that continuing to lack such an agreement will further jeopardize the competitiveness of the Union's economy and expose it to the risk of carbon leakage. On the other hand, I abstained in the vote on Amendment No 4 of the PPE Group as it did not agree with its content, just as it was not with the content of the original text of the report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to determine the European Parliament's position for the 21st Conference of the Parties on Climate Change. The Pargneaux report wants a universal and binding target and $100 billion a year in funding for developing countries. Efforts must be made through more global rules, which still disproportionately burden those who have the most, on Europeans. The proposed measures contribute to de-industrialisation of Europe for even more import and globalization encouraged by the United States, which hopes to take advantage of European deindustrialization. I voted against this text and these harmful proposals which only move low-polluting production to less standardised countries, encourage globalisation and remove Europe from its industrial and therefore economic power.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Pargneaux report on the prospects for the new international climate agreement in Paris is overly optimistic and does not take account of the reality of the facts and the results achieved so far. I therefore did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament is actively involved in European policy in the fight against climate change. The European Parliament recalls that it will have to give its consent to the ratification by the European Union of a legally binding agreement adopted at the Paris Conference. The European Parliament will therefore have to participate fully in the coordination meetings held at the Paris Conference. The Contribution of the European Union must inspire other countries to ensure clarity, transparency and the achievement of objectives. The success of the European Union (it reduced emissions by 19% between 1990 and 2012 and its GDP increased by 45%), and the fact that the EU's emissions account for an ever smaller share of global emissions shows that climate change mitigation is compatible with economic development.  The European Union must continue its diplomatic efforts and increase them in order to better understand the positions of partner countries, to encourage these countries to implement ambitious climate change policies and to build alliances to achieve this objective. Whether the commitments made by the Parties to the Paris Agreement will be implemented will also depend on the efforts of non-state actors such as cities, regions, industry and investors. The Paris Conference must send a clear signal to these actors to encourage them to take action, including international recognition of their efforts.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The upcoming International Climate Conference in Paris is undoubtedly one of the main international events of this year, and as before all climate conferences so far, there are high expectations of the policies adopted. The proposed report, which I supported, in my opinion, represents an ambitious starting point for the negotiations on the climate agreement that the European Parliament is setting for the negotiators.  Last year, in a resolution on recommendations for a future comprehensive EU policy on climate change, the latter called for the achievement of the following targets by 2030: reducing greenhouse gas concentrations by 40%, improving energy efficiency to 40% and increasing the share of renewable energy sources to 30% of all energy sources. With the resolution on the upcoming Climate Conference in Paris, he made a clear position to achieve these objectives and remained in the position that these remain binding.  Of course, achieving these goals will require a great deal of adjustment to the world's economy or the world's largest emitters - the US, China and the EU, as well as growing economies. Only then will it be possible, in my opinion, to achieve a long-term temperature increase of less than 2°C compared to pre-industrial levels. I sincerely hope that all participants in the Paris climate conference will be aware of their responsibilities and that they will reach a sufficiently ambitious agreement for a cleaner future.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 We are only a few weeks away from the twenty-first Conference of the Parties in Paris, an event for which we have been preparing for a long time and from which important results are expected. The fight against climate change is the challenge of our century. I fully agree with this statement and with the content of this resolution. Mr Pargneaux's report has relaunched high and ambitious targets for the EU, consistent with the desire to keep climate change below 2°C.  These include the reduction of greenhouse gases by 2050 (reduction of 85-90%), their reduction of at least 40% in 2030 and an increase in the share of renewables to at least 30% for the same year. An energy and climate policy of this kind also offers important opportunities in terms of economic growth, employment and improving the purchasing power of the 500 million European citizens we represent.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The report "towards a new international climate agreement in Paris" presents the wrong tools for bad decisions in order to avoid challenging globalist dogmas and weakening the power of Member States. So I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe that the climate crisis must be tackled decisively before the changes it has brought about become irreversible. It is also important for the European Union, the world's leading economy, to put itself at the head of this movement with conviction, in order to achieve concrete results.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris International Climate Conference (COP21) is one of the most important moments for establishing the points of a legally binding agreement in the fight against climate change. Our main objective, highlighted in the report by my Socialist colleague Gilles Pargneaux, is to combat global warming. It is therefore necessary to increase energy efficiency and energy saving, to increase renewable energy sources and to eliminate greenhouse gases completely. We must continue along the path towards a gradual but complete elimination of fossil fuels and introduce a funding package to support the fight against global warming. It is clear that the EU alone cannot solve the problem, but it can make a very significant contribution and, at the same time, by setting a good example, it can push other countries in the same direction. The EU has always been at the forefront of combating climate change and can continue to be so, in order to protect the environment in which we live and in which our children will live.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to determine the positioning of the European Union at the 21st climate conference in Paris. Tackling global warming is one of the key challenges facing governments in the 21st century. To combat climate change, the Commission had already adopted a measure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% between 1990 and 2030. It is clear that the Member States of the Union are far from having achieved their objectives in this area, since France is only at -13% while the Union is at -18%. As usual, the European authorities want to strengthen the constraints and environmental standards that weigh on our companies in order to achieve their delusional objectives. This policy is helping to de-industrialize our continent for the benefit of the less environmentally conscious emerging countries and the United States, which see it as an opportunity to increase their competitiveness. From an ecological point of view, this policy is counterproductive, as the increase in imports to Europe as a result of these relocations increases CO2 emissions. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Climate change is currently a global threat that requires urgent attention and potentially irreversible to human societies and the biosphere. In this context, there is a need as quickly as possible to address this issue at international level. Moreover, the seriousness of the threats to climate change should be a primary concern, especially since the planet is far from limiting global warming below 2 degrees Celsius relative to pre-industrial levels. Governments must take concrete and binding measures to combat climate change and act in favour of achieving an extremely ambitious and legally binding agreement in Paris in 2015. I voted in favour of the report on a new international agreement in Paris on climate change because the Paris Conference is not just a test meeting, but a decision-making meeting, and this conference symbolizes a decisive step in negotiating a new global climate agreement, which will enter into force in 2020.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. One-sided approach, emphasis on new global funding instruments, from sorcerer's apprentices of globalised finance, emphasis on the recognition of climate refugee status. The EU's climate policy is catastrophic.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The scenario of triggering a race to procure the most basic resources can become a reality in the near future if we do not implement concrete policies to combat climate change. I welcome the idea of a new international agreement on climate change, which will become effective and immediately applicable by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and keeping temperatures below 2°C. Imposing restrictions on the emission of pollutants from states that have not had the same economic start as those that have been through the Industrial Revolution is a constantly debated theme. To what extent, however, can we create progress if we do not have the resources and an environment in which to develop the economy? The answer can only be given through the circular and sustainable economy, as we have a moral duty to keep the planet functioning for future generations. I believe that there is a need for global solidarity in order to achieve a new agreement on climate change and to take decisions taken without delay. I therefore support the Pargneaux report on the proposed international agreement in Paris on climate change.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The International Climate Conference, or COP 21, will be held in Paris in December. The aim of this conference is to put in place a new agreement that will have to be respected by all the countries of the world, in order to keep global warming below 2 degrees Celsius.  The environmental situation we find ourselves in requires immediate action. We need to reduce our emissions of polluting gases in order to limit the harmful effects on the planet. However, we must ensure that this objective goes hand in hand with the European Union's growth, competitiveness and employment objectives. I voted in favour of this report. I stress, however, that pragmatism and realism are required in the implementation of these objectives.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the new international climate agreement to be adopted in Paris. Effective measures need to be found to counter alarming signs of climate change such as rising temperatures, melting glaciers and floods.  The EU and its Member States have committed themselves to jointly meeting a binding target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, compared to 1990, by at least 40% by 2030. These objectives are heading in the right direction, but they should be more ambitious. In fact, the Paris Conference represents the beginning of a dynamic and evolutionary process that will allow the international community to take corrective measures to realign itself with the trajectory necessary to keep the rise in temperatures below 2 °C. The Union must pursue an effective policy with a view to an energy transition to be implemented by 2050, through climate and energy policy instruments and with the involvement of other sectors, such as transport, research, innovation or development cooperation. The European Union's contribution must be a model for all other nations, in terms of clarity, transparency and ambition, and that is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which outlines Parliament’s position towards the UN conference on Climate Change to be held in Paris in December.  The challenge of COP 21 is delivering a new global climate agreement involving all countries by 2015, giving a renewed commitment after the Kyoto Protocol. This resolution was an effort to give vigour to the negotiating positions of the Commission and Council as representatives of EU Member States.  The report gives an inclusive view of the role of civil society, the respect of human rights and indigenous persons’ rights and all targets are foreseen in the attempt to limit the global rise in temperature below 2oC.

name: James CARVER
