text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%. The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the international community should set common goals to combat climate change. The resolution sets out ambitious goals and contains comprehensive solutions and guidelines to help us reach an agreement at the Paris conference. It aims to underscore the EU’s ambitious and central role at the Conference and to push for progress towards an international agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I was pleased to vote in favour of my colleague's report, which was ambitious on the objectives to be set at the climate conference scheduled for the end of the year in Paris. The European Union is called upon to play a strong role, without which our planet is in danger of succumbing to attacks from both overseas and from emerging economies.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. Mr Pargneaux's report aims to achieve a universal and binding target of $100 billion a year in funding for developing countries. I believe that the proposals contained in this report are counterproductive and harmful, because they only move low-polluting production to less standardised countries, encouraging globalisation and taking Europe's industrial, and therefore economic, power away from Europe. So I voted against this report.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change is nothing less than an existential threat. Climate change is affecting and will increasingly continue to affect every aspect of our lives, our well—being, our health, our economy and the  ecosystems we depend on for survival. In Ireland alone, our sea levels are rising on average about 3.5 cm per decade, we are facing more frequent and more serious sea storms, we face wetter autumn and winter seasons, leading to floods, and drier summers, leading to water shortages. We are more exposed to UV light than we have even been, the depletion of ozone will drastically increase the incidence of all types of skin cancer.  The impact of climate change and its causes on our health is already evident. Where there is high air pollution, a greater number of children are admitted into hospitals with lung problems, the quality of the water which we drink has decreased considerably. We urgently need a binding agreement, showing international collective responsibility, to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions.  We are at serious risk of failure in averting dangerous and potentially catastrophic climate change.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 There is great anticipation for the International Climate Conference, an extremely important event for the protection of the biosphere. It's hard not to related global warming in recent decades to the rise of extreme weather events. Last week there was heavy rain in my region, which caused rivers to overflow, devastating entire urban centres, an apocalyptic landscape to which we are not accustomed, and it was not the only Italian region to suffer serious damage. Reaching a legally binding global climate agreement is no longer a wish but a necessity and a commitment that no one should shy away from. The European Parliament, as requested by the report in favour of which I voted, arrives at COP21 with a clear, unified and unequivocal position: halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, increasing energy from renewable sources by 30% by 2030 and energy efficiency by 40%. Europe has long been a world leader in the fight against climate change and has set strict emission limits for Member States. The major international competitors must now make the same commitments if we are to avoid the serious and concrete risk of seeing massive climate migrations soon.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly points out that the EU is on track to meet its targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and renewable energy by 2020. It is stressed that a significant improvement has been achieved in terms of the intensity of energy use thanks to more efficient buildings, products, industrial processes and vehicles, while the European economy has been growing by 45% since 1990. It is also stressed that the 20-20-20 targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy and energy saving have played a key role in promoting this process and maintaining employment.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the International Climate Agreement to be negotiated at the UNITED Nations Climate Conference to be held in Paris from 30 November to 11 December 2015. Climate change is one of the main challenges facing humanity. In March, the EU and its Member States pledged to jointly meet a binding target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the EU by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990. However, these targets should be more ambitious.  The Paris Agreement must be universal and legally relevant. On the financial side, $100 billion is expected to be transferred annually to developing countries to help them pay for greenhouse gas reductions between now and 2020. With this proposal, the European Parliament calls for an intensification of discussions at intra-European level, with a view to agreeing a common position, and recalls that it will have to give its approval to the Union's ratification of the legally binding agreement resulting from the Paris Conference. Parliament should therefore participate fully in the coordination meetings during the Paris Conference.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because global warming is one of the greatest challenges facing humanity in the areas of sustainable development, health and the world economy. Rising temperatures, melting glaciers, increasing droughts and floods are all signs of ongoing climate change. Climate change requires an urgent, responsible and global response based on the solidarity of the international community. Furthermore, in order to strengthen the European Union's position in international negotiations, the European Parliament must defend the need to set ambitious and realistic targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, increase the share of renewable energy up to 45% of the energy mix and achieve energy savings of 40% , and at the Paris Conference, the parties do not meet to try to do something, but to take decisions. Finally, I am convinced that the Paris Agreement will be ambitious, universal and legally binding in order to provide a long-term response to the climate challenge, although the European Union should step up diplomatic efforts to better understand the positions of partner countries, encourage them to implement ambitious policies to combat climate change and forge alliances in favour of this ambition.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%.  The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Climate change requires an urgent, responsible and global response based on the solidarity of the international community. Climate warming represents one of humanity's greatest challenges to sustainable development, health and the world economy. The European Union and its Member States are committed to jointly meeting a binding greenhouse gas emission reduction target of at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990. However, I believe that we should have more ambitious targets and the European Parliament should advocate a greenhouse gas reduction of 50% by 2030 compared to 1990, and increase the share of renewable energy to 45% of the energy mix, achieving 40% energy savings. I support the need for the Paris agreement to be global, ambitious and legally binding in order to provide a long-term response to the challenges of climate change. On the other hand, the European Union should complete as soon as possible the process of ratifying the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and encourage the other parties to do the same so that it can enter into force quickly. That is why I support The Report by Gilles Pargneaux.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because of the urgent need for action. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 is imperative for me; it is therefore important that climate finance commitments are increased in Paris at the end of the year.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%.  The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 A stable climate system is key to ensuring water supply, sanitation, food security, biodiversity maintenance, as well as world peace and prosperity. Unfortunately, especially in recent years, the increase in global warming is causing invaluable damage to terrestrial and marine ecosystems, such as melting glaciers, drought, floods, etc. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to act urgently and without delay at world level, with binding and concrete measures and with the sharing of good practices. Firstly, calling on all Member States to work with all civil society actors (institutions, the private sector, NGOs and local communities) to implement national strategies on decarbonisation, and on the transformation of the energy sector by 2050, taking corrective measures to keep the rise in temperatures below 2°C. , capacity building, scientific research, technological development and innovation will play an essential role in reaching an agreement at the Paris Conference.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Contains a legally binding 2015 protocol that should aim to phase out global carbon emissions by 2050; a 50% reduction target binding on the EU in 2030 in order to stay on track for the reference of minus 2°C; a binding EU energy efficiency target of 40% for 2030; a binding EU target for 2030 to produce at least 45% of final energy consumption from renewable sources; the importance of the EU playing an ambitious and central role at the conference by encouraging other parties to take effective measures to maintain compliance with the objective of - 2° C. Supported all compromise amendments, except the ETS amendment, COMP 18, which welcomes the current ETS system and encourages the Commission to promote links between the ETS and other global emission systems.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the EU's position on the UN climate conference in Paris in December. Rising temperatures, droughts, floods and natural disasters are challenging not only in Europe but also globally. Experts on the subject say that we are facing irreversible environmental and natural changes if we do not prevent a global temperature rise of 2 degrees Celsius. The Paris Climate Change Conference in November and the agreement adopted there have an more important role to play than ever before. At the 21st climate change conference in a row, the European Union must take an ambitious position in the negotiations, which I agree is the only way to change the current negative processes. European environment ministers adopted the EU's greenhouse gas emission reduction commitments in March this year. Adequate financial support from developing countries, as set out in the report, is important in order to allow the regions concerned to take the path of environmentally conscious economic development using new technologies. Attention should also be paid to the financing of projects to protect communities exposed to climate change. A much more ambitious emission reduction agreement must be reached in Paris than before. Stronger joint action than ever is needed in the fight against climate change. The ratification by the European Union of a legally binding agreement as a result of the Paris Conference will also require the ep's agreement.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change is a global problem with grave implications, both on the environment and on the economy. Its worst impact is being felt by the most vulnerable and poorer countries, although technological advances could help, and we have the strength and power to change things. So, climate change calls for an urgent, responsible and global response, based on solidarity among the international community. In this sense, the EU is the key player fighting for a really ambitious and legally binding global agreement, therefore, I believe that the EU must speak out loud and clear to ensure a successful conference in Paris. The Paris Conference must be a meeting at which real decisions are taken to make sure that the world gets back on track to keep the average global temperature below 2 degrees. That is why I gave my strong support for this ambitious report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union must continue and intensify its diplomatic efforts to better understand the positions of partner countries, to encourage these countries to implement ambitious policies to fight climate change and to form alliances in favour of this ambition.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report outlines the mandate of the European Parliament delegation, which will travel to Paris from 30 November to 11 December as part of the COP21 climate conference negotiations. Supporting the goal of limiting global warming to 2oC compared to the pre-industrial era, the rapporteur advocates a reduction of at least 40% in greenhouse gas emissions, 40% in energy efficiency and a 30% share of renewable energy by 2030. The report also calls for a binding agreement and a regular review of state commitments. It also makes proposals to feed the Green Fund, an annual envelope of 100 billion euros to help developing countries transition to a low-carbon economy. Considering that the European Parliament must send a strong message in favour of reducing global warming at the Paris conference, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this text, because the new climate agreement must be ambitious, universal and legally binding. In particular, we want to encourage all financial actors to redirect their investments to finance a real transition to low-carbon economies. It is important that the European Union speaks out and gives the guidelines to make this conference in Paris a success.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. France will host and chair the 21st Conference of the Parties to the 2015 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21/CMP11), also known as "Paris 2015," from November 30 to December 11, 2015. This is a crucial deadline, as it must lead to a new international climate agreement. In this sense, I voted for the Pargneaux report, because I hope that we will get a binding international agreement for as many people as possible, and in particular for the most emitting countries. But this agreement will have to be realistic. Indeed, just because there will be an agreement in Paris does not mean that we have found the solution to climate change and its attendant disturbances (floods, hurricanes, droughts) that we are seeing more and more frequently. In addition, I think it is important not to stigmatize certain sectors, such as agriculture. On the contrary, we must work together to find viable solutions. This summit can only be considered a success if we get concrete solutions and binding commitments.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. As the climate conference (COP21) approaches, the European Parliament is voting on yet another attempt to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  The introduction of ever more stringent emission targets de facto results in a shift of these emissions to countries less concerned with these rules, such as China, India or the United States, and ultimately generates much higher pollution. Moreover, the share of pollution attributable to trade and trade is not addressed, another untouchable dogma. While Europe's economic competitors (who are among the world's leading polluters) welcome this self-limitation of Europeans, developing countries also continue to contribute to a situation for which only Europeans are considered responsible. This ecological repentance is not beneficial to our economy or to solving the real problems of polluting emissions. I therefore voted against this report, which is part of a mistake that the Union repeats at every climate mass, that Europe could encourage emerging economies to prioritise ecology before economic development.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 As regards this report, I have decided to abstain from voting on the resolution as a whole. At the same time, I support several of the compromises reached. My view is that the various aspects related to the unrealistically high 2030 targets, as well as the mortgage of public money for the Green Climate Fund (GCF), are not only unattainable, but also harmful to the economies of the Member States.  The Paris Protocol is not a problem here. This is about setting realistic and achievable targets for all EU countries. I do not see the serious economic and industrial issues that countries such as Poland and Bulgaria are struggling with on a daily basis, to be reflected in this report, and in order to achieve a good report, they are key.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against because, although the text contains many positive elements, it welcomes the carbon trading scheme, which we are opposed to.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I see that, with the resolution on the table, the European Parliament is sending a clear message to the Paris climate negotiations. The Union has made a firm commitment, which requires significant sacrifices from European economies. However, I expect – and this requirement is included in the text of parliament's resolution – that all the developed and developing economies on Earth will take the same step. We must not allow exceptions to this. As proposed by the Group of the European People's Party and the Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. I also agree with the need to reach an ambitious and legally binding global agreement at the Paris climate conference and to advocate reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030, increase energy efficiency by 40% and renewable energy sources by 30%. A stable climate system enabling food security, energy production, water and sanitation, infrastructure, as well as the preservation of biodiversity and terrestrial and marine ecosystems, peace and prosperity in the world is essential. It recalls that climate change accelerates biodiversity loss. It should be noted that between 2008 and 2013, 166 million people were forced to leave their homes due to floods, storms, earthquakes or other disasters, adding that climate-related developments in some parts of Africa may help exacerbate the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Climate change poses a global threat to human societies and to the maintenance of biodiversity and terrestrial and marine ecosystems, resulting in the loss of human lives and migratory flows, as well as economic, environmental and social damage. This must be tackled at international level. A comprehensive, ambitious and legally binding agreement is an important step in the process of combating climate change and the threats it poses, and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Climate change affects the entire planet. If we do not do something to stop climate change, the world in which we live will change irretrievably and the way of life that we have taken for granted will also change. The representatives of developed countries and parts of the world, such as the European Union, must contribute more to changing this alarming situation, because climate change is caused by the way people live, especially in richer countries with developed economies. I therefore support the actions of the European Commission, which adopted the communication entitled 'The Paris Protocol – the concept of combating global climate change post-2020', which is part of the European Union's preparations for the last round of negotiations before the 21st United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris. The European Union must be ambitious in the Paris negotiations and reject any compromise and reach a consensus with its partners and adopt an agreement that makes a fundamental contribution to climate change. I firmly believe that, if an acceptable agreement is reached, the European Parliament will give its consent to such an agreement.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report unfortunately continues with the unsuccessful approach of emphasising new global funding instruments, emphasising the recognition of 'climate refugee' status and, in general, myopic EU climate policies.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the new international climate agreement in Paris. Although the report contains many positive elements, it welcomes the carbon trading scheme, to which I am opposed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ We are all aware of the fact that climate change is a reality: around the world, the impacts of climate change are accelerating, and the most vulnerable countries are already paying the higher price. Last September, the conclusions of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change were published, and the debate about the human influence on the climate is now over: we are responsible for warming the earth. Luckily, next November is rapidly approaching. We have never had a better opportunity than the upcoming COP21 to tackle the tremendous danger of climate change. This is the greatest challenge that we must face: we must face it with the greatest ambition.  Next November, in Paris, not only the European citizens, but more than 7 billion people will ask us to be brave and our choices to be bold. They will ask us to go beyond our differences and our doubts, and to chart a new course together. Much has to be done in Paris, but if we are able to make the climate agreement a reality, our generation will not be remembered as the one that destroyed the world, but as the one who finally came to respect it.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Pargneaux report because it represents strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution entitled 'Towards the achievement in Paris of a new international climate agreement', which was adopted with a view to the TWENTY-FIRST Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21), because I believe that at a crucial event it is essential for the European Parliament to reaffirm the value of a final agreement in Paris.  The EU occupies a very important place in the negotiations and already made its contribution last March. It has taken a clear stand on its commitments to a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions in the EU by 2030. It is therefore a question of defending this position and of committing ourselves to taking binding decisions. The European Parliament believes that very important steps have been taken and that the objectives are heading in the right direction. However, they must be more ambitious, particularly on the financial aspects. I therefore hope that the Paris Agreement will be based on principles of fairness and joint but differentiated responsibility, on the basis of their respective capacities and taking into account national circumstances, and that it will be a legally binding agreement and therefore designed to provide a long-term response to the climate challenge for the coming decades.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have voted in favour of the request. Climate change can become a threat to the international community as a whole. At the moment, it is not yet clear to what extent the changes in climate change are to be reversed. It is precisely for this reason that it is all the more important that the existing negative changes are limited as much as possible. This requires rapid and joint action by all states at international level. In particular, the largest emitters of greenhouse gases must be held more accountable. The agreements to be reached in Paris must be legally binding and show a clear will to protect the global climate. Europe has already agreed on initial objectives in this context and is setting an international example. It is now important that the negotiations at the Paris climate conference are well prepared and that the results go beyond mere lip service. I agreed to these demands by today's decision.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because it raises the need for the EU to devote more economic and technological resources to the fight against climate change, as well as to establish and strengthen legally binding commitments in Paris to reduce EMISSIONs of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. However, although the report has an impact on the problem that transport-produced CO2 emissions have continued to grow, it does not introduce any criticism of free trade or TTE, and leaves everything in the hands of the development of clean transport technologies. As for the defence of CO2 emissions trading, it is a system that in my opinion generates a new economic bubble with the sale of emissions bonds and which is creating ineffective in meeting the objectives with which it was theoretically born, which is why we have spoken out against this system.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Giving up coal as a source of electricity by 2030 would help to considerably limit global warming. But the targets imposed in relation to the elimination of energy from coal are too steep, and Member States whose industry relies heavily on coal production will suffer both economically and in employment. A programme of gradual reduction of both fossil fuels and coal as a source of electricity should be initiated, while a retrofitting to reduce emissions should be initiated. At the same time, there is no flexibility for Member States to determine their own combination of different types of energy according to specific conditions.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group, voted in favour of this report as climate change is one of the most serious challenges of our time both for the environment and the economy.  Climate change is international in nature and calls for an urgent, global response. This must be based on solidarity among the international community. The Paris Conference must be a meeting at which real decisions are taken to make sure that the world gets back on track to keep the average global temperature below 2°C.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. I hope that the Paris Agreement will be as binding as possible, for the benefit of our environment, our citizens and the competitiveness of our companies on the international stage. When we know that the European Union accounts for only 10% of global CO2 emissions, this forces us to address the climate problem in a comprehensive way. This conference should be an opportunity to support new low-carbon technologies by identifying them and facilitating their deployment and investment. Companies developing these technologies therefore have a key role to play in the implementation of such an international agreement: they are the ones that will carry out innovative projects to reduce emissions. They must therefore be fully associated with this great climate conference. The private sector needs to be particularly engaged.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the resolution ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. This resolution calls for an ambitious, legally binding and comprehensive global agreement with economy-wide reduction targets. It underlines that the agreement should have a long-term mitigation objective in line with scientific findings. It underlines that the agreement must contain a 5-year review process that enables a progressive strengthening of the agreement. Therefore, based on these grounds I voted for this resolution.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 This December, not only will the TRADITIONAL ANNUAL UNITED NATIONS Climate Change Conference take place. Paris means so much more than that. The world is facing a historic step. With the resolution before us, the European Parliament is sending a clear message to the Paris negotiations. The Union has made a firm commitment, which requires significant sacrifices from European economies. Now in the developed and developing world it is your turn to follow this example. As a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I was pleased to support the reference to the Encyclopedia Laudato Si' as part of the resolution.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report addresses important issues ahead of the Paris climate conference in December 2015, which is expected to see a new international climate agreement. Topics include the EU's contribution to reducing emissions to the importance of climate diplomacy. Although the ECR shadow rapporteur has signed 14 of the 20 compromise amendments (on issues such as the recognition of human rights in climate policy and the importance of predictable Green Climate Fund Investment), I have chosen to abstain because some of the issues have proved unacceptable to my PARTY ALFA. Nevertheless, the ALFA members wanted to be constructive and communicate their position more clearly to the outside world. That is why we have requested two separate votes. The first part relates to the increase in the EU 2030 targets agreed by the European Council in October 2014. We voted against increasing the targets agreed by the Member States. However, we voted in favour of linking the European emissions trading system with other emissions trading schemes in order to reduce the potential risks of relocation effects. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because it raises the need for the EU to devote more economic and technological resources to the fight against climate change, as well as to establish and strengthen legally binding commitments in Paris to reduce EMISSIONs of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. However, although the report has an impact on the problem that transport-produced CO2 emissions have continued to grow, it does not introduce any criticism of free trade or TTE, and leaves everything in the hands of the development of clean transport technologies. As for the defence of CO2 emissions trading, it is a system that in my opinion generates a new economic bubble with the sale of emissions bonds and which is creating ineffective in meeting the objectives with which it was theoretically born, which is why we have spoken out against this system.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The threats induced by climate change are serious and we must be concerned that the world is far from being on track to limit global warming. A stable climate system  is important for food security, energy production, water and sanitation, and the preservation of biodiversity and terrestrial and marine ecosystems.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the road to a new international climate agreement in Paris, as global climate change is a pressing problem for all humanity and requires all parties at international level to be involved in its urgent resolution.  The EU, all Member States, civil society, institutions, the private sector, NGOs and local communities need to work together to meet greenhouse gas emission reduction targets in key sectors such as energy, technology, transport, etc. In addition to emissions, this international agreement also adopts many other ambitious objectives, and therefore, in order to achieve them, the key role in achieving it will be the envisaged means of implementation. Therefore, I support this report, which calls on Member States and the EU to prepare as efficient and quality a financial package as possible for the period before and after 2020.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. On the pretext that a global response to global warming must be given, the European institutions are out-of-the-art by targeting industry. The remedies devised propose, for example, to direct investment towards so-called less polluting activities, contributing to the deindustrialisation of Europe and de facto leading to an increase in imports (what about the pollution of cargo ships criss-crossing the seas?) Also, we ignore an essential reality, the fact that the biggest polluters (notably the United States) are far behind the EU. And that's where the problem lies. Indeed, an issue as serious as the climate has unfortunately become, in the game of global competition, a weapon of mass deindustrialization of Europeans.  The only global climate undertaking that would be valid and fair would be an agreement on measured targets for pollution per capita and a relocation process that would respond to this crazy race for free trade. It is unfortunate that such a line is never proposed. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%.  The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gilles Pargneaux's report on the Paris climate conference. The text calls for an ambitious and legally binding climate agreement, stressing the important role that the EU must play, speaking in a united voice and encouraging other participants to take the necessary steps to remain within the 2oC temperature increase limit. The success of this climate conference is indeed essential to prevent climate change from taking a dramatic turn, the consequences of which we would pay for in the future if States do not take their responsibilities today. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In the interests of the global climate, it would be absolutely desirable to conclude a binding agreement in Paris, which would in fact be ratified and respected by all the signatories. However, the proposals from the US and China are formulated in such a way that they themselves hardly have to take any measures. The same applies to other major polluters, such as Saudi Arabia, which has not put forward any proposals at all. In these circumstances, it seems difficult for the EU to unilaterally maintain very strict commitments without losing competitiveness.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the report. Climate change is one of the most serious challenges of our time both for the environment and the economy. It calls for an urgent, responsible, global response, based on solidarity among the international community. The Paris Conference must be a meeting at which real decisions are taken to make sure that the world gets back on track to keep the average global temperature below 2°C. Regrettably, the Conservative MEPs’ attempts to water down energy efficiency targets show they are not serious on tackling global environmental issues.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report addresses important issues ahead of the Paris climate conference in December 2015, which is expected to see a new international climate agreement. Topics include the EU's contribution to reducing emissions to the importance of climate diplomacy. Although the ECR shadow rapporteur has signed 14 of the 20 compromise amendments (on issues such as the recognition of human rights in climate policy and the importance of predictable Green Climate Fund Investment), I have chosen to abstain because some of the issues have proved unacceptable to my PARTY ALFA. However, ALFA's members wanted to communicate their position clearly to the outside world. That is why we have requested two separate votes. The first part relates to the increase in the EU 2030 targets agreed by the European Council in October 2014. We voted against increasing the targets agreed by the Member States. However, we voted in favour of linking the European emissions trading system with other emissions trading schemes in order to reduce the potential risks of relocation effects.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report towards a new international climate agreement in Paris proposes resolutions which go beyond the existing statement of the European Commission and the Council. The main improvements of the report are to get civil society involved, to respect human rights, to limit the rise of temperature at global level below an average of 2° C, and last but not least to reduce also greenhouse gas emissions. I voted in favour of this report, since it supports important changes for a new international climate agreement.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We voted for the resolution containing the negotiating mandate for the European Parliament delegation to attend the twenty-first meeting of the Convention of the Parties to the United Nations, scheduled for early December in Paris. The conference counts among its objectives to avoid global warming by more than 2 degrees compared to pre-industrial temperatures. This is an ambitious objective, involving a joint commitment by governments around the world, to defend the environment and climate. But our work only makes sense if we carry it out together with all the major players on the world stage and the main emitters of greenhouse gases, to defend our planet, without penalising our industries and their competitiveness. Europe has always played a leading role in achieving these objectives and will once again be the protagonist in enabling an ambitious agreement to be reached.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it unrealistically pushes the EU to be "exemplary" in the fight against global warming. The measures he advocates will contribute to further de-industrialisation of France and other EU countries, to the benefit of the world's most polluting states, such as China and the United States. The Americans cynically encourage us, because they use the climate debate as a weapon of mass deindustrialization of Europeans. Only a global agreement would really combat global warming.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. COP 21, held at the end of the year in Paris, must conclude with a binding agreement, if we are to hope to be able to contain global warming below 2 degrees Celsius.  At a time when states are evading their responsibilities, it is essential that the European Parliament mobilises for an ambitious agreement. The resolution on "the road to Paris" goes in this direction. It proposes that the European Union lead by example and commits to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 and by 80-95% by 2050. Unfortunately, that is less than the 50%, but it is the right direction.  The resolution also wants to ensure that the EU will fully assume its share of the $100 billion a year promised by rich countries to support the efforts of developing countries. I have therefore supported this initiative, because it is a strong signal to the negotiators of COP 21: that the European people are ready to commit themselves to the preservation of our planet and that we will not be content, once again, with a minimum agreement in Paris after great speeches.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The twenty-first Conference of the Parties (CP21) at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol will be held in Paris from 30 November to 11 December 2015. The European Parliament decided to draw up this own-initiative report after the publication of the Commission Communication of 25 February 2015 on the Energy Union Package entitled 'The Paris Protocol, a master plan to combat climate change beyond 2020'.  The report, which is the mandate of the European Parliament delegation for the MEETING of COP21 in December, is consistent with the positions advocated by our political group and I voted in favour of it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires legal obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions rather than non-binding commitments which are unfortunately the usual rule in this area. However, I believe that privileging its implementation through market instruments and, in particular, the financial market is incompatible with the commitment to effectively reduce emissions. On the contrary, these will accelerate the breakdown of the traditional productive fabric, without guaranteeing in any case a transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. That is why I doubt the European Union's ability to implement the recommendations of this report or to combine them with its commitment to neoliberal policies.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report addresses important issues ahead of the Paris climate conference in December 2015, which is expected to see a new international climate agreement. Topics include the EU's contribution to reducing emissions to the importance of climate diplomacy. Although the ECR shadow rapporteur has signed 14 of the 20 compromise amendments (on issues such as the recognition of human rights in climate policy and the importance of predictable Green Climate Fund Investment), I have chosen to abstain because some of the issues have proved unacceptable to my PARTY ALFA. However, ALFA's members wanted to communicate their position clearly to the outside world. That is why we have requested two separate votes. The first part relates to the increase in the EU 2030 targets agreed by the European Council in October 2014. We voted against increasing the targets agreed by the Member States. However, we voted in favour of linking the European emissions trading system with other emissions trading schemes in order to reduce the potential risks of relocation effects.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There is no doubt that climate policy is one of the greatest challenges for humanity in terms of sustainable development, health and the world economy. We must take care of the environment not only for the sake of our health, but also for future generations, who will also be beneficiaries of the same environment. Continuous climate change, such as melting glaciers on the one hand and frequent droughts and numerous floods on the other, requires a rapid response from the entire international community.  And that is the response to the Climate Agreement in Paris. I am fully convinced that a smooth, global action based on international solidarity is a good step, but it must be responsible. Targets that are rational and do not harm the economy should be set. First of all, those that do not comprehensively eliminate many jobs or partially reduce them. They must not place an undue burden on industry.  The important issue of financing the intended actions remains open. By 2020, developing countries are expected to receive $100 billion a year to help finance greenhouse gas emission reductions and other projects to protect societies at risk from climate change. I hope, however, that the provision of new funding will form the basis of the Paris Agreement.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Climate change has a major impact on sustainable growth and development, the economy and citizens' health, so we need to discuss them constantly internationally. The warming of the climate system is arguably, and the main cause is human activity.   While the EU reduced its emissions from 1990 to 2013 by 19%, global emissions increased by more than 50%. Climate change could be a major driver of population displacement.  The European Parliament must advocate ambitious but realistic targets: a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels by 2030. The Paris Conference must find and agree on solutions that will mark the beginning of a reduction in the global average temperature below 2 degrees Celsius. Between now and 2020, 100 billion US dollars will be transferred to developing countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  I supported MP Gilles Pargneaux's report on the need to act against negative climate change. Measurements of air temperature in Croatia indicate an increase of between 0.02 and 0.07 degrees Celsius over a period of 10 years, which in the finality has negative consequences on the Adriatic Sea, and thus on tourism and fisheries, and measures are necessary to reduce the risk of climate change.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Climate change as a result of human activity has negative impacts on overall life on our planet. The forthcoming new global climate agreement to be adopted in Paris in December may change this situation. However, the condition is that this will be respected and therefore a legally binding international treaty, to which both developed and developing countries will accede. The EU and the states acceding to the agreement must allocate funds linked to measures, projects and investments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, transition to a low-carbon economy and reduce the energy intensity of production and consumption in all areas of the economy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report to a new international climate agreement in Paris because the issue of climate change is a global problem and a threat to the environment and people. The report rightly emphasises the need for a binding legal agreement at global level. The report also underlines the future increase in refugee flows as a result of this phenomenon. I support the report on this point because it is very important to bring about international legal guarantee of environmental refugee status.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on 'Towards reaching a new international climate agreement in Paris'. A stable climate system is one of the biggest challenges in the areas of sustainable development and the world economy. The European Union and its Member States have, in fact, committed themselves to meeting the binding target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the EU by at least 40% by 2030. The aim of this report is to urge governments to implement concrete measures to combat climate change and to ensure that a legally binding agreement is reached in Paris in 2015 to achieve this objective.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a report on the ambitious project of concluding an international agreement on combating climate change, to be discussed at the COP 21 climate change conference in Paris in December 2015. I believe that the EU could play the role of mediator, thus contributing significantly to the conclusion of a legally binding and ambitious international climate agreement. I, too, recognise the need to combat climate change at global level, and of course I recognise the crucial importance of a stable climate system for food security, energy production, water and sanitation, infrastructure, biodiversity conservation, terrestrial and marine ecosystems, and for global peace and well-being. I also support the idea that stimulating innovation in technology and business models can drive both economic growth and emission reductions. That is why I supported the report in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing major and serious climate change. Recognising that this is one of the biggest challenges we face is the first step in moving in the right direction. As my colleague points out, these targets must aim for more ambitious and realistic results that lead to 50% reductions in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and increase the share of renewable energy by up to 45% in order to achieve 40% energy savings. By voting in favour of this report, I wanted to join in the desire to pursue an ambitious and effective policy that mobilises not only the instruments for a climate and energy policy, but also involves other key sectors such as transport, research, innovation and trade or development cooperation. We must finally provide a long-term response to the climate challenge, calling on the Eu ropean Union and the Member States to work with institutions, NGOs and other civil society actors to develop initiatives to reduce climate change.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In principle, the conclusion of an adapted legally binding protocol, which is actually complied with by each Party, would be desirable. Unfortunately, the actual leaders (USA, China) will continue to fail to comply. The EU's unilateral adherence to this commitment leads to a tremendous competitive advantage for the US and China. In order to maintain the Union's competitiveness, I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Parliament here calls for an "ambitious, universal and legally binding agreement" for the 21st Conference of the Parties (COP) on the fight against climate change. Yet the EU's objectives are themselves very timid. For example, the EU is committed to a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (compared to 1990 levels) in 2020 when it is already on a trend to reduce them by 23% without making further efforts... Similarly, while the text refers to the inadequacy of limiting global warming to an increase of 2oC above pre-industrial levels, it does not commit to targeting 1.5oC.  Finally, it fails to overcome the logic of green capitalism and therefore advocates the strengthening of the carbon market. This text is unnecessary and rather ridiculous. I abstain so as not to discourage Parliament's environmental desires.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. On the pretext that a global response to global warming must be given, the European institutions are out-of-the-art by targeting industry. The remedies devised propose, for example, to direct investment towards so-called less polluting activities, contributing to the deindustrialisation of Europe and de facto leading to an increase in imports (what about the pollution of cargo ships criss-crossing the seas?) Also, we ignore an essential reality, the fact that the biggest polluters (notably the United States) are far behind the EU. And that's where the problem lies. Indeed, an issue as serious as the climate has unfortunately become, in the game of global competition, a weapon of mass deindustrialization of Europeans.  The only global climate undertaking that would be valid and fair would be an agreement on measured targets for pollution per capita and a relocation process that would respond to this crazy race for free trade. It is unfortunate that such a line is never proposed. I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it explores the many ways that the Union can take the lead in the fight against climate change. The resolution highlights the importance of creating a truly circular economy as a means of not only reducing waste but also of opening up new avenues for research and development and also for employment in the green economy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change is one of the most serious challenges of our time both for the environment and the economy. Climate change is making climate disasters more frequent and intense. It is making the land and water more scarce and difficult to access and its impact increases the risk of hunger in many parts of the world. Therefore, with a few reservations I supported Parliament’s non-legislative recommendations towards a new international climate agreement in Paris. The twenty-first session of the Conference of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (UNFCCC COP21) will be organised from 30 November to 11 December 2015 in Paris, France and I believe that EU and Member States need to be ambitious so that the Paris Conference will be the meeting at which real decisions will be taken to make sure that the world gets back on track to keep the average global temperature below 2° C.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. The 21st United Nations Climate Change Conference will be held in Paris between November 30, 2015 and December 11, 2015. The report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety underlines that this conference is a crucial stage in the negotiation of a new global agreement on climate change, which will enter into force in 2020. It therefore proposes that the European Parliament stand by the ambitious but realistic objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, increasing the share of renewable energies in the energy mix to 45% and achieving energy savings of 40%. It also underlines the need to make $100 billion a year available to developing countries by 2020 to help pay for projects to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and protect communities exposed to climate change, and that the paris conference will be a cornerstone of the inclusion of new sources of funding to this end. In this context, it proposes to develop a credible 'financial package' to enable efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the effects of climate change. I largely agree with and support the aspirations.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report proposes ambitious goals to reduce the causes of global warming, and first and foremost industrialization.  On the basis that global warming must be tackled in a coordinated and global way, the Pargneaux report aims for a universal and binding target, as well as a $100 billion-a-year funding target for developing countries. Full of good intentions, this report is fraught with pitfalls. For example, efforts are measured as an overall percentage, without taking into account per capita pollution; the measures requested contribute to de-industrialisation of Europe and thus increased imports, ignoring the pollution generated by cargo ships travelling the seas. Moreover, the United States, the world's largest polluter, having understood that these measures are a weapon of mass deindustrialization of Europeans, support these measures without participating. The only audible line would be a truly global, binding agreement, with targets measured in pollution per capita and the end of the free trade race to initiate a process of relocation respectful of sovereignty.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Pargneaux report presents proposals on the ambitious goals that the European institutions will set for the international climate conference to be held in Paris in December. In addition to the binding targets already set by the Commission (-40% CO2 emissions), the report proposes "support" funding of $100 billion per year for developing countries, remittances at the main expense of EU Member States, and more stringent and environmental rules for economic activities. I believe that the French and Europeans cannot bear the burden of saving the world alone, at the expense of their well-being, and that the industrial deterrence measures demanded will contribute to accentuating the massive deindustrialisation affecting our countries, more relocations to less-looking countries, more globalisation and polluting flows of transport, the biggest polluters , the United States and China, are far behind the EU, having perceived that the "climate" is a weapon of mass deindustrialization in their favour at the expense of Europeans. So I voted against this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which gives the European Parliament delegation a clear mandate for its participation in the conference of the parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, known as COP21. This is a crucial deadline as it must lead to a new international climate agreement aimed at keeping global warming below 2 degrees Celsius.  I agree with the ambition of reducing greenhouse gases by 40-70% by 2050 compared to 2010 and bringing the zero-emissions threshold closer by the end of the century. However, I believe that the European Union should not engage alone in a binding agreement, or risk seeing its competitiveness once again threatened against third countries that do not apply the same measures. I regret that the amendment for which I voted and which calls for an agreement applicable to all countries has not been adopted.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing humanity in the areas of sustainable development and the world economy. They call for an urgent, responsible and comprehensive response based on the solidarity of the international community. By adopting this report, we intend to support the commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The EU and its Member States have committed to jointly meeting a binding reduction target of at least 40% by 2030. These objectives are heading in the right direction, but they should be more ambitious. The next Paris Conference will be just the beginning of a dynamic and evolutionary process that will allow the international community to take corrective measures to realign itself with the trajectory necessary to keep the rise in temperatures below 2 °C. , over and above the initial contributions submitted by the Member States. We need a forward-looking and effective policy with a view to an energy transition by 2050, mobilising not only the instruments of climate and energy policy but also involving other areas such as transport, research, innovation, trade and development cooperation.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting this report because although I support concrete measures against climate change I believe that countries should be helped in making this transition towards clean energy. This transition implies a good and fair energy mix for all countries but also investment in technologies reducing carbon emissions for the classical energy resources.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the forthcoming international climate conference in Paris, because I believe that the international community should move forward towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions. I consider it important that all major world issuers join the commitments in this area, and EU leaders should make every diplomatic effort in this regard. I am in favour of the solution expressed by the EP in its resolution of 5 February 2014, in which it calls for the adoption of a binding energy efficiency target of 40%, a renewable energy target of 30% and a greenhouse gas emission reduction target of 40%.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The conclusion and adoption of a legally binding protocol, as described herein, is only desirable if it is also respected by all parties concerned. Since the US and China are also taking responsibility for these climate agreements, they only mean a curtailment of the EU's competitiveness. In addition, the report aims to create new institutions that further reduce national competences and whose effectiveness is questionable. Consequently, I voted against.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report aims to be a roadmap for the European Parliament's commitment to the 21st UN Climate Conference to be held very soon in Paris. It calls for the inclusion of binding legal measures in the final text of this conference to ensure that the targets for global warming are met, including its staying below the 2oC mark.  It sets three main targets: 30% renewable energy use by 2030, achieving a 40% energy efficiency threshold and reducing greenhouse gases by 40% by 2020. It also calls for a timetable for the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies and a comprehensive funding policy for developing countries to combat global warming. I am voting in favour of this report, which gives an ambitious dimension to Parliament's commitment to COP 21 and to the environment.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Climate change is one of the most pressing global problems. It is therefore essential that an agreement is reached in Paris on a new international climate change agreement. We cannot remain indifferent to the challenges of climate change. There is an urgent need to address climate change mitigation, adaptation to climate change, finance, technology development, transparency of action and support. Particular attention should be paid to the world's largest polluters, who should participate in the agreement and make equivalent commitments. All countries around the world should make legally binding climate change mitigation commitments beyond 2020.  It should be noted that the new agreement should be in line with today's economic reality. All countries must contribute to the financing of climate change actions and the divide between developing and developed countries must be eliminated.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 The socio-economic metabolism of today's societies has produced numerous environmental degradation phenomena. The international community did not begin to worry about the consequences of over-use of resources until the late 1970s. Centuries of intensive and, many times, uncontrolled exploitation, due to the inability of human society to combine the reasons for the environment with those of development, have caused many irreversible damage. The consequences are clear to everyone and are manifested, in particular, in the phenomenon of global warming, which involves the increase in average global air and ocean temperatures, the widespread melting of snow and ice and the consequent rise in sea level.  Sustainable development is therefore the priority challenge of the 21st century and requires that the principles of environmental sustainability be taken into account in all sectoral policies. This action must be carried out from the local level, with a constant effort to internationalise awareness of environmental issues in order to move the environmental issue to the global scale. The Paris Conference is an opportunity to take corrective action and to realign itself with European and UN environmental objectives.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU's climate and energy strategy and its objectives for the agreement at the forthcoming International Conference in Paris serve the interests of large business groups. The EU is exploiting climate change to open up new areas of profitability for monopolies in the areas of "green technologies", renewables and other forms of "low carbon" energy. It seeks to use its comparative advantage in the development of the technologies concerned to strengthen the position of European monopolistic groups in raging imperialist competition for the conquest of markets and the bandit exploitation of resources. Whatever agreement is reached as a result of a temporary compromise, it will concern the settlement of interests between monopolies, it will do no good to the peoples and their needs. As long as monopolies dominate the economy and power, all popular problems will worsen, the environment will deteriorate, as will the health and quality of life of workers. The huge development of science and technology will be used to increase the profitability of enterprises and not to meet growing popular needs. Peoples can prosper if they decide to compete with the system of capitalist exploitation and become owners of the wealth they produce.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%.  The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, in view of the forthcoming climate conference in Paris next December and the work of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, of which I am a member, I hope for a global commitment to reducing emissions and a good capacity to adapt to climate change. That is why I am voting in favour and I urge the House to do the same.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ I supported the report 'Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris' prepared by the European Parliament for the COP21 meeting in Paris. The report is ambitious enough, is binding and covers all partners. Care for the future of our planet is closely linked to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and protecting the environment, and compliance with the agreed goal will be necessary to achieve the objective.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Europe needs an ambitious plan that will also contribute to an ambitious global agreement. The positions of the European Parliament can be seen as just such - ambitious.  We may not yet be aware of the importance of the Paris Climate Conference. The failure of this conference can lead to the collapse of the world's climate policy and prevent its main goal from being reached – limits on the rise in global average temperature by the end of the century to 2°C compared to the pre-industrial period.  Today we know that we are not on the right track and that further efforts should be made in due course.  I want Europe to remain at the forefront of this fight against climate change and that is why I supported this Resolution.  The highly set objectives posed by the technological challenge are simultaneously driving the advancement of European industry and creating the potential to create new jobs in green jobs.  I hope that Member States will be committed to implementing European climate and energy policies that contribute to the achievement of this objective.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Pargneaux report presents proposals on the ambitious goals that the European institutions will set for the international climate conference to be held in Paris in December. In addition to the binding targets already set by the Commission (-40% CO2 emissions), the report proposes "support" funding of $100 billion per year for developing countries, remittances at the main expense of EU Member States, and more stringent and environmental rules for economic activities. I believe that the French cannot bear the burden of saving the world to their own detriment and that the industrial deterrence measures demanded will contribute to accentuating the massive deindustrialization affecting our countries, more relocations to less-looking countries, more globalisation and polluting transport flows. The biggest polluters, the United States and China, are far behind the EU, having perceived that the "climate" is a weapon of mass deindustrialization in their favour at the expense of the peoples of Europe. So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I support this rightly ambitious report by my colleague Pargneaux.  Climate change is one of the most serious challenges of our time for both the environment and the economy. I support this report as it calls for an urgent and responsible global response based on the solidarity of the international community. The Paris Conference must be a meeting where real decisions are taken to ensure that the world returns to the track in order to achieve the objective of keeping the global average temperature rise below 2° C. I am pleased that the European Parliament will also be represented at this conference by a delegation of fellow MEPs and MEPs.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by the vote taken by Parliament on the report for the Paris climate agreement. It shows that the EU recognises the important work that needs to be done, and that it needs to be done on a global level. I agree that this Protocol must be legally binding in order for real change to transpire. Furthermore, we need to keep in mind the financial aspect of this agreement and have the EU and Member States create a plan to scale up our climate financial goals. This is an important part of the process in order for everyone to meet their fair share by 2020. In addition to increasing our financial support, we also need to increase the use of climate diplomacy. I believe that comprehensive climate diplomacy can be a great tool to help bring about tangible change. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of this protocol in Paris; the decisions that we make today will affect many generations of the future.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Environmental protection also involves compliance with the Kyoto Protocol and the international agreements signed. The latter must be the cornerstones for the future development of Europe. The aim of our policies, in the various sectors involved, should be to bring together the interests of industry with respect for the environment. The EU's policy on global warming needs binding and concrete measures. In order to combat climate change, it is necessary for the parties to meet at the Paris Conference not just to 'try to do something' but to take concrete decisions. With my vote in favour today, I hope that an international agreement will be reached quickly, including ambitious and binding targets for reducing emissions and energy efficiency and on the use of renewable energy sources by 2030. The EU must continue to be at the forefront in order to keep global warming below a 2°C increase and to help cut global carbon emissions from 40% to 70% by 2050. These ambitious objectives require efforts to be made in all regions of the world, and the EU certainly cannot stand by and watch.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In preparation for the international climate conference "COP 21" in Paris in December, the European Parliament wished to recall the climate issues and the importance of reaching agreement on a global action plan. I voted for this report and I believe it is important that all EU Member States and other States engage together and coordinate their actions to effectively combat global warming.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Pargneaux report: ‘Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris’. The UK represents only 2% of global emissions; the EU only 12%.  The European Union has chosen to destroy its economy while the rest of the world is behaving very differently. Whatever we do, global emissions will rise. EU Institutions are planning to spend unimaginable sums of money on mitigation measures which will only further damage our economy. UKIP believes that it is time to question the EU’s hysterical obsession with the new belief of climate alarmism.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's strategy in the run-up to a new international climate agreement to be concluded in Paris at the end of 2015. The looming global threat of global warming is well established and it is our duty to urgently adopt ambitious measures to achieve the goal of limiting warming to 2oC.  We call on all countries to present their planned contributions as soon as possible, determined at the global level according to their national realities.
