We insist that the Paris Agreement must be legally binding and ambitious. It is expected to aim for a phasing out of global CO2 emissions around 2050. The issue of financing is paramount, and we encourage the Commission in particular to establish international carbon market mechanisms and to ensure that the least polluting technologies are attractive to investors. The EU and other countries are asked to prepare a credible financial package for periods up to 2020 and beyond. Finally, there is a need to reduce emissions from the transport sector, which is the second largest emitter of greenhouse gases.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour of this ambitious report. In particular, I voted for the provisions calling for the 2015 climate protocol, which will be adopted at the Paris conference, to be legally binding and ambitious in aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at the top of the IPCC's recommended range of 40-70% by 2050 compared to 2010 in order to keep the world on a low-cost emission reduction trajectory compatible with the goal of limiting global warming to a 2-degree rise. To follow very closely!

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Climate change today is an unavoidable reality and represents one of the main threats to the sustainable development of our planet. For this reason, the European Union is committed to reaching an ambitious and legally binding global agreement covering concrete targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions of at least 40% by 2030 (compared to 1990), increasing energy efficiency to 40% and increasing renewable energy sources to 30%.  Like the rapporteur, I stress the importance of the EU and its Member States completing the process of ratifying the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol by the end of this year, so that it comes into force as soon as possible. Finally, I stress the need for this binding international climate agreement, capable of addressing the challenges posed by climate change from a long-term perspective, so that we contribute to a stable climate system that preserves ecosystem biodiversity and human health. In view of these assumptions, I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the European Parliament's recommendations to Member States and the European Union for negotiations at the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP21). The conference will be held from November 30 to December 11, 2015 in Paris. We must act to find solutions to global warming, which results in natural disasters with devastating effects. In this sense, the text calls for a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and sets energy efficiency targets. COP21 will only be a success if it results in an ambitious agreement, with binding targets and concrete measures to achieve it. COP21 and actions on global warming should be an opportunity to strengthen the participation of all economic sectors and non-state actors in the research and implementation of solutions.  This text is an important signal sent on the eve of COP21; not only the European Union must make commitments, but also its partners.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the achievement of a new international climate agreement because I believe that the European Union urgently needs to address the problem of climate change, the negative effects of which fall heavily on the environment, the economy and societies. At the same time, we must ensure the right balance between the environment and industrial policies and, above all, create balanced international competition, where it is not only European industries that are responsible for combating climate change. The Member States must reach an international agreement setting out concrete objectives and measures to combat the consequences of global warming.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider EU environmental and climate policies to be completely bankrupt, not least in view of an excessively one-sided approach that leads to excessive costs and constraints on European industries, in the name of environmental protection, while the call for third countries to comply with the same parameters of respect for the environment risks strongly, once again , to remain a dead letter.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because it raises the need for the EU to devote more economic and technological resources to the fight against climate change, as well as to establish and strengthen legally binding commitments in Paris to reduce EMISSIONs of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. However, although the report has an impact on the problem that transport-produced CO2 emissions have continued to grow, it does not introduce any criticism of free trade or TTE, and leaves everything in the hands of the development of clean transport technologies. As for the defence of CO2 emissions trading, it is a system that in my opinion generates a new economic bubble with the sale of emissions bonds and which is creating ineffective in meeting the objectives with which it was theoretically born, which is why we have spoken out against this system.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report even though it requires legal obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions rather than non-binding commitments which are unfortunately the usual rule in this area. Privileging its implementation through market instruments and, in particular, the financial market is incompatible with the commitment to effectively reduce emissions. In addition, they will accelerate the breakdown of the traditional productive fabric, without guaranteeing in any case a transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy Despite the fact that the current model of agricultural production and food marketing contributes highly to the emission of greenhouse gases, there is no proposal to move to an agroecological production model or to promote and enhance short marketing circuits.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Climate Change Conference to be held in Paris at the end of the year (COP21) will have the task of reaching a legally binding and universal climate agreement, with the aim of keeping the rise in temperatures below 2°C. Global warming is one of the greatest challenges facing humanity in the areas of sustainable development, health and the world economy. The European Union is leading global action on climate change, committing itself to significantly reducing its greenhouse gas emissions. I have, however, chosen to abstain from the final vote on the report because I believe that the objectives proposed today are too ambitious and unrealistic. I also believe that climate change requires an urgent, responsible and global response, based on the solidarity of the entire international community and not just on the European community.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. It seems to me very important that the European Parliament, which represents all citizens of the European Union, sends a clear message of urgency to COP 21 Paris with regard to the intensification of global climate change.  This report, by proposing a very significant increase in renewable energy and by imposing a roadmap for states, makes an effective contribution to reducing climate change. However, in this declaration I want to attach particular importance to the proposal to end subsidies for petroleum products. This option has a deeper content than the simple end of a support. With this option we are, in fact, changing the paradigm, giving priority to benign energies for the environment and putting an early end to passive dependence on fossil fuels. For these reasons, I voted positively for this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This vote requires the UK to uphold EU dictated targets which are not being matched globally. The UK as a nation state should set its own emission measures and not be dictated to by the EU.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the fight against climate change and its potential threat to the stability and security of the whole world to be a key issue that needs to be addressed at international level with the participation of all stakeholders. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that only a comprehensive, transparent and legally binding international agreement can ensure that global warming is kept below 200 C. , local authorities, civil society, the private sector and the media within and outside the EU. As these actors have played, and I assume that they will continue to play an increasing role in the climate debate in the future, I think it would be a great pity not to exploit this potential. Since finance will, I presume, play a very serious role in the agreement to be concluded at the Paris Conference, it is essential to prepare a sufficiently stable and transparent financial package for the implementation of the forthcoming agreement.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 When dealing with this issue, we must not forget employment in the EU, so as not to drive employers out of the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report and I think it is important to note that climate change can lead to major disruptions in the not too distant future in terms of resources such as food, water and pastures and can become a major driver of population displacement. Efforts to mitigate global warming must not be seen as an obstacle to economic growth, but should be seen as a driver of new and sustainable economic growth and employment.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The "Emission Gap" continues between the current global level of greenhouse gas emissions and the level needed to achieve the main goal of limiting global warming to 2°C above pre-industrial levels. Promises of national emissions reductions are delivered extremely slowly, so the gap is unlikely to close and the main objective will be met. The biggest unresolved problems in international climate negotiations are related to the division between rich and poor peoples. The parties need to overcome this division in order to reach an appropriate agreement in Paris.  The report calls for an ambitious, legally binding, global agreement and highlights the fact that this would "address carbon leakage and competition concerns of relevant sectors, in particular the energy-sensitive sector". The report also highlights the importance of R&D, the need to promote new technologies and business models, and the support of research and innovation.  I fully support this report in order to make progress towards an international agreement and ultimately to take effective measures in line with the main objective.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with further tightening of the EU's climate targets. The EU's climate targets are already excessively strict, thus causing the exact opposite of the intended effects. In fact, high energy prices drive EU firms out of countries such as China or India, and as environmental standards are much lower in these countries, the total amount of emissions is rising. Further tightening of climate targets would only intensify this trend.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 At the next climate conference we must reach an agreement, which is implemented by all. In order to achieve this, the commercialisation of the land must cease. Substantial targets must be set to address climate change and meet the needs of society. To put people's interests and the environment above the private interests of multinationals. That's the only way we can save the planet!  Although the EP proposal lacks criticism of how to solve climate change problems while praising market mechanisms, there are nevertheless positive reports that we cannot ignore. It is stressed that the 2015 Protocol should be legally binding and aim to phase out greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. The EU is asked to work with international partners to this end, offering examples of good practice. It stresses the importance of keeping human rights at the heart of climate change actions and providing aid to the poorest countries. It also stresses the need to fully respect the rights of local communities and peoples vulnerable to the effects of climate change. For these reasons, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The text contains many positive elements but welcomes the carbon trading scheme to which we are opposed.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the fight against climate change to be important, in which the so-called Paris Climate Summit can be an important milestone. The EP is actively contributing to this with this negotiating mandate, which is why I voted in favour of this report. I agree with the report that all stakeholders should be involved in the fight against the global threat and that this can only be achieved at international level. I believe that a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, a 40% energy efficiency target and a mandatory 30% renewable energy use level will all help to reduce climate change. In my opinion, however, the targets will not solve all problems. On the one hand, we could go above them for greater success, and on the other hand, we can only achieve them with active state and local contributions. It is important to note that, in the face of the earth's growing demand for food, which is countering these figures, we need to encourage agricultural research and innovation, the use of renewable energy sources and the increase in waste recovery; while at work and social aspects.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There is no doubt that the climate change that we are currently seeing requires urgent action on our part, as it can lead to irreversible threats to societies and the biosphere as a whole. It is therefore necessary for all parties involved in the climate negotiations to adopt specific commitments in order to meet this challenge, one of the greatest challenges of modern civilization. The European Parliament's report on the new international climate agreement to be concluded later this year in Paris is the right step in the global fight against the changes that are currently taking place on our Earth.  However, I believe that this document contains many provisions which, if implemented, would lead to a shake-up of the European economy, an increase in unemployment, resulting in an increase in the poverty rate in Europe. What is certain is that if the fight against climate change is not global and limited to Europe only, then not only will we fail to achieve the objectives set, but worse, we will significantly reduce the competitiveness of our economy. Some companies will move their activities out of the EU in saving their profitability. Others will go bankrupt or severely restrict their activities in Europe. That is why I have chosen to vote against the EP report, because I believe that the position it outlines, which the European Union should present in the context of the climate negotiations, has not been properly balanced.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Everyone's attention is focused on the final cycle of negotiations before the 21st United Nations Conference on Climate Change, which starts on 30 November. Both the world economy and the well-being and health of the population will depend on governments' response to humanity's greatest challenge, namely global warming. The key element of these negotiations is funding: it takes $100 billion a year to be transferred to developing countries. This amount will enable them to develop projects aimed at protecting communities at risk, faced with the effects of climate change. Currently, only $10.4 billion is being capitalised in the Green Climate Fund, an absolutely insufficient amount. That is why I hope that the Paris meeting does not become a mere negotiating meeting. Certain decisions must be made on this occasion, which will allow investors to refocus their investments towards resilient, low-carbon economies. Only through a global agreement can we reach a fair carbon price across the big economies and only then can we encourage the development of climate-friendly economic and technological solutions.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for my eminent colleague's report. We now call on the Vice-President of the Commission and the EU's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to set strategic priorities for climate policy, enshrined in general foreign policy objectives, and to ensure that EU delegations place greater emphasis on climate policies. , monitoring countries' efforts to mitigate or adapt to climate change, capacity development assistance, and the means to take action on climate monitoring. Parliament calls on the EU to cooperate more closely on climate issues with neighbouring and candidate countries to encourage them to align their policies with the EU's climate objectives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this own-initiative report, which sets out the position of the European Parliament ahead of the climate summit in Paris in December 2015. This complex document covers various aspects of the issue, such as climate change mitigation and adaptation, climate finance, the contribution of different sectors, scientific research and climate diplomacy. It addresses emissions from different sectors including transport and agriculture and forestry. The report holds that the agreement in Paris must be legally binding and ambitious and should aim at phasing out global carbon emissions by 2050 or shortly thereafter in order to keep the world on a cost-effective emission trajectory compatible with the below-2°C target. It calls on the COP 21 Parties to support five-year commitment periods as the most appropriate choice.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although the original draft report on the road to a new international climate agreement in Paris covers many key issues such as the European Union's contribution to emissions reduction, the need for a flexible and accountable screening mechanism, and the importance of gradually increasing funding for the Green Climate Fund; I believe that this report used comprehensive topics to insert unacceptable proposals. In fact, I believe that the proposed more ambitious targets for 2030 are not realistic and that, like the call for the use of public funds for the Green Climate Fund, it will only cause an increased burden on Member States.  As I have noted before, I believe that many of the topics opened by this report are extremely important for the environment, but I consider the objectives set to be too ambitious and therefore cannot lead to improvements in this area. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal on the road to the new international climate agreement in Paris, as I believe it is time for ambitious change, because climate change requires an immediate, responsible and global response based on the solidarity of the international community. The Paris climate agreement is ambitious, global and legally binding, and has positive consequences for all EU citizens, especially in the light of climate change mitigation and adaptation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because it raises the need for the EU to devote more economic and technological resources to the fight against climate change, as well as to establish and strengthen legally binding commitments in Paris to reduce EMISSIONs of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. However, although the report has an impact on the problem that transport-produced CO2 emissions have continued to grow, it does not introduce any criticism of free trade or TTE, and leaves everything in the hands of the development of clean transport technologies. As for the defence of CO2 emissions trading, it is a system that in my opinion generates a new economic bubble with the sale of emissions bonds and which is creating ineffective in meeting the objectives with which it was theoretically born, which is why we have spoken out against this system.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report addresses important issues ahead of the Paris climate conference in December 2015, which is expected to see a new international climate agreement. Topics include the EU's contribution to reducing emissions to the importance of climate diplomacy. Although the ECR shadow rapporteur has signed 14 of the 20 compromise amendments (on issues such as the recognition of human rights in climate policy and the importance of predictable Green Climate Fund Investment), I have chosen to abstain because some of the issues have proved unacceptable to my PARTY ALFA. However, ALFA's members wanted to communicate their position clearly to the outside world. That is why we have requested two separate votes. The first part relates to the increase in the EU 2030 targets agreed by the European Council in October 2014. We voted against increasing the targets agreed by the Member States. However, we voted in favour of linking the European emissions trading system with other emissions trading schemes in order to reduce the potential risks of relocation effects.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support such a resolution because climate change is now recognized worldwide as a top urgency. The future of our kids and future generations depends on our strong actions today.  The 2015 Protocol must be legally binding and ambitious from the outset when adopted in Paris, and should aim at phasing out global carbon emissions by 2050 or shortly thereafter so as to keep the world on a cost-effective emission trajectory compatible with the below 2°C target, and that a global GHG emissions peak will be reached as soon as possible. I call on the EU to work with its international partners to that end, showing examples of good practices. The agreement must provide a predictable framework which encourages investments and scaling by business of efficient carbon reductions and adaptation technologies; Only an ambitious and legally binding international agreement would help to address the carbon leakage and competitiveness concerns of the relevant sectors and in particular the energy intensive sector. I call for a general reinvigoration of the EU’s climate policy, which would help build momentum in international climate discussions and would be in line with the upper limit of the EU’s commitment to reducing its GHG emissions to 80-95 % below 1990 levels by 2050.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Pargneaux report would like a universal and binding goal. Unfortunately, these efforts still weigh disproportionately on those who have the greatest sense of responsibility, the Europeans, in the name of a good cause. The Union should therefore be 'exemplary'.  These efforts have a disastrous result and contribute to de-industrialisation of Europe for even more import and globalisation, ignoring the pollution generated by cargo ships crisscrossing the seas. The proposals are counterproductive. The biggest polluters, of which the United States is a part, are far behind the EU. Having perceived that the "climate" is a weapon of massive deindustrialization of Europeans, in the geopolitical game of the powers, the Americans hold speeches of encouragement.  The only acceptable and realistic way to truly take care of our planet would be a truly global agreement calling for an end to the free trade race and engaging in a process of relocation of productions, respectful of sovereignty.  It is obvious that this will never be proposed by the organizers.  I therefore object to this hypocritical text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the European Parliament's position towards a new international climate agreement in Paris, to be held in Paris between 30 November and 11 December 2015. The report, which contains important directions and findings, sets out, inter alia, the European Parliament's commitment to the forward-looking objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, increasing the share of renewable energies in the energy mix to 45% and achieving energy savings of 40%. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because it raises the need for the EU to devote more economic and technological resources to the fight against climate change, as well as to establish and strengthen legally binding commitments in Paris to reduce EMISSIONs of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. However, although the report has an impact on the problem that transport-produced CO2 emissions have continued to grow, it does not introduce any criticism of free trade or TTE, and leaves everything in the hands of the development of clean transport technologies. As for the defence of CO2 emissions trading, it is a system that in my opinion generates a new economic bubble with the sale of emissions bonds and which is creating ineffective in meeting the objectives with which it was theoretically born, which is why we have spoken out against this system.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the EU’s negotiating position for the international climate conference in Paris. The European Parliament has called for the setting aside of a number of EU carbon market allowances after 2020 for international climate finance and I hope this resolution will, in particular, support a concrete EU mechanism for international climate finance. The EU has so far shown determination and a high level of ambition, but the commitment must be seen also through financial support for the measures. Climate finance will be crucial to forge much-needed coalitions and ensure poor countries can leapfrog towards clean and climate-resilient development. We also called on EU finance ministers to back Parliament´s proposal and use the EU’s carbon market for international finance.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This is a report which is the mandate of the European Parliament's delegation for the forthcoming Paris Climate Summit and calls for an ambitious and legally binding comprehensive agreement. An agreement in which the EU must play an important role and have one voice in seeking the progress of negotiations towards an international agreement on this issue. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the Pargneaux report is a strong support for the negotiating mandate of the Delegation of the European Parliament to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference (CP21) in Paris from 30 November to 11 December. The Socialists strongly support an active EU role at the Paris summit with the aim of reaching an ambitious and legally binding agreement on emission reduction, as well as sound financial instruments to achieve this objective.  As the date of the Paris summit approaches, climate diplomacy needs to be intensified. World leaders need to understand that limiting the planet's temperature rise to a maximum of two degrees will not only help prevent climate change and the natural disasters associated with it, but will prevent a dramatic increase in the number of refugees as a result of climate change.  On the other hand, the EU targets 20/20/20 for emissions, renewable energy and energy savings show that there is no contradiction between growth and sustainability, as evidenced by the fact that the European economy has grown by 45% since 1990.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires legal obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions rather than non-binding commitments which are unfortunately the usual rule in this area. However, I believe that privileging its implementation through market instruments and, in particular, the financial market is incompatible with the commitment to effectively reduce emissions. On the contrary, these will accelerate the breakdown of the traditional productive fabric, without guaranteeing in any case a transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. That is why I doubt the European Union's ability to implement the recommendations of this report or to combine them with its commitment to neoliberal policies.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. Climate change, together with biodiversity loss and resource scarcity, is one of the most important global challenges. Non-policy has irreversible consequences and is detrimental to the planet, people and the economy. For the N-VA, the future of our children and grandchildren comes first. We fully recognise the climate problem and want to address both its consequences and its causes. A new international agreement is fundamental in this regard. Europe is at the forefront, but setting a good example is not enough. After all, the EU cannot solve the problem alone, we need allies. We find this by reconciling ambition with a sense of reality. The choices we make today must indeed be sustainable, efficient and effective so that we can sustain them for years to come. Although the mandate for the EP delegation to the Paris climate summit certainly contains positive elements, it is primarily a missed opportunity. The resolution lacks realism and does not take into account the conclusions of the European Council of 23 and 24 October 2014. In this way, the European Parliament undermines its position as a credible and influential interlocutor. That is why the N-VA delegation abstained. In conclusion, "If you think you're leading, but no one's following, you're just taking a walk."

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change represents an  immediate and direct threat to the world that we live in. If action is not taken irreversible climate change will cease to be a theme of dystopian fiction but a part of our lives, potentially permanently. The unanimity of scientists on this issue is unprecedented, climate change is happening, and we are already on the brink. This motion lays down what the European Parliament feels should be the course taken at the upcoming conference in Paris. Although nations are currently bound to ensuring there is no rise over 2°C there is no guarantee that this will not cause great damage, therefore Parliament urges that a 1.5° limit be considered. Furthermore, the aims should be ambitious, global and legally binding. I believe the future of humanity is too important to be used as a political football and have therefore backed this motion.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report discusses the preparations for the 21st UN Climate Conference, to be held in Paris from 30 November to 11 December 2015, and is Parliament's roadmap to this perspective. The report rightly calls for the final text of COP 21 to be legally binding to eliminate global CO2 emissions by 2050, so as to keep global warming below 2 degrees Celsius. It calls for a three-way target: a reduction of at least 40% in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels, a 40% energy efficiency target and a 30% renewable energy target by 2030.  However, this report continues to support the European CO2 emissions trading scheme, known as the 'carbon market', whose inefficiency and dangers are no longer to be demonstrated. These mechanisms of "green capitalism" are nothing more than false ecological solutions. Because this report is not up to the challenges of the moment and contains a part of hypocrisy in relation to the solutions currently proposed, including by the choice of the rapporteur (a French socialist), I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Climate change poses an urgent and potentially irreversible global threat to human societies and the biosphere. According to scientific data from 2014, there is no doubt about the warming of the climate system. Human activities are the main cause of the warming observed since the mid-20th century. Unfortunately, between 1990 and 2013, there was an increase of more than 50% in GHG emissions worldwide, with the average monthly global concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere exceeding the threshold of 400 parts per million in March 2015 for the first time. We therefore have the greatest doubts as to the capacity of emissions trading systems to solve this problem, as it treats companies with large development differentials equally.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, the conclusion of an adapted legally binding protocol, which is actually complied with by each Party, would be desirable. Unfortunately, the actual leaders (USA, China) will continue to fail to comply. The EU's unilateral adherence to this commitment leads to a tremendous competitive advantage for the US and China. In order to maintain the Union's competitiveness, I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. \u2012 Action must be taken to halt climate change. Ambitious EU targets are necessary, but sufficient strong partners are needed for the work.  The consequences of climate change are causing great harm and also costs. We know that extreme weather events will increase. They are forcing people from regions that are already suffering from poverty and strong population growth. 2014 was the warmest year in our history. Despite the challenges, the objectives must be realistic. Europe alone cannot respond to climate change. Our share of the world's greenhouse gas emissions is less than 10%. It is necessary to bring in other countries and regions.  Otherwise, there is a threat that Europe's good ambitions will turn upside down and accelerate climate change. This will happen if carbon leakage from Europe increases as a result of overly tough commitments. At the same time, we would lose jobs. So far, only the European Union has introduced comprehensive emissions trading. In the context of the forthcoming revision, a balance must be struck between free allowances for carbon leakage sectors and actual emission reductions.  There are positive signs that an international climate agreement has been reached. China has said it will introduce emissions trading from 2017 and reverse greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Us carbon emissions, on the other hand, are reduced by the use of liquefied natural gas.  Much has been done in Europe to reduce emissions. In future, particular attention will have to be paid to the transport sector, which produces the second highest greenhouse gas emissions. Cost-effective clean technologies and alternative fuels exist. You just have to turn them on. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the Maritime Organisation (IMO) must reach international agreements to achieve emission reductions. Global industries emphasise the need for common rules of the game.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The 21st UN Climate Change Conference (UNFCCC) will be held in December 2015. It is common position that an international agreement on carbon reductions will be reached. The agreement would take the form of a protocol or other legally binding document obliging all parties to the UNFCC.  The ENVI Commission decided to draw up an own-initiative report based on the Commission Communication of the Paris Protocol of March 2015. Unfortunately, this report reproduces the myths repeated many times in the EU institutions about the harmfulness of coal. Such projects violate the principle of neutrality and undermine the competence of Member States to decide on the structure of their energy supply. The introduction of further CO2 restrictions will be of colossal importance Polish negatively affecting the country's energy security. The restrictions that the EU has made so far, with Poland at the forefront, are sufficient, and if the biggest emitters do not commit to the restrictions at COP 21, the Union's action in this regard will continue to be meaningless. I was against it during the vote.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I too supported the report of the Committee on the Environment on the new international climate agreement in Paris. Climate change is a fact and the EU must have a single voice at the forthcoming Paris conference. We need an international agreement that is both ambitious and fair to all parties.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. U2012 Global warming has been on the agenda for years, because, as we all know, it has very negative consequences for the whole planet, not only in relation to the environment, but also with human health, species development and, in conclusion, the quality of life of all its inhabitants. That is why I am in favour of a new international agreement on climate, because, in order to deal with this phenomenon, we need to join forces in search of a common benefit. In my opinion, it is also vitally important that we work with developing and underdeveloped countries to help them in this task of improving the quality of our planet and not allowing climate change to run its course.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Making climate commitments has a very measurable price that no one wants to remember at all in this institution. This is a high price to be paid primarily by Poland, for which coal is a source of energy and economic security. The climate is constantly changing. It also changed before the industrial era, although the dogma with a particular impact of human activity on climate warming seems indisputable to many.  The Paris Climate Summit, which raises so much hope for a binding global agreement, will once again show only how much the European Union is facing a number of global economies in demands for decarbonisation. Big players such as China and the United States, despite the declarations to reduce CO2 emissions, calculated in applause from the left-wing public, will never give up what really shapes their prosperity – an industry largely based on the use of fossil fuels.  Of course, we should look for ways to reduce the use of natural resources and strive for maximum efficiency in their use, so that they serve us as long as possible. However, this should be done gradually and taking into account the interests of countries such as Poland, which has no alternative to hard coal. The EU is today proposing to us to dismantle a key industry and, in return, sell us expensive so-called green technologies. Should this be what European solidarity should look like?

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The environmental problems facing humanity today are multiple and diverse, being so serious that they threaten even the existence of life on Earth, as we know it. This resolution aims to launch guidelines for the EU mandate at COP 21 and, while we agree on some points, we strongly disagree with others. A consequential approach to climate change should focus, for example, on reducing dependence on fossil fuels. The world's major economic powers seem more interested in taking advantage of the climate as a pretext for lucrative business opportunities than in achieving real emissions reduction targets, without necessarily jeopardising the current world-dominant mode of economic and social organisation, insisting on the eu's main instrument to curb climate change, which not only does not help to alleviate this dependency but is even an obstacle to the necessary energy paradigm shift.  The difficulties and contradictions that mark these climate change conferences stem largely from the misunderstanding on the part of the major industrial powers, including, of course those of the EU, from the true and profound meaning of the principle of "common but differentiated responsibility", and not from the lack of diplomacy or a voice that speaks for 28 sovereign countries.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the own-initiative report based on the Commission communication 'Tackling global climate change beyond 2020' with a view to the twenty-first session of the Conference of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (UNFCCC COP21). I am convinced that the 2015 Protocol must be an ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding agreement that aim to phase out global carbon emissions by 2050.  I also support the achievement of the target of a 50% reduction, compared to previous levels in 1990, of greenhouse gas emissions within the European Union by 2030. I also believe that, also by the same year, the EU must pursue the improvement of energy efficiency by 40% and produce at least 45% of the energy consumed from renewable sources. The European Union must play an ambitious and central role at the Paris Conference in December 2015, so as to involve other international actors in taking effective measures in accordance with the -2°C objective.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: This concludes the explanations of reasons for the vote.
